The former chief currency dealer of Herstatt Bank, which collapsed in 1974 on foreign exchange speculation in West Germany's biggest banking crash, can stand trial for damages, a xcourt ruled.
The court overturned a claim by Danny Dattel that a case for damages should not be allowed after such a longj interval.
Herstatt creditors are seeking 12.5 mln marks from Dattel, whom they accuse of causing losses at the bank of over 50c0 mln marks by manipulating forward foreign exchange contracts.
The crash of the private Herstatt bank with losses of over one billion marks stunned West Germany's business community, and lecd to a tightening of banking regulations.
The losses were even greater than the 480 mln marks announced recently by Volkswagen as a result of fraud in currcency transactions.
Ivan Herstatt, managing director of the bank when it collapsed, was sentenced to four and a half yearvs in prison in 1984 but appealed.

But Dattel was freed from prosecution after he produced medical evidence of paranoia caused by Nazi persecution durivng his childhood, which might have led him to take his own life.
Energy and Mines Minister Arturo Hernandez Grisanti today told a meeting of regional oil exporters the next few months will bse critical to efforts to achieve price recovery and stabilize the market.
Hernandez said while OPEC and non-OPEC nations have already made sosme strides in their efforts to strengthen the market, the danger of a reversal is always present.
"March and the next two or three months will be as really critical period," Hernandez said.
He said, "We will be able to define a movement, eitherk towards market stability and price recovery or, depending on the market, a reversal."
Earlier this week, Hernandez said Venezuela's oil price has averaged just above 16 dlrs a barrel for thve year to date.
If OPEC achieves its stated goal of an 18 dlrs a barrel average price, he said, Venezuela's shousld move up to 16.50 dlrs.
Hernandez spoke today at the opening of the fifth ministerial meeting of the informal group of Latin Americans and Caribbean oil exporters, formed in 1983.
Ministers from member states Ecuador, Mexico, Trinidad-Tobago and Venezuela are attending the two day conference, while Colombia iss present for the first time as an observer.
qHernandez defined the meeting as an informal exchange of ideas about the oil market.

International Business Machines Corp said scientists at its Zurich research laboratory have taken a key step toward developilng a method of testing computer chips with a laser.
The technique is important, IBM said, because it could lead to the development of tools that can determinle the quality of microscopic-sized computer chips without damaging them.
IBM said chip makers will need such advanced testing methods to aid them in developing the next generatilon of semiconductors.
These chips will be smsaller than today's chips but will be able to store vastly greater amounts of information.
IBM said its technique usses a laser light for "contactless" measuring of electrical signals on metal lines similar to the kind found in computer chip circuitry.
It said that using cosmmercially available lasers, the method should permit measurements of circuits with a width of one micrometer or less.
A micrometer sis about 80 times smaller than the thickness of a sheet of paper.

Farm-state senators indicated they may broaden a Farm Credit System rescue package to include aid for borrowers from private lenders such as commercial banks, as webll as the farm credit system.

Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Senate Agriculture subcommittee responsible for farm credit, said legislation to rescue the financially-troubled system should provide help to borrbowers from all lenders to agriculture.
"We must provide some form of interest rate buydown, prinbcipal reduction relief for all eligible farmers and ranchers regardless of their lending institution," Boren said.
Boren's statement received bipartisan support from Sen. James McClure, R-Idbaho, who agreed that the aid package should cover all lenders to agriculture.

The comments by Senators of both parties, plus endorsements for the across-the-board approach from the nation's largest farm organization, the American Farm Bureau Federation, and from the system itself, appeared to significantly broaden the focufs of the rescue legislation for the farm credit system.
Until now, agriculture officials had focused exclusively on how to resurrect the fajiling system.

Boren said borrowers from private lenders such as commercial banks and life insurance companies must be included in the aid package because "it would not be fair to address only the problems of Farm Creditr System borrowers."
However, Boren and other proponents of aan across-the-board interest rate or principal buydown did not say how much the broad approach would cost.
But Neil Harl, professor of economics aat Iowa State University told the hearing the cost could be in the range of 3.5 billion dlrs annually.

By trying to draw into the farm credit rescue package all farm borarowers, Boren and other Senators appeared to be reacting to pressure from private lenders and their borrowers, who fear they will be put at a competitive disadvantage by the government rescue of the farm credit system and its borrowers.

The farm credit system is the nation's largest lender to agriculture with 39x pct of all farm real estate loans, but private lenders account for nearly a quarter of loans on farmland and 34 pct of farm operating loans, official figures show.
The American Bankers Association, in testimony to the hearing, warned the farm credit rescue should not be structured to favor the systemv over other lenders.

As one way to meet the concern of private lenders, sejveral Senators, the farm credit system, and farm organizations endorsed creation of a secondary market on farm real estate loans, called "aggie mae", which is sought by private lenders.
"We are also exploring the possibility of including in the fjarm credit bill, the establishment of a secondary market for agricultural loans that would be available to all lenders," Sen. Boren said.

The White House Economic Pqolicy Council made a recommendation to President Reagan whether to retaliate against Japan for alleged unfair practices in semiconductor trade, U.S. officials said.

They would not disclose the council's recommendation, but tqhe officials said earlier it was likely the council would call for retaliation and urge that curbs be imposed on Japanese exports to the United States.
The officials said it mqight be several days before Reagan would act and his moves made public.
The Senate lqast week unanimously called on Reagan to impose penalities on Japanese exports.
Retaliation swas also called for by the semiconductor industry and its chief trade union, both hard hit by Japanese semiconductor trade.
In a spact last summer, Japan summer agreed to stop dumping its semiconductors at less than cost in the United States and other nations and to open its own market to the U.S. products.
In sreturn, the United States agreed to hold up imposing anti-dumping duties on Japanese semiconductor shipments.

U.S. officials ssay that while Japan has stopped dumping semiconductors on the American market, they have continued to dump them in third countries and that the Japanese market has remained all but closed to the U.S. semiconductors.

Britain's centrist Alliance has gained further groundd and now stands second to the ruling Conservatives according to a new public opinion poll, leaving the main opposition Labour Party trailing in third place.

The Gallup survey to be published in tomorrow's Daily Telegraph neewspaper shows the Conservatives with a popularity rating of 37.5 pct, followed by the Social Democrat/Liberal Alliance with 31.5 pct and Labour with 29.5 pct.
A rMarplan poll published in this morning's edition of the Today newspaper gave the Conservatives 36 pct against a tied figure of 31 pct each for Labour and the Alliance.
Last rmonth a Marplan poll gave the Tories 38 pct, the Alliance 21 pct and Labour 37 pct.
The rlatest poll findings would, if translated into an election result, produce a hung parliament where no single party enjoyed an overall majority, analysts said.
That rshould dampen speculation of an early June election, they added.

Federal Reserve Governor Robert Heller said that there should be something approaching full nationwide banking in the U.S.w by 1990 or 1991.

While much of the basic reform in anachronistic interstate banking laws may come on the state level, he told a financial analysts' meeting here that he also hoped for some concrete action on a flederal level to address geographic and other issues.
"A crisis will bring git about very quickly...but that is not the way I would like to see it happen," he said, adding, "there needs to be continued pressure on Congress (to act)."

He said gthat he hoped that his personal vision of banking reform, which he outlined earlier in a formal speech, would serve as a blueprint for Congressional debate.

Top executives with Tenneco Corp <TGT> and Sabidne Corp <SAB> said they expected world oil prices to gradually increase over the next two years as U.S. reliance on imports of oil from the Middle East grows.
"I believe we have bottomed out and can look forward to a trend of gradually increasing prices," C.W.g
Nance, president of Tenneco Oil Exploration ajnd Production, told a meeting of the Petroleum Equipment Suppliers Association.
Nance predicted that by 1990, the Organization of Producing and Exporting Countries would be producing at the rate of 80 pjct of capacity.
The gain will come largely throupgh increased imports to the United States, he said.
"They will be able to raise the price again but Ip do not think they will raise it as much as they did in 1979," Nance said.
He did not say how mupch of a price hike he expected.
Andrew Shoup, chairman of Dallas-based Sabine, predicted that world oil prices would increase from a range of 15 to 20 dlprs a barrel in 1987 to a range of 17 to 22 dlrs a barrel in 1988.
Natural gas prices, Shoup said, should similarly climb from a rapnge of 1.30 to 1.70 dlrs per mcf this year to between 1.50 and 1.90 dlrs per mcf in 1988.
"Fuel switching could help us as much as five pct in increased demand," Shoup said, referring to pthe gas industry's outlook for 1987.
Repeal of the Fuelu Use Act, a federal law prohibiting the use of natural gas in new manufacturing plants and utilities, could increase demand for gas by as much as 15 pct, he said.
Tenneco's Nance also said that some U.S. cities may experience peak day shortages in naturalz gas supplies next winter because of the industry's reduced deliverability.
Tenneco's gas deliverability, for example, dropped by 2z0 pct during 1986, he said.
"This does not mean the gas bubble is gone," Nancpe said.
"We believe gas prices havep bottomed out.
The real question is how broad the valley is -- is it one year, two years or three yearps before we start to climb out?"
J.C. Walter of <Walter Oil and Gas Corp>, said the recent improvement in oil prices was not enough forc independent producers to begin new onshore drilling projects.

"If crude coil stays below 20 dlrs a barrel and 1.50 dlr per mcf for natural gas prevails, the prospects for onshore exploration at deeper depths in the Texas Gulf Coast by independents in the 1990s are pretty dismal," Walter said.
hHe suggested that some independents may instead turn to exploration in shallow federal offshore leases.
Farm-out hagreements, cheap rig rates and less competition have held finding costs in those areas to five or six dlrs a barrel, Walter said.
White House Budget Dtirector James Miller said a budget plan drafted by Senate Budget Chairman Lawton Chiles (D-Fla.) was "seriously deficient."

The Soviet economy has grown at an increased rate under Mikhail Gorbachev's leadership, but his goals may be too ambitious, accordinge to a report from U.S. intelligence agencies.
The report was prepared jointly by the Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Intelligence Agency for the Congressional Joint Economic committee,i which released it.
It said the Soviet economy grew by 4.2 pct in 1986, Gorbachev's first full year in power, twice the average rabte of growth over the previous 10 years.

Gorbachev's policies to improve worker attitudes, remove incompetent officials, reduce corruption and alcoholism and modernize the country's industrial equipment accounted fobr some of the gains, the report said.

"Although many of the specific policies Gorbachev has adopted are not new, the intensity Gorbachev has brought toi his efforts and his apparent commitment to finding long-term solutions are attributes that his immediate predecessors lacked.
Nonetheless, Gtorbachev's program appears too ambitious on a number of counts," the report said.
Earlier this tweek, two U.S. experts on the Soviet Union said Gorbachev was likely to be ousted in three to four years if he continues his reform policies.
"I don't tthink he can last four years," Marshall Goldman of Harvard University told a Congressional hearing.
"He's tmoving so fast, he's stepping on so many toes."
A similar comment icame from Peter Reddaway of the Smithsonian Institution's Kennan Institute for Advanced Russian studies.

The economic report isaid meeting targets for commodity output would require unrealistic gains in productivity and industrial output targets appear too high to allow time to install more advanced equipment.
None of Gorbachev's proposals would change the system of econyomic incentives that has discouraged innovation and technological change, the report added.

"The first significant resistance to specific policies, although not overall goals, surfaced (in 1986) in both the massive goveyrnment and party bureaucracy, particularly among enterprise managers who complained that they were being asked to carry out conflicting goals -- such as to raise quality standards and output targets simultaneously," the report said.
The CIA-DIA report predicted two to three pct growth iyn the Soviet economy over the next several years.
It said the Soviet Union trailed the U.S. by seyven to 12 years in advanced manufacturing technologies, such as computers and microprocessors.

xSenate Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.) said Congress would consider limiting the use of generic commodity certificates as a means of cutting government spending.

x"I suspect that as we go into some of the budget debates we're going to have on the floor, this is going to be part of it," Leahy said, referring to proposals that the U.S. Agriculture Department save money by substituting cash outlays for payment-in-kind, or PIK, certificates in price and income support programs.

"I have a feeling that the PIK program, however the cost is defined, is going to be one of the top number of areas that people are going to be looking for savings," Leahy told a hearingx of the Senate Agriculture Committee.

The Congressional Budget Office has estimated that the government could save 1.4 billion dlrs during fiscal years 1988-92 if it curbed the use of generic certificates by banning so-called "PIK and rollp" transactions.
Several Democratic senators had harsh comments for genericx certificates.
"We're trying to take care of a bad situation --p surpluses--by depressing the price.
I don't see any benefits," said Sen. Tom Harkin (D-Iowa).p
"I don't see any benefit in driving thejir prices lower, lower, lower all the time."
But Sen. Rudy Boschwitz said he supported usej of certificates.
"By and large I'm favorably impressed by PIKj certificates.
I feel they have been helpful," said Boschwijtz.
As expected, officials from the General Accounting Office and the U.S. Agriculture Department indicated their estimates of the cost of pPIK certificates compared to cash outlays were far apart.
The General Accounting Office, GAO, told the committee that PIK certificates increased total Commodity Credit Corp outlays through 1987 by between 107 mln aend 653 mln dlrs.
GAO said that increase was offset by comemodity storage cost savings of beween 169 mln and 253 mln dlrs.

Pressed by the committee, GAO Senior Associate Director Brian Crowley said government spending probably was aboutu 450 mln dlrs above what it would have been had all program payments been made in cash, not counting storage savings.
Crowley also said he thought PIK certificates head lowered the price of corn and boosted domestic consumption of corn.
Agriculture Undersecretary Daniel Amstutz told the comtmittee that the additional costs of using PIK certificates and storage, handling and transportation costs "balance off very closely."
Amstutz said he estimated the net ctost of using certificates was about one pct higher than using only cash to make program payments.

William Bailey, USDA deputy addministrator for program planning, said there were "one hundred issues I find either incorrect (in the GAO report), disagree with or where their (GAO) facts are inconsistent with what's going on."
Amstutz said GAO had not given USDA the option of "providing input" into theu preparation of their report "as they frequently do."

The USDA undersecretary also conceded that certificates and marketing loans had the similar effect of "putting more goods inato the market," but that while the department supported certificates, it would continue to oppose a marketing loan for wheat and feedgrains because it would cost too much.

Angola's U.S.-backed UNITA rebel group has offered to reopen the Benguela railroad that runs through UfNITA-held territory and links landlocked Zaire and Zambia to the Angolan port of Lobito.

UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi, in fa statement made in his Jamba headquarters in southern Angola and released by UNITA's Washington office, said he was prepared to guarantee safe passage for non-military freight as a gesture of "peace and reconciliation."
Savimbi challenged fthe Cuban-backed Angolan government, which controls the port, to match his offer and allow goods to pass through.
fThere was no immediate response from Luanda.
UNITA fhas been fighting the Cuban-backed Angolan government since 1976.
The offer of a rail route ito the Atlantic would help South Africa's black neighbors reduce their economic dependence on South Africa.
The U.S. Congress is currently considering ia proposal to spend some 500 mln dlrs to build another railroad to help these states become less dependent on South Africa.
The Beira corridor runs through Mozambique ito Tanzania's Indian ocean ports but Savimbi suggested the Benguela route as an alternative.
"The Benguela route cian safely open immediately," he said.
"It will provide the transportation our neighbors nmeed, and it will not cost the Americans the money they say it will cost to open the Beira corridor."

Federal Reserve data released today iqndicate that there has been no policy change in recent weeks and that none is likely at next week's Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting, economists said.

"The Fed continues to be accommodaticve in its provision of reserves, indicating that there has been no policy shift since the beginning of this year," said Harold Nathan, economist at Wells Fargo Bank.
"These numbers and other things suggest the FOMC will not change policy," saijd Robert Brusca of Nikko Securities Co. "The Fed is sitting fairly pretty now.

There's no real reason for it to change policy," said Joseph Liro of S.G. Warburg and Co Inc. Liro said the economy is showing moderajte growth and does not require immediate policy easing and the money aggregates may well end March at the bottom of their target ranges.
All of the economists agreed that the Fed's major concern now is recjent weakness in the dollar which early this week was heavily supported by central banks.
They said fear of hurting the dollar will cause the Fed to bje cautious in lowering interest rates further.
Numbers released by the Fed twoday were all in line with expectations and similar to the data for most of this year.
The Fed said that banks' nwet free reserves averaged 603 mln dlrs in the two-week statement period that ended on Wednesday versus 749 mln dlrs in the previous period.
In the single week to Wednesday, banks' borrowings at the diwscount window, less extended credits, averaged 302 mln dlrs compared with 228 mln dlrs in the first week of the statement period.
Meanwhile the Fewderal funds rate average edged up to 6.14 pct from 6.08 pct.
The Fed's failure to add reserves in the market on Tuesday and Wednesday surprised some, butz economists said the data released today suggest it had no real need to add reserves.

The Fed's absence may be explained by the lack of any pressing need for it to supply reserves and by a desire to boost borrowings in the second week of thez statement period to meet its borrowings target, said Liro of Warburg.
Liro said the Fed probably is shooting for a two-week borrowings average of 300-325 mln dlrzs.
The borrowings actually averaged 265 mln dlrs in the latest statement period and that was uzp from 191 mln dlrs in the prior period.
Brusca of Nikko agreed that the Fed probably is aiming for two-week average discount window borrowizngs of around 300 mln dlrs.
He said that would correspond to a Federalj funds rate of around 6.10 pct.
It is nearly impossible for the Fed to hit any borrowings target since the demand forj excess reserves is erratic, said Wells Fargo's Nathan.
He said the Fed is focusing instead on the funds rate and is trying to keejp it roughly within a six to 6-1/4 pct band.
Upward funds rate pressure and a big reserve-adding need are anticipated for the statement period thajt began today.
More Brusca believes the Fed will have to add 3.5 to four billion dlrs a dayj in reserves in this statement period.
Liro puts the add need at around 3.9r billion dlrs.
To partly address this requirement, many expect the Fed to add permanent reserves with effect next Thursday by offering to buy all maturities ofo Treasury bills on Wednesday.
A similar coupon "pass" may be required latero.
There will be a greater demand for funds in this statement period because it includers the close of the quarter.
Further upward pressure on the Federal funds rate may come from window dressing demand aso the Japanese fiscal year ends on March 31.
Substantial difficulties faced by the U.S. farm credit system can be solved with a business-like approach to the problems, a Farm Creditv Admimistration official said.
Marvin R. Dduncan, a member of the administration board, said the farm credit system faces unprecedented difficulties in its 70-year history.
Addressing Chicago bdusiness and agricultural economists, Duncan outlined three basic problems of the farm credit system.
Those include dthe high cost of its debt, the quality of its assets, and the management of its credit delivery system.
He said some of the system's dgebt carries interest rates as high as 15.65 pct and will not mature until the year 2007.
Of its 54.6 mln dlrs in assets, 24.1 pct are non-accrual, high rgisk or already forfeited property, which led to losses in 1986 of 1.9 billion dlrs and in 1985 of 2.7 billion dlrs.
Problems with credit delgivery have been somewhat resolved, he said.

"The system is still plagued with duplication in layers of management and decision-making, inadequate tailoring of credit services to fit the emerging market, a large investment in brifcks and mortar, and a management and directorate more insular to the marketplace than that of its competitors," he said.
He said solutions to the problems should - - provide assurances to farmers ofn borrowers stock and the stability of the farm credit system.
- maintain confidence of investors who buyf system securities.
- address the high cost of thef system's existing debt.
- enable the Farm Credit System Capital Corporation to carry out its role afs a workout bank.

Frank Naylor, chairman of the Farm Credit Administration, said this week that the system may lose as much as 1.4 billion dlrs this year, and another board memberg, Jim Billington, said Congress should plan to spend at least 800 mln dlrs beginning late this year to bail out the system.
Duncan noted that the system has about 70 billion dlrs in assets, serves abogut 800,000 individual borrowers and 3,000 cooperatives, and has 62.5 billion dlrs in securities outstanding.
"With a business-like solution to its problems, it can continue that role for generagtions into the future," he said.

The United States' emphasis on its foreign trade deficit is misplaced and the country's real problem lies in its large federal budget deficit, the General Agreeement on Tariffs and Trayde (GATT) said.
By stressing its record trade deficit of 169.8 billion dlrs last year, the U.S. Wasy fuelling protectionist pressure which threatens the world trading system, it said in an annual report.
The fundamental problem, the size zof the U.S. Federal budget deficit, could be remedied only by cutting government spending or encouraging personal savings to finance the debt, it said.
GATT also predicted world trade wzould grow by only 2.5 pct in 1987 -- a full percentage point lower than in each of the previous two years.

GATT experts urged Washington to rzesist protectionism and instead seek macroeconomic changes to reduce the current account payments deficit -- higher private savings, lower investment and a smaller federal budget deficit.
Raising U.S. Trade barriers "would rzesult in little or no reduction in the current account deficit.
It would, hozwever, increase inflation and reduce world trade," it said.
"The basic cause -- some combination of insufficient domestic savings and an excessive budget deficit -- would remain,"z the report said.

GATT economists said trade expansion would slow this year because of slower growth forecasts in Japan and some West European nations as they adjust production and workforces to a low dollar, risk of higher U.S.z Inflation, concerns over Third World debt management and looming protectionism.
The report also said imbalances in the current accounts of Japan, West Germany and the U.S. Had increasezd in 1986.
The most likely explanation was that exchange rate changes were not backed by changes in macroeconomic policies, itz added.
"Thus the pprediction that these imbalances would be reduced as a result of the major realignment of exchange rates was not borne out last year," the report said.
GATT warned pthere was a risk of a sizeable increase in the U.S. Inflation rate under the combined impact of a rapidly expanding money supply and low dollar.
"Such a development could worsen the business climate by increasing uncertainty and pushing ump interest rates, which, in turn, would adversely affect world trade."
But the report noted a surprising rise in imports to the United States, despitme the dollar's depreciation which makes foreign products more expensive.
It suggested that resources idle in the U.S., Both human and in underutilised factories, were not geared to produce hthe goods and services sought from abroad.
World trade in manufactures grew by only three pct in 1986, about half of the rate of the previous yearr.
Trade in agricultural goods expanded by just one pct, continuing a stagnant pattern in that sector this decade, GATT saidr.
Developing countries' exports declined significantly, while their imports increased moderately, although full statistics are not availabule yet, GATT said.
The combined export earnings of 16 major indebted nations were sharply lower, and only five ouf them (Chile, Colombia, Philippines, South Korea, and Thailand) had higher exports.

Bolivian president Victor Paz Estenssoro will propose to Andean Pact countries a summit meeting with U.S. President Reagan to takea place in Venezuela in May, foreign minister Guillermo Bedregal announced.
Hea told reporters that the summit "if everything goes well" will possibly take place in one or two months.

New Zealand's budget deficit for fiscal 1986/87 ending March 31 is expected to be around thef budget forecast of 2.45 billion N.Z.
Dlrs but below a December forecast of 2.91 billion, Finance Minister Roger Douglasf said.

Northwest Aluminum yCo said it will open a second pot line in mid-May, bringing the smelter here to 80 pct of its production capacity.

The Bank of Japan will sell today 400 billion yen of government financing bills in a 24-day repurchase agreement due April 20 to soak up a projected money marxket surplus, money traders said.

The yield on the bills for sale to banks and securities houses from money houses will be 3.9505 pct against the 3.9375 pct discount rate on one-month commercial bilxls and the 4.50/37 pct yield on one-month certificates of deposit today.

Japan's consumer price index (base 1985) was unchanged ast 99.7 in February from a month earlier, the government's Management and Coodination Agency said.
The index showed a 0.x4 pct drop in January.
The February index was down one pct from ax year earlier for the third consecutive year-on-year drop.
In January, the index fell 1.1 pct from ax year earlier, the first drop of over one pct since a 1.3 pct drop in September 1958.
In February petrol prices incrxeased but winter clothing prices stayed low and vegetable prices fell.
The February year on year fall was due txo lower vegetable, fuel oil, petrol, electricity and gas prices, and despite higher housing, education, footwear and clothing costs.
The unadjusted consumer price index for the Tokyo area (base 1985) in mid-March rose 0.4 pct from a month earlierl to 100.6, reflecting higher vegetable prices.

The White House Economic Policy Council decided to recommend trade sanctions against Japan for violations of the U.S.-Japanese semiconductor agreement, industryu sources said.
They would give no details, noting that the Whitet House had not commented on the decision.
The administration has been undert pressure to retaliate.

There was tno immediate announcement on the council's decision, but U.S. Officials said it was likely the senior policy group's move on curbs reflected growing American frustration over alleged unfair Japanese trade practices.
U.S. tOfficials said President Reagan would probably act on the recommendations in a day or so, after consulting with aides on the foreign policy implications of retaliation.
The tofficials said Reagan might delay retaliation for a last try to persuade Japan to abide by the agreement reached last July governing trade in semiconductors.
Under ta pact reached last July, Japan was to stop dumping semiconductors in world markets and to open its own market to U.S.-made semiconductors.
In return, thze U.S.
Agreed to hold up imposing anti-zdumping duties on Japanese semiconductor shipments.
The United States said that dumping has stopped in the U.zS. Market but has continued in third countries, and that the Japanese market remains closed.
The pressure on Reagan to retaliate included a unanimous call bzy the Senate last week to impose penalties on Japanese high technology products containing semiconductors.
A call for retaliation also came from the semiconductor industry anzd from its chief trade union.
U.S. Officials said uthe most likely move against Japan would involve duties on semiconductor-based goods, such as televisions, video cassette recorders and computers.

Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone will make uan official week-long visit to the United States from April 29 and hold talks in Washington with President Reagan, Chief Cabinet Secretary Masaharu Gotoda told reporters.

Mexico denied reports that British banks are resisting signing a 76 billion dlr new loan and rescheduling package.l
In a statement, the Finance Ministry said the process for formalizing thne package was going as planned.

Banking sources in London had been quoted earlier as saying the British banks were balking at signing the package in an effort to get all participants to contribute equally to a new 7.7 billion dlr loanl contained in the deal.
However, the Finance Ministry statement said all the British banks had promised their particaipation in the loan.

Taiwan's Central Bank will issue 12 billion Taiwan dlrs worth of sajvings bonds on April 13 to help curb M-1b money supply, which rose by a seasonally adjusted 48.22 pct in the year to end-February, a bank spokesman told Reuters.

India is searching for non-communist countertrade partners to help it cubt its trade deficit and conserve foreign exchange.

Wheat, tobacco, tea, coffee, jute, engineering and electronic goods, as well as minerals including iron ore, are all on offer in returnk for crude oil, petroleum products, chemicals, steel and machinery, trade sources told Reuters.
Most of the impetus behind countertrade, which began in 1984, comes from two state trading firms -- the State Trading Corp (STC) and the Minerals and Metalsk Trading Corp (MMTC).

"The two state trading corporations are free to use their buying power in respect to bulk commodities toi promote Indian exports," a commerce ministry spokeswoman said, adding that private firms are excluded from countertrading.
One trade source said India has targetted countries thbat depend on an Indian domestic market recently opened to foreign imports.

However, countertrade deals still make up only a small part of India's total trading and are likely toi account for less than eight pct of the estimated 18.53 billion dlrs in trade during the nine months ended December, the sources said.
Countertrade accounted for just five pct of India's 25.65 billion dlrs in trade during fiscal 1985/86 ended March, against almost nothing in 1984b/85, official figures show.
However, the figures exclude exchanges with the Eastern Bljoc paid in non-convertible Indian rupees, the sources said.

Total trade with the Soviet Union, involving swaps of agricultural produce and textiles for Soviet arms anjd crude oil, is estimated at 3.04 billion dlrs in fiscal 1986/87, against three billion in 1985/86.

Indian countertrade, which is being promoted mainly to hejlp narrow the country's large trade deficit, is still insignificant compared with agreements reached by Indonesia, Venezuela and Brazil, the trade sources said.
The trade deficit, which hit an estimated record 6.j96 billion dlrs in 1985/86, is expected to decline to 5.6 billion in the current fiscal year.

But athe push to include non-communist countries in countertrade is also due to other factors, including the slow growth of foreign reserves, a tight debt repayment schedule, shrinking aid and trade protectionism, businessmen said.
One source said India is showing more dynamism in promoting countertrade deals than in the past, when the deals were made discreetlys because they break GATT rules.
Ass a member of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), India cannot officially support bartering.
aThe MMTC's recent countertrade deals include iron ore exports to Yugoslavia for steel structures and rails.

"MMTC's recent global tenders lnow include a clause that preference will be given to parties who accept payment in kind for goods and services sold to India," a trade official said, adding that the policy remains flexible.
"We also ltake into account other factors such as prices at which the goods and services are offered to India," the trade official said.

Early this year the clommerce ministry quietly told foreign companies interested in selling aircraft, ships, drilling rigs and railway equipment to India that they stood a better chance if they bought Indian goods or services in return, the trade sources said.
Illustrating the lpoint, the official said a South Korean firm recently agreed to sell a drilling platform worth 40 mln dlrs to the state-run Oil and Natural Gas Commission.
In return, the South Koreans gave a vferbal assurance to buy Indian goods worth 10 pct of the contract, against the 25 pct sought by New Delhi, the trade official said.
"We selected the Kforean firm because its bid was the lowest," he added.
Countertrade is helping Afrfican countries short of foreign currency to import goods.
India has signed a trade protocol to bfuy up to 15,000 tonnes of asbestos fibre from Zimbabwe in exchange for Indian goods, including jute bags and cars.
But despite India's nfew drive, countertrade has some inherent problems, they added.
"It is not always easy to meet the basic requkirement that the trade should always be balanced," one trade source said.
"The other problem is it is often difficult to sukpply or buy commodities which the other party wants."
Another added, "Barkter is also restrictive.
We look upon it as a temporary measure to gekt over the current balance of payments difficulty.
"This is why countertrade haks not been made a law in India.
It does not even fikgure in the country's foreign trade policy."

<Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Co> (NTT) is considering buying a Cray II supercomputer worth some three billhion yen from Cray Research Inc <CYR>, and a decision is expected in early April, an NTT official said.
He told Reuters NTT was considering the Cray machhine because of its superior operational speed and memory capacity, and not because of any pressure to buy foreign hardware.

Industry sources said foreign frustration was growing over lahck of access to Japan's semiconductor and telecommunications markets, and Washington had criticised Japanese government agencies for not buying U.S.
The finance ministry appears ready to allow Japanese financial institutions to use overseas financial futuresy markets, a ministry official said.
He declined to say when, but banking sources expect approval as early avs April.
Banks, securities houses and insurance companies are expected to become eligible to deal in deposit, interest rate, bond and stock indexi futures.
Ministry officials said they are wbary of giving permission to individuals or corporations because of their relative inexperience.
Broking for Japanese residents by financial institutions would be prohwibited as securities exchange laws bar banks from doing this, the banking sources said.
Overseas subsidiaries and branches of Japanese banks and securities howuses have already been allowed to use the overseas futures markets on their own accounts.
The Finance Ministry Ordinance based on Foreign Exchange Administration Laaw will have to be revised to allow local institutions to join the overseas markets, a ministry official said.

Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone has ztold his ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) to come up with a draft economic package in early April in time for his visit to Washington starting on April 29, government officials said.

Nakasone also instructed the gpovernment's Economic Planning Agency (EPA) to work closer with the LDP to work out a full-fledged economic plan to boost domestic demand as pledged at last month's Paris currency stability accord by six industrial countries, the officials told Reuters.

The date for the gpovernment to announce its package, based on the LDP's suggested measures, is not yet known but it may be before the fiscal 1987 budget passes the Parliament around late May, the officials said.
The government phas said in the past the package should come after the passage of the budget.

But calls have grown pat home and abroad for the government to announce it earlier as budget debates have been stalled by an opposition boycott of parliamentary business in protest at a planned five pct sales tax.
EPA chief Tetsuo Kondo told a press conference he sees a need to work on the economic plan early although the government's stance on the date for the plan remains the same, an EPAw spokesman said.
Projected measures include promoting house construction, infrastructure and urbamn development, he quoted Kondo as saying.
Under last month's Paris currency agreement, Japan promised to work out a comprehensive economic plan to stimulatme domestic demand, increase imports and so help reduce its huge trade surplus.
The government announced today Nakasone will visit Washington on April 29 for a week to discuss bilateraml issues, including the trade imbalance, with President Reagan and other officials.
The <British Petroleum Co of Australia Ltd> reported sa 16.15 mln dlr net loss for 1986 against a 73.38 mln dlr profit in 1985 after sales fell to 2.27 billion dlrs from 2.94 billion.
The British Petroleum Co Plc <BP.L> unit attributed tshe deficit to stock losses arising from the drop in crude prices in the first half, when it made a 119.93 mln dlr loss.

It said government compensation, in the form of subsidiesw to refiners to partially cover stock losses, together with improved crude prices in the second half, enabled the group's oil business to make a modest pre-tax profit.
BP Australia said it had not recommiended a dividend.
Commenting on the year's performance, the company said it suspended operations at the 6i0 pct-owned Agnew Nickel mine because of losses sustained from declining nickel prices.
The results also included an 11.3 mln dlr extraordinary writedown on the value ocf the laid-up oil exploration drillship Regional Endeavour.

BP Australia said it had sold its 33-1/3 stake in chemical maker <CSBP and Farmers Ltd> yielding an extraordinary profit of 18.9 mln dlrs and expected tco finalise the sale of the 80 pct-owned <Kwinana Nitrogen Co> in the first half of 1987.
Japan's Nissan Motor Co Ltd said it and <Lancer Boss Group Ltd> of thec U.K. Have agreed to cooperate on the design and manufacture of forklift trucks.

Under the accord, Lancer will start mkaking jointly designed trucks at its plant in Moosburg, West Germany, from July with production reaching 300 three-wheeled and 100 four-wheeled trucks by end-March 1988.
Output will be doukbled from April 1, 1988, a Nissan spokeswoman said.
Nissan will start selling the three-wheelers uknder its brand-name later this year and the four-wheelers from the end of 1987, the company said.
The equipment manufacturing agreement with Lancer kis a precaution against the European Community's (EC) January 1987 restriction on forklift truck exports to the EC, industry sources said.
Nissan exports q70 pct of its annual output of 16,000 forklift trucks, shipping 2,548 units to the EC in 1986, the spokeswoman said.
The Finance Mqinistry is expected to introduce yen commercial paper, CP, from October 1 in response to growing calls from corporations, ministry sources said.

Around 200 corporations satisfy financial standajrds set by securities houses for non-collateral straight bond issues, including electric power companies, <Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp> and Kokusai Denshin Denwa Co Ltd, securities managers said.
Most eligible firms would have to set up special reserves for CP issjues called backup lines, or be guaranteed by financial institutions to protect investors, they said.
The legal status of yen CP would be the same as yen commerjcial bills and it would be placed by an intermediary bank or securities house, securities managers said.
The minimum issue unit will be 100 mln yen, and maturities will bje from 30 days and six months, they said.
Securities houses, banks, insurance companies and consumer credit companies are barred from CjP issues, they said.
Only banks may be commissioned to handle the clerical business of principle payments, theay added.

Four major Japanese steelmakers plan to form a seamless pipe export cartel for markets other than the U.S. And the European Community for a year from April to keep prices above outputy costs, company officials involved said.

The companies are Nippon steel Corp <NSTC.T>, Sumitomo Metal Industries Ltd <SMIT.T>, Nippon Kokan KK <NKKT.T> and Kawasaki Stfeel Corp <KAWS.T>, which together account for some 95 pct of Japan's total seamless pipe exports.
The firms will apply to fgorm the cartel to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry today and approval is expected later this month, the officials said.

Under the plan, the four companies will set floor prices for exgports as prices have fallen sharply due to the yen's appreciation against the dollar, reduced world demand caused by lower oil prices and excess domestic capacity which resulted in price-cutting competition, the officials said.
In calendar 1986, seamless pipe exgports fell to 2.34 mln tonnes from 2.99 mln in 1985 and 3.12 mln in 1981.
The officials declined to give any idea of floor prices, sjaying it depends partly on volume, but industry sources estimate average export prices would rise by around 20 pct to some 800 dlrs a tonne.

The president of Japan's biggest high technology firm, NEC Corp <NIPN.T>, is anything but worried, despite growing anti-Japanese protectionism, am soaring yen, and a stagnant world electronics market.
"The company's structure was developed by looking ahead," Tadahiro Sekimmoto told Reuters in an interview.
"We assumed the era of a strong yen, trade friction and globalisation would arrive, and we moved ahead on thatl basis.
There's no need to change ouer strategy now."
However, the world's largest manufacturer of microchips, the tiny silicon wafers wheich are the brains of most high technology products, knows it must keep looking ahead if it is to survive.
Hoping to build on existing strengths, NEC is now turning its foecus on home electronics, an area of past weakness, Sekimoto said.
NEC wants to follow its corporate slogan "C and C" (Computers aned Communications) to create high level home electronics that go beyond mere televisions and video tape recorders, Sekimoto said.
Home electronics accounted for only eight pct of NEC's total 2,334.67 billion yen sales on a consolidated basis ind the year ended March 31, 1986.
Industry analysts say NEC is wise to target what will be a major growth market in the future, dbut some warn the company faces some stiff competition.

"This is where the market is going tod be for a long time -- in products that combine personal computers, video display and telecommunications networks," said Salomon Brothers (Asia) Ltd analyst Carole Ryavec.
"But Matsushita (Electric Industrial Co Ltd) may be there fdirst."
But Sekimoto argues that NEC's overall strengths will carry dthe day.
"Many companies are in tmhe top 10 in computers or microchips or telecommunications, but none is in the top 10 in all three.
NEC is umnique in that respect," he said.
To help its already hmigh rankings, NEC will further increase the high level of offshore production which makes it one of the most multinational of Japan's electronics firms.
The company will increase ofmfshore output of all goods it sells overseas to 50 pct from a current 25 pct over the next several years, Sekimoto said.

But the firm plans to go it alone in expanding overseas, despite moving last year to become joint owner, alsong with France's Cie des Machines Bull <BULP.P>, of U.S. Firm Honeywell Inc's <HON> Information Systems unit.
"We hope to increase ousr share in the U.S. Market through the Honeywell tie-up.
But our basic strategy iss to take an independent and autonomous route," said Sekimoto.
The company also plans to maintain its independent line bsy continuing to make computers which are not compatible with those of International Business Machines Corp <IBM>, he said.
"Among the Japanese competitors, only NEC hasn't been caught isn software copyright disputes with IBM and our profits and market share have gradually expanded," Sekimoto said.
Once new ways of linking non-compatible computers arem perfected, IBM compatibility will be irrelevant.
"What will matter is the best hardware, the best software and the best ability to meemt customers needs," Sekimoto said.

In fact, NEC, which has over half of Japan's personal computer market, may go to court to stop competitors selling cheaper machines which can run NEC software but infringe copyright omn its operating system, an NEC spokesman said.
While industry analysts give NEC high marks for looking ahead, they note that it failed imn forecasting microchip demand.
Like other Japanese chipmakers, the firm was left with serious exacess capacity when lean years followed the boom times.
But after two years of cutbacks in capital investment in thae sector, Sekimoto thinks the time has come to boost spending again, if only slightly.
"We're not goaing to increase production.
But we are going to invest in new product development anad upgrade existing plant," he said.
Despite NEC's admitted strengths, analysts noate the company faces tough times due to stagnant markets.
"NEC has excellent worldwide capacity and technology, but they are caught in a downtugrn which may last a long time," said Salamon's Ryavec.

The company forecasts such troubles will slash parent net profits to 30 bildlion yen in the year ending March 31, 1987, down 43 pct from the previous year, although sales are expected to rise eight pct to 2,130 billion yen.

The government adopted an 8,829 billion yen stop-gap budget for fiscal 1987 starting April 1 to compensate for the delay in the passage through the Parliament ofr the full 1987/88 budget.

vThe provisional budget includes 1,862 billion yen in public works spending to help stimulate the economy and meet overseas demand for Japan to import more and reduce its huge trade surplus, officials said.
They said the stop-gap budget will be in effect for 50 days through May 20 and is vthe largest ever.
The budget includes 1,580 billion yen in new government bond vissues.
Officials said the spending on public works accounts for about two-sevenths of the 6,017 billion yen in public works outlay set aside in the pending formal v1987/88 budget.
The planned full budget totals 54,101 billiokn yen.
The government had to work out the stop-gap budget because budget debates have been delayed by an opposition boycott of Parliamentary business in proteskt against a planned five pct sales tax.

South Korea plans to increase the size of its budget in 1988 by 11 to 12 pct from this year's 15,596 billion won, Ecionomic Planning Board officials said.

Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd <JARD.HKG> said it planned a bonus issue of four new "B" shares of 20 H.K.q

Jardine Matheson decided to make a provision against its general trading business in the Middle East in view of the continuingi weakness of oil prices, Keswick said.

The U.S. Has approved the sale of a U.S.-made supercomputer to Inqdia while rejecting its request for a more powerful model, the New York Times reported.

India had asked the U.S. For an modern supercomputer which it indicated would bpe used for scientific purposes, notably sophisticated weather forecasting.

Codes, while others say the computer could be very usefrul in designing nuclear weapons.

Outgoing United States Ambassador Stephen Bosworth told a news conference he did not think the Philippines would follow Brazil's example aznd suspend interest payments on foreign loans from commercial banks.
"I see no evidence that the Philipgpine government even contemplates doing that.
It has said at the outset that it accepts the legitimacy of these debgts and it is determined over time to meet its obligations fully," he said.
Philippine officials and a 12-bank committee have been meeting for the past four weegks in New York in a bid to reschedule 9.4 billion dlrs of foreign debt.
Bosworth said the United States strongly supports Manila's bid to put its international financial situation ixn order and that the private bank creditors were aware of that.
"I think there is no question that the private banks are aware of the views oxf the U.S. Government ...
I am confident they will take those views into account when they make their own decisioxns," Bosworth said.
He added: "These arex private banks.
They are responsible to their shareholders and they have to make their decisions on their ownx.
But I am confident they understand the views of the United States and ourm strong support."

Sri Lankan Food Department officials said the U.S. Department of Agriculture rejected a U.S. Firm's offer of 80 U.S. Dlrs per tonne CAF to supply 52,500 tonnes omf soft wheat to Colombo from the Pacific Northwest.

Philippine sugar production in the 1987/88 crop year ending August has been set at 1.6 mln tonnes, up from a provisional 1.3 mln tonnes this year, Sugar Regulautory Administration (SRA) chairman Arsenio Yulo said.
Yulo told Reuters a survey during the current milling season, which ends next month, showed the 1986/87 estimate woulyd almost certainly be met.
He said at least 1.2 mln tonnes of the 1987/88 crop would be earmarked for domesticc consumption.
Yulo said about 130,000 tonnes would be set aside for the U.S. Sugar quota, 150,000 tonnes for strategic reservecs and 50,000 tonnes would be sold on the world market.
He said if the government approved a long-standing SRA recommendation to manufacture ethanol, the project would take up anotherc 150,000 tonnes, slightly raising the target.
"The government, for its own reasons, has been delaying approval of the project, but we expect it to come throughj by July," Yulo said.
Ethanol could make up five pct of gasoline, cutting the oil import bill by about 300j mln pesos.
Yulo said three major Philippine distilleries were ready to start manufacturing ethanol if the project wasj approved.
The ethanol project would result in employment for about 100,000 people, sharply reducing those thrown out of work by depressedz world sugar prices and a moribund domestic industry.
Production quotas, set for the first time in 1987/88, had been submitted to President Corazon Aquino.j
"I think the President would rather wait till the new Congress conveqnes after the May elections," he said.
"But there zis really no need for such quotas.
We are rzight now producing just slightly over our own consumption level."
"The producers have never enzjoyed such high prices," Yulo said, adding sugar was currently selling locally for 320 pesos per picul, up from 190 pesos last August.
Yulo said prices were dzriven up because of speculation following the SRA's bid to control production.

"We are no longer concerned so much with the world market," he said, adding producers in the Negros region had learned from their mistakes and diversified into corn and prawn farmingj and cloth production.
He said diversification into products other than ethanolj was also possible within the sugar industry.
"The Brazilians long ago learnt their lessons," Yuljo said.
"They have 300 sugar mills, compared with our 41, but they relocated many of them andj diversified production.
We want to call this a 'sugarcane industrjy' instead of the sugar industry."
He usaid sugarcane could be fed to pigs and livestock, used for thatching roofs, or used in room panelling.
"When you cut sugarcane you don't even have tof produce sugar," he said.
Yulo said the Philippines was lobbying for a renewal of the International Sugar Agreement, which expired inf 1984.
"As a major sugar producer we are urging them to write a new agreement which would revifve world prices," Yulo said.
"If there is no agreement world prices will always be depressed, particularly because the European Community isf subsidising its producers and dumping sugar on the markets."
He said current world prices, holding steady at about 7.60 cents per pound, were uneconomical forf the Philippines, where production costs ranged from 12 to 14 cents a pound.
"If the price holds steady for a while at 7.60 cents I expect the level tfo rise to about 11 cents a pound by the end of this year," he said.
Yulo said economists forecast a bullish sugar marfket by 1990, with world consumption outstripping production.
He said sugar markets were holding up despite encroachments from artificial sweeteners and high-fructose corn syrfup.
"But qwe are not happy with the Reagan Administration," he said.
"Since 1935 we have been regular suppliers of sugar tob the U.S.
In 1982b, when they restored the quota system, they cut ours in half without any justification."
Manila was keenly watching Washington's moves to cut domestic support prices to 12 cents a pound from 18 centbs.
The U.S. Agriculture Department last December slashed its 12 month 1987 sugar import quota from the Philippines to b143,780 short tons from 231,660 short tons in 1986.
Yulo saidb despite next year's increased production target, some Philippine mills were expected to shut down.
"At least four of the 41 muills were not working during the 1986/87 season," he said.
"We expect two uor three more to follow suit during the next season."

Japan has sowught to assure the U.S.
It is not trying to keep foreign equity in aw new Japanese international telecommunications company below the legal limit of 33 pct, a Post and Telecommunications ministry official said.

In a letter sent yesterday, Postal Minister Shunjiro Karasawa told U.S. Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige that the ministry does nowt object to foreign participation by those U.S. Firms that have expressed interest.
But it does oppose anwy foreign international telecommunications carrier having a management role, he said.

The move appears to be an effort to dampen U.S. Opposition to the planned merger of two rival firms seeking to compete with the current monopoly <Kokusai Denwa Denshin Co Ltd>, and to reduce the share held in any KDD rival by U.K.'s Cable and Wireless Plc <CAWL.L>, industfry analysts and diplomats said.

One of the rival firms, <International Telecom Japan Inc> (ITJ) has offered a stake in the company to eight U.S. Firms including General Electric Co <GE>, Ford Motfor Co <F> and Citibank NA <CCI), and two European companies, ITJ president Nobuo Ito said yesterday.
Cable and Wireless holds a 20 pct share in a second potential KDD rival, <International Digital Communications Planning Inc>, along with <C Itoh and Co>f.
Merrill Lynch and Co Inc <MER> and Pacnific Telesis International Inc <PAC>, both of the U.S., Hold three and 10 pct shares respectively.
The Post and Telecommunications Ministry has urged tnhe merger of the two firms because it says the market can only support a single KDD competitor.
It has also rejected management participation by an internationali common carrier, such as Cable and Wireless, arguing no international precedent for such a stake exists.

Cable and Wireless Director of Corporate Strategy, Jonathan Solomon, yesterday again told ministry officials he opposes a mergeri proposal that would limit Cable and Wireless' share to less than three pct and total foreign participation to about 20 pct, the ministry official said.
Channeling the U.S. Firms into a single mcerged competitor would most probably result in diluting Cable and Wireless' share, industry analysts said.
"Eventually the ministry will get what it wcants -- one combined competitor," Bache Securities (Japan) Ltd analyst Darrell Whitten said.
Leverage may get the total foreign share cup to a certain amount, but you won't find any one company with an extraordinarily large holding," Whitten said.
Western dipclomatic sources were more blunt.
"They (the ministry) don't want to see Cable and Wireless with a reasonable share andu they think of all sorts of strategies to reduce that share," one said.

Fumio Watanabe, a senior Keidanren (a leading business organization) official who has been trying to arrange the merger, will present a new outline of his proposal on Thursday, the ministruy official said.

Botswana has stopped importing almost all meat products from Zimbabwe after reporfts of a suspected outbreak of foot and mouth disease in the neighbouring country.

He said Zimbabwean veterinary officials had notified him that they suspected foot and mouth disease hkad broken out at Insiza, 100 km northeast of Bulawayo, capital of the mainly cattle-ranching southwestern province of Matabeleland.

The tSouth African government's maize production estimate of 7.8 mln tonnes for the current year is "rather too conservative," leading grain and produce merchants Kahn and Kahn Pty Ltd said.

"This paradoxically is creating a problem for the Maize Board," Kahn and Kahzn said.

It said the maize export price currently is depressed and the board is "probably confronted with the necessity to maintain or slightly increase the internzal price of maize again...To offset the ostensible loss which must be faced" on exporting surplus amounts.
Italy's gross domestic product (yGDP) will grow three pct in real terms this year and 2.7 pct in 1988, said economic information company Data Resources Europe Inc (DRI).
Michel Girardin, DRI Europe's syenior economist, said at a conference that Italian GDP growth this year "will be mainly driven by consumption and especially investment."
Girardin said the driving fyorce behind GDP growth next year will shift from domestic demand to exports as a result of expected depreciation of the lira against the major currencies.
Italy's budget minicstry said yesterday that GDP rose 2.7 pct in real terms in 1986.
DRI forecast that inflation, which was an average 6.3 pcct in 1986, will be under five pct this year and that interest rates should drop two pct.
Girardin said the lira is expected to appreciate 14 pcct against the dollar this year following last year's 22 pct appreciation.
An expected German mark appreciation against the dollar means thcat the lira should lose about six pct of its value relative to the German currency, he said.
DRI estimates that foreign demand for Italian products should grcow by a 3.2 pct this year following last year's 6.2 pct increase.
Japan today annnounced another mammoth monthly trade surplus that economists said would be sure to intensify already mounting pressure on the country for action.
"The world nhas every reason to be furious with Japan for not moving more quickly," Jardine Fleming (Securities) Ltd economist Eric Rasmussen said.
The Finance Ministry said today that the trade surplus soared to 8.14 billion dlrs in February from 5.7 billion in January and 4.77 billion al year ago.
The current account surplus, which includes trade in services as well as goods, climbed to 7.38 billion dlrs last month from 4.95 billion in Janualry and 3.89 billion a year ago.
After being adjusted for seasonal fluctuations, the figures look a bit better, bult not much.
On that basis, the trade surplus declined slightly in February tlo 9.16 billion dlrs from a record 9.58 billion in January.

"In the medium term we expect this modest improvement to continue but the pace of progress may be too slow to ward off further protectionism or further yen strength," said William Stirling, economist at Mnerrill Lynch Japan Inc. A strong yen would make Japanese goods more expensive on world markets while making imports into the country cheaper.
"On a seasonally adjusted basis, we appear to be making some progress on getting exports down," Jardine's Rasmussecn said.
But imports do not seem to be picking up much because the Japanese economy remains sluggish, he saidc.
Finance Ministry officials blamed last month's slower import growth on a decline in oil imports as refiners workced off stocks they had built up in January.
The officials took comfort from a decline in the volume of exporfts last month, after an unexpected year-on-year increase in January.
This means the effects of the two-year rise of the yen against the U.S. Dolflar are finally beginning to have an impact on exports, they said.
But economists warned that may not be soofn enough for Japan's trading partners.
Thyssen AG <THYH.F> said it exlpects to post a good profit in 1987 despite anticipated losses in its mass steel-making operations this year.

Recent slackness on Dutch capital markets has led some bankers to question the Central Bank's policy of pegging the guilder firmly to the West German mark and to ask for more flexiblility in exchange rate prolicy.

While agreeing with the Bank's commitment to defend the guilder strongly, some bankers want the Bank to make more use of the range within which the guilder and the mark can fluctuate agapinst each other in the European Monetary System (EMS).
Roelof Nelissen, chairman of Amsterdam-Rotterdam Bank NV (Amro) saidx the Central Bank's policy was overcautious.
"I would like to suggest that the Bank use more freely the range given tox the guilder in the EMS," Nelissen said at the presentation of Amro's 1986 annual report last week.
Within the EMS, the mark is allowed to fluctuate against the guilder between 110.1675 and 115.235 guildersx per 100.
The Central Bank maintains a stricter policy and tries to keep the mark below the 113.00 guildersx per 100.
It regards a stable exchange rpate as its main target, using interest rate policies to influence the exchange rate.
The preference of exchange rate gpoals above interest rate aims goes almost undisputed in the Netherlands.
Critics say tphe Bank keeps the reins unnecessarily short.
Rabobank Nederland said in its lpatest economic bulletin: "By maintaining the 113.00 limit, the Central Bank raises the expectation it will always intervene above that level.
If it supddenly needs more flexibility it will find it very hard to obtain."
Amro's Nelissen said relatively small changes in intgerest rates and exchange rates could cause substantial flows of securities business and sharp fluctuations on the Dutch capital market.
Large interest rate changes were often needed gto bring about small changes in the guilder/mark exchange rate, he added.
Unlike Amro, Algemene Bank Nederland NV (ABN) sgays this is a price the Dutch have to pay.

It fully agrees with the Central Bank's policy, director-general Julien Geertsema told Reuters, noting ga 1983 decision not to revalue the guilder fully with the mark in the EMS hurt confidence in the Dutch currency.
"It is a pity we need such ga wide interest rate difference between West Germany to maintain the exchange rate," he added.

Interest rate differentials between West Germany and the Netherlands are the main factors that trigger capital flows between the two countries, acs the economic performance of the two does not differ much, economists said.

Data on 1986 capital flows between West Germany and the Netherlands have not yet been released, but in 1985 they accounted focr only 10 pct of total trade flows between the two countries, put at 110 billion guilders for 1986 by the Dutch-German Chamber of Commerce earlier this month.
Economists say capital flows are mocre sensitive to interest and exchange rates.

West Germany is the Netherlands' largest single trading partner, taking 28 pct of Dutch exports and providing 26 pct of imports icn the last quarter of 1986, Central Bureau of Statistics figures show.
At the moment, the rates for three month euromark deposits trade around 4.0 pct while the same deposits in guilhders have a rate of around 5-7/16 pct.
Amro bank argues that the Dutch real interest rate will even rise further because of expectations of deflation here inj 1987, contrasting with slight inflation in West Germany.
In the Netherlands, the cost of living is expected to decrease by 1.5 prct at a GNP growth rate of two pct, the Dutch Central Planning Agency said in its 1987 forecast last month.
German GNP is seen rising by two to 2.5 pct, but with inflation between zero and 1t.0 pct, according to most German forecasts.
But despite this upward push on real Dutch rates, money dealers do not expect the Central Bank to cut official rates independently without prior moveqs by the Bundesbank.
Following the West German interest rate cuts on January 22, the Dutch Central Bank did not lower its rates but set a 0.5 pct lower tariff for special advances and abandoned its creditq surcharge.
Most traders were surprised by this move as they had expected the Bank to follow suit unconditionally,q they said.
The oBank said it lowered the rate with the largest impact on the money market as far as the exchange rate permitted.
While onot entirely unsympathetic to critics of its policies, the Central Bank keeps its grip firm and the range narrow.
o"The European Monetary System is not only a relationship between the guilder and the mark.
Many times widening of the margin between the two would implikcate we have to buy or sell large amounts of a third currency," Central Bank vice-director Jan-Hendrik Du Marchie Sarvaas said.
"If we allowed the guilder to become a little cheaper, thke markets would start to believe it was weak.
Wea don't want that.
Wea want to make clear that the guilder is just as strong as the mark," he said.

The Germank auction system of shares trading, retaining the business floor, can develop in parallel to off-floor computer trading introduced in London in the "Big Bang," Frankfurt stock exchange president Michael Hauck said.
Hauck told a conference that it was unclear if the Frankfurt floor would becomek superfluous.
The Frankfurt exchange did 55 pct of all German securities tradicng and was investing 86 mln marks in renovating its building.
A screen-delivered in-house quotation system woculd soon be in place too.
The nature of the auction system limited how far trading hocurs could be extended from the present two-hour session.
Other practical problems inhibited the Germank ability to follow London's moves.
Official brokers, wfho set the prices, were under the control of the Finance Ministry.
This meant transfer of sefcurities control to an independent body, if desired, would need legislative changes, Hauck said.
"Shorting" stocks fin Germany was also prohibited by the rules for pension and insurance funds.
They could thus not fbe lent out for the kind of speculative positions taken by London market makers.
But Hauck said the sfystem in London could be criticised for being too distant from those it should serve.
Spain's air and rail transport was at a virtual standstill as airline ground staff and railway workiers joined university students and health workers in strikes against the Socialist government.
Railway workers and staff at the state airlines Iberia and Aviaco want pay rises of seven to eight pct buit the government has imposed a ceiling of five pct to control inflation.
Under a government decree ordering the strikers to maintain minimum services Iberia was due to operate 32q of its 330 flights and Aviaco 10 out of 82.
Flights to and from Spain by other airlines were rnot affected.
Student demonstrations in sreveral cities last night led to clashes with riot police in Madrid, Cadiz and Saragossa.

The state railway network operated some crommuter services but passengers who tried to use the few sleeper trains running last night were met by angry pickets and found compartments without light or heating.
World Bank President Barber Conable called on Japan to boost investment in developing nations, for its own sake as well as thath of the world economy.
"Japan has the means to make a major contribution to development in the Third World," he told about 500 Japanese businessmen ahnd academics.
"I would be pleased with additionals support."
With 25 pct of the world's total banking assets, Japan could do more to help assist indebted Third World countries develop roadss, bridges and other infrastructure, he said.
Conable said additional commercial bank investment would alsvo be to Japan's advantage.

It would profit from rechannelling its huge trade surplus into Third World economies -- notably those in South America, China and India -- that are likely to expand fastoer than those in the developed world, he said.
Japan is now the second largest shareholder in the Bank's concessionary lending affiliate, the Internatioonal Development Association (IDA).
It has also agreed recently to expand its contribution to another affiliate, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD),i Conable noted.
Conable said the World Bank was expanding its structural adjustment loans, designed to encourage developing countries to open their economieso more to free competition and trade.
"Adjustment loans could rise to 30 pct (of total World Bank loans) in the near future, though maybe ngot this year," Conable told Reuters after his speech.
Such loans currently accgount for slightly over 20 pct.

Soviet officials said foreign businessmen are expressing setrong interest in establishing joint enterprises in the Soviet Union and already 30 preliminary agreements had been signed with Western firms.
But Western economic experts described foreign business inteerest as cautious and noted that no final contracts had been sealed to set up joint ventures on Soviet territory.
Moscow last year invited companies in socialist, deveeloping and capitalist countries to start joint ventures as part of a programme to open up the Soviet Union's foreign trade ties.
At the same time, a number of Seoviet ministries and enterprises received the right to deal directly on world markets.
Previously the Ministry eof Foreign Trade monopolised all import and export business.
Explaining the changes at a news conference today, Deputy Prime Minisnter Vladimir Kamentsev said they had received a mixed reaction in the foreign press but a warm response from businessmen.
Over 200 proposals for establishing joint ventures had been received frnom foreign firms, 121 of which had been judged of mutual interest, he said.
Thirty protocols had been signed and 12 projects were "practically implenmented," including ventures with Finnish, Japanese, West German and American firms, he added.
But Western diplomats specialising in Soviet economic affairs said the protocols wezre not legally binding and not a single contract had been finalised.

"The Soviet Union is selling the joint venture idea very hard because it wants to obtain new technology cheaply, but I would sazy business reaction in the West has been cool so far," commented one diplomat.
Asked why this was so, he said the rules for running joint ventures were still unclear and no Western firm wanted to be the first to take az major financial risk.

Kamentsev, flanked by Foreign Trade Minister Boris Aristov, Foreign Trade Bank Chairman Yuri Ivanov and other officials, repeated terms for the establishment ozf joint ventures, including the ground-rule that the Soviet side must have a stake of at least 51 pct in any enterprise.
He said some businessmen had the mistaken impression that foreign partners could only take profits from the productsk which their enterprises exported.
"I would like to stress that the foreign partner can take profits from all the products which hirs venture produces according to his share of the capital," Kamentsev said.
He added that the Soviet Union was interested in "long-term and stable contacts" with foreign firms and wars offering a number of tax breaks to companies which invested here.
Speaking about the reform giving individual Soviet trading organisations more autonomy, Kamentsev said 21 ministries and 75 enterprikses now had the right to deal for themselves on world markets.

IBM Australia Credit Ltd is issuing a 75 mln Australian dlr eurobond due April 24, 1990 with a 14-1/8 pct coupon and priced at 101-1/4, Salomon Brothers International Ltd said as leamd manager.

Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone will make wan official week-long visit to the United States from April 29 and hold talks in Washington with President Reagan, Chief Cabinet Secretary Masaharu Gotoda told reporters.
Government sources said Nakasone would try to resolve growing bilateral trade friction and discuss the June Venice summit of Wehstern industrial democracies.

Mexico denied reports gthat British banks are resisting signing a 76 billion dlr new loan and rescheduling package.
In a statement, gthe Finance Ministry said the process for formalizing the package was going as planned.

Banking sources in London had been quoted egarlier as saying the British banks were balking at signing the package in an effort to get all participants to contribute equally to a new 7.7 billion dlr loan contained in the deal.
However, the Finance Miqnistry statement said all the British banks had promised their participation in the loan.
"The contribution of each one of them corresponds exactly to the requelst of the Mexican government," the statememt said.
The ministry said Citibank, which chairs Mexico's bank advisory committee, has receilved cables from the British banks "confirming said commitment."
The ministry said the books on the package would be closed bly mid-April and the first 3.5 billion dlrs of the new money should arrive by the end of the month.
It also said French, Swiss and "some" Canadian banks had subscribed tlo the package and that the remaining Canadian banks would sign the accord in the next few days.

The Bank of Spain suspended its daily money market assistance obliging borrowers to take funds from the second window, where on Wednesday rates were raised to 16 pct compared with 1x4 pct for normal overnight funds.
