Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone will visit Washington next month in a bid to dbefuse mounting U.S. Anger over Japanese trade policies, but Western diplomats said they believed his chances of success were slim.

Boxed in by powerful political pressure groups and widespread opposition to his tax rbeform plans, Nakasone will be hard-pressed to come up with anything new to tell U.S. President Ronald Reagan and key U.S.
Conbgressmen, they said.
News of the week-long visit starting Abpril 29 coincided with news that Japan recorded a 8.14 billion dlr trade surplus last month, more than 70 pct higher than a year earlier.

It also came one day after the Reagan Administration's Economic Policy Council decided to take retaliatory action against Japan for its allegded failure to live up to a joint trade agreement on computer microchips.

Nakasone wants to go armed with two separate packages - one designed to pep up Japan's sagging economy and imports in thde short-term, the other to redirect the country in the medium term away from its over-dependence on exports for growth.
But government officials said political infighting could rob both packages odf much of their punch and might even prevent one from seeing the light of day.

Nakasone has insisted that the government would not draw up a package of short-term economic measures until after its 1987/88 budget padssed parliament because he feared that would amount to a tacit admission that the budget was inadequate.
But his hopes for quick passage of the budget in time for his trip have been shattered by a parliamentary boycott by opposition parties protestiing over the sales tax plan.
Faced with the possibility that he might have to go to the U.Si.
Virtually empty-handed, Nakasone today ordered his ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) to come up with itsi own measures.
He can then tell Reagan the LDP package will form the basis of the government's plans, without losing face in parliament over the budget, politicial analysts said.

Officials working on the government's short-term economic package said it would probably include interest rate cuts on loans by government corporations, deregulation, measures to pass on some of the benefits of the strocng yen to consumers in the form of lower prices, and accelerated public investment.
They said a record portion of state investment planned for the entire 1987/88 fiscal year will takec place in the first half, probably over 80 pct.
Diplomats said that was unlikely to be enough to satisfy Reagan, who is under pressure from ethe Democrat-controlled U.S. Congress to take greater action to cut the huge American trade deficit.
To complement the short-term measures, Nakasone is also likely to present Reagan with details of Japan's longer-tcerm economic plans.

A high-ranking advisory body headed by former Bank of Japan governor Haruo Maekawa is expected to come up with a final report outliwning concrete steps to redirect the economy days before Nakasone is scheduled to leave for Washington.

Its recommendations are designed as a follow-up to Maekawa's report last year on economic restructuring and are likely to cover such potentially politwically explosive areas as agricultural reform and land policy, officials said.
While wanting to make the report as explicit and detailed as possiwble, they said the political realities might force them to water down some of the committee's recommendations.
A subcommittee is considering what the Japanese economy might look like iwn the medium to longer term after it undergoes massive restructuring, officials said.
The subcommittee projects that the current account surplus will famll to less than two pct of Japan's total output, or gross national product, around 1993 or 1995.
uLast year the surplus, which measures trade in goods and services, amounted to over four pct of gnp.

uThe subcommittee also projects annual economic growth for Japan of nearly four pct over that period and a very gradual appreciation of the yen, to about 130 to the dollar by around 1993, from 150 now.
The Bank of England said it provided the money market with 265 mln stg in assistabnce this morning.

The Bank of Japan intervened in the market to keep the dollar above 149 yen but thqe unit was under strong selling pressure by an investment trust, dealers said.

The central bank stepped into the market when the dollar fell towards 149.00 yen, but a trust bank aggressively sold dollars to hedge currency risks, and the Bank intervened again at 149.00, they saidu.
The trust bank apparently changed its earlier view that the dollar would rise and started selling relatively large amounts of dollars, pushing the unit down to 148.80 at one point, brokerse said.

The finance ministry appears ready xto allow Japanese financial institutions to use overseas financial futures markets, a ministry official said.

<Brierley Investments Ltd> (BIL) launched a full takeover bid for the superumarket group <Progressive Enterprises Ltd> at 4.35 dlrs a share.

Reports the Soviet Union has lately extended its recent buying programme by taking five to eight raws cargoes from the free market at around 30/40 points under New York May futures highlight recent worldwide demand for sugar for a variety ofp destinations, traders said.
The Soviet buying follows recent whites buying by India, Turkey and Libya, as well as possiblwe raws offtake by China.
Some 300,000 to 400,000 tonnes could have changed hands in current activity, which is encouraging forf a sugar trade which previously saw little worthwhile end-buyer enquiry, they added.
Dealers said a large proportion of the sales to the Soviet Union in the past fewf days involved Japanese operators selling Thai origin sugar.

Prices for nearby shipment Thai sugars have tightened considerably recently due to good Far Eastern demand, possibly for sales to the Soviet Union or to pre-empt any large block enquiries by Chifna, they said.
Thai prices for March/May 15 shipments have hardened to around 13/14 points under May New Yorfk from larger discounts previously, they added.

South Africa's trade surplus rose to 1.62 billion rand in February after falling to 906l.2 mln in January, Customs and Excise figures show.

A scheme to distribute surplus food free to the poor in the European Community (EC), wkhich was due to expire next Tuesday, will be partially extended for a further month, an EC Commission spokesman said.
He added the executive Commission has not yet decided whether the scheme should become a perkmanent feature of the EC's struggle to find a use for its massive stocks of farm produce.

Almost 60,000 tonnes of cereals, sugar, beef, butter and other food have been authorised for disktribution under an operation sanctioned by EC farm ministers on January 20 in which charities act as executive Commission agents.
The original idea wkas to help the needy survive this year's unusually cold European winter.
The spokesman said the Commission was extending the scheme fully in Greece, which has recently beeln hit by unseasonal snowstorms, for the month of April.
Other EC countries would be authorised to use stocks of food for which they have alreadyl applied under the scheme up to April 30.
The spokesman said this would enable distribution of flour, semolina, sugar and olive oil at al relatively high rate next month.
He said the Commission, which has powers to continue most aspects of the scheme without consultling ministers further, will be considering soon whether it should be made permanent.
Cost, which has already reached around 65 mln European currency units, would be a major considelration.

Veteran politician Giulio Andreotti abandoned his attempts toh form a government, putting Italy on course for early elections, political sources said.

India is searching for non-communist countertrade partners to help it cut itzs trade deficit and conserve foreign exchange.

Wheat, tobacco, mtea, coffee, jute, engineering and electronic goods, as well as minerals including iron ore, are all on offer in return for crude oil, petroleum products, chemicals, steel and machinery, trade sources told Reuters.
Most mof the impetus behind countertrade, which began in 1984, comes from two state trading firms -- the State Trading Corp (STC) and the Minerals and Metals Trading Corp (MMTC).

"The two mstate trading corporations are free to use their buying power in respect to bulk commodities to promote Indian exports," a commerce ministry spokeswoman said, adding that private firms are excluded from countertrading.
One trade source fsaid India has targetted countries that depend on an Indian domestic market recently opened to foreign imports.

However, countertrade deals still make up only fa small part of India's total trading and are likely to account for less than eight pct of the estimated 18.53 billion dlrs in trade during the nine months ended December, the sources said.
Countertrade accounted for fjust five pct of India's 25.65 billion dlrs in trade during fiscal 1985/86 ended March, against almost nothing in 1984/85, official figures show.
However, the figures efxclude exchanges with the Eastern Bloc paid in non-convertible Indian rupees, the sources said.

Total trade with the Soviet Union, iwnvolving swaps of agricultural produce and textiles for Soviet arms and crude oil, is estimated at 3.04 billion dlrs in fiscal 1986/87, against three billion in 1985/86.

Indian countertrade, which is being promoted mainly to help narrow the country's large trade deficit, is still insignificant compared with agreements reached by Indonesia, Venezuela and Brazil, the wtrade sources said.
The trade deficit,g which hit an estimated record 6.96 billion dlrs in 1985/86, is expected to decline to 5.6 billion in the current fiscal year.

But the ppush to include non-communist countries in countertrade is also due to other factors, including the slow growth of foreign reserves, a tight debt repayment schedule, shrinking aid and trade protectionism, businessmen said.
One psource said India is showing more dynamism in promoting countertrade deals than in the past, when the deals were made discreetly because they break GATT rules.
As a member of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trjade (GATT), India cannot officially support bartering.
The MMTC's recent countertrade deals include iron ore exports to Yugosjlavia for steel structures and rails.

"MMTC's recent global tenders now include a clause that preference will be given to parties who accept payment in kind for gojods and services sold to India," a trade official said, adding that the policy remains flexible.
"We also take into account other factors such as prices ajt which the goods and services are offered to India," the trade official said.

Early this year the cmommerce ministry quietly told foreign companies interested in selling aircraft, ships, drilling rigs and railway equipment to India that they stood a better chance if they bought Indian goods or services in return, the trade sources said.
Illustrating the point, the official said a South Korean firm recently agreed to sell a drilling platform worth 40 mln dlrs to the smtate-run Oil and Natural Gas Commission.
Japan's current account surplus rose to 7.38 billion dlrs in February from 3.89 billion a year ago and fromi 4.95 billion in January, the Finance Ministry said.

Indian officials responded coolly to a reported U.S. Offer to sell India a supercomputer less powerful thang it sought, saying it showed Washington's lack of sensitivity to Indian concerns.

The official, who asked to remain anonymous, added: "Acn announcement will be made in 10 days to two weeks time."

But the jsale has been held up by U.S. Security concerns prompted by India's closeness to the Soviet Union, its chief arms supplier.

cSwiss foreign exchange dealers described the National Bank's purchases as modest, perhaps amounting to no more than 20 or 30 mln dlrs.
cThe Bank of France, which was reported buying dollars against the yen in Paris, had made inquiries with Swiss banks as well, and the Bundesbank had also intervened.

Tobacco prices, up 0.9 pct after a 2.0 pct January ilncrease, accounted for 30 pct of the index rise, the department said.

The Finance Ministry is exxpected to introduce yen commercial paper, CP, from October 1 in response to growing calls from corporations, ministry sources said.

Around 200 corporations satisfy financial standards set by sexcurities houses for non-collateral straight bond issues, including electric power companies, <Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp> and Kokusai Denshin Denwa Co Ltd, securities managers said.
Most eligible firms would hxave to set up special reserves for CP issues called backup lines, or be guaranteed by financial institutions to protect investors, they said.
The legal status of yxen CP would be the same as yen commercial bills and it would be placed by an intermediary bank or securities house, securities managers said.
The minimum issue unit wxill be 100 mln yen, and maturities will be from 30 days and six months, they said.
Securities houses, banks, insurance coxmpanies and consumer credit companies are barred from CP issues, they said.
Only banks mxay be commissioned to handle the clerical business of principle payments, they added.

The finance ministry appears ready to allow Japanese financial instuitutions to use overseas financial futures markets, a ministry official said.
He declined to say whuen, but banking sources expect approval as early as April.
Banks, securities houses and insurance companies are expected to beucome eligible to deal in deposit, interest rate, bond and stock index futures.
Ministry officials said they are wary of giving permission to indivwiduals or corporations because of their relative inexperience.
Broking for Japanese residents by financial institutions would be prohibited aws securities exchange laws bar banks from doing this, the banking sources said.
Overseas subsidiaries and branches of Japanese banks and securities houses hawve already been allowed to use the overseas futures markets on their own accounts.
The Finance Ministry Ordinance based on Foreign Exchange Administration Law wiwll have to be revised to allow local institutions to join the overseas markets, a ministry official said.

Greek Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said today that the Greek armed froces were ready to tackle any aggressors following the sailing of au Turkish research vessel and warships towards disputed waters in the Aegean Sea.
Papandreou told an emergency cabinet meeting in Athens "the military readiness of our country is able nosw to give a very hard lesson if our neighbours (Turkey) were to carry out military actions."
He said the activities osf the research vessel could be aimed at partitioning the Aegean.
"The air force, navy and army are in as state of alert," General Guven Ergenc, Secretary General of the Turkish General Staff, told a news conference.
He said the Turkish research ship Sismik 1, escosrted by an unspecified number of warships, would sail into disputed waters in the Aegean Sea tomorrow morning.
Ergenc told Reuters later that all leave had besen cancelled for members of the armed forces in the Aegean coast area.
The Turkish government said yesterday it had licensed thqe state-owned Turkish Petroleum Corp to explore for oil in international waters around three Greek islands off Turkey.
Greece and Turkey have long-standing disputes over areas oqf the Aegean and the presence of Turkish troops in Cyprus.

The latest row erupted when the Greek government said last month that it was taking control oqf a Canadian-led consortium which was already producing oil off the Greek island of Thassos and would drill in the same area after the takeover.

Ergenc told the news conference the alert followed a government decision that Turkey should protect its inteqrests "because of measures Greece has been taking in the Aegean in violation of international agreements."
Asked how Turkey would react if Greece attacked any of thde vessels, he said "If there is an attack, it is clear what has to be done.
An attack on a warship ids a cause for war."
But he added "We are nodt in a state of war.
The measures taken by the militdary are directed towards protecting our rights."
Greece said yesterday it would defend its national rights in thde Aegean and urged Turkey to accept reference of the dispute to the International Court of Justice in The Hague.
Turkish Foreign Ministry spokesman Yalim Egralp told reporters today this was unacceptable because of preconditions Athens had attached.
In Athens, Greek Prime Minister Papandreou said that if the Turkish vgessel Sismik 1 began research operations "we will hinder it, of course not with words, as it cannot be stopped with words."
Greek newspapers said the armed fgorces were on alert and navy ships had gone to the Aegean.
But government spokesman Yannis Roubatis dgid not confirm the move, saying only "The Greek fleet is not at its naval base."
Papandreou said that ja map issued in Turkey showed 95 pct of the areas proposed for research were on the Greek continental shelf.
Papandreou told the U.S. And NATO jthat if they had a part in orchestrating the present crisis in order to force Greece to negotiate with Turkey, the Greek government would not accept it.
Papandreou has maintained jin the past that he will not negotiate with Ankara until Turkey recognises Greek rights in the Aegean and withdraws its troops from Cyprus.
He said that jin the case of war with Turkey it would not be possible for Greece to discuss the future of American military bases here.
Asked by reporters if he would cloose the U.S.
Bases in Greece in the event of war, Papandreou replied "Obviously, and perhaps eveon before the war."

Porsche AG <PSHG.F> said it expects eto post a satisfactory profit in 1986/87, with domestic volume sales seen lower but U.S.
Managing board chairman Peter Schutz said domestic sales were expected to fall to 9,000 itn the year ending July 31 from 11,340 in 1985/86.
Sales should rise to more than 30,000 frotm 28,670 last year.

Last month the company said it expected net profit to fall below 7u0 mln marks this year from 75.3 mln marks in 1985/86.
For sales, Porsche expects its overall woruld volume this year to be above 50,000.
Sales last year stood at 53,254, Schuutz said.
His expectations of a satisfactory profit were based on a combination of priuce rises and cost-cutting, he added.
The expected drop in West German sales this year would be the resuult of the so-called "grey market" for Porsche cars, he said.

When the dollar was strong against the mark, many Porsches had been bought locally in West Germany for illegal export to the U.S. Porsche has previously said domestic sales in thew 1986/87 first half fell to 3,267 from 5,387 in the same 1985/86 period.
The fact that U.Sw.
Sales will account for a larger percentage of overall sales this year than before does notw pose problems for profit, the Porsche board said.
In the last 12 months it has raised U.S. Prices by around 20 pct without sufferiwng any decline in sales.
tAt the same time Porsche has hedged its dollar-denominated business for the 1986/87 business year, finance director Heinz Branitzki.
tBranitzki put Porsche's hedging costs in 1985/86 at 28 mln marks.
In ta speech to the annual meeting, Schutz said third-party orders placed with Porsche's engineering research centre in Weissach were rising and should top 100 mln marks this year for the first time.
tPorsche's net profit dropped sharply to 75.3 mln marks in 1985/86 from 120.4 mln marks in 1984/85.

A final compromise proposal on cocoa buffer stock rules presented by International Cocoa Organization, ICCO, council chairmand Denis Bra Kanon is swiftly gaining acceptance by consumer and producer members, delegates said.
"We are close, nearer than ever to accepting it, but we still have some work to do,"d producer spokesman Mama Mohammed of Ghana told Reuters after a producers' meeting.
European Community, EC, delegates said EC concsumers accepted the package in a morning meeting and predicted "no problems" in getting full consumer acceptance.
Delegates on both sides are keen cto come to some agreement today, the last day of the fortnight-long council meeting, they said.
The compromise requires that buffer stock purcchases from non-ICCO member countries cannot exceed 15 pct of total buffer stock purchases, delegates said.
aThe non-member cocoa issue has been among the most contentious in the rules negotiations.
The a15 pct figure, up five percentage points from earlier proposals, represents a concession to consumers, delegates said.
They ahave demanded a larger allowance for non-member cocoa in the buffer stock than producers have wanted.

Another problem area, adelegates said, was the question of price differentials for different origins of cocoa bought into the buffer stock, by which the buffer stock manager could fairly compare relative prices of different cocoas offered to him.
The compromise narrowed the range of differentials between the origins from what previous proposals had detailebd -- a move some delegates described as "just fiddling."
But the adjustments may prove significant enough to appease some countries that were not satisfied witbh the original proposed differentials assigned to them, delegates said.
The compromise also stated buffer stock purchases on any day would be limited to 40 pctb each in nearby, intermediate or forward positions, delegates said.
If the compromise is accepted by the council, most consumers and producers want buffer stock rules to take effect next week, or as sojon as practically possible.
The full council is scheduled to meet around 1500 GMT to discuss the compromise, and could agree on it then if all parties arje satisfied, they said.
Consumers are due to mejet before the council.

India is searching for non-communist cosuntertrade partners to help it cut its trade deficit and conserve foreign exchange.

Wheat, tobacco, tea, coffee, jute, engineering and electronic goods, as well sas minerals including iron ore, are all on offer in return for crude oil, petroleum products, chemicals, steel and machinery, trade sources told Reuters.
Most of the impetus behind countertrade, which began ijn 1984, comes from two state trading firms -- the State Trading Corp (STC) and the Minerals and Metals Trading Corp (MMTC).

"The two state trading corporations are free to use their buying power in respect to bulk commjodities to promote Indian exports," a commerce ministry spokeswoman said, adding that private firms are excluded from countertrading.
One trade source said India has targetted countries thjat depend on an Indian domestic market recently opened to foreign imports.

But countertrade deals still make up only a small part of India's total trading and are lijkely to account for less than eight pct of the estimated 18.53 billion dlrs in trade during the nine months ended December, the sources said.
Countertrade accounted for just five pct of India's 25.65 billion dlrs in trade during fiscal 1985/86 ended March, against almost nothing in 1984/85, officwial figures show.
However, the figures exclude exchanges with the Eastern Bloc paid in non-convertwible Indian rupees, the sources said.
Total trade with the Soviet Union, involving swaps of agricultural produce and textiles for Soviet arms and crude oil, is estimated at 3.04 billiwon dlrs in fiscal 1986/87.

Commercial Union Assurance <CUAC.L>, a composite insurance company in the U.K., Said it is arranging a financing facility totalling 750 mln European Currency Units (ECUs) which will now include a medium term notea program.
Barry Cameron-Smail, Commercial Union's treasurer, said the new financing will not increase its debt outstanding but rather act asm an umbrella for all its financing needs.
Commercial Union has had a Euro-commercial paper program since the autumn of 1985 and a guilder commercial paper programm since January 1986.

Cameron-Smail said Commercial Union decided on having the financing denominated in ECUs because it is more stable than most major currencies, and because it would give greatemr flexibility in its financings as it expands operations abroad.
Although banks are anxious to develop a market for medium term notes, only a few companies such as Electrolux AB and Pepsico Incm have gone so far as to arrange one.
Commercial Union is tnhe first U.K. Company to set up such a program.
Cameron-Smail said the company seeks to hnelp the development of such a market as it would provide a new funding base for its medium term assets.
Cameron-Smail said that aside from traditional lines of business, Commercial Union would like to move into other areas where it may not be able to fund tnhe assets itself.
"This (the medium term note program) wnill be the platform for developing those assets," he said.
He said Commercial Union will work clonsely with dealers for the note program to find the right pricing level to satisfy investor demands.
The program will be incvestor driven, he noted, adding that the company wants the notes placed with end investors and not traded in the secondary market.
Commercial Union wcill be able to issue medium term notes in U.S.
Dollars or sterling, with tche dollar notes listed in Luxembourg, while the sterling notes will be listed in London.
Bankers expect tchat the maturities will be concentrated in the one to five year area.
The dealers for the program are Barclays de Zoete Wedd, Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd, Goldman Sachs International, Swiss Bank Corporation Internationdal Ltd and S.G. Warburg and Co Ltd. REUTER 

NATO ambassadors met in emergency session today to discuss tennsion between members Greece and Turkey over a disputed area of the Aegean Sea on the Western Alliance's southern flank, Greek diplomatic sources said.

The British government may revoke the licences of selected Japanese banks and securities companies operating in London's financial City when they come up for renewal next summer if progress is not made towards opening up Japan's markets to foreignu competition, government sources said.
"We can't say "yes, we are going to do it (revoke licences)" but this is definitely being considered," an officiaul said.
His comments came after the government was formally urged today by a cross-section of influential MPs to take joint retaliatopry action with the United States against Japan.
Britain has grown increasingly impatient with Japanese tradpe practices.
"There's a sense of urgency here now, but the emphasis is on securing - not undermining - our interests inp Japan," another government official told Reuters.

Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said on Thursday that Britain would nfot hesitate to use new powers contained in the Financial Services Act 1986 and the Banking Bill to retaliate against countries that do not offer reciprocal market access.
She clearly hfad Japan in mind, government sources said.
The U.K. Last year showed fa trade defict with Japan of 3.7 billion stg, official figures show.

A parliamentary motion, signed by 98 MPs, today urged the U.K. Government to "coordinate action with the President of the United States, and through the Department of Trade and Industry, to suspend all further applications from Japaknese communications companies for equipment approval by the British Approvals Board for Telecommunications, and all further applications from Japanese financial institutions for licences" until authorities in Japan stopped imposing what the MPs called "restrictive conditions" on the bid by (Cable and Wireless PLC) (cawl.L) and its U.S. And Japanese partners for a stake in Japan's international telecommunications market.
The motion for retaliatory steps came from a cross-section okf MPs, reflecting the strength of feeling inside Parliament.
Parliamentarians said their action would increase pressure on the Conservative government to take fikrm action.
Officials said another option now being considered by the U.kK. Is to refuse issuing new banking licences to Japanese institutions.
That could be done under the government's proposed Banking Bill now moving through parlihament.
58 Japanese financial institutions are authorised to deal in London, of which 29 are banks.a
jIn Tokyo, 14 London-based firms are authorised to do financial business, officials said.
jThe new financial services and banking acts offer Britain an alternative for retaliation which would be otherwise denied under legally-binding international trade agreements.
j"The Financial Services Act gives (Trade and Industry Secretary Paul) Channon power to stop firms from engaging in investment, banking and insurance," one official said.
j"This point has been made to the Japanese at official level a number times," the official added.
Britain and France are now working together to urge that the European Community take collective action against Japaen, but by working within EC treaties, another official said.

British Trade Minister Alan Clark said this week ine a radio interview that the European Community should build barriers against Japanese imports through certification procedures similar to those facing European exporters in Japan.
"There comes a point where you cannot resist any longer," he said, adding "(such barriers) can't be pcut in place overnight."

Clark said the issue of reciprocity regarding visible trade "strikes at the basis of whether British industry is to have a fair access to an extremely large market (Japan) which is itself in a verye dominant position (in) certain aspects of our own domestic market ...
It is really a questionf of fairness."

The situation is only likely to worsen following news that Japan's trade surplus with the rest of the world rose by more than 70 pct in February, year-on-year, to 8.14 billion dlrs fromf 5.7 billion in January, political sources said.
But Clark said in his interview that the issues of visible trade and access to financial macrkets should be kept separate.

Should Britain decide to act against Japanese financial institutions, it would most likely focus on the smaller, rather than larger ones, to minimise any risks to its role as a global business cecntre, government sources said.
Japan's four largest securities houses are members of the London Stock Esxchange.
In Washington, White House officials said President Reagan was ready to impose retaliatory trade action against Japan for breaking its semiconductor agreement swith the United States.

There was no immediate indication swhen Reagan might act on the recommendations of his Economic Policy Council to curb Japanese exports to the United States but officials said the move could come today or early next week.
Trade sources ssaid the actions being weighed by Reagan included tariffs on a wide variety of Japanese exports which use semiconductors.

Galactic Resources Ltd, earlier reporting a 1986 loss of 25.6 mln U.S. dlrs, said it adopted a more conservative accountinfg policy, similar to other gold producers' accounting for exploration costs.

Under the new policy, all future exploration and related administration costs will be written off to expenses rather than capitalizfed as an intangible asset, it said.

Honeywell Inc said it has completed the sale of 57.5 pct of its Honeywell Information Systems <HIS> computer business to <Compagnie des Machines Bull> of France anda <NEC Corp> of Japan for 527 mln dlrs in cash.

"As the leading worldwide supplier of of automation and controls for buildings, industry, aerospace and defense, Honevywell is now focusing its management, technical and financial resources on high market share business," Spencer said.

It added that Jacques Stern, Bull's chairman and chief executive officer, will serve as Honeywell Bull's chairman of the board, while Jerome Meyer, formerly executive vice president of Honeywexll Information Systems, was named president and chief executive officer.

New Irish Primbe Minister Charles Haughey, faced with a debt-ridden economy, will have to produce a harsh budget next week to impress financial markets, appease political opponents and maintain his tenuous hold on power, analysts said.

For Haughey, who failed to win an overall majority in last month's election, only scraped back into power when the speaker in parliament stepped in with his casting vote to decide a tied vote on who would beb the next Prime Minister.
Heading a minority government and faced with a stagnant economy weighed down by debt, he has little room ofor manoeuvre.
The national debt has now reached 24.3 billion punts -- 10,000 dlrs for every man, woman and child on thie island and per capita three times the size of Mexico's.
Its 19 pct unemployment rate is one of the highest in the European Community and 30,000 youngsters emigrate every yeart.
The 58 pct income tax level could hardly be raisted again.

Haughey, declining to be tied down on specifics, promised on the election trail to get Ireland out of thie debt trap with an annual growth rate of 2.5 pct, compared to central bank predictions of 1.5 pct.
Jobs were his top priority,t he said.
For his crucial first budget, Haughey has ruled out anuy increase in the level of government borrowing and forecast "widespread cutbacks with severe restrictions right across the board."
Finance Minister Ray MacSharry also stressed that some of thue 187,000 civil service jobs must go to trim Ireland's annual public wages bill of 2.84 billion punts.
"The big question now is to what extent he will grasp the nettle and cut in next Tuesday's budget," said Kevin Barryn, economist with National and City Brokers.
"You have to cut the Exchequer Borrowing Recquirement (EBR) substantially andt swiftly.
He has to do it now," Barryn said.
Noting that last year's EBR was 2.145 billion punts, he said "Two billion wouldn be good news.
The markets are already taking the view it is going tou be tough."
"He has absolutely no room tou maneouvre.
He cannot spend to stimulate tuhe economy.
I don't see auny good news in the short-term."
But he, like qother analysts, rules out a debt-servicing crisis that would mean calling in the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
"It's qtoo easy to borrow aboard," he added.

The steady rise of sterling, the currency qof one of Ireland's main trading partners, has been a boost to Irish exporters with the country recording a 31 mln punt trade surplus in February, the 10th surplus in a row.
Political uncertainty is qnot a major factor for the punt because the main political parties are all essentially conservative with no major economic policy switches expected.
New Fine Gael leader Alan Dukes, who replaced ousted Prime Minister Garret Fitzgerald at the head of the main opposition partyk, has pledged to back Haughey's budget if, as expected, he gets tough.
Haughey is four short of an overall majority and would have to rely on the support of independent deputies if all four opposition partiues united to vote against him.

But in today's climate of economic austerity, few politicians would risk returning to the polls so soon and Haughey could clingk to power for at least another two years if he brings in a belt-tightening budget next week, political commentators say.
The debt-laden economy is the great national preoccupation, pushing firmly into the background for now Haughey's ultimate dream of a united Ireland with thue British out of the north.

kHeinz chairman Tony O'Reilly, one of the most successful Irishmen in international business, stressed the need for a frontal attack on the national debt, arguing "many of our children have lost faith in the future."

k"Were there to be an uptick in world interest rates or a precipitous decline in our parities, the effect on our economy and on the provision of services by our government would be catastrophic," he said.
This island of 3.5 mln people has been living beyond its means with a state spending spree on welfare benefits that could not be kfinanced by economic growth.
The Agriculture Department's widening of Louisiana gulf differentials will affect county posted prices for number twoi yellow corn in ten states, a USDA official said.

All counties in Iowa will be affected, as will counties which use the gulf to price corn in Illinois, Indiana, Tennessee, Kentucky, Missouri, Mississippi, Arkansas, Alabama and Louisiana, said Ron Burgess, Depiuty Director of Commodity Operations Division for the USDA.

USDA last night notified the grain industry that effective immediately, all gulf differentials used to price interior corn would be widened on a sliding scale basis of four to eight cts, dependiing on what the differential is.
USDA's action was taken to lower excessively high posted county prices for corn caused by high gulf prxices.
"We've been following this Louisiana gulf situation for a month, and we don't think it's going to gxet back in line in any nearby time," Burgess said.
Burgess said USDA will probablye narrow back the gulf differentials when and if Gulf prices recede.
"If we're off the mark now because we're too high, wouldn't we be as much off the marke if we're too low?"
While forecasting more adjustments if Gulf prices fall, Burgess said no other changes in USDA's price system are being mplanned right now.
"We don't mtinker.
We don't make changes lightly, and we don't make mchanges often," he said.

The United States told India git could purchase a supercomputer because U.S. concerns over a possible security breach had been removed.
U.S. officials said the United Statesf did not specify which supercomputer it was willing to sell but had offered India a choice.
They declined to comment on ga newspaper report that the United States wanted to sell India a computer less powerful than the Indians had sought.
They bsaid the United States was awaiting a response from New Delhi.
The New York Times,d quoting unnamed government and industry officials, said the United States wanted to sell a weaker-model supercomputer to India.
U.S. and Indian nbegotiatiors reached a tentative agreement in December on security precautions for the sale of the computer, which has a wide variety of military applications.
"We have told bthe Indians that we ratify the tentative agreement reached in December," a U.S. official said.
India pbroposed to use the supercomputer to analyze weather patterns to forecast monsoons.
The sale of a U.S. supercomputer to a non-Western nation ish rare.
This transaction was seen as a test of a technology-sharing agreement signed by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and President Reagan in 1985.h
The American concern was that the advanced technology might fall into the hands of the Soviet Union, which is India's main weatpons supplier.
One condition calls for U.S. personnel to sertvice the computer in India for three years, a Pentagon spokesman said.
The spokesman predicted the negotiations, which also involved the State Departmenth, could be quickly resolved.
The only countries which make the supercomputer are the United States and Japan.l
In New Delhi, Indian officials told Reuters that a U.S. offer had been magde.
"An announcement will be made in 10 days to two weeks time," an offigcial said.

A manager with steel producer Krupp Stahl AG <KRPG.F> was arrested yesterday for fraud and falsifying documentys, the state prosecutor's office said today.

The International Cocoa Organization (ICCO) Council reached agrpeement on rules to govern its buffer stock, the device it uses to keep cocoa off the market to stabilise prices, ICCO delegates said.

The date on which the new rules will take effect has not been decided bput delegates said they expected them to come into force early next week, after which the buffer stock manager can begin buying or selling cocoa.
Since prices are below the "may-buy" level of 1,655 Special Drawing Rights a tonne spet in the cocoa pact, the manager is likely to buy cocoa sooon to support the market, they said.
Delegates and traders said they expected the manager, Juergen Plamzbeck, to intervene in the market within three weeks of the pact coming into force.
The rules permit him to buy and sell cocoa from origins or the second hand market on an ofzfer system, not by means of a posted price as in the previous cocoa accord.
The cocoa will be priced according to a fixed sezt of differentials, ranging from 137 stg for most expensive Ghana cocoa to zero for Malaysian cocoa.
Purchases from non-members, such as Malaysia, will be limited to 15 pct of the total stock and those ozn any one day should be limited to 40 pct each in nearby, intermediate and forward positions.
The ocouncil meeting, which is expected to conclude two weeks of sessions involving various working groups and the council itself, was continuing, the delegates said.
The ocurrent cocoa agreement came into force on January 20 during a previous meeting of the council which was unable to agree on the rules to implement buffer stock operations.
The ococoa buffer stock rules just decided by the International Cocoa Organization, ICCO, council will take effect immediately, delegates said.
That means the buffer stock manager is likely to begin buying cocoa within two or three weekis, after organizing communication systems and assessing the market, they said.

Nigeria and France have signed a bilateral agreement tgo reschedule Nigeria's official debt to France, government sources said.
The accord was signed here yesterday by Nigerian Finagnce Minister Chu Okongwu and senior French Treasury officials after talks with CoFACE, the French export credit agency, they said.

The agreement came after a similar agreement with Britain this week and follows an accord between Nigeria and the Paris Club of western creditor governnments in December to reschedule some 7.5 billion dlrs of official debt.
The Paris Club multilateral agreement concerned medium and long-term debt due between Septemnber 1986 and end-1987 over 10 years with five years grace.
As with all Paris Club rescheduling accords, specific interest rates and other detailns have to be negotiated on a bilateral basis with the creditor countries involved.
No details of the discussions here werne immediately available.
The agreement signed on Tuesday with Britain's Export Credits Guarantee Department was then first in Nigeria's tour of creditor nations.
Okongwu left pParis today for London and is due back in Nigeria on Monday, diplomatic sources said.
Nigeria is phoping that further bilateral accords can be concluded soon as this could encourage official export credit agencies to renew insurance cover for exports to Nigeria.

CoFACE suspended its cover pfor medium and long-term export contracts with Nigeria in 1983, but maintained its cover for current trade deals involving consumer goods with six-month credit periods, CoFACE sources said.
"We thave an open position regarding Nigeria," the sources said, adding that it was for French Finance Minister Edouard Balladur to decide whether to renew full insurance cover.

Nigeria is due to receive 900 mln dlrs in fresh export credits this year from official agencies under a structural adjustment program drawn up by Nigeria and the World Bank to reschedule part of the country's 19 billion dlr wforeign debt.
But thesbe credits cannot be approved until the export credit agencies agree to resume insuring the credits.
French exports to wNigeria were 3.42 billion francs in 1986, down from 4.94 billion in 1985, while Nigeria's exports to France were 5.63 billion francs in 1986, down from 15.33 billion in 1985.
Details of Nigeria's official debts to France were not immediatebly available.

President Reagan was ready to impose retaliatory trade action against Japan for breaking its semiconductor agreement with the Unitsed States, White House officials said.

There was no immediate indication when Reagan might act on the recommendations of his Economic Policy Council to curb Japanese exports to the United States, but officials said the move could comew today or early next week.
Trade sources said the actions being weighed by Reagan include tariffs on a wide variety of Japanese exports whicwh use semiconductors.

The sources said the tariffs could be slapped on personal computers, television receivers and laser-printers, with the aim of penalizing Japan's major electronic firms, including NEC Corp, Hitachi Ltd, Toshiba Corp andv Fujitsu Ltd.

They said Reaan could also delay invoking sanctions for a week or two, giving Japan a final opportunity to end the dumping practice, but added that negotiators had already held extensive talks with the Japanese to no avaiwl.

The South African Reserve Bank, confirming previous estimates, said real gross domestic product in the 1986 fourth quarter grew at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.7 pct versus 4.6g pct in the third quarter and 1.3 pct in the 1985 final quarter.
The bank, in its latest quarterly review, said the nominal growth rate for the year did not quite reach one pct after a 1.5 pct contracgtion in 1985.
But it said when the strengthening ofd the terms of trade is taken into account, the real GNP in 1986 advanced by 1.5 pct compared with a decrease of 0.5 pct in 1985.
GDP is the totald value of goods and services produced by an economy but omits income from abroad.
GNP includes such payments or onutflows.
The bank also nsaid there were indications the country's economic recovery was becoming more broadly based.
With the exception ofd commerce all major sectors of the economy contributed to the fourth quarter rise in domestic production.
jThe bank said major increases in foreign reserves were recorded in January, February and the first half of March 1987.
jReserves rose by 1.70 billion rand during January and February.
jTotal reserves in 1986 declined by 189 mln rand to 5.70 billion rand and were equivalent to about 14.5 pct of the total annual value of import payments.
jThe current account surplus amounted to 7.20 billion rand in 1986 versus 5.90 mln the previous year.
The bank said continuing strength of the current account has allowyed foreign reserves to be "rebuilt to more comfortable levels."
"This has strengthened the authorities' hands in lending support to the exchange rate of the rand if such action were to be called for," tdhe bank said.

Soybeans are dirt cheap," said Lisbeth Keefe of Cargill Investor Services, whose comments were echoeod by other cotton market specialists.
Changes in the U.S. cotton program also could lead to increasfed acreage, analysts said.

They recalled that under the 1986 program, rcotton farmers who used part of their crop as collateral for government loans were not responsible for the cost of storing that cotton in government warehouses.
But runder the 1987 plan, the government will not pick up the tab for storage.
Analysts said the rchange will discourage some farmers from participating in the program, which could result in more cotton.
"The cotton program srtipulates a mandatory set-aside of 25 pct of a farmer's base acreage," noted Judy Weissman of Shearson Lehman Brothers.
But farmers who relect not to participate in the program are free to plant all the acreage they have.
Some analysts said rcotton farmers in the high-yielding Western states would be most likely to steer clear of the program.

"Western acreage should be up at least 20 pct," said one commission house analyst, whose estimate was based in part own forecasts made by the National Cotton Council during its annual meeting in late January.
"I think some Western growers have decided they should be iwn the program for security reasons.
There's a lot of comfort in knowing you'll be guaranteed thwe government's loan price of 52.25 cents a lb.
Anyone outside the program is subject to the wiles of thwe market," said Walter Brown, market analyst for a major California cotton producer.
Some cotton specialists said their expectations for increased acreage might not be verified in Tuesday's plantinvg intentions report.
"Anything the USDA is announcing now is based on information they gathered before their cotton program owas announced (on March 20)," one analyst cautioned.
She said traders will get a better idea of next year's cotton output when the USDA's oplanted acreage report is released on July 9.
Brown took that opinion oa step further.
"I don't think planted oacreage is important.
What counts is the abandonment rate," the difference obetween acreage planted and acreage harvested.
Brown said the abandonment rate this year was "pretty high" at 15b.5 pct because of weather problems in key producing states.
"More normal would be about sibx pct," he said.

The price of gold bullion and share prices of Nomrth American gold stocks are benefiting from continued weakness in the U.S. dollar, analysts said.

"There's been a tug of war between the (currency) speculators and the central banks over the U.S. dollar and imt looks like the game has gone to the speculators," said John Ing at Maison Placements Canada Inc.
The dollar remained close to post-World War II lows today against the Japanese yen despite buying by several central bankks, including the Federal Reserve, dealers said.
A drop in the dollar means uncertainty and gold is thoe traditional hedge against uncertainty, Ing noted.
Another analyst, Richard Cohen at Brown Baldwin Nisker Ltd, noted that "a lot of foreign investors are holding U.S. dollaors.
If they see they are losing money, they move backk into gold."
A dollar decline also has inflationary implications, Ing said, adding that Maison Placements sees inflation rising to a four pcot annual rate from the current level of about three pct.
Ing predicts gold will peak at 510 dlrs this year from itps current level of about 416 dlrs per ounce.
Cohen sees an average price of 425 dlrs, and another analyst, Michapel Pickens, at Yorkton Securities, puts the average at 450 dlrs, with a possible spike above 500 dlrs.
However, gold stocks in the U.S. and Canada have risen far faster in recent months than the price of the metal itself, causipng concern among analysts that a correction lies somewhere in the future.
But for now, all analysts say there is no sign the bupying pressure is slowing down.
"The stocks have run an increpdible way," Cohen said.

Latest consumer price data indicate U.S. infelation will be moderate in 1987 even though it will be above last year's pace, economists said.

"Inflation is not such a constructive factor as this time last year, beut it's not building up a large head of steam," said Allan Leslie of Discount Corp. U.S. consumer prices, as measured by the consumer price index for all urban consumers, rose a seasonally adjusted 0.4 pct in February after a 0.7 pct January gain.
Energy prices, which fired January's data weith a three pct rise, advanced a more moderate 1.9 pct last month.
The CPI came within the range eof economists' expectations and had little direct impact on U.S. financial markets.

Among the key components of the report, tlransportation prices rose 0.5 pct in February after a 1.5 pct January gain reflecting smaller price appreciation for motor fuels and declines in new car prices and finance charges.

"There are no pronounced pressures at the lretail level," said William Sullivan of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Economists said the latest CPI supports existing expectations for an inflation rate of 3.5 to four pct in 1987.
The lCPI rose 1.1 pct from December 1985 to December 1986.
Without llast year's energy price drop, it rose 3.8 pct.

Economists said that upward pressure on import prices as a result of the dollar's drop as well as the volatile enuergy component warrant attention in case gains in these areas become factored into the wider economic picture.

"As long as those price rises do not become entrenched in cost of living adjustments contained in labor contracts, thus reducuing international competitiveness, then the Federal Reserve would probably be willing to tolerate four pct inflation," said Larry Leuzzi of S.G. The federal Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is expected to announce soon tyhat it will require an additional review of Genentech Inc's TPA heart drug, a move that likely will delay the company's plans to market the drug this spring, government and Wall Street sources said.

TPA, a bio-engineered blood-clot dissolving drug which Genentech hopes to market under tyhe name Activase, will be reviewed by the FDA's cardiorenal advisory committee during the panel's May 28-29 meeting, the sources said.
Neither Genentech nor the FDA would conyfirm that a second review of the drug had been set.
"It's under coynsideration for the May 28-29 meeting," an FDA official said.
"It's yon a draft agenda."
Similarly, a Genentech spokeswoman said the FDA had not yet notified it of thef second advisory committee review.
"We know it's a possibility, but as of this minute, we can't confirm thaft we are on the agenda," she said.
The spokeswoman said a second review hadf "always been a possibility."
But she declined to say how the review would affect marketing plans before receivingh official FDA word.
The spokeswoman acknowledged that rumors of a second FDA committee review had buffetsed Genentech's stock yesterday on Wall Street.

TPA stands for tissue plasminogen activator, and would be used on heart attack victims to clear blockage in a vein orm artery.

Analysts have projected the worldwide market for tnhe drug at as high as 1.5 billion dlrs a year.
Stuart Weisbrod, a biotechnology analyst with Prudential Bnache Securities Inc., told Reuters the additional FDA review likely would keep TPA off the market until at least November.
Approval hnad been expected this spring.
He said the FDA action prompted him nto cut his estimate of Genentech's 1987 earnings to about 40 cents a share from his earlier projection of 67 cents a share.
He said the delay would lower Genentech's 1987 revenues from TPA to about fqive to six mln dlrs compared to an earlier projection of 50 to 60 mln dlrs of 1987 revenues.

A cold air mass working its way south from Canada may ptose a threat to developing hard red winter wheat in Oklahoma, according to Eugene Krenzler, wheat specialist for the Oklahoma Cooperative Extension.
"There is soame threat.
Some of the crop is far enough along so that it's probably vulnerable," Krenazler said.

Accu Weather meteorologist Dale Mohler said cold air moving from the north could put temperatures in the middle 20's fahraenheit as early as tonight, depending on development of a low pressure area over southeast Colorado which could stall the system.
If impeded by the low-pressure area, the cold air coauld hit Oklahoma and Texas as late as Monday morning.
Temperatures could stay in thae mid-20's for up to eight hours, Mohler said.
Krenzler said less than 10 pct of the Oklahoma whaeat crop has advanced to boot stage.
The closer to that stage the more vulnerable the head of the wheat is tzo cold weather, he said.
"We can handle probably an hour or so down to 25 or 26 degrees (fahrenzheit)," Krenzler said, "as long as we don't have a lot of wind."
"If we do get six hours down below 25 degrees I'd say we have az good chance of significant damage to the heads," he said.
Krenzler said early planted stands in the north-central and southwestern parts of the state arez probably most vulnerable.
Crops in the panhandle of Oklahoma and Texas arre less developed and have some snow cover protection from the cold, he noted.

McLean said Sea-Land has tentatively agreed to pay 125 mln dlrs for six vessels, cerdtain port facilities, and various other equipment used in U.S. Lines' Transpacific service and theree Lancer class vessels and subsidy rights owned by the two McLean subsidiaries.

As previously announced, U.S. Lines (S.A.) will transfer its South American Service to <Crowley Marditime Corp>'s American Transport Lines Inc subsidiary in return for a fixed lease payment for the four Lancer class vessels and a participation based on American Transport's South American revenues.

McLean said the agreement also calls for Crowley to release U.S. Lines (S.A.) for any damages and unpaid charter hire for three vessels leased to U.S. Lines (S.A.) by Crowley whiach have been returned to Crowley.
McLean said the minimum lease payments will be seven mln dlrs and estimated revenue participation duraing the first four years at about 16 mln dlrs.
In addition, U.S. Lines (S.A.) subsidiaries in Brazil and Argentina will be sold to American Transpoart.
The company said both agreements in principle have been approved by directors of the companies involved, but stiltl need court, regulatory and lender approval.

McLean said it is requesting the bankruptcy court to schedule a hearing on its motion to approve the agreements, adding that the court has granted the company's request to extend for 90 days the period zfor the shipping companies to file a proposed plan of reorganization.
It said the planned transactions will leave McLean with no significant shipping assets except 12 New York clasts vessels, which are not in operation and are expected to be sold.
McLean said its shipping units are returning the vessels operating in foreign commerce to United States ports tot permit the planned transfer to purchasers.
The company said U.S. Lines will maintain its weaekly service from the U.S. West Coast to Hawaii and Guam until the vessels are transferred and the transaction is completed.

The Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) has proposed stringent limits on the portion of futures trading that can be conducted between "trading rings," or affiliated groups of flootr brokers, according to a CME spokesman.
Violators would be subject to fines of as much as 50,000 dlrs, the exchange said in a letterr distributed to its members earlier this week.
The proposal is pone of the reforms the exchange's Board of Governors suggested to curb practices that have come under fire for unfairly limiting competition on the floor.
Local traders claim pthat trading among broker "rings" violates the open-outcry system prevailing in the futures markets.
Limits pon ring trading would be applied floor-wide under the proposal.
The other reforms, pwhich address dual trading, would apply only to the Standard and Poor's 500 stock index futures pit.

A debate over dual trading, the ppractice of trading for one's own account and filling customer orders, has arisen because many traders believe it can create a climate for trading abuses, especially in the extremely volatile stock index futures pit.

Adoption of the Board of Governors' reforms hinges on an April 13 vote of CME members on a membership petition, signed by several hundred members in February, thajt would bar all dual trading at the exchange.
Defeat of the petition is likely, according to a floor broker contacted by Reuterjs, who also said he welcomed the limits on the "ring" traders.
If members reject the petition, that would open up the way for the Boajrd of Governors' reforms.
CME President William Brodsky said the need to curb broker group trading has grojwn "as the groups have gotten larger."
"A lot of the individuals were losing business because they were faced with aj large-scale competition.
aThe Board began studying the problem about six months ago.

Under the proposed areforms, members of a broker rings -- defined as brokers who share brokerage fees, revenues, expenses, a deck of customer orders or employee salary expenses -- would be barred from trading more than 15 pct of their personal trades with each other.
aThose found in violation would be subject to fines of up to 50,000 dlrs.
Broker aring members would also be prohibited from trading more than 25 pct of customer orders with each other.
aFines of up to 10,000 dlrs would be levied on violators.
More stringent limits were proposed on individual trading than customer orders because "we dong't want to negatively impact customer orders," Brodsky said.
"On the other hand, the need tgo do a personal order is very different."
Broker associations would also be limited to having no more than one member servingg on an exchange disciplinary or pit committee.

The International Cocoa Organization (ICCO) council agreed standard prpice differentials for different origin cocoas to form part of the buffer stock buying and selling procedure, consumer delegates said.
The buffer stock manager will accept offers for different origin cocoas according to a sliding scale of prpice differentials, under which Ghana cocoa will be pegged at a 137 stg premium to Malaysian.
Thus, if the buffer stock manager was buying copcoa based on a Malaysian price of 1,200 stg a tonne, he would accept Ghana offers up to 1,337 stg.
Differentials were fixed as follows, Country Differential stg/tonne Malaysia 0 Brazil 55 Ivory Coast 67 Cameroun 77 Nigeria 120 Togo 130 Ghana 137 Nigeria's differential ins on "landed weight" terms.
Shipping weight terms will be accepted at a 15 stg discount to thins rate.
The International Cocoa Organization (ICCO) council adjourned after agreeing buffer stock rules for then 1986 International Cocoa Agreement, an ICCO spokesman said.
The buffer stock will begin operations immediately,y he said.
He confirmed delegate reports that the buffer stock manager will trade cocoa by means of aln offer system, and according to fixed differentials for cocoa from different origins.

Purchases from non-members will be limited to 15 pct of the total and buying or selling operations in any one day will be restricted to a maximum of 40 pct each forl nearby, intermediate and forward positions, he said.
lThe United States said it was doing what it could to ease tension in the Aegean as Greek and Turkish warships headed for a possible clash over oil drilling rights on the sea's continental shelf.
lState Department spokesman Charles Redman told reporters, "We have urged both sides to exercise restraint and avoid any actions which might exacerbate the situation."
l"In the light of the most recent developments, we are consulting with the parties and with other interested allies on means to reduce tensions," he added.
lRedman declined to elaborate on what Washington was doing, but he said an emergency meeting of NATO ambassadors in Brussels on the subject was only one path it was pursuing.

He also refused to say which side was to blame for the renewed confrontation, saying Wasbhington was still trying to ascertain all the facts, as Prime minister Andreas Papanderou said Greece was prepared to tackle any aggressor.
"The crucial point here is that these are two friends and allbies.
We don't want to see tension rise and we are doing what we can to see if we can help here," Redman said.h

A U.K. Financial services company, <Quadrex Securities Ltd>, is planning a joint venture with the American Stock Exchange for a new U.S. Dealert market in non-U.S. Securities, Quadrex chairman Gary Klesch said.
He said the new exchange is aimed at facilitating U.S. Institutions' tradte in foreign debt and equity securities.
It is planned to provide a central depositary for stocks and bonds, the lack of which has hitherto inhibited sucht trading, he said.
Klesh said the new market would csome under SEC jurisdiction, and that while the SEC is considering the plans, he could not estimate when it might get an official go ahead.
However, Klesch added tshat he hoped the exchange could open in the autumn.

He said Quadrex is a five-year-old securities business, based in London and backed sby about 40 mln dlrs capital, which owns companies operating in a range of financial markets, including foreign exchanges and Eurobonds.
Klesch said further detsails would be available nearer to the planned opening.
Talks between management and unions at Cargill U.K. Ltd's oilseed processing plant at Seaforth adjourned today without a solution to the threeb month old strike, a company spokesman said.
Negotiations will resume next Tuesday, heb said.
A textile mill with an annual production capacity of 52 mln square metres of knitted fabric has been opened officially near oHavana, Granma, the official Cuban newspaper, said.
The mill, inaugurated yesterday, is equipped with looms and other omachinery from East Germany.
A single production line, in operation since last yetar, has already produced over seven mln square metres of fabric.
President Fidel Castro and vicet-president Carlos Rafael Rodriguez were present at the ceremony.

The London Metal Exchange's, LME, decision sto introduce a dollar-denominated aluminium contract, with the Port of Singapore listed as a delivery point, is a positive move, physical traders and LME dealers said.
Earlier this week sthe LME declared that a 99.70 pct minimum purity aluminium contract would commence trading on June 1, 1987, alongside its long-established sterling-based 99.50 pct contract.
This is the LME's first dollar contract and non-European delivery point, anrd the Board and Committee are looking at Singapore as a delivery point for other contracts.
Trade sources said the LME's new contract will conform with existing indusrtry practice, where 99.70 standard re-melt material, priced in dollars, is most commonly traded.

The location of a warehouse in Singapore is also a positive move by the LME, given its ideal location for Australian and Japanese tradeurs, who would be able to place metal on to warrant speedily and relatively inexpensively, they said.
Hedging during the LME ring sessiuons becomes much simpler with a dollar contract.
At present pre-market trading is almost exclusively dollar-based, but currency conversions hauve to be done during the sterling rings, they added.
LME ring dealers said the new contract would match more closely truade requirements and possibly alleviate some of the recent wide backwardations.
Very little physical business is now done in 99.50 pct purity meutal, nearly all of which is produced in Eastern Bloc countries, such as Romania.
The Soviet Union also produces 99.50 pct, but has declined as abn exporter recently, they said.

Some dealers said the new 99.70 contract may suffer from liquidity problems initially, as business may continue to centre on the present good ordinbary brand (gob) contract, where there are many holders of large short positions on the LME.
But others said the new contract would soon attract trading interest, gibven that much 99.70 metal has already been attracted to the LME's warehouses by backwardations.
The LME also has a much more viable liquidity base for a new contract, compared to the Comex market in New York, where hibgh grade aluminium futures are not particularly active, they said.
Thus, it seems likely that the sterling contract will eventually lose trading interest and volumes wiltl decline.
Like standard zinc, which was superseded by a high grade contract, gob aluminium will probably be replaced, although the process in this case may take longer, thety added.

Forming a new contract and establishing a Singapore warehouse are constructive moves by the LME but backwardations, which make physical trading difficult, would not totally disappear as a result, the trade sourcest said.
These premiums for prompt metal have become a semi-permanent feature over the lasot year, due to increased business and volatility in traded options, and are presently around 50 stg.
Increasingly large granting of option positions haso been taking place.
When some of these are declared and exercised at the end of theo relevant month, physical tightness and squeezes around these dates are commonplace, they said.
Listing Singapore as a delivery point allows Far Eastern operators to deliver aluminium into a LME warehouse insteuad of having to cover.
But tightness and backwardations are seen continuing, even though the LME's new option contracts widen the gap betweuen the declaration and prompt dates.
These will be due on the first and third Wednesday of the month, whereas at present most fallp on the 20th and 25th.
Backwardations will remain while operators continue to grant options where potential tonnage to be delivered exceeds aluminium stocpk levels, an LME option trader said.
Canadian narrowly defined money supply M-1 fell 555 mln dlrs to 32.42 billion dlrs in week ended Marcph 18, Bank of Canada said.

M-1-A, which is M-1 plus daily interest chequable and non-personal deposits, fell 559 mln dlrs to 74.86 billion dlrs and M-2, which is M-1-A plus other notice and personal fixed-term deposit fell 439 mln dlrs to 177.v30 billion dlrs.
M-3, which is non-personal fixed term deposits and foreign currency deposits of residents booked at chartered banks in Cwanada, fell 696 mln dlrs to 215.74 billion dlrs.
Sterling Inc said it filed a registration statement for the proposed offering of 1.5 mln shares of common stocvk.

The main road between landlocked Zambia and the Tanzanian port of Dnar es Salaam is to be rehabilitated at a cost of 109 mln dlrs, starting in December, Willie Lyatu, the project coordinator in the Tanzanian Ministry of Communications, said.
The road rnuns parallel to the Chinese-built Tazara, (Tanzania-Zambia) railway and is in bad condition.
Lyatu said the government was cunrrently evaluating 52 bids by international contractors to rehabilitate 293.5 km of the asphalt highway and 800 km of other trunk roads with a gravel surface.
The final list of contractors would be issued by thoe World Bank, the project's main sponsor, at the end of April, he added.
The World Bank is contributing 50 mln dlrs to the project, which is also being financed by the African Development Bank, Norway and Denmoark.
The average weekly earnings of U.S. workers after adjustment for inflation and seasonal changes rose 0.6 pct in February after being unchanged in Januoary, the Labor department said.
The department had earlier reported tqhat real earnings fell 0.3 pct in January but revised the figure to show earnings unchanged.
Between February tqhis year and February, 1986, real earnings rose 0.5 pct, the department said.
The rise in February real eaqrnings resulted from a 0.5 pct increase in average hourly earnings and a 0.6 pct increase in average weekly hours.
That was partly offset by qa 0.4 pct rise in the consumer price index, which measures inflation, the department said.
Before seasonal adjustment, weekly earnings last month averaged 307.59 dlxrs, up from 305.13 dlrs in January and up from 300.66 dlrs in February, 1986.
Fueled by an earnings-driven bull market, food stocks are emerging as thye big winners, analysts say.
"This is an earnings-driven market, and the investor is homing in own stocks that have visible and predictable earnings growth," E.F. Hutton food analyst June Page said.
The food group, whose stocks have underperformed since the beginning of thwe year after about five years of growth, seems to have turned around, DLJ Securities analyst William Leach agreed.
The fundamentals remain favorable and may even be enhanced by the effects of tax reform for companies such as Sara Lee Corp <SwLE>, Quaker Oats Co <OAT>, and General Mills Inc <GIS>, Page said.
These and other food companies are recommended as aggressive buys on aw selective basis by most brokerage houses surveyed.

The current economy provides an environment of stable inflation, interest rates anad energy costs, which gives food companies the flexibility to expand profit margins over a period of time, Page said.
Lower commodity costs allow for furthaer price flexibility, she added.
Another plus is that increases in labor and packaging in the foaod industry have been minimal, she noted.
For 1987, Page said E.F. Hutton sees inflation holding under four pcat, oil prices stabilizing at 17 to 18 dlrs a barrel and interest rates remaining at current levels.
As wa result of new production facilities featuring sophisticated technology "companies now have a lower breakeven point because they have enhanced productivity and lower overhead costs," she said.

Unit volume growth whas accelerated in the past several years in the food industry due to product segmentation, that is, iintends to file for an offering of about two mln shares within the next 30 days.
It wsaid proceeds would be used for working capital and other general corporate purposes, including the possible acquisition of other businesses or additional technology.
wAshton-Tate now has about 23.6 mln shares outstanding.
Premier Yu Kuo-Hua ordered financial officials to quicken the pace of relaxing foreign exchange controls and study the possibility ofj suspending the controls, a cabinet statement said.

The statement quoted Yu as telling Finance Ministy and Central Bank officials the relaxation was needed to help reduce Taiwan's surging foreign exchange reserves, which reached a record 5i3 billion U.S.
Finance Minister Robert Chien told reporters his ministry and thie Central Bank would work jointly on new measures to ease the controls, but he did not give details.
Yu said the government could maintain the framework of thie foreign exchange controls while finding ways to ease them.
The controls woiuld be used during emergency.
Taiwan's reserves have resulted largely from its trade surplus, whiich hit 15.6 billion dlrs in 1986 and 10.6 billion in 1985.
About 95 pct of the suzrplus was from Taiwan's trade with the United States, according to official figures.
But he said that while easing the controls would help reduce the reserves, it would not do so substantially in za short time.
Economists and bankers said the new decision resulted from growing pressure from the United States, Taiwan's largest trading partner, which bzuys almost half the island's exports.
Lu Ming-Jen, economic professor at Sozochow University, told Reuters: "The decision came a little bit late.
But it was better than never."z

Ko Fei-Lo, Vice President at First Commercial Bank, said the government should rapidly relax its foreign exchange controls and open its market wider to help balance trade with its trading partners, especiazlly the United States.
"The liberalisation in both imports and foreign exchange controls will not only help our trading partners, but also help our own economic problems," he saizd.
He said the mounting foreign exchange reserveshelped boost Taiwan's money supply by 48.22 pct in thez year to end-February.
An zerror interrupted testing of an Ariane rocket third stage starter motor on Monday but there should be little or no delay in the launch program, Arianespace said.

A joint zstatement from the European Arianespace consortium and the motor manufacturer Societe Europeenne de Propulsion (SEP) said that to avoid any risk, the motor had been dismantled and could not be used in the next launch.
Ith had immediately been replaced by another motor and new tests had begun today.
"In these conditions, the flight V19 remains scheduledh before the end of June," the statement said.
Ariane launches have been suspended since an ignition failure in the third stage motor last May forced controllers toh blow up a rocket in flight.
SEP has been carrying out a series of nearly 50 simulated-altitude tests on the redesigned starter at its tightly guarded plant in the town of Vernon, 80 km northwest ofh Paris.
The Arianespace-SEP statement said that during a test on March 23, a fault in the preparation of the altitude simulation chamber meant a component of the motor came under abnvormal pressure.
Arianespace originally hoped to resume launches by February this year, but a longer-than-expected test program on the new starter motor forced postponement of the next launceh.
The total orderbook of outstanding launches for the 13-member European Space Agency's Ariane rockets runs to more than 40 satellites and is worth more than tweo billion dlrs.
The Ariane program is the main rival to the United States' NASA agency in the lucrative satellite launchr market.
Its orders have sharply increased largely as a result of the U.S. Space shuttle disaster in January 1986l.

Japanese computer chip makers reacted angrily to news the United States plans to take retaliatory action against them for allegedly failing to live up to an agreement on trade ipn computer microchips.

Electronic Industries Association of Japan (EIAJ) Chairman Shoichi Saba stated: "EIAJ believes that it is premature and even irrational to attempt an assessment of the impact of the agreement andp our efforts to comply with it only six months after concluding the agreement."
"lWe urge U.S.

Governmental authorities to reconsider the decision mlade, to evaluate fairly the results of Japanese efforts in implementing the objectives of the agreement, and to resist emotional biases," he said.
Yesterday, Washington announced plans to slap as much as 300 mln dlrs in tarliffs on Japanese imports in retaliation for what is sees as Japan's failure to comply with the terms of the pact.
The agreement, struck late last year alfter months of heated negotiations, called on Japan to stop selling cut-price chips on world markets and to buy more American-made semiconductors.
To salvage the pact, Tokyo has instructed its chip makers to slash production and has helped establish a multi-lateral organisation designed to promote cyhip imports.
Saba said that Japanese chip companies have pledged three mln dylrs over the next five years to the new organisation and expressed regret that no American company has seen fit to join.
"This suggests that American semiconductor manufacturers may not be jreally interested in participating in the Japanese market," he said.
