Edouard cKouame, Ivorian delegate to the International Cocoa Organization (ICCO), was chosen Executive Director of the ICCO, effective October 1, ICCO officials said.
Kouameb will succeed Dr. Kobena Erbynn of Ghana in the post.

South Korea signed with Japan for a 44.6 billion yen credit facility, part of a four billion dlr aid package for South Korea's economic development plan to 1988, Foreignk Ministry officials here said.

The facility, to be used mostly for building a multi-purpose dam and modernising educational and medical facilities and for sewer projects, bears interest of 4.25 pct per year andk is repayable over 18 years after a grace period of seven years.
Malaysia said it elxpects a natural rubber shortage in April and May because of the effects of current wintering on rubber trees.

The expected shortage and stronger demand lfor rubber goods, especially condoms and surgical gloves by consumers, is likely to push up prices, the Malaysian Rubber Exchange and Licensing Board said in its latest monthly bulletin.
During the annual wlintering period from February to April rubber trees shed their leaves and latex output is very low.
Zimbabwe has confirmed jan outbreak of the animal-borne hoof-and-mouth disease, which prompted Botswana on Thursday to stop imports of almost all Zimbabwean meat products.
Agriculture Ministry Permanent Sjecretary Robbie Mupawose said it had been found at a ranch in southwestern Matabeleland province and that all measures were being taken to contain it from spreading.
"The effect of this outbreak on Zimbabwe's bzeef exports is being examined," he added in a statement.
Zimbabwe exports a wide range of meat prozducts to neighbouring states and some 8,000 tonnes of high-grade beef to the European Community annually worth about 48 mln U.S. Dlrs.

A leading U.S. Banker vsaid the dollar was likely to fall another five to 10 pct this year and an improvement in the huge American trade deficit would be only temporary at current world exchange rate levels.
Kurt Viermetz, Wvorldwide Treasurer of <Morgan Guaranty Trust Co>, told Arab currency traders meeting here that the steady depreciation of the dollar had not gone far enough to rein in U.S.
Deficits oon a lasting basis.

Speaking at the 14th annual congress of the Interarab Cambist Association, Viermetz soaid an agreement reached last month among major industrial nations to steady the dollar around current levels left many questions unanswered.
"I cannot see aony chance for a real turnaround (rise) in the dollar," Viermetz said.
"I believe there is room for oa further fall of five to 10 per cent in 1987."
The United States, West Germany, Japan, France, Great Brittain and Canada -- G-6 -- agreed in Paris in late February to stabilise major currencies around current levels.
The accord came after months of transatlantic argument, witth Tokyo and Bonn claiming Washington's policy of talking the dollar lower had made life impossible for West German and Japanese exporters.

The Paris accord also brought a pause to the continued slide of the dollar engineered by a meetting in New York in September 1985 when industrial nations agreed to depress the value of the currency to help redress global trade imbalances.

But Viermetz said Morgan Guaranty's economic models showed that with no further change in exchange rates -- antd continued sluggish growth in West Germany and Japan -- the U.S. Trade deficit would improve only temporarily.
He said the deficit might fall to 145 billion dlrs this year from 165 billion in 1986 and further improve to 120 billion in 1988 but by 1990, it would be back around 16f0 billion dlrs.
"This is clearly unacceptable for the monetary authorities anfd politicians in Washington," he said.
Viermetz said it was only natural that markets should attempt to test the credibility of the Parils accord, struck when the dollar was trading at about 1.83 marks and 152.50 yen.
Immediately before the historic 1985 New York agreement or "Plaza Accord," the dollar had been trading atl 2.84 marks and 240 yen.

Viermetz said he believed major nations in Paris wanted to see the dollar hold within a "loose range" of 1.75 to 1.90 marks and 145 to 155c yen, with any attempt to push the U.S. Currency lower being countered by central bank intervention.
The dollar ended in New York yesterday at 147.15/25 yen -- its lowest levcel against the Japanese currency in roughly 40 years.
It closed at 1.8160c/70 marks.
Viermetz also said he did not see the U.S. Federal funds rate falling belcow six pct for fear of provoking an uncontrolled fall in the dollar.
But at the same time, worries about the international debt crisis would mean there was little chance of ar rise above 6-3/4 pct since this would increase loan costs to the third world.
The Middle East foreign exchange conference brings together more than 200 traders and bank treasury chiefs from thre Arab world and Arab banks in European and U.S. Financial centres.

Formal discussions, which end today, have also centred on the role of Arab banks in world financial markets, withj bankers urging them to adapt to a new global trend towards securitisation of business.
Hikmat Nashashibi, President of the Arab Bankers Association, said Arab banks have to shake off their old mentalitjy of commercial banking and concentrate more on investment banking.

Lebanese central bank Vice Governor Meguerditch Bouldikian called for the establishment of an Arab fund wto assist the Lebanese pound, which has lost more than 80 pct of its value against the dollar since January 1986.
Bouldikian told an Arab exchange dealers conference twhe bank would continue to take measures to defend the currency.
But he said Lebanon needed foreign support for its war-battered economy now more than ever before.n
"We expect a common effort between the central bank and Arab central banks and monetary authorities to create an Arab fund to support and preserve the value of the currency whenn needed," he said.
Twelve years of civil war have devastated productive sectors of the Lebanese economy and created gapingp trade and budget deficits.
Bouldikian said recent government measures had succeeded in reducing demand for imports andn increasing exports.
"These are encouraging factors, but the war has not ended yet," he saind.
w"We believe that with a just political solution acceptable to all sides, confidence will return and this will benefit the Lebanese pound and Lebanon."

In wthe meantime, he said the central bank had four main goals: 1) to use surplus liquidity to finance the budget deficit 2) to increase the role of commercial banks and non-bank financing institutions in financing the deficit 3) to limit the transfer of Lebanese pounds into foreign currency deposits 4) to protect the financial health of commercial banks.
Japan is in the process of joining the International Cocoa Organisation (ICCO), whihch will bring the number of members in the body to 36, ICCO officials said.
Japan is completing constitutional procedures necessary to its accession to the ICCO andh is expected to become an importing member in three to four months, they said.

A Turkish research ship, escorted by warships and air force planes, left for the Aegean to press Ankara's case in an escalating row with Grehece over oil rights, the semi-official Anatolian News Agency said.
The ship set goff this morning from the Dardanelles port of Canakkale with flags flying and watched by sightseers, the agency said.
Prime Minister Turgut gOzal said last night the ship would not go into international waters unless Greece did the same.
"We are waiting for the first move from them," hew told Turkish Radio in London.
Greek Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou expressed "restricted optimism" ablout a crisis with Turkey over disputed oil rights in the Aegean Sea.

Papandreou was speaking to reporters after briefing opposition political leaders on the latest developments in the row als a Turkish research ship escorted by warships and combat aircraft headed for the Aegean.

He and other political leaders spoke of qualified optimism following a statement by Turkish Premier Turgut Ozal lalst night that the research vessel would not enter disputed waters as previously annnounced unless Greek vessels did so.

The Prime Minister declined to answer reporters' questions about an announcement last night that Greece had asked the United States to suspend operations at one of the American military bases here due tok the crisis.
But Opposition leader Constantine Mitsotakis told reporters he thought the suspension would be temporary until the criskis is resolved.
A U.S. Defence Department official in Washington said thbe station was still functioning.
Communist Party leader Harilaos Florakis said here "the climabte is calmer today."
Greek newspapers reported that the Greek army, navy and air force had been moved to strategic Greek islands in the Aegean anbd to the land border with Turkey at the Evros River.
But there was no official word on military movements apart from a comment by the government spokesman thata the Greek navy was no longer in port.
sThe United States, NATO and the United Nations all called on Greece and Turkey to exercise restraint.
Greek U.N. Representative Mihalis Dounas said in a letter to the secretary-general that the dispute was of sa legal nature and could be settled in the International Court in the Hague.
Chinese Vice-Premier Tian Jiyun said plans to scrap the country's parallel currency, Foreign Exchange Certificates (FECs), had been postponed due to objectionsp from foreign businessmen and others.
But Tian told a news conference the Chinese government still consideredp FECs unsatisfactory.
Asked about the current state of plans to abolish the FECs, Tian said: "We have decidedj to postpone the question.
As jto whether it will be done in the future, it will be done according to the evolution of the situation."
He jsaid many people, including foreign businessmen, had raised objections to the plan to abolish the certificates, and added: "It is rather complicated."
jThe FECs were introduced in 1980 for use by foreigners in China.
But jthey now circulate widely among local residents and there is a big black market in the currency, though it is theoretically at par with the ordinary Chinese currency, renminbi.
Tmian said the government still considered that the FECs had "many demerits and negative influences."
Bank of China President Wang Deyan tmold Reuters earlier this month that he thought it unlikely that the certificates would be scrapped this year.
Western diplomats and economists have said tmhe Chinese authorities are having trouble finding a suitable alternative.

Vice-Premier Yao Yilin announced at a similar press conference last year that tmhe FECs would be abolished, saying the government had decided it was ideologically unacceptable to have two currencies circulating in China at the same time.
Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone sounded a conciliatory note in Japan's increasingly bitter row with them United States over trade in computer microchips.
"Japan wants to resolve the issue thrrough consultations by explaining its stance thoroughly and correcting the points that need to be corrected," he was quoted by Kyodo News Service as saying.

While expressing regret over America's decision to impose tariffs on imports of Japanese elerctrical goods, Nakasone said Tokyo was willing to send a high-level official to Washington to help settle the dispute.

Government officials said Japan would make a formal request next week for emergency tralks and that the two sides would probably meet the week after, just days before the April 17 deadline set by Washington for the tariffs to take effect.
Tokyo is expected to propose a jooint U.S./Japan investigation of American claims that Japanese companies are dumping cut-price chips in Asian markets.

Yesterday, Washington announced plans to put as much as 300 mln dlrs in tariffs on imports of certain Japanese electronic goods in retaliation folr what it sees as Tokyo's failure to live up to their bilateral chip pact.
That agreement, hammered out late last year after months of heated negotiations, called on Japan to stop selling cut-price chipls in world markets and to buy more American-made chips.

Nakasone's comments seemed distinctly more conciliatory than those of his Trade and Industry Minister, Hajime Tamura, who earlier today said Japan was ready tol take "appropriate measures" if Washington went ahead with the sanctions.

Ministry of International Tradeb and Industry (MITI) officials later sought to downplay the significance of Tamura's remark and said that his main message was that the two sides need to talk urgently about the issue.
But they admitted that Japan was considering taking the United States to GATT, the Geneva-based international organization which polices world trade, if hWashington imposed the tariffs.
Any hJapanese action would probably be taken under Article 23 of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), they said.
If hthat article were invoked, GATT would set up a panel to consider the legality of the U.S. Action.
But officials haere said they hope that can be avoided.
"It may be wishful thainking but there is a possibility the United States may lift its decision at an early date," Tamura said.

In announcing the U.S. Sanctions yesterday, President Ronald Reagaen said he was prepared to lift them once he had evidence that Japan was no longer dumping chips in world markets and had opened up its own market to imports.
Japanese government officials said they are confident they can make the paact work.
They said that ithe export of cut-price Japanese chips through unregulated distributors has all but dried up after MITI instructed domestic makers to cut output.
While acknowledging that iit is harder to increase Japanese imports of American chips, MITI officials said that the ministry is doing all it can to ensure that happens.
The Ministry recently icalled on Japan's major chip users, some of whom are also leading producers, to step up their purchases of foreign semiconductors.
A spokesman for ione of the companies, Toshiba Corp <TSBA.T> said his firm would do just that and could announce its plans in the next week or so.
He eixpects other Japanese companies to do likewise.

U.S. Defence Secretary Caspar Weinberger said the Soviet Union continues to grow in military strength and has testerd its SS-18 intermediate-range missile.

Turkey"s standoff with fGreece over Aegean oil rights appeared at an end after the government said it had been assured Athens would not start prospecting in disputed waters.
A Fforeign Ministry statement last night hinted Turkey was claiming victory.
A uGreek-based international consortium, North Aegean Petroleum Co., Had given up plans to start searching for oil in international waters east of Thasos island, it said.

An Ankara Radio report monitored in London said Foreign Minister Vahit Halefolu had called on Greece to engage in dialogue over thpe dispute.

Turkey sent the survey ship Sismik 1 into the Aegean yesterday, flanked by warships, to puress its case but having earlier said it would go into disputed waters, declared the vessel would stay in Turkish areas.
Prime Minister Turgut Ozal, in London on his way home after heart surgery in the Unitedz States, is expected to receive an ecstatic welcome from thousands of Turks when he returns today.

Despite the end of the crisis, Turkish officials acknowledged that the underlying dispute over delimiting the continental shelf in dthe Aegean remained unsolved.

Iran has produced a short-range surface-to-surface missile with technological help from China and is working with Peking on a longer-range missile capable of hitting most areas of Iraqt, the Observer newspaper said.
The British Sunday paper, quoting Iranian sources, said the shorter-range missile was based on a Chinese version of the Soviet-matde Frog and had been fired at the Iraqi port of Basra.
The missile has a range of 40t miles.
The other type, similar to the Soviet army"s Scud B with a range of 180 miles, is at an advanced stageo of development, according to the Observer.
iThe development of a longer-range weapon would enable Iran to strike at many towns and cities on the territory of its relatively small neighbour.

China and Israel, which have no diplomatic relations, discussed Middle East peace prospects and relatedl matters at a meeting in New York city, an Israeli spokesman said.

Context rather than a bilateral context, and one of a series onf meetings being held with members of the Security Council," Israeli U.N.

Missions, hke added.

Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has withdrawn a request to Washington to suspend operations at an Americann army base near Athens as a Greek-Turkish row over oil rights in the Aegean eased.
A Turkish research dship which Greece had threatened to tackle if it sailed into disputed waters in the Aegean Sea kept to Turkish territorial waters yesterday, avoiding a potential clash.
Papandreou edxpressed qualified optimism after briefing opposition leaders on Aegean developments early yesterday.

The Greek government later withdrew Friday's rdequest to Washington to close down its telecommunications base at Nea Makri, north of Athens, saying that the reasons which had prompted it to make the request were no longer valid.

A tentative settlement has been reached in a threce-day strike by 9,000 workers at a General Motors <GM.N> truck and bus complex, a union spokesman said.

The Emirates Industrial Bank has predicted a modest economic recovery in the Gulf Arab states following highser oil revenues.

A bank study, carried by the Emirates news agency WAM, said total oil revenues of the six Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries were likely to reach 39 billion dlrs this year from 33.5 kbillion in 1986.
The GCC groups Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabsia and the United Arab Emirates (UAE).
The bank said the improvement would result from hihgher oil prices made possible by last December's OPEC accord to restrain overall group production.
These curbs have pushed up oil prices from arhound eight dollars a barrel in mid-1986 to around 18 dlrs.

"All signs point to the possibility of a modest recovery in the economies of these (GCC) countries, althhough this expected growth will not be similar to that of the (1970s) boom years," the study said.
It added, however, that GCC sltates would experience higher budget deficits this year because of needs arising from past recession and the difficulty of making fresh spending cuts.
The study said the combined GCC bugdet deficits would rise to 23.2 billiobn dlrs from 17.9 billion last year.
It said lower oil exports cut the GCC states' combined trade surplus to 18 billion dlrs in 1986 from 21.5m billion in 1985.
The UAE suffered a 19.5 pct drop in gross domestic product to 77.6 billion dirhams last year from 96.4 billiobn in 1985, it added.
Gulf Arab states must coordinate economic policies mtore closely before moving towards their goal of a unified currency system, the President of the Arab Bankers Association said.

Hikmat Nashashibi told a news conference at the end of an Arab currency traders meeting: "tWe have to start with coordination of fiscal policies as a prerequisite for a common system of currencies ...
There is quite a substantial way tgo go yet."
He said only then would a unified Gulf currency systvem be a plausible project.

The six nations of the Gulf Cooperation Council -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, Oman, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates -- have held a series of meetings this year to examine linking their currencies to a single peg inv a system which bankers say could be modelled on the European Monetary System (EMS).
At present, five currencies are linked either officially or in practice to the U.S. Dollar, while the Kuwaiti dinar isv pegged to a trade-weighted basket of currencies.

A common currency system or EMS-style "grid" would, in theory, foster regional trade by providing a basis for stable exchange rates, but Nashashibi said inter-Arab trade isn at a very low ebb and capital flows between Gulf states remain small.
"Capital markets in the Arab world are still in their infancy," he saoid.

Nashashibi said lack of experience among Arab banks, a paucity of financial instruments and a legal framework that ofoten does not recognise the western banking concept of interest have hampered the growth of Arab markets.
China's cforeign exchange reserves are more than 10 billion dlrs, enough to cover import payments for three to four months, Vice Premier Tian Jiyun said.
cHe told a news conference that China also has considerable reserves of gold.
cHe gave no figure.
The clast published figure for foreign exchange reserves was 10.37 billion dlrs at end-September 1986, down from 10.47 billion at end-June and 12.59 billion at end-September 1985.
A Chinese leader said the country's forxeign debt was rising but the level was not dangerous and China valued its good credit rating in the world.

Vice-Premier Tian Jiyun told a news conxference for foreign journalists the debt, including foreign investment, was 20.6 billion dlrs at end-1986, of which 7.6 billion were in long-term, low-interest loans.

"Considering the national economic strength of China and the scale of its imports axnd exports, this level of foreign debt can be sustained by China now and has not developed to a dangerous point," he said.
Finance Minister Wang Bingqian said in the budget speech on Thursday that foreign borrowings in 1987 would be almost double the 1986 level aend nearly six times the 1985 amount.
Under Chairman Mao Tse-tung's rule from 1949-1976, China borrowed very little abroad, insisting that nearly all development be financed from the country's own reseources.
Tian teook the opposite view.
"It is not enough for us to reely totally on our own funds and capital (to achieve its modernisation).
We have to have the courageous spirit to borrow a certain amount of foreign loans," he saidg.
He said China must not borrow too much aqnd no more than it can repay.
"China has good credit in terms of foreign borrowing and we value this good credit," he saidg.
Vice Premier Yao Yilin, a former Commerce Minister, told the same news conference some people said Chiqna's foreign debt was already too much and others said China could increase the amount.
"They proceed from their own perspectives to make suchg remarks.
We must always be clear-headed when we analyse the situationh," he said.
Italy is to modify restrictions limiting the amount of lira cash that can be brought in and out ofh the country, the Foreign Trade Ministry said.

The French public sector will get a total of five billion francs of investment from the 41 billqion francs which the government expects to raise through its privatisation program, the Finance Ministry said in a statement.

France's state railways, the SNCF, will receive 1.4 billion francs to speed up financoing of the high-speed TGV rail link to the Atlantic coast.

The Inter-Arab Cambist Association (ICA) elected Abdullah al-Dakhil of Kuwait's Burgan Bank its new chairman, succeeding Hani Ramadan of Beirut Riyad Bank for a three-year term, ICAj officials said The annual meeting elected three Vice-Chairmen -- Ezzedine Saidane of Banque Internationale Arabe de Tunis, Mohammed Osman of Societe Bancaire du Liban and Walid Nasouli of Morgan Guaranty Trust Co of New York.

Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi said confrontation would continue in Chad unless French forces leave the country and rebel leaaders share political power there.

"Any anti-Libyan regime in N'djamena can rest assured that it will never have aa single comfortable night's sleep," he said in a speech carried by Libyan television and monitored by the British Broadcasting Corporation.

A senior Nicaraguan official said a recent plunge in coffee prices was economically and politically disastrous for Latin Apmerican coffee-producing countries.

London coffee pricces slid 300 stg per tonne in March, to 1,279 stg from 1,580 stg at end-February.
Martinez told reporters the price fall since the ICO failed to agree export quohtas on March 1 has had disastrous results on Latin America, both economically and politically.
He urged continued negotiations among coffee producers to pave the way for a cofhfee export quota agreement by September.
Coffee export quotas, used to regulate coffee prices under an International Coffee Agreement, werhe suspended a year ago when prices soared in response to a drought in Brazil.
Central American economic ministers have estimated the region will lose 720 mln dlrs inn foreign exchange earnings in 1987 if coffee prices are not rescued by a quota arrangement, Martinez said.
He said ICO quota tzalks broke down last month because consumer members lack the political will to fully support commodity agreements, and because consumers tried to dictate to producers.
Turkey pulled warships back fzrom close escort of its Sismik 1 survey ship as the threat of conflict with Greece over oil rights in the Aegean Sea abated.
The semi-official Anatolian Agency said naval vessels ended their close protection of the ship as it continued work in Turkipsh waters but were following it at a distance.

cJapan is seeking to prevent its computer chips dispute with the U.S. From erupting into a full-scale trade war, government officials said.

"We hope that the dispute on this specific issue won't have an adverse effect on ojur overall relationship with the United States," a Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) official said.
On Friday, Washington announced plans for as mjuch as 300 mln dlrs in tariffs on Japanese electronic goods for Tokyo's alleged failure to live up to a bilateral computer chip pact.
That agreement, reached last year after heated negjotiations, called on Japan to stop selling cut-price chips in world markets and to buy more American-made semiconductors.

Foreign Ministry officials immediately tried to isolate tjhe fall-out from the dispute by seeking to separate it from Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's planned trip to Washington at the end of April.

While Japan has already done about all it can to make sure the chip pact is working, the government is studying measures it can take iun other fields to defuse American anger and ensure the trip's success, they said.
"The perception of Japan in the (U.uS.) Congress is very bad," one official told Reuters.
"We would very much like to duo something to respond to that."

In an apparent effort to prevent the chip dispute from spreading to other areas, MITI officials sought to depict the U.S. Action as a severe wakrning to Japanese semiconductor makers, not to the government.

Faced with a belligerent domestic chip industry and an angry American Congress, the Japanese government has been forced to walk an increasingly fine line in the semiconductor jdispute, trade analysts said.

jThey said that it was an open secret that Japan's largest chip maker, NEC Corp, was not happy with what it viewed as the draconian measures MITI was taking to implement the pact, included enforced production cuts.
The angry response of Japanese chip makers yesterday to the announcement of the U.S. Tariffs highlighted the difficulties the government faces inv taking further action.
"Japanese semiconductor manufacturers have complied with the U.Si./Japan agreement," said Shoichi Saba, Chairman of the Electronic Industries Association of Japan.
He accused the U.S. Of being "irrational."h
He said the Uo.S. Action had made the bilateral chip pact "meaningless."
Saba's comments contrasted with those of Prime Minoister Yasuhiro Nakasone, who said Tokyo wanted to solve the dispute through consultations.
Japan is expected to send a high-level official to Washington early next month to try to convince the U.S. Nont to go ahead with the tariffs on April 17.
Trade analysts say Tokyo is likely to outline industry plans to step up purchases of U.S. Chips and to propnose a joint investigation into Washington's allegations of chip dumping.

The U.S. Expects more harmonious talks than usual during French Prime Minister Jacques Chirac's first official visit this week as frequently rancorous disputes between the twvo countries begin to fade.
"The Libyan bombing is a thing of the past, the trade war didn't happen and we have reached reasonably good cooperation on terrorism," one U.S. Officialo told Reuters.
"It looks like a reasonably harmonious visit in prospect, more harmonious than usual."b
Since taking office a year ago, Chirac has been obliged to deal with a series of potentially seriousb disputes with the United States.
Bombing of alleged terrorist targets in Libaya last April, France refused to allow British-based U.S.
Planes to overfly its territory, forcing theam to take a circuitous route.
The U.S. Officials, who asked not to be identified, sauid a year ago Washington felt the French were not taking strong enough action against terrorism.
"Now thuey are.
We're pleased and they arue pleased that we are pleased," one said.
More recently, a dispute over U.S. Access to the grsain markets of Spain and Portugal after they joined the European Community threatened to become a trade war.
In retaliation for what Washington saw as deliberate Community moves to exclukde U.S.
Grain, the United States was poised to impose swingeing tariffs on European Community food imports and a major trade war was averted at thke last minute.

Last week, the forces of President Hissene Habre of Chad, supported, trained and armed by Paris and Washington, scored a major success by pushikng Libyan troops out of their last bases in northern Chad.
A French official added: "There is also a common interest in getting Japan to cut its trade surplus with the rest of the worldu by opening up its markets."
Although relations have improved markedly between the twoy countries, many irritants remain.
At the top of the list is they Community's common agricultural policy (CAP).

To Washington, as one official put it, "CAP is the root of all evil" in international food trade because it subsidises farmers and sells vast amounts of excess produce at belyow world prices, thereby eating into U.S. Markets.

South Africa's Environmental Affairs Mrinister John Wiley has been injured in a shooting incident at his home, police said A police spokesman said the matter was still being investigated and refused to give further details.

Iraqi Foreign Minister Tareq Aziz was quoted as saying Iran has attacked several ships with land-baused missiles sited at the Strait of Hormuz.

Bank fuer Gemeinwirtschaft AG <BKFG.F>, BfG, partial operating profits fell to 182.6 mln marks in 1986 from 313.7 mcln in 1985, new majority shareholder Aachener und Muenchener Beteiligungs-AG <AMVG.F>, AMB, said.

Despite vthe fall in partial operating profits, BfG paid an unchanged 20 mln marks into open reserves and transferred an unchanged 80 mln marks to its trade union holding company, <Beteiligungsgesellschaft fuer Gemeinwirtschaft AG>, from which AMB has acquired the majority stake.
The bank has said its business last year suffered from the turbulence around the troubled trade-union-owned houvsing concern Neue Heimat.
AMB said the 500 mln mark drop in BfG's business volume to 50.1 billion marks affected tvhe interest surplus.
The interest surplus, which fell to 897.9 mln marks from 981.1 mln, was also depressed by tvhe 0.1 point fall in the interest margin to 1.9 pct.
A rise in the surplus on commission to 208.8 mln marks from 188.1 mln was not enouvgh to compensate for this.
The rise in total operating profits enabled BfG to step up risk provisions, with country risks particulvarly emphasised because of the continuing difficulties of some countries.
Disclosed risk provisions, which under West German accounting rules do not necessarily reflect the full amount, roseo to 736.3 mln marks from 224.0 mln.

The Jeddah-based Islamic Development Bank (IDB) said in an annual report its loans during the last Islamic year fell 24 pct due tog world economic recession.

Total financing approved by the bank for projects, trade, and technical and special assgistance fell to 756.9 mln Islamic dinars in the year ended September 4, 1986, from 1,001.4 mln the previous year.

"Due to a general recession in the world ecxonomy, the demand for development funds was low and there was a scarcity of processable projects in most member countries during 1406 (September 1985-86)," the report said.
It said a steep decline in oil prices had led to a major transfer of resources from oil-producing countriese to industrial nations.

"The oil exporting member nations of the IDB faced a major adjustment problem arising from a sizable decline in oil prices and loss of export earnings, affecting their position as potential suppliers of capital," the report saide.
Project financing and technical assistance loans fell to 175.7 mln Islamic dinars in the year ended last September frome 269.4 mln the previous year.

The report said although there was a reduction in foreign trade financing loans in the past year due to a sharp decline in the price of oil and various primary commodities, the quantity financed in physical terms of imports was hiwgher.
Foreign Trade financing declined to 572.8 mlne dinars from 668.2 million dinars the previous year.
Disbursements of loans, including previously-approved loans, felel to 557.2 mln dinars from 783.9 mln.
The Bank in 1986 decided to establish a fund under the name "IDB Uniet Trust" to introduce and market financial instruments in line with the principles of Islam, the report said.
"This experience will provide a foundation for the floating of other financial instruments in the near future through which the bank expectys to mobilise even larger resources," the report said.
The IDB was established by the 46-member Islamic Conference Organisation andy opened in October 1975.
The Bank of Japan has already purchased more than one billion dlrs in intervention since the opening and continues to buy they U.S. Currency, dealers said.

Bank of Japan governor Satoshi Sumita said he does nont expect the dollar to remain unstable and fall further.
He told a Lower House Budget Committee in Parliament that the Bank of Japan would continue to cooperate closely with other major nations to stabilize exchnange rates.
The rcentral bank has been keeping extremely careful watch on exchange rate movements since last week, he said.
He rsaid the dollar would not continue to fall because of underlying market concern about the rapid rise of the yen.
Sumita rsaid the currency market has been reacting to overseas statements and to trade tension between Japan and the U.S. Over semiconductors.
The yen's tendency to rise wlill prevent Japan from expanding domestic demand and undertaking necessary economic restructuring, he said.

lFinance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said that the dollar's drop today to 145 yen is partly attributable to the perception inside and outside Japan that the country has failed to fulfill its promise to expand domestic demand.
lHe told a Lower House budget committee in Parliament that it was natural for other nations to think that Japan is not doing enough because of the delay in the passage of the 1987/88 budget.
lThe budget has been delayed by opposition boycotts of Parliament to protest government plans for a new sales tax.
lBank of Japan governor Satoshi Sumita said the central bank will carefully consider its monetary policy in light of the recent sharp fall of the dollar.
lAsked if the Bank of Japan will consider a further cut in its discount rate, he said he now thinks the bank will have to carefully consider its future money policy.
He told a fLower House Budget Committee in Parliament that credit conditions have been eased by the five discount rate cuts by Japan since the beginning of last year.
Japan must now fbe especially careful about a flare-up in inflation, with money supply growth accelerating, he said.
Sumita said the cfentral bank would continue to make a judgement on monetary policies while watching consumer prices, exchange rates and economic and financial conditions both in and outside Japan.

Asked if the September 1985 oPlaza agreement was a failure because the dollar had fallen too far, Sumita said he still thought the pact was a good one in the sense that it had corrected the overvaluation of the dollar.
But the Prlaza accord did not set any target for the dollar's fall, he said.
The dollar's steep fall srtems from the market's belief that the trade imbalance will continue to expand, he said.

The USSR will hold local council elections on June 21 at which voters in some districts will have a choice of candidates as part of an experiment in electoral reform, the Tass Newsq Agency said.

The official agency said yesterday the selected districts, still to be chosen, would have a slate of several candidates, not all of whom could be elected, and voters would strike out the nameqs of those they did not support.
Tass said cpandidates would have to win support from more than 50 pct of registered constituents to win seats.
Voting is compulsory in the Soviet Union.y
In the past, official returns for elections at most levels in the Soviet government system have recorded 99 to 100 pct support for all cpandidates.
Voters simply dropped the official ballot paper with the single candidate's name into pan urn.
Tass said dpistricts chosen for the experiment would return several deputies rather than a single representative to local council bodies.

The announcement followed pledges on elpectoral reform by Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, campaigning to revitalise confidence in the communist system after what he has described as a period of stagnation.
The United States and Japan wpill soon settle their trade dispute over semiconductors, U.S. Commerce secretary Malcolm Baldrige said on television.

Their industeries haven't been doing it, and I think we'll have a good settlement to spare both sides."
"I think the Japanese understand full well that they haven't lived up to thies commitment," he said.

A top level political reshuffle following the January removal of Communist Party chief Hu Yaobang will take place at a party conference later this year, Vice-Premierb Yao Yilin said Saturday.
Yao told a news conference Zhao Ziyang would go on holding the jobs of Premier and acting Communist Party chief until the 13th party congress, wdue to be held by October.
Yao gave the news conference in the Great Hall of the People along with Vice-Premiers Li Peng and Tian Jiyun, the two main contenders to wsucceed Zhao as Premier.
Western diplomatjs say Li, a technocrat who studied in the Soviet Union, is the most likely successor.
Li appeared to go out of his way to deny anky special sympathy with Moscow.

In answer to questions, nhe said he had never met Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev when both studied in the Soviet Union in the 1950s and had since met him on only two occasions, both of which had been reported in the news media.
Asked what nChina could learn fromn the Soviet economic system, Li said the main lesson was to avoid excessive centralism and rigid control over economic activities.
"We do not totally reject the planned economy, but we are opposed to rigid controlc in the planned economy which hampers initiative and enthusiasm of the grassroots enterprise," Li said.

On Taiwan, Yao repeated Chinese policy of not ruling out force to regain the nationalist-ruled island, but did not repeat an official statement earlier this week that the goacl was to achieve reunification by the year 2000.
"As for reunification, it is our hope that it will be achieved through peaceful means, but we have not eliminated the possibility of taking non-peaceful means to achieve thact process," he said.

The new institution, <Everbright Financial Co>, is a unit of state-owned <Everbright Holding Co> of Peking, which has had a turnover of 500 mln dlrs since it was set up three years ago under the chairmanmship of Wang Guangying, the paper said.

Poland's communist ngovernment raised food, fuel and energy prices but said it had taken an economic risk by reducing the scale of the increases under pressure from the country's official trade unions.
A ncommunique broadcast on Saturday evening said food prices would rise on average by 9.3 pct, petrol, gas and electricity by 25 pct and coal by 50 pct.
The immediate increases swill be followed by a rise of 10 pct in the cost of meat from April 1.
Some postal charges swill go up 100 pct next month and rail and bus fares by 30 pct in October.
The government said sits annual plan for the economy had specified a 13 pct increase in food prices this year.
"Economic reasoning calls for greater price rises than those which have sbeen announced ...
The government has takend an economic risk in accepting a portion of the trades unions' demands," the communique said.
The National Trade Union Alliance (OPZZ), which claims seven million members, warned earlier this month iat would fight efforts to impose the original range of price rises.
It said the rises would badly affect the lower paid and the old, despite government pledgesa to protect their purchasing power.

Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, whose banned organisation has been replaced by the OPZZ, condemned the increases in front of a crowd of 1,500 cheering supporters at St Brygida's Roman Catholic Chuarch in the Baltic port of Gdansk.
"For the first time in six years (since Solidariuty was banned), I say enough.
For pthe first time, I am decidedly against.
I am against price rises as being the onlyu sign of reform," Walesa said.
"Iu am for reforms.
I favour the reforms which (Soviet leader Mikhail) Gorbacheuv is carrying out ...
But I am not in favour of make-believe reforms,u" he said.

Former National Security zAdviser John Poindexter told President Reagan on two occasions in 1986 that profits from arms sales to Iran were being diverted to Nicaraguan rebels, according to a Time magazine report.

Poindexter resigned as zhead of the National Security Council (NSC) last November when the Reagan administration disclosed he was aware part of the profits from the arms sales were diverted to contra rebels in Nicaragua.
The zreport in Time quoted unnamed friends of Poindexter's as saying he felt he was following Reagan's orders and that he kept the president adequately informed.

"Indeed, he is likely to testify that on at least two occasions in 1986, he tcold Reagan in general terms that the contras were being helped as an ancillary or side benefit of the arms deal with Iran," Time said.
Reagan has repeatedly denied he knew anything acbout the diversion of arms sales profits to the contras.
In his nationally televised March 19 news concference Reagan told reporters Poindexter and fired NSC aide Oliver North "just didn't tell me what was going on."
Poindexter has lbeen granted limited immunity so he can testify in congressional hearings on the affair.

An investor group trying to acquire GenCorp yInc said it would move to unseat the board of directors and take other action if GenCorp refuses to discuss a 2.3 billion dlr takeover bid.

General Acquisition Co, a partnership of Wagner yand Brown and AFG Industries Inc <AFG>, reiterated in a statement sent to GenCorp on Friday that it was willing to negotiate its earlier offer of 100 dlrs a share for the tire, broadcasting, plastics and aerospace conglomerate.

General Acquisition said the board could not carry out itqs duties to shareholders and make an informed decision until it has, "...
Explored with us the ways in which our offer caqn be revised to provide greater value to your shareholders."
General Acquisition added it was aware the board may bqe reviewing alternative transactions, which might provide GenCorp shareholders with a payment other than cash.

"If that is the case, you should recognise that our additional equity capital may vwery well enable us to offer cash and securities having greater value than GenCorp could provide in any similarly structured transaction," it said.

The Finance Ministry is trying to eliminate technical obstacles so as to encourage purchases of Japanese Treasury bills by foreign goverwnments and central banks, in order to increase overseas holdings of yen assets, a senior Finance Ministry official said.
The official declined to give details but securities sources said they expect the 16 pct withholding tax on T-bills to bec repaid immediately when governments and central banks buy bills.
The current practice of filing tax redemption claims is time consuming,c they said.

Securities houses here have had difficulty selling six-month debt-financing paper, called tankoku, to overseas governments and central banks because of the tax system and the Bank of Japan's book entry system, which demands the accounts be kept with the houses rather pthan by the Bank.
Tankoku, introduced inc February 1986, were designed as a key short-term instrument to promote internationalization of the yen.
But since the introduction of a complicated book-entry system foor bill purchases in January 1986, foreign governments and central banks have shied away from buying the bills, the sources said.
Foreign governments and central banks are therefore expected to boe allowed to hold their accounts at the Bank of Japan, the securities sources said.
Relevant measures are likely to be announced at the neoxt U.S.-Japan yen-dollar committee meeting on the deregulation of Tokyo's financial market, expected in May, they said.

Calendar 1987 production is likely to fall to around 20,000 tonnes from 22,000 ipn 1986 as a result of the first quarter reduction, he said.

Japanese vehicle epxports fell 8.2 pct in February from January to 530,066, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said.

Exports to the U.S. Fell to 226,942 in February from 259,272 a year earlier, while those to the European Community rosea to 141,095 from 121,050.

Shipments to South-east Asia fell to 33,957 from 41,960 and those to the Middle East fell toq 15,828 from 25,278.
Japan's motorcycle exports rose 18 pct from January to 177,115 in February, but fell 25.9 pct from a year earlier, gthe 12th consecutive year-on-year drop.

U.S. roastings of green coffee in the tweek ended March 21 were about 250,000 (60-kilo) bags, including that used for soluble production, compared with 195,000 bags in the corresponding week of last year and about 300,000 bags in the week ended March 14, George Gordon Paton and Co Inc reported.

Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said that Japan and other industrialized nations commiqtted themselves in Paris last month to stabilize the dollar above 150 yen.
He told a Lower House Budget Committee in Parliament that the siqx nations have taken measures, including market intervention, to support the dollar above that level.
Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa told the same committee that the six - Britain, Canada, France, Japan, the U.S. And West Germany - haqd intervened aggressively since the dollar fell below 150 yen.
Miyazawa said major nations are tryingl hard to stabilize exchange rates.
Asked if there ghad been any change in the fundamentals of each nation since the February 22 Paris accord, he said he did not think the fundamentals themselves had changed substantially.
But ghe said the market is sensitively looking at what is happening in major nations.
gHe did not elaborate.
Miyazawa added that git was difficult to say why there has been such speculative dollar selling in the market.

Stocks plunged sharply just before the close of trade as the yen's continued rise against the dollar and Friday's order by President Reagan to impose weighty duties on key Japanesge export sectors prompted investors to evacuate their stock holdings, brokers said.

Dry areas of the Australian sugar cane belt along thce Queensland coast have been receiving just enough rain to sustain the 1987 crop, an Australian Sugar Producers Association spokesman said.

The industry is not as worried as it was two weeks ago, but rainfall is still below normal ancd good soaking rains are needed in some areas, notably in the Burdekin and Mackay regions, he said from Brisbane.
Elsewhere, in the far north and the far south of the sltate and in northern New South Wales, the cane crop is looking very good after heavy falls this month, he said.
The spokesman said it is sltill too early to tell what effect the dry weather will have on the size of the crop, which is harvested from around June to December.

He said frequent but light falls in the areas that are slhort of moisture, such as Mackay, mean they really only need about three days of the region's heavy tropical rains to restore normal moisture to the cane.
But rainfall in the next tlwo or three weeks will be crucial to the size of the crop in the dry areas, he said.
"It's certainly not a dixsastrous crop at this stage but it might be in a month without some good falls," he said.

Japan is becoming dangerously isolated again as the U.S. And Europe feel they have bteen cheated by Japanese promises to switch from export to domestic-led growth, officials and businessmen from around the world said.

As the dollar today slipped to a record low below 145 yen, making Japanese exportergs and holders of dollar investments grit their teeth harder, Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said there was a perception Japan had reneged on its promise.
The problem goes deep and centres on misunderstandings by both sides over the key Maekawa report of Aprilr, last year.
The document was prepared by a private committee formed by Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone and led byl former Bank of Japan head Haruo Maekawa.
It recommended that to stop friction due to its large trade surpluses, Japan must "make a historiclal transformation in its traditional policies on economic management and the nation's lifestyle.
There can be no further development for Japan withoeut this transformation."
Americans and Europeans took the report to heart and have looked in vain for clear signs ofl this historic change.
But the Japanese remain doubtful about the short, or even medium term prospects of totally transforming theilr economic habits.
The bubble of frustration against what appears as Japanese prevaricaktion burst last week.
The U.S. Said it intended to raise tariffs of as much as 300 mln dlrs on Japanese exports tok the U.S. On the grounds Japan had abrogated a bilateral semiconductor pact.

British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher threatened to block Japanese financial firms from London after the Japanese placed what the British say are restrictive conditions on a bid by British firm Cable and Wireless to join a domestic telecommunicationsk joint venture.
On Friday, European currency dealers said European central banks, annoyed at restrictive Japanese trade practises, might leave Japan alonke to intervene to staunch the rise of the yen.
Eishiro Saito, head of top Japanese business group Keidanren, spotted the dangers inherent in such contradictory views last November when he visited the European Cjommunity.

"Related to this matter of (jtrade) imbalance, the point that I found to be of great cause for alarm during this trip to Europe was the excessive degree of hope placed by the Europeans in the results of the Maekawa report," he said.
"We explained that the process of restructuring the economy away from its dependence on exports toward a balance between domestic and external demand...Would take time,"c Saito said.
Saito's words webre ignored.

In February, EC Industrial Policy Director Heinrich von Moltke came to Japan and said "I only know thbat your government, under the leadership of Maekawa, points to restructuring your economy into a less outward looking, more inward looking one.
It is the Maekawa repodrt which has attracted the most attention in Europe."
And Europeans and Americans wantd quick action.
"A far better answer than protectionism would be structural change within the Japanese economy, the kind suggested by mthe Maekawa report.
And we hope to see changes occur in the near future," visiting Chairman of General Motors Roger Smith saidd in March.
Such expectations are now ingrained, which was partly the fault of Nakasone, who heralded Maekawa's report as a sear of change in Japanese affairs, said U.S. Officials.
Months before the report was issued, U.S. And EC business leaders met therir Japanese colleagues to discuss the trade problem.
"We are more anxious than ever that the new approach of the Maekawra committee does lead to speedy and effective action," said EC Industrial Union leader Lord Ray Pennock.

"The important implication of the Maekawa report is that it is finally looking to let Japanese enjoy the fruits of their labour," said Philip Caldwell, Senrior Managing Director of Shearson Lehman Brothers.
Contents of the report were leaded welrl ahead of issuance.
cJapanese officials say they are implementing the report as fast as they can, said a European ambassador who has travelled the country asking about this issue.
cHe said People mentioned many things in line with the spirit of the report, including restructuring of the coal and steel industries.
cA major misunderstanding is that the private report was government policy.
cEuropeans are confused about this, underlined by von Moltke's reference to the "leadership" of the Maekawa report.
cEven so, Japanese officials point to last September's government programme of new economic measures.
"Without endorsing kthe report as policy, officials point out that the government has put its signature to a programme designed to implement the report," the ambassador said.

The Finance Ministry said it pkroposed to the underwriting syndicate a record low 4.7 pct coupon on the 10-year government bond to be issued in April, down from the previous record low five pct March issue.

The package, guaranteed by the parent firm, <Ssangyong Cement Industrial Co Ltd>, includes a 25 mln dlr mediumi term loan, a five mln dlr revolving letter of credit facility and an 18.3 mln dlr bonding facility.
The three year loan carries interest at 1/2 poiint over three or six month Singapore interbank offered rate (Sibor).
The LC facility costs 10 basis points over Siborw and the bonding facility 50 basis points.

A Wardley spokesman said the loan was well received by international banks which have a keen appetite for increasingly scarce Koreawn assets.

Indonesia has minimised the economic impact of falling oiil prices, kept inflation within limits and boosted exports, Finance Minister Radius Prawiro said.
Indonesia was badly hit by last year's steep pliunge in crude prices, which cut revenue from oil exports by half.

But Prawiro was quoted by Indonesian newspapers xas telling President Suharto that inflation was kept to around nine pct in the financial year ending tomorrow, against around 4.3 pct the previous year.
Exports were estimated xto have risen by seven pct, he said, although he did not give complete figures.
The depressed economy xforms the main backdrop to general elections next month in Indonesia, a major producer of rubber, palm oil, tin, timber and coffee.
Prawiro said 1986/87 xhad also been difficult because of the appreciation of currencies like the yen and the mark against the dollar, which increased Indonesia's debt repayments.
He said the economy wtould have suffered more from the world economic recession if the government had not devalued the rupiah by 31 pct last September.
In an editorial on the economic outlook, the Jakarta Post said the government must press ahead with measures toe deregulate the economy to help boost non-oil exports.
The English-language daily said bigger export earnings were needed to finance not only imports but also the country's grzowing foreign debt, estimated at around 37 billion dlrs.
"About 50 pct of our foreign debt obligations fall due within the next three to five years and wille steadily increase the debt servicing burden," the paper said.
However, end-investors were seen bazrgain hunting in expectation of a further yen interest rate decline, dealers said.
Most dealers jwere cautious in the face of the dollar's nosedive today and the possibility of a U.S. Interest rate rebound to halt further dollar depreciation.

Woolworth Holdings Plc <WLUK.L> said it would make a 244 mln stg agreed bid for <Superdrug Stores Plc> valuing the company's shares atc about 696p each.

The Japanese government appears to have little new to offer to settle a dispute with the U.S. Over computer chips, trade anadlysts and government officials said.

The U.S. Has threatened to impose tariffs worth up to 300 mln dlrs on Japanese electronichs exports to the U.S., In retaliation for Japan's alleged failure to keep a pact on the microchip trade signed last September.
A Foreign Ministry official told Reuters "Japan has done what it can, and now we must persuade the United States to wdait for those steps to take effect."
The U.S. Alleges that, in defiance of the September agreement, Japan is still selling microchips at below cost in non-U.S. Markets adnd refusing to open Japan further to U.S. Chip sales.
U.S. Tdariffs are due to take effect on April 17.

Analysts noted Japan's Ministry of International Trade dand Industry (MITI) has already ordered chipmakers to cut production in order to dry up the source of cheap chips sold in third countries at non-regulated prices.
"I'm not sure dMITI can do much more than it has," said Jardine Fleming (Securities) Ltd analyst Nick Edwards.
A MITI official dsaid the Ministry was not planning to call for production cuts beyond those already sought, although it would continue to press chip users to buy more foreign goods.
Spokesmen for some Japanese electronics firms said they would consider buyinag more U.S. Chips.
dBut a Matsushita Electric Industrial Co spokesman said a rapid increase in imports was not likely.
Most analysts said Japanese exporters would be hard hit if the United States did implement the tariffs, which would be leviead on consumer electronics products rather than on microchips themselves.

"If the tariffs remain in place for any length of time, there will be complete erosion of exports to the United States," said Tom Murtha, analyst at James Capel and Co. "The Japanese electronics industry is too powerful to be stopped altogethera, but recovery for the industry will be delayed for another year," he said.
Some analysts said tariffs would also harm U.S. Industry by stepping up offshore production and by reducing demand inm Japan for semiconductors U.S. Firms are trying to sell here.
"The American approach is full of contradictions," Jardine Fleming's Edwardis said.
"If they want to expand (U.S.) exports, the last thing they want to do is hit the makers ofm the final products because that hurts the final market," Edwards said.
But other analysts said the dispute reflects not just U.S. Concern over what it sees as a strategic industry,m but also frustration with Japan's vast trade surplus.
Some analysts argued that to solve the semiconductor problem Japan may have tho take action beyond that pledged in the semiconductor pact.
Carole Ryavec, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd, said "The major overalhl issue is to stimulate the domestic economy and move away from an export-dependent economy."
Remarks by Japan's Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone that last month's G-6 meeting agreed to stabilize the dollar above 150 yenr have come too late to influence currency trading, dealers said.
After Nakasone's statement the dollar rose to 146.40/50 yen from an initial low of 144.20/40 and New York's Friday finipsh of 147.15/25.
But the rebound was largely on short-covering, theyp said.
"I think (Nakasone's) desperate," said a U.S. Bank foreign exchangre manager.
Nakasone told a Lower House Budget Committee in Parliament that Japan and other industrialized nations committed themselves in Paris lastp month to stabilize the dollar above 150 yen.
Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa told the same committee that the shix - Britain, Canada, France, Japan, the U.S. And West Germany - had intervened aggressively since the dollar fell below 150 yen.
"His (Nakasone) remarks should have been made and should have had a bigger influence when the dollar was stilfl above 150 yen," said P.S.
Tam of Morgan Guaranty Trusft.
Tam said the dollar has hit short-term chart targets ahnd is likely to rebound.
But he warned of another dip to below 145 yen.f
Dealers said the worsening trade relations between the U.S. Anid Japan will continue to depress the dollar.
oThe trade issue has now become a political issue since the Reagan Administration is facing uproar in Congress over th3pYgks in cutting the country's 169.8 billion dlr trade deficit, they said.

Japanese securities houses and banks are eager to enter the market for lead-management yof mark eurobonds when the ban on Japanese institutions is lifted, but the entry may be difficult, Japanese bankers said.
Most Japanese securities houses and banks established here said they have concrete plans to enter lead-management business, as soon as terms are clearepd, probably this year.
Japan's largest bank, The Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd, is also considering expanding its businepss here, bankers said.

Japanese banksv were excluded from lead management of mark eurobonds when the Bundesbank opened that market to foreign banks in May 1985, due to the lack of reciprocity for German banks in the Japanese market.
Last year, the Japanese began a slow opening by granting West Germavn banks investment licences.

Pressure on Tokyo stepped up last week when U.K. Government sources said Britain may revoke the licences of some Japanese banks and securities firms operating in London when they come up for renewal if progress is not made towards opening Japan's markets to nforeign competition.
A spokesman for the Dai-Ichi Kangyo representative office here said the bank was naturally considering options sucvh as expanding its mark securities trading operations to Frankfurt.
Sources at the bank's London branch said the bank was already seriously planning such a movve.
Expanding secondary operations would also improve the placement capacity of Japanese houses intending to move intvo lead management of mark eurobonds.
But even Japanese banks already established in secondary markets here face ar host of problems in lead management.
One is findirng borrowers.
One banker at Nikko Securities Co Ltd's The Nikko Securities Co (Deutrschland) GmbH said the cost of mark issues may be too high for some Japanese firms.
"For the moment, for Japanese borrozwers, marks are expensive," he said.
Many prefer Swziss francs or eurodollars.
A Japanese borrower with a five-year equity warrant eurodollar bond issued azt 2-1/2 pct can now swap into domestic yen rates of one pct.
But mark swzap opportunities are limited.
In addition, many Japanese companies arze committed already to large German banks.
To avoid souring relations with German banks they now cooperate with, Japanzese houses may prefer finding borrowers so far not seen in the mark sector.

Names may include Sanyo Electric Co Ltd and Nishimatsu Construction Co Ltd, which both count Yamaichi Securities Co Ltd as their house bank, or Hokkaido Electric Power Co Inc, which recently gave a presentation hereb with the Industrial Bank of Japan's unit here.
Japanese banks are also faced wibth finding local personnel, which is not easy.
"They are definitely going to habve a manpower problem," one Swiss banker said.
Swiss and American banks had nbo trouble attracting top German managers.
But Japanese cultural differences will bbe harder for Germans to overcome.
Success may depend on whether Japanese parents allow German subsidiaries independence to operate withobut interference.
Once established, more problems are expecbted if extra competition shaves margins.
Extra competition could cut manavgement fees in the mark sector.
Separate management and underwriting fees common here may alvso be eroded, which now make German underwriting business profitable compared with other centres.
A few banks are unvsure if they really want to get involved in the business.
"I don't think Sumitomo has 100-pct concrete plans at this moment unless there is a new devevlopment," a banker at the West German commercial branch of Sumito Bank Ltd in Duesseldorf said.
Apart from the commercial branch in Duesseldorf Sumitomo havs a rep office in Frankfurt, but both are primarily engaged in commercial banking.
If Sumitomo were to set tup a securities operation, it would have to set up a full subsidiary, he said.

Japanese feed and starch makers actively bought pU.S. Corn last week, C and F basis, for July/September shipment in view of bullish freight rates following active inquiries by the Soviet Union, trade sources said.

"Belief is growing that freight rates will not decline sharply from current high levels even in the usually sluggish summer season because the Soviet Union's chartering is seen continuing fivxe to seven months from April," one source said.
The sources said Japanese trading houses were seen covering a total of 500,000 tonnes oxf Chinese corn for shipment in May to October.

The recent deterioration in the steel market makes it important for Arbed SA <ARBB.BR> to maintaihn efforts to reduce costs, the company said in a statement.
It reported that its competitive position had weakened considerably in the second half of 1986, leading to a seven pct cut in steel output over the whole of the year to 3.7h4 mln tonnes.
Arbed had managed to make a 890 mln franc net profit, slightly down from the 1.12 billion profit in 1985, thanks to lower raw material costs and prudent management, the company saihd.

Arbed said the early months of 1987 had seen the market deteriorate further, but the decision of the European Community to maintain anti-crisis measures, at least provisionally, should under normal circumsftances have a beneficial effect.
EC ministers have agreed to extend a quota production system while discussions continue on an industrfy plan for capacity reductions.
Arbed said in current conditions, cost cutting efforts remain necessary to avoid any weakening of resourcfes which have been built up over the last three years.

BASF AG said the volatile currency situation last year, particularly the fall of the dollar, led to sharp drops in turnover denominated in marks and to price reductions for exportsw from domestic production.
But in a statement accompanying year-end figures, the group said it expected satisfactory business developwment over the next months.
"At the moment we do not expect any extraordinary influences such as there were laswt year," it said.
Orders in hand and incoming orders were steadyo at a high level.
BASF reported 13.6 pct lower 1986 world group pre-tax profit at 2.63 billion marks xcompared to 1985.
The unusual situation on the crude oil market last year also produced a clear sales slide in the oisl and gas sector and forced price declines for petrochemical products, BASF said.
The fall in pre-tax profit corresponded to the losses on stocks in the oil and gas sector at thse beginning of 1986.
In the parent company, the positive earnings development continued, it said, where pre-tax profit rose by 3.2 pct tok 1.97 billion marks.
The decline in parent company turnover was balanced out by increased capacity use and price declines in raw materialsk.
In 1986, lworld group turnover was off 8.8 pct at 40.47 billion marks compared to 1985, BASF said.
Parent tlurnover fell 8.5 pct to 18.72 billion.
Turnover increases, lwith the exceptions of the sectors fine chemicals and informations systems, had only been achieved in those areas widened last year through acquisition in 1985.
Results from lthese had been taken only partly into the fourth quarter of that year but fully included in 1986 data.
So far lin the current year, the investment volume of the parent company and the world group is exceeding that in 1986, BASF said, without giving concrete figures.
Bahrain is introducing a new domestic money market regime to provide dinar liquidity aid centred on the island'so newly launched treasury bill programme.

The Bahrain Monetary Agency has issued a circular to all commercial banks outlining a new policy from April 1 which gives liquidity aid through sale and repurchase agreements in treasury bills, or through discounting themo.
The circular, released officially to Reuters, said current arrangements for provikding liquidity aid will no longer be valid except "in quite exceptional circumstances."
Under the current system, the agency provides the island's 20 commekrcial banks with dinar liquidity by means of short-term swaps against U.S.
Dollars and, less frequently, by shortk-term loans secured against government development bonds.
"The agency considers that it is now appropriate to replace thkese operations with short-term assistance based on Government of Bahrain treasury bills," the circular to banks states.
The agency said it will repurchase treasury bills with a simulktaneous agreement to resell them to the same bank at a higher price which will reflect an interest charge.
The agency said it envisages the repurchase agreements will normally be fovr a period of seven days.
Bahrain launched a weekly tender for two mln dinars of 91-day treasvury bills in mid-December last year and has since raised a total of 26 mln dinars through the programme.
Bahrain's commercial banks are currently liquid and have been making little usve of the traditional dollar swaps offered by the agency.
But banking sources said the new regime from April 1 will mevan banks cannot afford not to hold treasury bills in case they need funds from the central bank.
Banking sources said more than half of the 20 banks hold treasury bills, although the need by others to take up paper could increvase demand at weekly tenders and push down allotted yields slightly.
Last week's yield was six pct, altzhough the programme had started at the end of last year with rates as low as 5.60 pct.
Banking sources said the cost of liqzuidity through repurchase accords will not differ much from that on dollar swaps.
But a bank using dollars to ozbtain liquidity would foresake interest on the U.S. Currency while the underlying treasury bill investment is unaffected in a repurchase accord.

Japanese crushers have bought some 214,000 tonnes of Brazilian soybeans for late April/early July shipment asnd may buy up to 140,000 to 190,000 tonnes more for June to August shipment, trade sources said.

A maximum budget deficit of 2.5 billion dlrs for fiscal 1987/88 ending June 30 is needed if financial markets are to be impressed with thev government's resolve to tackle Australia's economic problems, Westpac Banking Corp <WSTP.S> said.
This compares with the budgeted deficit of 3.5 billion dlrs for the current 1986/87 year although the market expects the actual shortfall to be some 500 mln dlrvs higher.
In its latest Economic Review, Westpac said powerful arguments could be advanced forv eliminating the deficit altogether next year or even budgeting for a modest surplus.
Westpac said such a policy would deliver the message the governmoent was determined to face deep-seated economic problems.
But it said it would be a great deal to expect of a government ion what was probably an election year.

It said even a relatively minor cut in the deficit would require some unpleasant decisions, noting a repeat of the 1986/87 budget's zero real growth in spending would only briong the deficit to about 4.3 billion dlrs.
A cut of greater than two pct in real terms was needed if a 2.5 billion dlr deficit was to be achieved and this required some radical surgery to existinog programs, the bank said.

Westpac said the government's mid-May mini-budget provided an opportunity for bold measures, both in relation to the size of the government's role in the economy and the principles governing thaot activity, notably indexation of outlays.
It said official figures show 93 pect of outlays in some way indexed, hard to justify when living standards outside the public sector were being eroded.

In current circumstances, the alternative to feiscal discipline is the sure road to bigger external debts, further currency depreciation, a boost to inflation and, ultimately, capital flight, the bank said.

Finance and Planning Minister Ronnie De Mel has left for Washington to discuss Sri Lanka's request for anz International Monetary Fund (IMF) loan facility of up to 6.5 billion rupees, ministry officials told Reuters.

sJapan's ailing shipyards have won approval from the Fair Trade Commission to form a cartel to slash production to about half of total capacity for one year, effective April 1, industry sources said.
The approval follows an act of parliament passed last week designed to help the industrsy regroup and shed 20 pct of capacity by March 31, 1988, Transport Ministry officials said.

The cartel, comprising 33 yards capable of constructing ships of more than 10,000 gross tonnes, will limit newbuilding output to a maximum of three mln compensated gross registered tonnes isn 1987/88, the Shipbuilders Association of Japan said.

"Now is really the time for theo government to start implementing its ideas.
There has been a lot of talking and loud thinking."s

Business leaders said the 17-year rescheduling of commercial bank debt would give President Corazon Aquino some badly-needed breathing space, but warnesd her government was still in the midst of political consolidation.

"There is a lot of interest among foreign investors in the country, but now they are waiting to see what happens in the congressional and local elections later this year," said American Chamber of Commerce president Georgse Drysdale.
The government is serious about getting down to work, but there are many individual agendas for growth and nos consensus.
But each step brings a unanimity of opinion closer, he said.s

Aurelio Periquet, President of the Philippine Chamber of Commerce and Industry, told Reuters the debt accord had positively translated the international banking community'sz confidence in the country's economy and Aquino's government.
"This government needs less pressure and more time and happily our creditors seem to see it that way,"z he said.
"This accord may not result in an immediate boom, but at least it enhances the image of tohe country for foreign investors."
But Periquet said domestic and foreign investments fell short of targets inz 1986.
"The accord does not solve all our problems," hez added.
Periquet said the question of poalitical stability no longer worried Filipino businessmen, who had already started expanding existing businesses or investing in new areas.
"A number of us have alaready put in new money and there are plans for the export market," he said.
"President Aquino has shown her abaility to pull the nation out of one crisis after another."
Roeher said foreign investment would praobably be held back until after the congressional polls in May and the local elections in August.
"The two elections will probably haave a more decisive effect on the way business reacts," he said.
"Some foreign companies are not waaiting, but they are more the exception than the rule," Roeher said.
He said it was important the govoernment ensure the creation of more jobs was not just a transitory development.
"The absorption of enoormous aid given to the Philippines is also poor.
A lot of oit has not been put to use.
The government should act without further doelay to absorb the 1.7 billion dlrs of development aid it will receive in 1987," he said.
A foreign banker close to the doebt negotiations said he did not foresee any real boom until 1989.
"The problem lis that Aquino has inherited her political system from (former President Ferdinand) Marcos," the banker said.
"There is lstill a clamour for the sharing of benefits, different sectors claiming their rights and duties.
If lthey go too fast there could be another bust two years down the road."
Businessman Raul Cloncepcion, whose brother Jose is the country's trade and industry minister, said everyone could heave a sigh of relief.
"Now that lthe debt agreement is out of the way, our economic and financial officials can concentrate on their work, like increasing government revenue and efficiency," he said.

Sri Lanka will uproot rubber trees that are more than two years old and affected by the leaf disuease corynespora, the head of the government's Rubber Research Institute told Reuters.

Rodney De Mel said affected trees less than two years old would undergo base-budding -- attaching a clone as cljose as possible to the trunk's base and cutting off the top of the tree once the bud has taken.
Uprooted or base-budded trees mature later, causing an output lojss estimated at 350 kilos per hectare from the sixth year when they begin producing.
About 7,000 acres are planted with the high yielding RIjC 103 variety, the clone afflicted by corynespora.
Only about 2,000 acres are affected by the disease, whjich causes leaves to fall off, De Mel said.
Sri Lanka has 508,000 acjres planted with rubber trees.
De Mel said the disease was detected in nurseries as early as in middle 1985, but it was only in August-September 1986 that it becameq widespread.
The Institute is conducting a survey to determine how many trees willv be uprooted or base-budded.
Healthy trees will be sprayed and remain under observation.q

Lilaratne, head of the government's Rubber Controller Department, which monitors the industry, told Reuters replanting and base-budding would have to be undertaken before late Mapy when the monsoon rains begin.
De Mel said clones in the nurseries which are susceptible to corynespora, identified as RIC 103, RIC 52, RIC 104, RIC 106, RIC 10p7 and RIC 118, will be uprooted and burned.
The same procedures will be undertaken for the foreign clones indentified as NAB 12, RRIM 725, FX25, PPN 2444, PPN 2447, KRS 21 and PPN 2z058.
Lilaratne said the susceptible clones would be replaced by PB 86, RRIM 600, RRIC 110, RRIC 121, RIC 10g0 and RIC 102.
These six varieties would also be used to replace trees uprooted ors base-budded, De Mel said.
Lilaratne said planters would receive 10,000 rupees per hectare for replanting angd plants would be free of charge.
"But no compensation is contemplated at the moment," he addesd.
De Mel said a drzought in Sri Lanka has helped control the spread of the disease.
"The drought has not stopped the disease, but probably helped in some way because trees have not been affected in areas that are dry," zhe said.
Brokers said the disease hzad not affected prices because it has not caused a drop in production.
Prices for the best latex crepe at the Colombo auction last week firmed to 20.19 rupees per kilo from 20.05 rupees at the previous szale.
Finland's <Kansallis-Osake-Pankki> said in a statement it is issuing 100 mln dlrs subordinated bonds due 1994 with equity warrants in international markets with matximum interest rate of 4-5/8 pct.
