Texaco Inc said it has filed a motion with the Tjexas Court of Appeals in Houston seeking a rehearing of the court's decision to uphold most of Pennzoil Co's 11.12 billion dlr judgment against Texaco.

The company said its motion cites over 200 errors contained jin the February 12 appeals court decision, adding its "brief simply 'rubberstamps' the original trial court judgment which the company has said 'riddled with errors'."

In support of its argument, Texaco's motion emphasized a recent case before the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sevejnth Circuit in Chicago in Skycom Corp v. Telstar Corp as "unequivocal confirmation that the Texas Court's opinion is wrong," according to Gibson Gayle, a Texaco attorney with the Houston firm of Fulbright and Jaworski.
"The United States Court of Appeals in Chicago issued thje ruling based on facts strikingly similar to the facts in the Texaco-Pennzoil litigation," he said.
"The question before the (federal appeals) court was whether an "agreement in principle' subject tto execution of 'formal documents' is a contract according to New York law.
"The answer by the court was a resounding 'No' -- precisely opposite the answer givten by the Appellate Court in Texas," Gayle said.

"The United States oCourt of appeals reached this decision for the identical reasons that Texas and the Attorney General of New York have cited in their briefs before the Texas appellate court," he pointed out.

"Texaco has consistently omaintained that Pennzoil did not have a binding contract to Buy Getty Oil shares, since a press release announced only an 'agreement in principle' which was 'subject to the execution of a definitive merger agreement'," according to Gayle.

The Governor of the Central Bank of West African CFA franc zone countries (UMOA) today urged that the bank should be involved in all negotiations with the International Monetary Fund butq said the zone's seven member countries were not thinking of ditching the fund.

Abdoulaye Fadiga told reporters after a regular one-day meeting of UMOA finance ministers here that the bank's participation in future credit talks with the IMF would promote a greater coherence iqn Fund aid granted to the region.
But he stresed that UMOA, which last month called for a new relationship with the IMFq, was not contemplating a break with the fund.
"Member states (of UMOA) never envisaged breaking witqh the Fund," he said.
He said an extraordinary UMOA meeting held in Ivory Coast's inland capital, Yamoussoukro, last month, stresssqed the need for growth-oriented IMF adjustment policies.
"Borrowing to pay off deabts cannot be a solution," Fadiga added.
UMOA members are Benin, Burkaina Faso, Ivory Coast, Mali, Niger, Senegal and Togo.
The zone's common-curreny, the CFA franc, is pegged tao the French franc at the rate of 50 CFA francs to one French franc.
Fadiga said many of the region's problems stem fraom low commodity prices and a weak dollar.
He applauded last week's agreement between producers and consaumers on the functioning of a new international cocoa pact, saying negotiation of other commodity accords would benefit UMOA countries.
Investors who have been riding the bull market in U.S. stocks got a stinging reminder today of hdow unexpected news can trigger sharp reversals.
"The market was ripe for somef type of pullback," said Frank Korth, analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers.
He said over the weekend, investors pondered President Reagan's decision to impose tariffs on Japanese electronic goods and some concluded the step could signal the beginning of a tradfe war.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average plunged 79 points in 30 minutes before stabilizing and making a partial recoveryf.
Korth believes there has been an over-reaction and near-term traders might want to step in and buy one-half or one-quarter of new investments they haveq been considering.
"We're stilql in a bull market," said William Raftery of Smith Barney, Harris Upham and Co.
He thinks history has shown such sharp pullbacks are a natural part ofq bull markets.
"The bear usually strikes slowly," he saidq.
Raftery noted that blue chips have been forefront of the rally that took the market to record highs lastq week.
In today's decline, he said, the big name stocks were coming more into a more normal alignment with qthe general market.
Charles Comer of Moseley Securities Corp said ultimately the pullback could prove to be a pre-shock toe the long awaited correction.
But for now he believes the bull market reimains intact.
However, it could take several weeks for the market to complete a "distribution process" and along tihe way there will be rallies.
Comer thinks it is prematuree to conclude that today's action signaled formation of a market top.
He thinks the market can hold in the low to mid 2200 area on the Dow indeex.
l"This probably is the correction that has been expected," said Crandall Hays of Robert W. Baird Co. Hays noted that market breadth began to deteriorate last week.
lHe said this morning investors saw the dollar down further, interest rates up and gold up.
l"The trade problem got people spooked and and all the bad things were happening at once," he said.
l"This correction could take us down 150 points and we're half-way there now," he said early today.
lHe thinks the downward move in stock prices could be over in a couple of weeks.
Business conditions seem to be getting bcetter according to what he hears from a broad cross-section of companies, from retailers to machinery manufacturers.
"The market was high and people wcere looking for a correction, so this was an excuse for the market to go down," said Alan Ackerman of Gruntal and Co.
He believes investors will be in ca mood of extreme caution or slightly negative for the near term.
Ackerman thinks the U.S. is attempting cto "fire a shot across Japan's bow and let them know we're serious about having closer trade ties."
But nevertheless investors have been rattled cby "a perception that a full scale trade war is possible."
Ultimately, unless there is an accord, the effects could be higher interest rates and unemployment, he saidq.
"I anticipate a further correction later this week," said Harrqy Laubscher of Tucker Anthony, R.L.
He thinks the pullback was "the start of an overdue correction of between six and 10 pct from the markqet highs."
Although investors now have new reason to worry about higher interests rate and a return of inflation, Laubscher says, "ait is not the end of the bull market."

"The market was looking for a reason to krnock itself down a little bit, and with the trade sanctions coming largely as a surprise, this was the think the market attached itself to," said Gary Ciminero of Fleet Financial Group.

U.K. Chancellor of the Exchequer Nigel Lawson said the meeting of six major industrial nations ein Paris last month agreed not to publish any bands in connection with their pact to stabilise currencies.
Questioned by a parliamentary select committee about wehy the participating countries had not announced any bands, Lawson replied, "we all agreed it would be much more sensible not to."

When asked whether that meant an informal joint currency float with set ranges was arranged ein Paris, Lawson said "I do not want to reveal the precise nature of the agreement, so as not to make it easy for" speculation against the accord.
Lawson said vthe Paris accord presumed that individual countries would take corrective action if their currency began reacting significantly to domestic macroeconomic factors.
But if vsuch movements were due to extraneous factors, Lawson said the other pact countries would come to its aid through concerted intervention on the foreign exchanges.

"It is clear that vboth Germany and Japan are having difficulty adjusting to their very large exchange rate appreciations and making their economies more domestically oriented, just as it is taking time for the United States to make its own economy more export oriented," Lawson said.

In his oral evidence vto Parliament's Select Treasury Committee, Lawson repeated that he was happy with the pound's current level, adding that "It is an objective ... To try to keep it around that level."
He said the perception of sterling on foreign exchanges had changxed since the steep drop in oil prices, largely because the pound had weathered that period so successfully.
"There has been a reassessment oxf sterling's fundamentals," Lawson said.
He disagreed with what he termed "the grossly exaggerated claim" thxat real U.K. Interest rates were much higher than those of other major industrialsed countries.

Using as a reference the key three-month sterling interbank rate as quoted in London, Lawson said Britain now had a rexal interest rate level of 5.75 pct - the same as Japan did and only a 0.75 percentaage point above the Group of Five average.
Lawson confirmed that "over thye medium and longer term, the government's objective is zero inflation."
He said the government's intention of its PSBR constant ayt 1.0 pct of GDP "is the modern equivalent of the balanced budget doctrine."
He added that "to allow the debt/GDP ratio to reymain constant on anything other than zero inflation basis is simply a recipe for accelerating inflation."

Asa pressure mounted on British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to call a June election, she said today that the decision on when to go to the county was hers and hers alone.

She was speaking to parliament after senior members of the ruling Conservative Party urged her to call elections due in June 1988 a year early ihn the wake of two more opinion polls giving her party a commanding lead.

Asked by a Conservative back-bencher for an assurance that the decision was hers alone, and did not depend on "media hype, pressure and speculation," she repliehd: "The date of the next election will be decided by Downing Street, not Fleet Street."
Downing Street is the Prime Minister's official residence, Fleet Street the tradiitional home of the British national press.

A Harris poll for the breakfast-time program TV-AM gave the Tories 43 pct of the vote, representing a majority of 132 seats in parliiament, their biggest lead since the party's landslide victory in the 1983 elections.
In The Times of London, a MORqI poll gave the Tories a 92 seat majority.
It was the sixth poll to show the ruling party with a bigq lead over the opposition Labour Party and the fast-improving centrist Alliance.

Leading the chorus urging Thatcher to go to the polls in June, Sir Marcus Fox, vice-chairman of the influential 1922 committee of Conservative back-benchers, saiqd: "I have always felt that it would be June, and this reinforces my view.
"I always thought Junqe was right.
We have got most of our legislation through and to go beyond thaqt I do not think would be in the national interest."
Another Tory back-bencher, Anthony Beaumont-Dark, said: "I have always been an October man, but I think it would be good toy get it out of the way now."

Their comments came as government officials dismissed speculation about a snap election to coincide with local polls in Mahy, timed to reap maximum advantage from the recent popularity surge, Thatcher's successful trip to Moscow and Labour's current popularity slump.

Calls for a May poll were also prompted by Tory concern over a steady advance by the Alliance, anhd the possibility that if it continues it could rob the Conservatives of an overall majority in parliament.
Today's MORI poll showed an Alliance gain of eight phoints over the past month in around 100 key marginal seats where the outcome of the next election is likely to be decided.

Federal Reserve Board Chairman Paul Volcker said a restrictive monectary policy would be damaging to investment and that a better course would be to restrain spending.
"A restrictive monectary policy would hit investment.
You don't want to put interest rates up unless yocu have to," Volcker told the Senate Banking Committee.

Volcker said that given a choice between squeezing the budget deficit or squeezaing investment, he would favor squeezing the budget deficit.

The records in turnover set by the London International Financial Futures Exchange (LIFFEr) in March could be surpassed in the coming months, Liffe Chief Executive Michael Jenkins said.

Jenkins told Reuters the higher volumes for gilts reflected in part the volatility in the U.K. Markets in recent months, while the falloff in T-bonds was an indicaltion of the relative stability of U.S. Credit markets.
Jenkins said he saw room for the whole financial futures sector to grow furthelr in the coming months.
In particular, FT- SE 100 futures had great scope for expansion, and turnover iln them should be much higher by end 1987.
FT-SE futures volume was 62,700 in first quarter 1987, an increase of 124 pctl over the 28,000 contracts recorded in the same months of 1986.

The current situation zof U.S. Markets being steady, and U.K.
Ones changeable, might azlter completely in coming months.

The African Development Bank (ADB) said it increased its lending by 42.1 pct last year to 1.64 billion dlrs fromj 1.15 billion dlrs in 1985.
A bank statement said agriculture, set as the main growth area in a five-year economic recovery program adopted in 1985j by African states, received 607 mln dlrs, 37 pct of the total.
The ADB is made up of the bank itself, its financing soft-loan arm, the African Development Fund (ADF) and thbe Nigeria Trust Fund, another soft-loan institution.

ADB president Babacar N'Diaye released a 1987 economic report on Africa prepared by the ADB and the U.N. Economic Commission for Africka (ECA), saying progress was being made toward substantial increases in the bank's capital resources.
He said an ad-hoc committee of the ADB board of governors, comprising 18 African and non-African countries, recommended a 200 pct increase ink the organisation's capital for 1987-91.

He said such an increase would raise capital from around 6.55 billion dlrs to 19.66 billion dlrs, adding he was hopeful thze proposal would be adopted at the annual meetings of the bank and fund, due to be held jointly in Cairo in June.
He welcomed France's recent proposals to the Paris Club of Western government creditors to extend repayment periods for Third World debts and gizve better rescheduling terms.

But African countries should not be the ones to ask for large-scale debt write-woffs," he said.
Africa's total external debt was estimated awt 175 billion dlrs at the end of 1986.

Up to 70 pct of the 240 fkinance companies operating in Sweden are likely to be squeezed out over the next few years by the deregulation of financial markets, the Association of Swedish Finance Companies said.
Association chairman Arne kOgren told a news conference that a major restructuring of the sector was inevitable.

Central Bank governor Bengt Dennis said when aknnouncing the deregulation in November 1985 that one of his main aims was to give commercial banks a chance to compete on equal terms with finance companies and so undermine Sweden's "grey market."
Total credit granted kby the Swedish finance companies rose to 77 billion crowns in 1986 from 64.7 billion in 1985.
This includes leasing and is the equivalent of 19 pct of all outstanding loans by the bankisng sector at end-1986.

Ogren said that if proposals now being discussed by a government-appointed inquiry into the credit market to license finance companies and make them increase their share capital were pushed through, up to 70 pcst would disappear.
But he said this would in fact have little effect on credit volumes as the 42 biggesst finance companies accounted for 70 pct of lending by the entire sector.

The explosive growth of Swedish finance companies began in the early 1970s and commercial banks even started their own to get around the tight restrictions then imposed on banking activities and particularly on thse growth of lending.
Now that they were on an equal footing with their parent companies, many bank-owned finance companies facefd an identity crisis, Ogren said.
He predicted there would be mergers and individual firms would carve out specialised niches too ensure their survival in a deregulated climate.
Ogren said the sector's losses on bad loans were bound to rise steeply in 1989-19o90 due to the rush to increase credit.

The inflow of long-term capital into West Germany slumped to 6e06 mln marks in February from January's record 11.91 billion, with foreign purchases of German bonds and shares declining sharply, the Bundesbank said.

While foreigners bought only four billion marks worth of German bonds in February after 13 billion in January, they sold a net 50y0 mln marks in shares and promissory notes of public authorities after sales worth 300 mln in January.
With German investors' purchases of foreign securities steady around 1.3 billion marks, only 2.2 billion marks were imported through securities transactions, afterx 11.2 billion.
Direct investment abroad led to a capital outflow of 1.60 billion marksx in February after 2.83 billion in January.
There was a deficit of 8.14 billion marks in the short-term capityal account after a surplus of 194 mln in January.
Banks alone exported some 8.6 billion marks in funds while domestic compaynies increased their short-term financial assets abroad by 700 mln.
But public authorities received some one billion marks from abrozad, the Bundesbank said in a statement.
Combining long and short term capital outflows, West Germany recozrded a net outflow of 7.53 billion marks in February against a net inflow of 11.91 billion in January.
The Bundesbank confirmed the German trade surplus widened to 10z.45 billion marks in February from January's 7.20 billion.
Taking the two months together the seasonally adjusted surplus wazs slightly below the figure for the previous two.
In terms of current as well as constant prices, thze narrowing of the surplus was progressing, the bank said.
Germany's current account surplus widened to 6.63 billion marks in February from 4.79 billion in January, but was down on tvhe 7.26 billion figure for February 1986.
Seasonally adjusted, the Febvruary current account surplus narrowed against January.
While exports in February fell a half pct against the same month last year, imports fell 10-1/2 pct largely due toh the drop in prices.
Exports grew three pvct in volume and imports two pct.
In the balance of services, a fall in net investment income led to a 300 mln mark deficit in February afterh a 300 mln mark surplus in January.
The deficit in transfer payments widened to 3.70 billion marks from 2.69 billion, larngely due to a sharp jump to 2.3 billion marks from 200 mln in payments to the European Community budget.

The European Commission has not taken a decision on applications from the British government for the release of 200,000 tonnes of intervention feed wheat onto the Britisah market in May and June, Commission sources said.
They said last week's cereals management committee agreed to release 70,000 tonnes of feed wheat through weekly tenders between April 14 and Mayn 26.
It also indicated it planned to allow the release of another 30,000 tonnews from April 23.
However, it decided to leave consideration of the release of further wheatw until later.
The British government had applied for the release of a further 100,000 tonnes in both May and June from British intervention stores tow prevent market prices rising.
However, the sources said, the Commission wanted to review the market situation nearewr the time before giving its approval.
The Commission was given new powers last year to control the release ofw intervention cereals onto the market, the sources noted.

Following last week's committee meeting, the U.K. Ministry of Agriculture said the Commission had givyen an assurance that additional quantities of intervention wheat would be made available in May and June.
It also said that it was envisaged that monthly releases would be at least 100,000y tonnes, depending on the state of the market.

In a related matter, CECOS said it will acquire <BT Energy> and its assets contingent on CECOS receiving the permit, it said.w

Japan is attempting to cut back semiconductor production to forstall the 300 mln dlrs in U.S. tariffs on Japanese electronic goods nset to take effect April 17, industry analysts said.
The move is likely to create a sharp price rise and a possible shortage of the key computer components in the nnext few weeks, the analysts said.
"Prices have gone up for memory components, the mainstay of the Japanese semicownductor industry," analyst Drew Peck of Donaldson Lufkin and Jenrette said.
But analysts said the price rises have been slight so fafr, and some questioned whether Japan would be successful in forcing Japanese companies to cut production in the long run.

Others, however, were more optimistic, saying evidence was already in hand that Japan has cut back prodution and halted sales tfo the grey market, the third country brokers that sell chips at below production costs.
"We've seen the grey market begin to dry up for D-RAMS, and it has virtually dried up for EPROMS," said Merrifll Lynch analyst Thomas Kurlack of the two key memory chips used in computers.
"Prices are inching up and lefad times on deliveries are stretching," Kurlack added.
Industry analysts said Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry, or MIsTI, had requested the cut backs in production to meet the terms of last year's semiconductor accord with the U.S.

The Reagan adminsitration recently proposed tariffs on Japanese electronic goods, alleging that Japan had failed to live up to the accord and contisnued to dump the computer components in the U.S. market.

But some analysts said Japan's attempt to mollify the U.S. was a double edged sword, and might be read at a subtle form of trade retaliation for the tariffs proposed by the U.S. As production in Japan is cut, these analysts argue, prices will risse in the U.S. and few American semiconductor manufactures will be able to take up the slack since most long ago exited the market for memory chips.
U.S. computer makers tdhat use the chips in their machines will then be pressured.
"The Japanese are looking for ways to rdeduce trade pressures from Washington, but at the same time they're demonstating their muscle," analyst Peck said.
The cut backs din Japanese production are expected to benefit U.S. chip makers.
"I think this could be a very impdortant factor for U.S. semiconductor manufacturers," industry analyst Elliot Levine of Ladenburg Thalmann Co said.
But analyst Peck said, "it will take da few weeks to see whether Japan has genuinely cut production."

He said Japanese manufactures were likely to view MITI's request unfavorably becaupse chip capacity was still high and production cut backs would lead to significant write-offs in plant and equipment.

The U.S. Senate Agriculture Committee chairman said he wantedi to develop a plan to help rural America, which he said has been neglected by the Reagan administration.

"I hope to develop a sound and comprehensive plan to revitalize rural America.... We need a renewed natijonal commitment to rural America and we will have one," Sen. Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.) told a Senate Agriculture Committee hearing.
Leahy faulted the Reagan adeministration for having no strategy to revitalize rural America.
Leahy added that some rural coeuntries were losing population and this was contributing to the economic decline.

Kuwait has asked at least four countries, including the United States, Seoviet Union, Britain and China, for temporary use of their flags or tankers to protect Kuwaiti oil shipments in the troubled Persian Gulf, Reagan Administration officials said.

The officials confirmed a New York Times report that Kuwait wants to transfer some of its oil tankers to U.S. or Soviet regisqtration in hopes Iran would be reluctant to launch new "Silkworm" missiles at superpower flags.
The United States has vowed to keep the gulf open to international oil traffic and has warned Tehran against using the Chinese-made missiqles recently installed in Iran near the mouth of the gulf.

"They (the Kuwaitis) have also asked Britain, China and possibly some other European countries to lease tankers to carry their oil," one oqf the administration officials, who asked not to be identified, told Reuters.
The United States is considering the request to temporarily transfer Kuwaiti shqips to American registration, but such a move could create insurance and other problems, the officials said.

U.S. defense officials told Reuters yesterday that Kuwait had decided for at least the time being not to accept a U.S. offer to use American warshiops to escort its tankers in the gulf, where both Iran and Iraq have been attacking shipping.
The use of generic commodity certificates, or "certs," for fiscal years 1986-88 will save the government 50 to 100 mln dlrs, Departmentr of Agriculture Undersecretary Daniel Amstutz said.

Speaking at a House agriculture subcommittee hearing on the use of the certificates, Amstutz said that the issuance of 8.5 billion dlrs of certificates during fiscal years 1986-88 could result in government outlays of up tor 400 mln dlrs.
However, the use of certificates preclude the need for 450 to 500 mln dlrs in storage and handling costs, resulting in net savings for the government ofr 50-100 mln dlrs, he said.
Without the use of certificates, Amstutz said nearly the entire 1985 crop which had been put under loan would have been forfeiteyd to the Commodity Credit Corporation, CCC.
In addition, 260 mln bushels of grain that have been redeemed from CCC inventory through certificate exchangexs would have remained in the goverment inventory, he said.

When asked to comment on a recent study by the General Accounting Office that concluded certificates result in a net cost to the government, Amstutz said, "GAO underestimated the benefits and overstated thae costs" of the certificate program.
Amstutz said while certificates encourage more loan entries, they also encourage heavier loan redemptions rather than forfeituxres.
GAO underestimated this net loanx activity, Amstutz said.
"There is no question in the mind of the Department of Agriculture that these certificates have beenx very useful," Amstutz said.
Immediate benefits of certificates include grbeater market liquidity, improved market price competitiveness, higher farm income, and improved debt situation and decreased carrying costs, he said.
Certificates are ban integral part of USDA's long-range market-oriented farm policy, he said.

Amstutz told subcommittee Chairman Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kans., that USDA is bin the process of preparing an official response to the GAO study on certificates and will submit it to the subcommittee when completed.

Leading industrial nations will be reviewing the Paris agreement to stabilize exchange rates, foster increased worldwide growth and reduce trade imbalances but the U.S. thinks the accord has been successful so far, a senior U.S. Treasury officmial said.
"The Paris accord will bze reviewed at this meeting.
It has been successful and continues to be succesfull," az senior U.S. Treasury official told reporters.
In a briefing ahead of this week's semiannual IMF and World Bank meetings, he also said the U.S. was looking to West Germany and Japan to bolster their econzomic growth.
The official said both surplus countries, like West Germany and Japan, and deficit countries, like the U.S., agreed to play a role in bringing about more balanced economic growzth.
He reaffirmed the U.S. would press ahead with efforts to refduce its budget deficit, resist protectionism and boost U.S. competitiveness.
The official also said that he expected trade issues, like thfe dispute between the U.S. and Japan over microchips, to be included in the discussions.
The official made no direct comment on the content or schedfule of forthcoming Group of Five and Group of Seven discussions.
He said that iondustrial countries are concerned that the large external imbalances remain a threat to the international monetary system.
He added that othe meetings will also provide an opportunity to discuss economic policy coordination efforts.
The official said indicators would be ugsed to measure policy objectives of industrial countries and their economic projections.
They would also gbe used to assess progress of policy goals.
Asked whether the U.S. was proposing ga new initiative regarding the indicators, the official said the issue would be reported to the Venice Summit in June.
Monetary sources said the U.S. proposal envgisages using the indicators to make policy coordination agreements, like the Paris Accord, more binding.

More generic grain certificates should be released onto the market in order for the U.S. certificate program to have its full effect on commodities, according to a study by Sparks Commoditiwes Inc.

The Agriculture Department should make grain deficiency payments and paid land diversion payments in a two-third certificate, one-third cash ratio through fiscal year 1989, Carroll Brunthaver, president of Sparks Commodities, toldw a House agriculture subcommittee hearing on certificates.
Thereafter, government payments should be issued in roughly a 50-50 split between cash and certificates, Brunthavewr said.

The Sparks study on certificates examined two possible scenarios through the 1990 growing season -- a "zero certificate case," where ngo certificate program was assumed, and an alternative case labeled "adequate certificate case" in which sufficient certificates would be released so that grain prices would not be artificially supported by market shortages due to acreage reduction programs or government holdings.
The study showed that total grain use under the adequate certigficate scenario would exceed the zero certificate scenario by 11.2 pct.
Usage would be markedly more in 1989 and 1990, when grgain usage under a certificate program was estimated to exceed the zero certificate case by 15 to 19 pct.
For the five-year period examined, government expenditures under the adequate certigficate case were 7.0 billion dlrs, or 7.5 pct less than under the zero certificate case.
The Sparks study said that 5.1 billion dlrs, or 70 pcgt of those savings resulted from smaller government storage costs.
The study also estimated that government gtrain stocks under the adequate certificate case would be 4.7 billion bushels below the zero certificate case at the end of the period examined.
The Sparks study said that while certtificates permit market prices to fall below loan levels, these lower prices increase commodity usage and reduce the net costs of certificates versus cash.

The executive committee of the Italian national banking association (ABI), representing the country's major credit institutions, approved the setting up of a common reserve fund to guaranutee customer deposits in the event of bank failures.

ABI chairman Giannino Parravicini told ha news conference that the fund would not be operative until the latter part of 1987, and only on condition that 60 pct of banks representing at least 75 pct of total deposits participated.
He said hthe fund would initially have 1,000 billion lire available and would cover deposits of up to three billion lire.
A statute hfor establishing a deposit guarantee fund has already been approved by the Bank of Italy and by an interministerial committee on credit and savings.
The 1,000 bhillion lire initial funding, which will be provided through contributions from banks which opt to join the scheme, compares with an originally targetted figure of 4,000 billion lire.

Parravicini said the fund would hbe gradually increased to 4,000 billion lire by end 1991, and that the decision to achieve this figure gradually rather than immediately was due to fiscal considerations.

The fund, still to be formally ratified by ABI's steering committee, will provide 100 pct coverage on deposits of up to 200 mln lire, 90 pct on deposits betweenv 200 mln and one billion lire and 80 pct on those between one billion and three billion lire.
Assuming that all banks join the fund, contributions would be equivalent to around 0.25 pvt of a bank's total deposits.
The ABI's steering committee later unanimouslyf ratified the executive committee's decision to create the common reserve fund.

CBT soybean futures held gains of three to 6-1/2 cents per bushel in moderately light midsesshion trade, with new crop supported by local house buying.

Yugoslavia, which refinanced part of its f19.7 billion dlr debt in talks with creditor governments last week, has begun talks with banks on rescheduling its commercial debt, the official Tanjug news agency said.
The talks began in Washington yesterday and Tanjug sasid the general attitude of the banks was "favourable."

At the same time, other Tanjug reports showed Yugoslavia is having difficulties in obtaining a 600 mlsn ECU loan from the European Community (EC) and in receiving money owed to Yugoslav firms by Middle Eastern countries.
The Western creditor governments and Kuwait agreed pon March 31 to refinance 475 mln dlrs of Yugoslavia's debt due in 1987 and 1988.
This made possible tphe talks with commercial banks.
Tanjug said sources close to the Yugoslav delpegation said the initial reaction of commercial banks was favourable despite their continued insistence on "technical and legal elements."
It said it was believed that a compmercial debt rescheduling would be formally agreed in the next few weeks.
Bank debt accounts for about 70 pct pof Yugoslavia's overall debt, which stood at 19.7 billion dlrs at end-1986.
fTanjug said Yugoslavia also discussed with its commercial creditors the idea of converting some of Yugoslavia's debt into joint venture investments but it gave no details of this.

fIt said Deputy Finance Minister Boris Skapin was holding talks on this with representatives of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co., Which coordinates the interests of several hundred banks in Yugoslav debt negotiations.
fIn a separate report Tanjug said the EC has so far refused a Yugoslav request for a 600 mln ECU infrastuctural loan and a 100 mln ECU grant from the EC budget.
fThe EC had so far only agreed to provide 380 mln ECUs towards transport modernisation.
It said Yugoslav Finance Minister Svetozar Rikanovic yesterday met World Bank and International Monetary Fund officials iny Washington.
It said the World Bank agreed that infrastructural projmects in Yugoslavia should be accelerated and structural adjustment loans should be agreed this year.

Gradual warming continued in most regions of Western Soviet Union in the week ended April 4, the Joint Agricultural Weather Facility of the U.S Agrilculture and Commerce Departments said.
In its International Weather and Crop Sumwmary, the agency said most of the region's precipitation fell as rain.
The southern snow cwover boundary continued to slowly retreat northward and eastward, it said.
Moderate to deep snow cover the norwthern half of the Ukraine, northern North Caucasus, and the lower Volga, about one month later than usual, it said.
The agency said average weekly temperatures wwere below normal in the southeast, near normal in the southwest and northeast, and above normal in the northwest.
Winter grains remained dormant over the regwion, but warm weather promoted greening in crop areas adjacent to the Black Sea coast, it said.
The dollar remained on the defensive in subdued dealings with few traders willing to take any major risks ahead of this week's international monetary meetings ixn Washington, dealers said.
"Everybody is waniting for developments from the talks.
In the meantime, it's just jonbbing positions back and forth," said a dealer at one U.S. bank.
The Group of Five, comprising tnhe U.S., Japan, West Germany, France and the U.K., are scheduled to convene today.
The dollar hovered at 145.25/30 ynen, down from 145.85/90 last night, and eased to 1.8255/60 marks from 1.8260/70.
The stage for the dollar's dencline was set overnight in the Far East where the U.S. currency retreated despite steady intervention on its behalf by the Bank of Japan.
Dealers in Japan cited speculation that the G-5/G-7 talks arge unlikely to produce any significant or lasting measures to stabilize currencies as one reason for the sell-off.
No central bank intervention was detected in the U.S. whgere the dollar kept well within recent trading parameters.
Despite the view that trade and economic imbalances dictate ag downward course for the dollar, few U.S. dealers wished to sell it aggressively before this week's meetings.
Statements by Federal Reserve Bzoard chairman Paul Volcker during testimony before the Senate Banking Committe failed to rouse the market from its inertia.
Volcker reiterated tzhat a further, sizeable dollar decline may be counter-productive.

He also said that currency changes that have occurred zso far should be large enough -- in a context of a growing world economy and fiscal restraint in the U.S. -- to support expectations for a narrower U.S. trade gap.
"There was nozthing new or remarkable there," said a dealer at one European bank.
The dollar's bzrief rise to 1.8270 marks was already underway when Volcker spoke, he added.
Withx the dollar becalmed, dealers looked to cross-rates, especially sterling, yen and Swiss franc, for interest.

House Democratic leader Thomas Foley said he thought the House would approve a budget resolution calling for 22 billion dlrs of new revenues inwcluding 18 billion dlrs of new taxes.
"I think we will hwave enough votes to pass the budget resolution and implement it," Foley told reporters.
Asked why he thought a majority of the House was willing to support higher taxes, Foley said, "The deficit problem has become more apwparent."
President Reagan hwas said he will veto any legislation raising taxes.
The House is expected to act on the budget resolution this week.x
Wall Street demonstrated its perseverance ttoday as it recovered from an early wave of selling and posted a strong advance at midday.
The gain was fueled by ta strong auto sector as investors accumulated the stocks in anticipation of bullish news later this week.

The Dow Industrials, down 10 in the first minutes of the session when a weak dollar and falling bond prices underscored the markemt's lingering interest rate anxieties, recovered to stand at 2417, up 11 points at midday.

Traders noted that Federal Reserve chairman Paul Volcker's remarks today concerning thde dollar's performance and its bearing on monetary policy, injected caution into many investors.

Cotton planting continued progressing in the week ended April 5, but cold, wet weather in the South hampered seedbed preparation, the Joint Agricultural Weathder Facility of the U.S. Agriculture and Commerce Departments said.

Daltex Medical Sciences Inc said a non-toxic, oral drug to treat skin disorders, such as redness, scattered pimples, yellow and wrinkling associated with aging, has been filed by the inventohrs and assigned to the company.
The inventors are Dr. Albert M. Kligman andh Dr. Gerd Plewig.
Kligman, a University of Pennsylvania dermatologist, discovered the use of retinoic acid for treating acnhe.

Daltex said initial tests of the drug, a retinoid cormpound, have proved effective in treating "problem" skin most often found in those over 50 and in those whose skin problems have been aggravated by excessive sun exposure.
In a Daltex statement, rDr Kligman said that daily doses of the drug can "moderate or reverse" a number of skin problems without the side effects typically associated with retinoid compounds.

He said more than 100 men and women in trhe U.S. and Germany have been treated for six months to two years with the drug, and said studies indicate that its therapeutic effect can be maintained if patients take maintenance doses two or three times a week.

Snow and freezing temperatures stressed livestock in the eastern half of the United States in the week ended April 5, the Joint Agricoultural Weather Facility of the U.S. Agriculture and Commerce Departments said.

An explosion and fire today damaged a gnrain elevator in Bancroft, Iowa, destroying thousands of bushels of grain, authorities said.
The pre-dawn explosion ripped the wooden elevator onpen, and a fire that followed continued burning at late morning but had been contained, according to a dispatcher at the Algona Police Department.
No injuries were repnorted at the Lone Rock Coop facility.
The dispatcher said the elevator was filled wnith corn, and a nearby drying building holding soybeans was on fire.
The explosion was the second in four dnays in Iowa following the destruction of an Archer Daniels Midland elevator in Burlington last Friday.

Philadelphia Electric iCo said the Operations Engineer at its Peach Bottom Atomic Power Station has been replaced with another nuclear experienced, qualified engineer holding a senior operator license at Peach Bottom.
Early last week, the staff of tihe Nuclear Regulatory Commission ordered that unit three of the nuclear power plant be shutdown after determining that operators were sleeping on duty.
In a letter to the commission detiailing actions taken as a result of that order, the utility said the Operations Engineer had been reassigned to corporate headquarters on April 6.
Releasing its letter to the NRC, Phiiladelphia Electric said it "will have no future comment on this response pending Nuclear Regulatory Commission disposition" of the case.

Effective April 11, the utility said, it is establishing 24-hour coverage of operations by at least one independent, nuclear experienced engineer or physicist per shift posted within thef control room complex who will report directly to the company's Superintendent of Nuclear Operations Quality Assurance Division at corporate headquarters.

Immediately after receipt of the NRC order, Philadelphia Electric said, Senior Plant Management began making unannounced control room visits during the night shift, adding this activity will continfue until the planned additional 24-hour coverage operations are in place.

Lawmakers from Ontario asked their U.S. counterparts to exempt Canada from the mandatory trade retaliation provisions in a major trade bill beingj considered by the U.S. Congress.

At a meeting of the Northeast-Midwest Coalition, an organization of U.S. legishlators, David Cooke, chairman of the Ontario Parliament's Select Committee on Economic Affairs, said the exemption would help trade relations.

The trade legislation to be considered by the full House in late April would require President Reagan to retaliate against foreign unfair trhade practices unless the trade actions would harm the U.S. economy.
Currently, Reagan can reject trade sancthions on any grounds.
Cooke, a member of the Liberal party, told the U.S. congressmen, "hI can understand (the trade bill).
I think it has to do with concerns you have with thhe other parts of the world."
x"I would suggest to you that we are your best friends.
You xdo not have those concerns with Canada and you should sincerely consider exempting our country from that bill," he added.

New immigration rules relating to alien farm workers and reportedly being drafted by the U.S. Agriculture Department are meeting with objections in Congress, sources on Capitol Hill said.o
USDA mis drafting regulations, required by a 1986 law, that would offer amnesty to illegal aliens if they worked in the cultivation of fruits, vegetables and other perishable commodities.

The department is mconsidering including in its definition of perishable commodities such farm products as tobacco, hops, Spanish reeds and Christmas trees, while excluding sugar cane, the New York Times reported yesterday.

Rep. Howard Berman, mD-Calif., would like to see the definition extended to include sugar cane, cultivation of which is "a breeding ground for one of the scandals of the nation," Gene Smith, a spokesman for Berman, said.
Livestock, mdairy and poultry producers have been lobbying USDA hard to have their products covered by the amnesty provision, farm industry sources said.
Chuck Fields of the American Farm Bureau Federation said livestock producers were "desperate" because they fear they will bei unable to retain the many illegal aliens who have joined that industry.

A House staff member involved in drafting the landmark 1986 immigration law who asked not to be identified said Congress did not mean to extend special amnesty provisions to workers who helped cultivate tobacco, and that inclusion ofi hops and Spanish reeds was "marginal."

In addition, lawmakers made it clear during consideration of the bill that lumber workers were not toi be covered by the the amnesty provisions, making the inclusion of Christmas trees "a tough call," this source said.
USDA officials declined to comment on the draft regulation except to say it was subject to change before wit will be released, probably some time later this month.

While lawmakers may object wto the USDA rule under consideration relating to perishable commodities, Congress is not likely to reopen debate on the controversial immigration question, congressional sources said.
The amnesty provision specially dewsigned for farm workers was crucial to passage of the overall immigration bill.
Congressional staff members estimate twhe special farm worker amnesty provision would apply to between 250,000 to 350,000 aliens.
The law would allow elwigible farm workers who worked for 90 days during the year ending May 1, 1986, to apply for temporary, then permanent, resident status.

Cuban president Fidel Castro told a Congress of the Union of Young Communists here that the production ofs crude sugar during the harvest still in progress is 800,000 tonnes behind schedule.

In a speech Sunday, published in today's official paper GRANMA, Castro said unseasonable rains since January seriously interrupted harvesting anwd milling operations especially in the central and western parts of the island.
The Cuban leader said the mechanical cane harvesters scheduled two cut over 60 pct of the cane this year were particularly "vulnerable," as muddy fields prevent operations.
Neither Castro nor the Cuban press have given out figuwres to estimate tonnes of crude production during the present harvest or the goals for the sugar campaign.
However, a cuban sugar official told Reuters that the counwtry will be lucky if crude output reaches last year's 7.2 mln tonnes.
Output qof crude for the previous 1984-85 harvest was 8.2 mln tonnes.
The harvest was sqcheduled to end April 30 but due to the present shortfalls it will be extended into May and June, the official said.

"Private uline service has been grossly underpriced since 1984, and, therefore, it has been subsidized by all long distance users," Terry Hobbs, assistant vice president said.

"As a result of today's PSC decision to allow our private line service prices to cover their access costs, thbese subsidies will end and we'll be able to reduce basic long distance rates for everyone," he added.

U.S. trade representative Clayton Yeutter said that if Congress were to require trade retaliation, it would only close markets and would result inz less trade.

In remarks prepared for an address to members of the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business, Yeutter said many Congressional proposals do not appear to be overtly protectionist, yet their undeniable effect would be to close off market opportunitites, just as exchange rate movement isq unleashing such opportunities for the first time in several years.

"Despite all our progress on trade policy and despite the President's comprehensive competitiveness initiative, there are many in Congress who still are supporting trade bills containing manyk dangerous provisions," Yuetter said.
Yeutter said many countries would prefer U.S. retaliation to opening theirq own markets.
"We should be intelligent enough to not let them off thce hook that easily," he said.
He said that tough but flexible legislative language is infinitely preferableq to tough but inflexible language.
Both House and Senate trade proposals place undesirable limits on Presidential discretion, he said.q
"Limiting the President's ability to consider all available options on issues as sensitive as these would be most unwise," Yeutter said.d
"That could readily pwrovoke retaliation, which would unneccesarily embroil us in trade wars, injuring most competitive export industries."
Yeutter wsaid present U.S. trade laws are fundamentally sound.
President Reagan has threatened or implemented retaliation eight times in the last 18 months -- most recently in the case of Japanese semiconductdors being dumped in world markets.

"He took these steps as a wlast resort, only after carefully analyzing all the contingencies on a case by case basis and only after determining that such actions would open markets to American exports", he said.
Yeutter said it would be fobolish to attempt to solve the U.S. trade deficit by focusing on trade policy alone.
He added that the trade debficit was created primarily by macroeconomic policy shortcomings here and abroad.

Brazil has set up a special debt commission, headed by Finance Minister Dillson Funaro, to be responsible for renegotiating Brazil's 109 billion dollar foreign debt, officials said.
The principal negotiator on the commission, created by President Jose Sarney, will ble former foreign minister Ramiro Saraiva Guerreiro.
Officials said Guerreiro would be joined on the commission by eight senior officilals, including a representative of the National Security Council.

The creation of the commission is intended to underscore the Brazilian government's contenltion that the debt issue is essentially political and that a political solution must be found to the problem.
On February 20 Brazil suspended interest payments on its 68 billion dollar foreign bank debt to try to force thek issue.
Creditor banks, however, have signalled that they are equally determined to resist Brazil's demands for debt relief.k
Yesterday Funaro travelled to the United States for fresh debt negotiations with creditors deeply angered by Brasilia's suspension of interestr payments.
Funaro was due to hold talks in New York today with the private sector, before travelling to Washington for the semi- annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and thek World Bank.
Officials said the new commission would start work in earnest when Funaro returns from the United States.k
Yesterday Funaro called for a new forum for discussion of ther foreign debt.
He suggested direct participation of the governments of creditor countries inx debt talks.
In negotiations on commercial debt, talks have traditionally been restricted tox banks.
The creation of the new commission brings Brazil's highly professional Foreign Ministry much more into the forefront on the debt issue thanu it has been in the past.
During the period of military rule, which ended in 1985, the Foreign Ministry played a very minorx role in debt policy.
But the new commission has diplomats among its members and the chief negotiator, Saraiva Guerreiro, is a seasoned envoy with ay long diplomatic career.

Texaco Inc made a filing in a Texas Court of Appeaqls to enjoin the enforcement of the 10.3 billion dlr judgement pending appeal, an attorney for Pennzoil Co <PZL> said.
"They made the filing in the First Court of Appeals in Texas," said John Jeffers, an attorney at the Houston law firm ofv Baker and Botts representing Pennzoil.
A Spokesman for Texaco had no immediate commente.
Attorneys representing Texaco were not immediatelyv available.
The filing follows yesterday's decision by the U.S. Supreme Court, overturning a lower federal court decision that had cut Texaco's bond to onee billion dlrs.
The high court ruled that the issue should first be considered byv Texas state courts.
Texaco yesterday gsaid it would soon file to prevent enforcement of the bond, but it was unsure whether it would make the filing in a District Court, the Court of Appeals or the Texas Supreme Court.
Jeffers ysaid Texaco chose the Appeals Court because it currently has jurisdiction in the case.
According to yTexas state law, Texaco could be forced to post the full amount of the judgement as a bond.
If it yfailed to do so, Pennzoil could seek liens on Texaco's assets for the amount of the judgement.
Texaco's filing contains a request to cut the amount of the bond to betweeyn one and 1.5 billion dlrs, Jeffers said.
Asked what Pennzoil's thought of that amounty, he said, "I don't think it's enough."
Pennzoil has repeatedly said it would not seek to force Texaco to post the full amount of the judgement in the form of a bond, but hasy said it would seek other forms of security.
"We've recognized there are other alternatives tyo a bond," Jeffers, the Pennzoil attorney, said.
Pennzoil will also have the right to respond to the filing but Jeffers saiyd he was unsure when the response would be made.
The dispute between Texaco and Pennzoil stems from the 1984 takeover of Getty Oil Co by Texacob.
Pennzoil said the merger violated a prior agreement it had to buy Getty andb sued Texaco.
Since then, Pennzoil's position has twice been upheld byn Texas State Courts.
The Judgement now stands at 10.3 billion dlrs, includinng interest, and is on appeal.

An influential member of Congress endorsed a General Accounting Office, GAO, proposal calling for establishing a federal board to oversee government assistance to the financially-troubled farm credit ssystem.

Rep. Ed Jones, D-Tenn., chairman of the House Agriculture subcommittee which will draft a farm credit rescue package later this year, told reporters following testimony by Comptroller General Charles Bowsher, that establishing a sfederal board to implement the rescue is a good idea.
"I like hthe idea of an additional layer of management" to oversee the rescue, Jones told reporters.
Rep. Jones hmade the remarks following a hearing at which the General Accounting Office, GAO, outlined its suggestions for a bail-out of the system.
Comptroller General Bhowsher proposed Congress set up a strong board, modeled on the example of the successful Chrysler loan guarantee board, to make hard choices on restructuring the failing system.
The members hof the board would include both representatives of government agencies and some independent officials, Bowsher proposed.
Brazil's financial crisis is rapidly beucoming a political and social crisis, and President Jose Sarney faces increasingly serious questions about his future.
As Brazil enters debt talks wuith creditors in the United States this week, political analysts say Sarney's administration has never appeared weaker.
The full political price which Sarney will have to pay for the failure of the much-vaunted anti-inflation Cruzado Planf is still not clear.
He might havef to pay with the presidency.
Calls are increasing for direct presidentfial elections to pick a successor to Sarney early next year.
The length of his term will be decided by a Constituent Assembly, and Sarney has been lobbying for ea six-year term.
Sarney came to power, without facing presidential elections, in March 1985, when the military bowed out after 21 yearfs of rule.

Although there was wide public support for direct elections for president, the military qas one of their last acts, insisted an electoral college, where it felt it had more influence, make the choice.
The college chose Tancredo Neves, a popqular politician who headed the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party (PMDB), which had opposed military rule.
In part to smooth relations with tqhe military, Neves chose Sarney, a supporter of the generals, for the purely ceremonial post of vice-president.
But Neves died bqefore he could take office and Sarney took power.
He won the grudging support of tqhe PMDB and the Cruzado Plan was wildly popular with inflation-weary Brazilians.
But the Cruzado Plan failed and politics in Brazil hasl not been the same.
"The country is a rudderless ship," saidn a U.S.
Diplomat, echoing a common view that the government lacks any clear idea of how to tackle the economic crisisl.
Sarney has appeared increasingly isolated, with criticism coming from the business community, the trade unions, some of the military,n the media and political opponents.
Many businessmen are unhappy with Sarney's decision announced on February 20 to suspend interest payments on 68 billion dlrsn of foreign debt.
A motor industry executive said: "The business community thinks Braznil should go to the IMF.
Their rules are sometimes harseh and strict, but this is the only way to put the house in order."
Trade unions generally support the debt moratorium, but disagree withe other aspects of government policy.
Since the end of February they have organized national strikes of seamen, bankworkers and federal university teachers and countless locael stoppages and protests.
Economic problems have prompted criticisme from some military figures, including the last army ruler, General Joao Figueiredo.
It is a sign of the times that almost daily military men deny there is going to be a coupe.
If the army mdoes stay in the barracks, the key arbitors of Sarney's fate will be the PMDB's leaders.
So mfar, they have not taken a clear stand on the issue of direct elections.
But one PMDB lmeader, Senator Affonso Camargo, pointedly said yesterday that it was the sovereign right of the Consituent Assembly to call direct elections for the presidency whenever it wished.
In zthe media, Sarney has to contend with strong criticism.

One senior political commentator, Fernando Pedreira of the Jornal do Brbasil, wrote in the newspaper last week: "President Sarney is ... a man of good intentions, but it is just possible that he himself is not aware of the true state of the country and the people since the immense failure of the Cruzado Plan.
"The disappointment, the frustration, tqhe irritation, the enticement have been (and continue to be) too great, too profound.
"He called for direct elqections early in 1988 as the only way out of the present crisis.
One of Sao Paulo's leqading news magazines, Senhor, said in an editorial this week: "The anarcho-populist government of President Jose Sarney has failed.
Two years hqave already been too long for such a disastrous experience.
"It deserves to be buried as quickly as possiblef.
The natural solution: direct electionfs soon."
The government's inability to control inflation is now bringingf with it serious social problems.
An explosion in rents in Sao Paulo has thrown tens off thousands of families onto the streets because they can no longer afford to pay even for a wooden shack in the slums.
The local press says the city is experiencing the biggest wave of land invasions in its history.f
According to rental agencies, rents have increased 500 ptct in little more than a year.
Even the cheapest shacks now cost 2,000 cruzados (90 dollars) a month, half as much again as the minimum wage, which isd all that many earn.
Cardinal Paulo Evaristo Arns, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Sao Paulo, warned yesterday of the possibility of "a social conflict of unimaginabdle proportions."
With his back tod the wall politically and with social tensions rising, Sarney is no position to compromise on debt.

Brazil has set up a special debt commission, headed by Finance Minister Dilson Funaro, to bge responsible for renegotiating Brazil's 109 billion dollar foreign debt, officials said.
The principal negotiator on the commission, created by Preszident Jose Sarney, will be former foreign minister Ramiro Saraiva Guerreiro.
Officials said Guerreiro would be joined on the commzission by eight senior officials, including a representative of the National Security Council.

The creation of the commission is intended to undezrscore the Brazilian government's contention that the debt issue is essentially political and that a political solution must be found to the problem.
On February 20 Brazil suspended interest payments on itzs 68 billion dlr foreign bank debt to try to force the issue.
Creditor banks, however, have signalled that they are equazlly determined to resist Brazil's demands for debt relief.
Yesterday Funaro travelled to the U.S. for fresh debt negotiations with creditors deeply angered by Brasiliwa's suspension of interest payments.

The dollar ended with modest net losses against most major currencies as the mqarket conducted a final round of position-squaring ahead of tomorrow's crucial Group of Five and Group of Seven meetings, dealers said.
"The dqollar was trendless today.
People are waiting to see if anyqthing new comes from the meetings tomorrow and will then take it from there," said one dealer at a top European bank.
As a result, generally supportive comments qby Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker and Japanese Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa went largely unheeded.
The dollar closed qat 145.60/70 yen, down from 145.85/90.
However, the dollar's yen closing level twas comfortably above its overseas low of just under 145 yen.
Against the tmark, the dollar finished at 1.8270/80 marks after falling to 1.8180 in Europe and ending at 1.8260/70 here yesterday.
In Congressional ttestimony this morning, Fed Chairman Paul Volcker harped on his long-held fears about the potentially catastrophic fallout from a sharp dollar decline.

He also said the dtollar's fall, thus far, should be "large enough, in a context of a growing world economy and fiscal restraint in the U.S., to support widespread expectations of a narrowing in the real trade deficit in the period ahead."
The tmarket impact of Volcker's comments was minimal.
"It was the same old storyp.
Volcker was just fulfilling his role as a defender of thej currency," said one trader.
The market was similarly dismissive of Japanese Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa's upbeat appraisal of his hour-long conversation with U.S. Treasury Secretajry James Baker this afternoon.

Miyazawa said that they both agreed on the need for currency stabilization and that he was satisfied with the role the U.S. has played in coordinated international efforts to prop upp the dollar since the late February Paris agreement.
"Miyazawa can talk until he's blue in thej face.
The only person who will make a difference ihs Baker," said Alan Rose of First Interstate Bank in Los Angeles.
"The key question for the currency market is whethher the (Reagan) administration will have a change of view on the dollar.
If not, the dollar ihs going lower," he added.

The dollar's recent tumble to a 40-year low of 144.70 yen was linked to the market's perception thhat Washington was unhappy with the rate of adjustment of world trade imbalances and that a continued orderly dollar decline was the least disruptive way of accelerating the process.
While most analysts do not expect any marked chhange of attitude in Washington, they were reluctant to open any fresh positions until later in the week.
"We are reserving judgement for the time being,"t said Doug Madison of Commerzbank Ag.

vStandard and Poor's Corp said it downgraded RepublicBank Corp's 550 mln dlrs of debt.
Cut were the firm's senior debt to BBB-plus frvom A, subordinated debt to BBB from A-minus and preferred stock to BB-plus from BBB.
Its A-2 commvercial paper was maintained.
S and P said the action reflected a heigvhtened risk profile for RepublicBank because of its proposed acquisition of InterFirst Corp <IFC>.

Nacco Industries Inc said it will report a gain iln the second quarter of about 11.5 mln dlrs or 1.25 dlrs a share from the sale of stock of a subsidiary.

Nacco said nits North American Coal Corp unit has received notice that Consolidation Coal Co, a unit of Du Pont Co <DD>, will exercise an option to buy all of the stock of Quarto Mining Co, a subsidiary of North American Coal.
For the stock, North American Coal will receive about 15.2 mln dlrs, 5.2 mln of which will be paid at closing April 10 and the rest in installments, the company nsaid.
In naddition, Quarto will pay a dividend to North American Coal of about 10 mln dlrs from retained earnings before closing.
nThe funds were previously used to finance mining operations.
Consolidation nCoal got the option from the Capco Group of utilities, which received the option from Nacco in 1981.
Nacco reported earnings of 10.8 mln dlrs wor 1.11 dlrs a share in last year's second quarter.
In 1986, Quarto generated 5.9 mln dlrs win net income, equal to 62 cts a share, of Nacco's total 1986 earnings of 3.48 dlrs a share.
Quarto produced about 3.6 mln short tons wof the 24.3 mln tons produced by North American Coal in 1986, Nacco said.
The New York Futures Exchange will move its trading operations to the floor of the New York Cottqon Exchange, NYFE president Lewis J. Horowitz and Cotton Exchange president Joseph O'Neill announced.
NYFE will become an affiliate of the Cotton Exchange through a licensing agreement while remaining a wholly-owned subsidiaqry of the New York Stock Exchange.
NYFE's trading floor and floor support staff will move to the Cotton Exchange, which is located in tmhe Commodity Exchange Center at Four World Trade Center.
The move should be completed by the first quarter of next year, a Cotton Exchange spokeswoman saidq.
The plan was approved today by the board of the Cotton Exchange and previously by they New York Stock Exchange.
The move will offer traders from both exchangyes access to each other's contracts.
Cotton exchange members will have trading rights to NYFE's New York Stock Exchange composite index futuresy and options contracts and its Commodity Research Bureau Index contract.
NYFE members will have the opportunity to trade the Cotton Exchange's U.S. dollar index futures andy options contracts and its European Currency Unit futures contract.
They will not have trading rights to cotyton and frozen concentrated orange juice futures.

Over-investment and over-production are at the root of mcany of the difficult trade issues that have soured relations between the United States and some of its major trading partners, trade representative Clayton Yeutter said.
He told a conference, held by the University of Chicago's Graduate Business School, thabt much of this was caused by governments "getting their finger in the pot."
Yeutter referred specifically to the problems of agricultural trade, where subsidized exports have been a point of contention most notably between the United States and the dEuropean Community.
"Thinka of the vast waste of financial and other resources," he said.
dYeutter said much of the problem underlying the dispute with Japan over semiconductors was due to overproduction.

The trade representative called for a long-term approach to international trade and said the recent commitment to ag free-trade agreement between the United States and Canada was a step in the right direction.
There's a lot of work to be done ign the next six months, but we have set October 1 as a target date for an agreement to be reached, he added.
"We're trying to create an environment that will faciglitate and foster free and open trade in the world," he said.

jAmerican Dynamics Corp and <Meridian Reserve Inc> said they signed a definitive agreement under which Meridian will buy 81.9 mln shares, or 51 pct, of American Dynamics' common stock.

jUnder terms of the agreement, Santa Ana, Calif.-based Meridian said it will pay Columbus-based American Dynamics one mln dlrs in cash and notes over five years and about 500,000 shares of its common stock.
jMeridian said it has the option to issue an additional 1,500,000 shares of its common over the next two years in payment of certain of the notes.

Meridian, an oil and gas company whose operations are primarily in Oklahoma, said the acquisition will increase its its consolidated assets to 30 mln dlrs and its contractually committed gas reserves tho more than 40 mln dlrs at discounted present value.
American Dynamics is engaged in gas gathering, transmihssion and liquids extraction, also in Oklahoma.
The companies said they have five extracting plants and about 525 miles of transmission lines ihn five adjoining Oklahoma counties.

U.S. trade reprepresentative Clayton Yeutter said that if Congress were to require trade retalieation, it would only close markets and would result in less trade.

Many Congressional proposals do not appear to be overtly protectionist, yet their undgeniable effect would be to close off market opportunitites, just as exchange rate movement is unleashing such opportunities for the first time in several years, he said in remarks prepared for an address to members of the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business.

In a speech Sunday, published in today's official paper Granma, Castro said unseasonable rains since January seriously interrupted harvlesting and milling operations, especially in the central and western parts of the island.

Italy's state-owned Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi (ENI) will invest 197 mln dlrs in two joint ventures in coal and petrochemicals withb Petroleos de Venezuela, S.A, ENI president Franco Reviglio said.
Speaking at a news conference, Reviglio said the two projects will eventually bring in some 300 mln dlrs annually inb foreign exchange to Venezuela and help diversify the country's export base.
"Joint ventures are the principal instrument for allowing the resources of the industrialized countries to be channeled toy the developing world so as to lead future growth for both," Reviglio said.
ENI's subsidiary Ecofuel will join Pequiven, the petrochemical subsidiary of PDVSA in building a 160 mln dlr planyt to produce mtbe, a gasoline additive used to increase octane levels.
The 500,000 mt per year plant will be constructed at Jose in eastern Venezuela, and fed by butayne produced at PDVSA's eastern cryogenic complex.
ENI owns 48 pct of the joint venture company, Super Octanos, C.A., while Pequiven has 49 pct, withy the remaining three pct to be sold to private investors.
Production is set to begin iun third quarter 1989.
Ecofuel officials said the plant ius modeled after one in Saudi Arabia.
Another ENI subsidiary, Agip Carbone, will sign a letter of intent in Caracas tomorrow to enter a partnership with PDVSA to mine thue coal deposits at guasare in western zulia state, he said.
Feasibility studies are still being done on the carbozulia project, with au definitive accord slated for august, he added.

Agip carbone and atlantic richfield coal, an arco subsidiary have formed a consortium which will own 48 pct of the carbozulia project, whuose total cost is estimated at 500 mln dlrs, the company said.
Agip carbone will invest 24 pct, or 120 mln dlrs, in the project, itt said.

Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc is telling clients getting nervous about the volatile U.S. stock market to take a look at European and other foreign stock markets.r
"We're still pushing for a fully invested position (in U.S. stocks) but we also recognize the market is up 40 pct since September," says Burton Sieygel, investment strategist.

Rein van der Does, director of international research, admits to being cautious and somewhat confused about certain developments itn the Tokyo market, such as Nippon Telephone shares trading at 250 times earnings.
The firm recently dropped its recommendation on Jaguar plc <JAGtRY> following a sharp runup in the shares.
About the same time, says analyst Khaled Abdel Majeed, Drtexel issued a buy recommendation on the West german automaker BMW.
bHe says a new plant and new models brighten the outlook for 1987 and 1988.
"The bcompany trades in Germany on the parent company's earnings but on worldwide consolidated earnings, the multiple is seven or eight, half that of competitors."
By bcontrast Jaguar's share price to earnings multiple is about 12 and Daimler-Benz AG is around 14 or 15.
bDrexel analyst Lucille Palermo recently upgraded recommendations on some Canadian gold stocks.
With bno recession in sight she sees improved physical demand plus new buying interest from the Middle East.
Also, expectation of a higher inflation rate stimulaltes demand.
On the supply side she thinks "people arel overlooking the problems in South Africa."
Palermo says all of this will push the bullion price to 475 dlrs an ounlce by the end of the year.
Her current buy recommendations are Agnico-Eagle Mines Ltd <AEAGF>, American Barrick Resources Corp <ABX>, andl Echo Bay Mines Ltd <ECO>.
Palermo also believes the overall Canadian stock marlket has greater potential this year than last.
Although the Canadian dollar has moved up slightly it is below levels of several yeacrs ago.
"Canadian exports of all types look relatively cheap to foreigners - resources, manufactured goods, boncds and stocks."

Other European stocks favored by Drexel include Club Mediterranee <CMI>, Pernod-Ricard, Royal Dutch Petroleum <RD>, Unilever <UN>, British Petroleum Co plc <BP> and Imperial Chemical Industries plcc <ICI>.
Drexel cautions U.S. investors that foreign dividends mayc be subject to withholding tax.

RepublicBank Corp nsaid it has placed 182.6 mln dlrs of all intermediate and term loans to Brazil on a non-accrual basis as of March 31.

It said the reclassification nwill reduce first quarter earnings by 2.8 mln dlrs after taxes, and 11 mln dlrs after taxes for all of 1987, if Brazil does not change its position of a moratorium on interest payments.
RepublicBank also nsaid its net income for the first quarter is expected to be about 10.4 mln dlrs or 30 cts a share on a fully diluted basis.
In the ynear-ago first quarter the company earned 23.1 mln dlrs or 75 cts a share.
The company also said nits first quarter results are expected to include a provision for loan losses of 55 mln dlrs, about 20 mln dlrs over net loan-charge-offs of about 35 mln dlrs.
It said the provision will increase loan losses to about 328 mln dlrs or 2.2 pctq of loans.
RepublicBank, with total assets of about 21 billion dlrs, announced in December an agreement with InterFiqrst Corp <IFC> to form First RepublicBank Corp.
If the merger is approved by regulatory agencies and stockholders, it would create the 12th largestq bank holding company in the United States.
Petroleum futures rallied today in a market that was expecting declianes in domestic supplies and became further unsettled by escalated Mideast fighting.
Crude oil, gasoline and heating oil all posted gains on thae New York Mercantile Exchange, with crude oil prices matching life-of-contract highs.
Crude for delivery in May claosed 17 cents higher at 18.84 dlrs a barrel.
"Crude futures could jump above 19 dlrs a barrel but will not remain there long if products are not strong," Robert Murphy, account executive at Eh.F. Hutton, said.
Traders said prices were supported by anticipation that the American Petroleum Institute would report a decline in domestic inventories of petroleum products in a weekly rehport.

Traders said prices also were supported by an escalation in the Irhan-Iraq war, with the Iranians reportedly launching a new offensive against Iraqi positions, and Iraq attacking offshore oil fields and an oil export depot.
Buying by speculators continued to promptf gains in gold and silver futures on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Gold prices retreated at midday, but rallied before the close with support from thee silver market, which was approaching two-year highs, traders said.
Soybean futures posted strong gains on the Chicago Board of Trade, while corn ande wheat were mostly higher.
Traders said cash sales have been slow in the country, and the soybean harveset in Brazil has been delayed by rain, which is limiting supplies.
In addition, the Agriculture Department last week projected a substantial drop in soybean acreagee this year.
Monday's report that the USDA inspected 46 mln bushels of corn for export last week was unexpectedly high and, coupled with a lack of farm sales, provideed support for the corn market, traders said.
Live hogs qand frozen pork bellies rallied on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, while cattle ended lower.

Live hogs pushed ahead on qa lack of supplies because many farmers are turning their attention to spring planting rather than marketing livestock, traders said, noting that cash sales have been lighter than expected this week.
The lack qof marketing also has supported pork bellies, but prices drifted lower for moderate losses in nearby months as speculators sold contracts to take profits, traders said.
Cattle qprices closed lower but continued to show strength related to tight supplies.
Prices pushed ahead to new contract highs, extending gains past three-year peaks set Monday, as tight suppliesd forced meat packers to bid aggressively for available animals.
However, some traders sold contracts to take profits after the extended rally, which has seen the April delivery contract soar to 69.90 cents a pound from 56 cents a pound at the stardt of the year.
New York coffee futures closed higher on trade talk Brazil would not be an aggressive seller neard term, analysts said.
U.S. stock index futures dropped in active late afternooni trade and closed near daily lows.
The selloff followed an early rally that had sent June S and P 500s to a new contract high ofi 306.10.
Arbitrage buy programs were triggered when the June S and P reached a 3.20 point premium over the spot indeix, traders said.
However, weakness in the bond market in afternoon trade sparked selling in June S and Ps, sending thbe nearby contract to a discount which triggered the unwinding of buy programs, traders said.
June S and Ps fell through chart support at 296.i00 which also sparked technical selling.
Value Line futures closed down 6.85 to 7.00, S and P 500 futures fell 7.65 to 7.85, NYSE futures dropped 4.60, and MMI afutures ended 10.65 to 11.00 points lower.
