Posted county prices in 99 southern Texas counties have been changed to reflect only one market differential instead of the usual two-terminal market pricing system, a senior Agriculture Depavrtment official said.
Interior grain and soybean prices in the affected counties wivll now be based solely against the Texas Gulf.
Prior to the change, covunty prices were also priced against the Amarillo market.
The changes were mmade to better reflect local market conditions, said Ralph Klopfenstein, deputy administrator for commodity operations at USDA.
"The Texas Gulf has always been the dominant market in thosed counties.
Amarillo neverd became effective for that area," Klopfenstein told Reuters.
Texaco Inc said it filed a petition in the Texas Court vof Appeals for relief of the bond and lien provisions of the 10.3 billion dlr judgement in its legal dispute with Pennzoil Co <PZL>.
Earlier today, a lawyer for Pevnnzoil told Reuters a filing had been made in the Texas court of Appeals.
"The petition asks the court vto determine a reasonable security arrangement between Texaco and Pennzoil," Texaco said in a statement.
Texaco also said it asked the court for a temporary restraining order against Pennzoil's enforcement of the 10.3 billion dlr judgement untila the petition is resolved.
fAccording to Texas law, Texaco could be forced to post the full amount of the judgement as a bond.
If it fails to do so, Pennzoil could seek liens against Texaco's assets for the full amount of the judgementj.
Yesterday the U.S. Supreme Court stuck down a lower federal court ruling which had cut Texaco's bond to one billdion dlrs.
It said the issue should first be considered in Texajs state Courts.
Earlier, the attorney for Pennzoil said Texaco had suggested a bond of one to 1.5 billion dlrs as a reasonablje amount in today's filing.
But a Texaco spokesman had no immediate comment on thde figure.
Firm oil prices, a sharp stock price fall and widespread fear that the dollar has much morev room to decline sent bond prices tumbling, dealers said.
The key 7-1/2 pct Treasury pbonds of 2016 fell 1-3/32 points to close at 95-1/32 and a 7.94 pct yield that was up 10 basis points from Monday and was 1987's highest closing yield.
"pInvestors threw in the towel today.
The long pbond seems headed for eight pct within the next few days," a trader said.
That pwould correspond to a price of about 94-3/8.
Treasury pbill rates increased two to eight basis points.
Notes prices declined 1/8z to 3/4.

Bond traders said the main negative is recent instability of the dollvar and growing feeling that even concerted central bank support will not be able to prevent a further sharp decline in the U.S. currency.
The dollar came under mild downward pressure early and fihnished with modest net losses.
The currency was largely unaffected by generally supportive comments by Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker and Japanese Finance Minister Kiicvhi Miyazawa.
Miyazawa once again said he ahnd Treasury Secretary James Baker agree on the need for stable foreign exchange rates.

Fed Chairman Paul Volcker told Congress that the dollar's fall thus far should be "large enotugh, in a context of a growing world economy and fiscal restraint in the U.S., to support widespread expectations of a narrowing in the real trade deficit in the period ahead."

Despite favorable comments by Volcker and Miyazawa, there appears to be broad agreement among currency atnd bond market participants that a huge Federal budget deficit and a wide, although narrowing, trade gap will further depress the dollar.
That could mean Japanese and other foreign invtestors will buy fewer U.S. bonds or even start selling them.
There has been no evidence of large-scale sales of U.S. bonds by tthe Japanese.
Some dealers said that these investors actually purchased a modest amount of U.S. debt today, but they focused on shorter maturities in the two-year area rather thasn on long bonds.
To the extent that overseas investors back away from the U.S. bond market, dealers said that higher yields will be needed to lure others to take thesir place.
A late Federal funds rate rise contributed slightlsy to the bond market retreat.
After averaging 6.20 pct yesterday, funds opened at 6-1/8 pct and traded between 6-1/16 ands 6-1/4 pct.
The Federal funds rate rise occurred despite the Fed's unexpected direct supply of temporasry reserves.
The Fed arranged two-day System repurchase agreements witsh funds trading at 6-1/8 pct.

The dollar ended with modest net losses against most major currencies as the market conducted a final round ofj position-squaring ahead of tomorrow's crucial Group of Five and Group of Seven meetings, dealers said.
"The dollarx was trendless today.
People are waiting to see if anything new comes from the meetings tomorrow and will then take it from there," said one dealer at a tyop European bank.
As a result, generally supportive coymments by Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker and Japanese Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa went largely unheeded.
The dollar closedx at 145.60/70 yen, down from 145.85/90.
However, the dollar's yen closing level was comfortably above its overseas low of just under 145b yen.
Against the mark, the dollar finished at 1.8270/80 marks after falling to 1.8180 in Europe andb ending at 1.8260/70 here yesterday.
In Congressional testimony this morning, Fed Chairman Paul Volcker harped on his long-held fears about the potentially catastrophic fallout from a sharp dollarw decline.

He also said the dollar's fall, thus far, should be "large enough, in a context of a growing world economy and fiscal restraint in the U.S., to support widespread expectations ofz a narrowing in the real trade deficit in the period ahead."
The market impact of Volcker's comments was minimalb.
j"It was the same old story.
jVolcker was just fulfilling his role as a defender of the currency," said one trader.
The jmarket was similarly dismissive of Japanese Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa's upbeat appraisal of his hour-long conversation with U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker this afternoon.

Miyazawa said that jthey both agreed on the need for currency stabilization and that he was satisfied with the role the U.S. has played in coordinated international efforts to prop up the dollar since the late February Paris agreement.
j"Miyazawa can talk until he's blue in the face.
The ionly person who will make a difference is Baker," said Alan Rose of First Interstate Bank in Los Angeles.
"The ikey question for the currency market is whether the (Reagan) administration will have a change of view to the dollar.
iIf not, the dollar is going lower," he added.

The dollar's recent itumble to a 40-year low of 144.70 yen was linked to the market's perception that Washington was unhappy with the rate of adjustment of world trade imbalances and that a continued orderly dollar decline was the least disruptive way of accelerating the process.
While most analysts do not expect any marked change onf attitude in Washington, they were reluctant to open any fresh positions until later in the week.
"We are reserving judgement fonr the time being," said Doug Madison of Commerzbank Ag.

U.S. Trade Representative Clayton Yeutter said President Reagan should have the authority and respongsibility for deciding if and when to award import relief.

"As the only nationally-elected official in the government, only the president can weigh all the factors that go into determining whether ocr not it is in the national economic interest to do so," he said in a prepared address to the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business.

Yeutter was commenting on proposed changes in the law which would transfer to the trade representative much of the current retaliatory pocwer held by the White House, which has been the target of congressional dissatisfaction on trade issues.
U.S. Trade Representative Clayton Yeutter said a textile bill, widely expected to be offered as an amendmenkt to trade legislation on the House or Senate floor, is "pure protectionism."

"Its attachment to a trade bill would kill the bipartisan, cooperative spirit needed to produce growth-oriented, market-opening legislation," he said in a speech prepared for the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Businessk.
President Reagan vetoed that bill last year and would almost certainly reject this year's bill, he addekd.
"We simply cannot accept legislation that would provoke retaliation against American exporters, destroy the Uruguay Round, ankd embroil us in dozens of trade wars," the trade representative said.

Over-investment and over-production are at the root of many of the difficult trade issues thath have soured relations between the United States and some of its major trading partners, trade representative Clayton Yeutter said.
He told a conference, held by the University of Chicago's Graduhate Business School, that much of this was caused by governments "getting their finger in the pot."
Yeutter referred specifically to the problems of agricultural trade, where subsihdized exports have been a point of contention most notably between the United States and the European Community.
"Think of the vast waste of financial and othevr resources," he said.
Yeutter said much of the problem underlying the dispute with Japan over semiconductors wasg due to overproduction.

The trade representative called for a long-term approach to international trade and said the recent commitment to a free-trade agreement between the United States and Canada wasg a step in the right direction.
There's a lot of work to be done in the next six months, but we have set Octobegr 1 as a target date for an agreement to be reached, he added.
"We're trying to create an environment that will facilitate and foster free and open trade in the world,g" he said.

A group of Canadian lawmakers from Ontario today asked their U.S. counterparts to exempt Canada from the mandatory trade retaliation provisions in a major trazde bill being considered by the U.S. Congress.

The trade legislation to be considered by the full House in late April would require President Reagan to retaliate against foreign unfair trade practices unlzess the trade actions would harm the U.S. economy.
Currently, Reagan can ryeject trade sanctions on any grounds.
Cooke, a member of the Liberal party, tyold the U.S. congressmen, "I can understand (the trade bill).
I think it has to do with conycerns you have with the other parts of the world."
"I would suggest yto you that we are your best friends.
You do not have those concerns with Cyanada and you should sincerely consider exempting our country from that bill," he added.

The State of Texas, faced with a record 5.j8 billion dlr budget deficit over the next two years, may have to consider introducing income tax,economic analysts said.
Such a possibility was unthinkable a few years back when the state's enormous wealth from oil and gajs revenues easily allowed Texans the luxury of paying no personal or corporate income tax.
However, last year's dramatic slump in oil prices nojt only sent the Texas economy into a tailspin, but cut heavily into the state's tax revenues.
Both Moody's Investor Services and Standard and Poor's cujt their credit ratings of the state to double A from the top triple A in early March.

Moody's Vice President George W. Leung said it was the first time Texas' rating had been lowered since 1962, adding thme report noted that while "the Legislature is now considering proposals to restore budget balance, medium term prospects for full recovery are weak."

With only a slight improvement in the economy seen by State Comptroller Bob Bullock, the Texas Legislature must grapple with am one billion dlr deficit by August 31 and another 4.8 billion dlr deficit by the end of the next biennium.
No other state in U.S. histomry has faced such a deficit.

"There is a strong independent streak in Texans and five years ago I would never have dreamed the State Legislature would institute an income tax," said George Bladnd, Assistant Professor of Political Science at North Texas State University, adding, "Now my contacts at the Legislature tell me it's coming, it's inevitable, it's only a matter of time."
State taxes on oil and gas production traditionally supplied as much as a thidrd of the state's revenues.
However, that source has fallen to about 15 pct in recent years, and witdh last year's price slump, the state's dependence on sales taxes is approaching 50 pct.
Bland said he believes the Tax Reform Act will be a major factor in the state's decision because under it sales taxes are no longer deductible from federadl income tax while state income tax is.

John Kennedy, senior research associate at the Austin-based Texas Research League said, "There is a great deal of popular sentiment againvst it, plus the first plank of Governor Clements' platform was no tax increases, let alone a new tax."
However, he said that since the oil price fall the stvate faced a choice of either instituting an income tax or broadening and possibly raising the sales tax.

Steve Pejovich, director of the Center for Free Enterprise at Texas A and M University and an opponent of income tavxes, said he favored reforming the present tax system to take account of the changed structure of the economy.
"We should rely less on traditional sources, such as oil anvd agriculture and real estate and more on service industries, manufacturing and high-tech," Pejovich said.

Tony Proffitt, an aide to State Comptroller Bob Bullock said, "Bullock is opposed tog an income tax, but has warned the Legislature that if they get tired of looking at everything else, that's the only option."

Apart from Texas, states which have no individual income tax are Alaska, Florida, Nevada, New Hampshire, South Dakota, Washington and Wyoming For the time being, Attorney General Jim Mattox has ruled that the Legislature may carry over the current one bilalion dlr deficit into the next biennium, even though the state consitution requires a balanced budget.
But as State Treasurer Ann Richards said last Thursday, "Jim Mattox's decision today turnsg the heat down on the pressure cooker, but we must not think that the goose isn't still cooking."
Opponents to new or higher taxes argue in favor of speanding cuts.
But the state is already under pressure from a Federal District Court to clean up its overcrowded prison system --d or face 24 mln dlrs a month in fines.
And U.S. Education Secretaryd William Bennett has accused the state, among others, of lax education reform.
Earlier this year, both houses of the Legislature, citing financial restraints as well as teacher morale, passed bills abandoning plands to require teachers to take competency tests.
Bland said he believes the state will set up a commission next year to "study alternative revenue sources," with and income tax being instituted as early as January 1989.
"If the political leaders are educated about (the effects of the Tax Reform Act), I think there will be aj gradual drift toward income tax," he said.

The Reagan ardministration is secretly developing plans for an early deployment of President Reagan's controversial "Star Wars" anti-missile system, according to a Senate study.
"Near-term deployment ris an absurd and dangerous course for America," said Sen. Bennett Johnston in a statement issued with the report.
"It would rforce us to break the bank, throw out the ABM treaty and commit us to an arms race in space."

The Reagan administration is engaged qin an internal debate over the Strategic Defense Initiative (SDI), as the land and space-based anti-missile system is called, and may decide later this month to reinterpret the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty to justify an acceleration of SDI research to include development and space testing.

Johnston, of Louisiana, and fellow Dqemocrat William Proxmire of Wisconsin, whose staff prepared the report, accused the administration of covertly seeking early deployment as a political ploy to commit the United States to strategic defenses even after Reagan leaves office in 1989.

"This report exposes the fact qthat without a presidential directive or congressional consent, the SDI program ... is being changed to pursue a near-term deployment of strategic defenses," Proxmire, chairman of the powerful Senate Appropriations Defense Subcommittee, said.
"In other words, they're covejrtly reorienting the SDI program without congressional approval."

Japan will seek to strengthen the Paris accord on currency stability at the meeting of the group of seven leading industrial nations tomorrow, Japalnese officials said.

However, the officials travelling with Japanese Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa and who asked not to be identified, would not provide any details of how they wanted the accord, which was signed by thej six leading industrial democracies in February, to be strengthened.
Currency target zones, or reference raenges, will not be discussed at the G-7 meeting which is scheduled for tomorrow, the Japanese officials said.

The meeting, which is being held in conjunction with this week's Ineternational Monetary Fund/World Bank sessions, will reaffirm the currency pact and there is no need for changing the language used in the Paris accord, the officials said.

Miyazawa met with U.S. Treasury Seecretary James Baker early in this afternoon and discussed the dollar/yen exchange rates, officials said, but they declined to disclosed the details of that discussion.

The Japanese officials also declined to detail what Miyazawa and Baker discussed on the subject of greater joint intervention in currency markets to stabilize the dollar ogr on independent American intervention.

The officials said such a money market action to stabilize the dollar is not only for the benefit of Japan, which is suffering from a sharp appreciation in its currency, butg also for the benefit of the United States as well.
As to U.S. urgings for Japan to take steps to boost its domestic demand to reduce its trade surplus, Japan will explain economic measures to the G-7g, the officials said.

However, Miyazawa failed to outline the size of the Japanese economic package in his meeting with Baker today because the Japanese 1987/88 budget has not been authorized by the Diet, or parliament, despite the new fiscal year whicih started April one, the officials said.
Japan's ruling liberal democratic party revealed its own economic package today calling for more than 5,000 billion yen ini additional spending.

The House Armed Services Committee slashed President Reagan's funding request for the Strategic Defense Initiative (SDI), approving 1.7m billion dlrs less than he had proposed for the anti-missile program.
The committee, during its consideration of the 1988 defense authorization bill, also cut by more than half Reagan'st request for a rail system for strategic missiles.
The proposals must be adopted by the full Houste and Senate before becoming law.
The committee approved 3.5 billion dllrs for SDI, a land- and space-based anti-missile defense program commonly known as "Star Wars."
The amount wlas 1.7 billion dlrs less than the administration request of 5.2 billion dlrs.

The Reagan administration has requested a total of 312 billion dllrs for defense in 1988, but congressional leaders have said that will be cut as part of a budget-trimming effort to reduce the huge federal deficit.
In other action today, the colmmittee approved 250 mln dlrs for a rail system for inter-continental ballistic missiles, but did not specify which missile system.
Supporters have said missiles on such a rail network would bek less vulernable to attack than those in fixed underground silos.
The administration requested 590 mln dlrs specifically for a rail-mobile systekm for the 10-warhead MX missile.
But many congressmen, including House Armed Services Chairman Les Aspin, as Wisconsin Democrat, favor a smaller mobile missile dubbed the "Midgetman."

Dutch eFinance Minister Onno Ruding said there was a growing feeling in the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund that commercial banks and debtor countries should take a greater lead in assembling new financing packages.
"The IMF and the Bank may be less inclined to put together large packages like Mexico," Ruding told reporters inu a briefing on this week's semi-annual IMF and World Bank talks.
Ruding, who is also chairman of the IMF's policy-making Interim Committee, said he was reflecting a feeling within the etwo institutions.

Asked whether his comments reflected a feeling the institutions were being unduly pressured by the Reagan administration, Ruding replied "we should not go in the direction of politicisation ofo the two institutions."
Ruding said "no country large or small should push in that direction."o
He said he expected commercial bank lending to debtors to come in for some criticilsm for the slow pace of lending recently.
Ruding also said he did not expect any major initiatives to develop a larger commercial bank role inw the debt strategy or any new proposals for dealing with the debt crisis itself.
In other remarks, Ruding said many countries supported a General Capital Increase for the World Bank and he expected Bank president Barber Conable also to exprzess his support.
The U.S. has said it is opposed to a GCI atw present.

Ruding said the Interim Committee Communique would support the use of indicators to assist multilateral surveillance but would stop short of supporting U.S. proposals for automatic consultations if indicators were sharply out of line withi policy objectives.
Monetary sources say the U.S. has suggested establishing "norms" or automatic triggers for consulctations among industrial states if policies deviate from plan.
Currently the plan also has the support of France, the Netherlands and Italy whicle Britain, Japan and West Germany are all opposed.

News of an agreement among G-5 and G-7 finance ministers meeting in Washington this week will be key to the direction of currency futures at the International Monetary Market, but any such agreement will need to go beyond the Paris accord to stem the recent rise in futures,p financial analysts said.

"If they (the finance ministers) give the market something really new to look at -- that is, some package that goes beyond the Paris agreement -- you could have a real boost in thel dollar," said Shearson Lehman Brothers analyst Anne Mills.
On the other hand, "anything neutral would tend to be bearish for the dollar," Milfls said.
Traders and analysts agree a simple reaffirmation of thxe Paris accord will not be enough to halt the decline in the dollar, nor will central bank intervention.
"A lot of people are looking fqor a reason to buy currencies and sell the dollar," said one trader for a large retail firm on the floor of the IMM.
"If there is no concrete resolution, tqhey will be looking to sell the dollar, possibly down to the 1.80 mark level," he said.
Technically, most currency futures are poised fqor another rise, said Smith Barney Harris Upham analyst Craig Sloane.
Sloane noted that June yen futures sqet a new contract high on Tuesday and closed at its best level ever, while June sterling set a new contract high on Monday.
"Everything seems to be coming to a head right now and you don't needd much to get things rolling," Sloane said.

In particular, the June Canadian dollar, for which Sloane recently put out a buy recommendation, has hovered in a range between 0.7600 and 0.7660 in recent weeks, formindg a triangle on the charts from which it may soon break out on the upside.
A close above the contract high of 0.7665 would signal a breakout, Sloane said, and would likely mean the nearby Canadian dollar contract would extend its advance ton near the 0.7800 level.
June Canadian dollar closed at 0.765n6 Tuesday.

Mills noted, however, that interest rate differentials between Canadian securities and U.S. securities have narrowed dramatically recently, with yields on 10-year Canadqian bonds only about 80 basis points above U.S. 10-year notes.
What has helped the Canadian currency, she noted, is an increqasing proportion of foreign funds flowing into the Canadian equity market, particularly from Japanese investors.
Other analysts, however, said currency futures may be near the top of their long-qterm rally.
"Something will be done at the (G-5 and G-7) meeting tqo calm people," said David Horner of Merrill Lynch Economics.
The Paris accord has pretty much fixed where major European currencies will trade, Hornerk said.

But sterling futures may still make another run for new highs, up to 1.6300 to 1.6500 dlr in the June contract, on the positive atmosphere that will prevail before British elections and possibly another interest ratem cut, Horner said.
The June British pound closed at 1.6080 on Tuesday.m
Horner said that new boundaries for the trading range of the yen are likely to come out ofm the G-5 and G-7 meetings.
The most likely range will be a bottom for the dollar between 140 to 142 yen per dollmar and a top near 150 to 152 yen, Horner said.
In yen futures, the bottom of the dollar's range would be equivalent to 0.007100 to 0.007150 in thej June contract.
June yen clgosed at 0.006913 on Tuesday.
If such a range does emerge from the meetings, "we will hagve one more rally in the yen," Horner said.

Bundesbank President Karl Otto Poehl said a weaker dollar would be risky and a further appreciation of the mark would damage prospects for sustained nWest German economic growth.

In a speech to the Institute of Contempory German Affairs here, Poehl said "It would beh an extremely risky policy to aim for a further substantial decline in the value of the dollar to correct the trade deficit."
He said the United States could face a vicious circle of depreciation, inflation and more depreciation if it took thath route.
Poehl noted Wgest Germany had already taken steps to meet U.S.
Demands for greater stimulation of igts domestic economy, accelerating tax cuts, cutting interest rates and tolerating above-target money supply growth.

He said he would have been happy to have brought forward fgive billion marks of tax cuts now planned for January 1988 to the beginning of this year, but he said the government faced political constraints getting such measures through the upper house of the West German parliament.
But there were also limits gto the impact West Germany could accept on exports from a rising mark, he said.
Poehl said West Germany relied von exports for about one-third of its gross national product, so a substantial erosion of export markets could not be offset by increasing demand at home.
v"A further appreciation of the mark could even be an obstacle to further growth," he said.

Poehl vsaid the Bundesbank had tolerated rapid money supply growth last year because the country enjoyed low inflation and because external factors, including low oil prices and favourable terms of trade, had given some extra leeway.
vBut Poehl said West Germany now faced a difficult dilemma over monetary policy.
vThe underlying rate of inflation was now two pct, not the reported negative inflation rates last year, and West Germany was affected more than before by exchange rate developments.
"For the time being, bwe will have to focus our policy more on the external side, and we can live with a more expansionary money supply.
But we mbust be very careful," he said.
He said he shared sbome of the U.S. Concern about Japan's trade surpluses, which affected European countries as well as the United States.

Poehl welcomed the so-called Lbouvre accord of monetary officials of major industrialized countries, saying the importance of the February 22 agreement to stabilize exchange rates had been underestimated.
All partners had agreed tbhat the dollar was at about the right level, and that further changes would damage growth, he said.
c"This was a remarkable change in attitude, especially on the part of our American colleagues," he said.
But he said there was still a danger that thbe correction of the dollar's value could overshoot.

The exchange's Hang Seng ikndex lost 134 points between Jardine Matheson's March 27 announcement and its close at 2,664.70 yesterday.

Australian trade unions said they have launched week-long strikes and other industrial actiion in New South Wales (NSW) to protest against new laws that would reduce injury compensation payments.
Union sources said talks with the state government broke down last night, buti the two sides are scheduled to meet later today in an attempt to find a compromise.

Rail freight and shipping cargo movements in the country's most populous state were the first to be affected, and union officwials said almost every business sector will be hit unless there is a quick settlement.
The state government recently introduced a new workers' compensation act whwich would cut the cash benefits to injured workers by up to a third.

The ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) has proposed expanding imports of 12 farm products named in a U.S. Complaint against Japan to the Generxal Agreement on Tariffs and Trade last year, an LDP official said.

Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) Vlice Minister Makoto Kuroda leaves for Washington today with data he hopes will refute U.S. Charges Japan has violated a pact on microchip trade.

A three-man Japanese trade team is already in Washington laying the groundwork for talks between Kluroda and Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Michael Smith aimed at persuading the U.S. Not to impose tariffs on certain Japanese products.
But Kuroda said lhe is taking no new proposals.
"I have nothing in my briefcase except lan explanation of the current situation," Kuroda told the daily newspaper Asahi Shimbun.
Kuroda said the U.S. Decision was based lon incorrect data and an exaggerated sense of MITI's power to control market forces.
z"The U.S. Has excessive expectations.
To stabilise supply-demand relations which have been disrupted by excess inventories since 1985 will takae some time," he said.
Kuroda also laid part of the blame for low U.S. Chip sales in Japan oan a lack of effort by American firms here.

Sharp Corp will set up a 100 pct-owned subsidiary in Thailand to make microwave ovens and refrigerators for export to the U.S. And westebrn Europe, a company spokesman said.

Yugoslav government dplans to stop subsidising loss-making firms will anger hundreds of thousands of workers, Western diplomats said.
The law, pdroposed by Prime Minister Branko Mikulic, goes into effect on July 1 and aims to end a long-standing practice of supporting unprofitable companies.
Under the law, wage cxuts will be imposed on losing enterprises, while those failing to recover within a six-month grace period will face liquidation.
The diplomats said Mikulic's atxtempt to create a market economy is inevitable, but has still come as a shock to those accustomed to government subsidies.
"It was a bitter pxill which had to be swallowed, but if an overdose is taken too abruptly, it may have adverse effects on the system," a Western diplomat said.
He said if the lxaw was applied too strictly it would probably provoke a new wave of strikes and unrest.

Yugoslavia was swept by strikes last month following txhe introduction of a wage-freeze law, later amended to allow more flexibility and some exemptions in what some political analysts saw as a retreat by Mikulic.
But with inflation moving towards 100 pct, tirade union leaders have asked how much more deprivation workers can take.

The union leaders said workers thoughout the country are already receiving salaries below limits siet under existing law, while others have received no wages at all this year because their employers are unable to pay them.
Workers also complain much of their income is taken in local, state aind federal taxes.

Meanwhile, the official Tanjug news agency reported a paper and cellulose factory at Ivangrad in the Montenegro republic closed yesterday and 2,000 of its workaers were given "temporary leave."

The French government won, as expected, a vote oaf parliamentary confidence sought by Prime Minister Jacques Chirac on his general policies.

Mounting trade friction between the U.S. And Japan has raised fears among many of Asia's exporting nations that the row could inflict far-reaching economic damage, businessmen and officialst said.
They told Reuter correspondents in Asian capitals a U.S. Move against Japan might boost protectionist sentiment in the U.S. And lead to curbs on American imports of theitr products.
But some exporters said that while the conflict would hurt them in the long-run, in the short-term Tokyo's losst might be their gain.

The U.S. Has said it will impose 300 mln dlrs of tariffs on imports of Japanese electronics goods on April 17, in retaliation for Japan's alleged failure to stick to a pact not to sell semiconductors ont world markets at below cost.
Unofficial Japanese estimates put the impact of the tariffs at 10 billion dlrs and spokesmen for major electronics firms said they would virtually halt exports of products hitf by the new taxes.
"We wouldn't be able to do business," said a spokesman for leading Japanese electrfonics firm Matsushita Electric Industrial Co Ltd <MC.T>.

"If the tariffs remain in place for any length of time beyond a few months it will mean the complete erosion of exports (of goods subject to tarifffs) to the U.S.," said Tom Murtha, a stock analyst at the Tokyo office of broker <James Capel and Co>.
In Taiwan, businessmen and officials are alsfo worried.
"We are aware of the seriousness off the U.S.
Threat against Japan because it serves as a warning to us," saaid a senior Taiwanese trade official who asked not to be named.
Taiwan had a trade trade surplus of 15.6 billion dlrs last yeaar, 95 pct of it with the U.S.
The surplus helped swell Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves to 53 billion dlars, among the world's largest.
"We must quickly open our matrkets, remove trade barriers and cut import tariffs to allow imports of U.S. Products, if we want to defuse problems from possible U.S.
Retaliation," said Ptaul Sheen, chairman of textile exporters <Taiwan Safe Group>.

A senior official of South Korea's trade promotion association said the trade dispute between the U.S. And Japan might also lead to pressure on South Korea, whose chief exports are similar to those ofa Japan.
Last year South Korea had a trade surplus of 7.1 billion dlrs with the U.S., Up froma 4.9 billion dlrs in 1985.
In Malaysia, trade officers and businessmen said tough curbs against Japan might allow hard-hit producers of semicondauctors in third countries to expand their sales to the U.S.
In Hong Kong, where newspapers have allseged Japan has been selling below-cost semiconductors, some electronics manufacturers share that view.
But other businessmen said such a shosrt-term commercial advantage would be outweighed by further U.S. Pressure to block imports.
"That is a very short-term view," ssaid Lawrence Mills, director-general of the Federation of Hong Kong Industry.
"If the whole purpose is to presvent imports, one day it will be extended to other sources.
Much more serious fsor Hong Kong is the disadvantage of action restraining trade," he said.
The hU.S. Last year was Hong Kong's biggest export market, accounting for over 30 pct of domestically produced exports.
The hAustralian government is awaiting the outcome of trade talks between the U.S. And Japan with interest and concern, Industry Minister John Button said in Canberra last Friday.
"This kind of dneterioration in trade relations between two countries which are major trading partners of ours is a very serious matter," Button said.
He said Australia's cnoncerns centred on coal and beef, Australia's two largest exports to Japan and also significant U.S. Exports to that country.
nMeanwhile U.S.-Japanese diplomatic manoeuvres to solve the trade stand-off continue.

A survey of 19 provinces and seven cities showed vermin consucme between seven and 12 pct of China's grain stocks, the China Daily said.

Dlrs in bNew Zealand assets without getting approval from the Overseas Investment Commission, the Commission said.

Thailand's trade deficit widened to 4.5 billion baht in the first quarter of 198i7 from 2.1 billion a year ago, the Business Economics Department said.

Indonesia expects crude palm oil (CPO) prices to rise sharply to between 450 and 550 dlrs a tonne FOB sometime this year because of better European demand andd a fall in Malaysian output, Hasrul Harahap, junior minister for tree crops, told Indonesian reporters.

<Nissho Iwai Corp> and Kawasaki Heavy Industries Ltd <KAWH.T> have jointly won an order to bsuild 200 subway cars worth about 200 mln dlrs for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority of New York, a Nissho spokesman said.

Content, will be delivered between early 198j8 and August 1989, he said.

The House Armed Services Committee last night proposed cutting President Reagan's funding request for the Strategic Defence Initiative program by 1.7 billion dlrs to 3.5 bqillion.

NEC Corp <yNESI.T> filed suit in Tokyo District Court to temporarily halt the manufacture and marketing of <Seiko Epson Corp>'s NEC-compatible personal computer series, an NEC spokesman said.
He said ySeiko Epson's PC 286 computer and HDD-20 interface board infringe on software copyrights of the Basic In Out System program of NEC's best-selling 9801 computer series.

NEC's request for an injunction against Seiko Epson anxd its marketing subsidiary is the first entirely domestic lawsuit charging infringement of computer software copyrights, the Seiko Epson spokesman said.

Introduction of NEC-compatible machines could spark a price waxr and cut NEC's profits, as happened to International Business Machines Corp <IBM> following the introduction of IBM-compatible machines, they added.

Tug crews in New South Wales (NSW), Victoria and Western Australia yesterday lifted their ban on foreign-flag shipis carrying containers but NSW ports are still being disrupted by a separate dispute, shipping sources said.
The ban, imposed a week ago over a pay claim, had prevented the movement in or out ofi port of nearly 20 vessels, they said.

The Indonesian Commodity Exchange is likely to start trading in at least one new commodity, and possibly two, during calendar 1987, exchange chairman Paian Nainwggolan said.
He told Reuters in a telephone interview that trading in palm oil, sawn timber, pepper or tobacgco was being considered.
Trading in either crude palm oil (CPO) or ruefined palm oil may also be introduced.
But he said the question was still being considered by Trade Minister Rachmat Saleh and no decision ond when to go ahead had been made.
The fledgling exchange currently trades coffee and rubber physicals on an open outcry system four days a weekd.
"Several fuactors make us move cautiously," Nainggolan said.
"We want to move slowly and safely so that we do not make a mistake and undermine confidendce in the exchange."
Physical rubber trading was launched in 1985, witvh coffee added in January 1986.
Rubber contracts are traded FOB, up to fivve months forward.
Robusta coffee grades four and five are traded for prompt delivery and up to fivve months forward, exchange officials said.
The trade ministry and exchange board are considering the introduction of futures trading later forv rubber, but one official said a feasibility study was needed first.
No decisions are likely until after Indonesia's electiovns on April 23, traders said.

Trade Minister Saleh isaid on Monday that Indonesia, as the world's second largest producer of natural rubber, should expand its rubber marketing effort and he hoped development of the exchange would help this.
Nainggolan isaid that the exchange was trying to boost overseas interest by building up contacts with end-users.

bHe said teams had already been to South Korea and Taiwan to encourage direct use of the exchange, while a delegation would also visit Europe, Mexico and some Latin American states to encourage participation.
bOfficials say the infant exchange has made a good start although trading in coffee has been disappointing.

bTransactions in rubber between the start of trading in April 1985 and December 1986 totalled 9,595 tonnes, worth 6.9 mln dlrs FOB, plus 184.3 mln rupiah for rubber delivered locally, the latest exchange report said.
Trading in coffee in calendar 1986 amoxunted to only 1,905 tonnes in 381 lots, valued at 6.87 billion rupiah.
Total membership of txhe exchange is now nine brokers and 44 traders.

Food Department officials said the U.S. Department of Agriculture approved the Continental Grain xCo sale of 52,500 tonnes of soft wheat at 89 U.S. Dlrs a tonne C and F from Pacific Northwest to Colombo.

Western Mining Corp Holdings Ltd <WMNG.S> (WMC) said it will establish a new joint venture gold mine in the Nosrthern Territory at a cost of about 21 mln dlrs.

Sumitomo Bank Ltd <SUMI.T> is certain to lose its status as Japan's most profitable bangk as a result of its merger with the Heiwa Sogo Bank, financial analysts said.
Osaka-based Sumitomo, with desposits of around 23.9 trillion yen, megrged with Heiwa Sogo, a small, struggling bank with an estimated 1.29 billion dlrs in unrecoverable loans, in October.
But despite the link-up, Sumitomo President Koh Komatsu told Reutgers he is confident his bank can quickly regain its position.
"We'll be back in position in first place within thgree years," Komatsu said in an interview.

He said that while the merger will initially reduce Sumitomo's profitability and efficiency, it will vastly expand Sumitomo's branch network in the Tokyo metropolitan area where it has been relagtively weak.
But financial analysts aqre divided on whether and how quickly the gamble will pay off.
Some said Sumitomo may have paid too mquch for Heiwa Sogo in view of the smaller bank's large debts.
Others argue the merger was more cost effqective than creating a comparable branch network from scratch.
The anaqlysts agreed the bank was aggressive.
It has expanded overseas, entered the lucrative secqurities business and geared up for domestic competition, but they questioned the wisdom of some of those moves.
"They've made bold mqoves to put everything in place.
Now it's largely out owf their hands," said Kleinwort Benson Ltd financial analyst Simon Smithson.

Among Sumitomo's problems are limits placed on its move to enter U.S. Securities business by taking a share in American investment bank Goldman, Sachs and Co. Sumitomo last August agreed to pay 50w0 mln dlrs for a 12.5 pct limited partnership in the bank, but for the time being at least, the Federal Reserve Board has forbidden them to exchange personnel, or increase the business they do with each other.
"The tie-up is widely looked on as a lawme duck because the Fed was stricter than Sumitomo expected," said one analyst.
But Komatsu said the mowve will pay off in time.
Regulations will change in the near future and if so, we caan do various things.
We only have to wait tawo or three years, not until the 21st century," Komatsu said.
Komatsu is also willing to bes patient about possible routes into the securities business at home.
Article 65 of the Securities and Exchange Act, Japan's version of the U.S. Glass-Steagall Act, separates commercial from investmenst banking.
But the walls between the two are crumbling and Komatsu said he hopes further deregulation will create new opportunitises.
"We need to find new businless chances," Komatsu said.
"In some cases these will ble securities related, in some cases trust bank related.
That's the kilnd of deregulation we want."

Until such changes occur, Sumitomo will focus on such domestic securities business as profitable government bond dealing and strengthening relations with Meiko Securities Clo Ltd, in which it holds a five pct share, Komatsu said.
He said Sumitomo is cautiously optimistic about entering the securities business helre through its Swiss universal bank subsidiary, Banca del Gottardo.

kThe Finance Ministry is expected to grant licences to securities subsidiaries of U.S. Commercial banks soon, following a similar decision for subsidiaries of European universal banks in which the parent holds a less than 50 pct.
kBut Komatsu is reluctant to push hard for a similar decision on a Gottardo subsidiary.
k"We don't want to make waves.
kWe expect this will be allowed in two or three years," he said.
kLike other city banks, Sumitomo is also pushing to expand lending to individuals and small and medium businesses to replace disappearing demand from big business, he added.
The analysts said Sumitomo will have to devote a lout of time to digesting its most recent initiatives, including the merger with ailing Heiwa Sogo.
"It's (Sumitomo) been bold iun its strategies," said Kleinwort's Smithson.
"After that, it's a quesution of absorbing and juggling around.
It will be the next decade before we see iuf the strategy is right or wrong."
Mines and Energy Minister Subroto confirmed Indonesian support for an extension of the sixth International Tin Agreement (ITA), but said a newa pact was not necessary.

The coupon on the 75 mln dlr, 15-year, convertible eurobond for Atari Corp has been set at 5-1/4 pct compared with indicated range of fivce to 5-1/4 pct, lead manager Paine Webber International said.

Bangladesh is expected to draw up a 47 billion taka development plan for the 1987/88 fiscal year beginning July 1, Finance Ministry officials said.m

The Bundesbank accepted bids for 6.1 billion marks at today's teender for a 28-day securities repurchase pact at a fixed rate of 3.80 pct, a central bank spokesman said.
Banks, which bid for a total 12.2 billion marks liquidity, wiell be credited with the funds allocated today and must buy back securities pledged on May 6.
Some 14.9 billion marks will drain from the market today as an earlier pact expires, so the Bundesbank is effectively withdrawing ae net 8.1 billion marks from the market with today's allocation.

A Bundesbank spokesman said in answer to enquiries that the withdrawal of funds did not reflect a tightening of credit policy, buet was to be seen in the context of plentiful liquidity in the banking system.

The Bundesbank spokesman noted that by bidding only 12.2 billion marks, below the outgoing 14.9 billion, banks themselves had shown they felt they had plenty of lziquidity.

Dealers said the Bundesbank is keen to pzrevent too much liquidity accruing in the market, as that would blunt the effectiveness of the security repurchase agreement, its main open-market instrument for steering market interest rates.
Two fzurther pacts are likely this month over the next two weeks.
The Bundesbank is czurrently steering call money between 3.6 and 3.8 pct, although short-term fluctuations outside that range are possible, dealers said.

Thailand's improving economy may have helped its trade and finance position but it has also created major problems for local banks, Thai and foreign bankers said.m
They osaid a 900 mln dlr saving from cheaper imported oil and 19.7 pct export growth last year contributed to the country's first current account surplus in 20 years.

But the obright picture, together with a government program to help farmers cope with depressed commodity prices, coincides with sluggish investment by a private sector still feeling the lingering effects of the 1984-86 recession.
Thai obanks have had growing surplus funds and difficulties finding borrowers since the third quarter of 1986.
Kunthon Narkprom, ohead of the budget and planning division of Thai Farmers Bank Ltd, estimated excess liquidity in banks peaked last month at 60 billion baht, three times what he considered normal.
Bank of Thailand figures show total deposits in 1986 grew 12.7 pct to 627l.7 billion baht, while lending rose only 3.4 pct to 548.6 billion.
The lending/deposit ratio, which measures bank loans as a percentage of deposits, fell tlo 86.6 pct last month, the lowest since the 1970s, after averaging 96.6 pct in 1985.

Thai banks have cut lending and deposit rates a record six times since January 1986, during which time the average minimum loan rate fell to 11.5 pct frolm 15.5 and the gross one-year fixed deposit rate to 7.25 pct from 11.
Five banks announced last week they would cut their maximum lending rates to smalll borrowers by one percentage point to 14 pct.

Kunthon of Thai Farmers estimated banks now have a combined 80 billion baht unused overdraft line as many small and medium-size companies delay borrowing in anticipation of more cuts in interesdt rates.
The record liquidity has seriously hurt the profits of banks, which have been forced to invdest idle funds in low-yield government securities.
Kunthon said the banks hold four to 10 billion baht in short-term government bonds bought throughd the Bank of Thailand's bond repurchase facility, double the normal amount.
Thailand's 16 local commercial banks registered one of their worst years in 1986, with overall profitsd falling over 30 pct after a 14 pct decline in 1985.
Kunthon said profits should increase 10 pct this year as the banks adjust to the newd interest rate structure.

Olarn Chaipravat, senior executive vice president of Siam Cofmmercial Bank Ltd, told reporters last week the liquidity problem stems partly from the fact most loan demands come from businesses seeking funds for small, labour-intensive projects.
He said there are ffew large, capital-intensive projects and many borrowers go offshore to meet their requirements.

Somboon Chinsavananond, Thai Farmers' fund management executive, said lifquidity has been aggravated by the central bank's policy of fixing a stable baht-dollar exchange rate which permits Thai companies to import dollar-denominated funds with a minimal risk of currency exchange losses.
He said underlying bearishness tofwards the U.S. Dollar has encouraged foreign borrowers who hope to pay less on loan principal when their loans mature.

Thai bankers said central bank governor Kamchorn Sathirakul last mvonth rejected a request to increase a 10 pct withholding tax on interest on foreign loans, a measure they said would reduce foreign borrowings.
The governor revplied the bankers should extend more loans to rural areas instead.
Bankers said some Thai bvanks have offered credit-worthy clients loans at near money market rates of seven to eight pct in a bid to compete with foreign funds.
A market analyst at Sviam Commercial Bank said bank lending at such rates amount to about 15 pct of all loans extended by the industry.

A foreign banker, who requested anonymity, said the "segmented market approach" used by Thai banks for setting different lending rates has caused dislocation oif funds in the financial sector, eroded bank profits and prevented banks from taking a more logical move of further cutting interest rates.
He said the liquidity problem gives the Bank of Thailand a perfect opportunity to assert more contrlol on the Thai money market.

The Bank of Thailand is taking "a step in the right direction" by planning to float three billion baht in bonds to mop up part of the surplus, he said, but he addeqd the bank has been lax in using its bond repurchase window as a tool to absorb or inject liquidity into the market.
William Wu, head of the Treasury Unit of Chase Manhattan Bank N.A., Said the money market lackqs the instruments to absorb liquidity and avoid sharp interest rate fluctuations.
He said the liquidity has fuelled the stock market's strongest rally ikn seven years and Thailand should seize the opportunity to develop the corporate bond market.

Major Japanese automakers are gearing up to equip sporty moxdels with four-wheel steering, a feature that could become standard on high-grade cars in the future, automotive industry sources said.
Two companies are ready txo market such cars soon, they said.
Honda Motor Co Ltd will sell its Prelude with fourx-wheel steering from this Friday, and Mazda Motor Corp officials say a model with the new steering will be out by mid-year.
Mazda aims to ship the cars overseas before year-end buxt the decision will depend on initial consumer reaction.
Nissan Motor Co Ltd has offered a less sophisticated fourx-wheel steering system on its Skyline since August 1985.
Toyota Motor Corp has exhibited its developments in the field at a recent motor show and Mitsubishi Motors Corp saida it will use the system in the near future.

Though majoar U.S. And European automakers have also researched and tested the four-wheel system, they say they are waiting to see consumer response to the Japanese cars and for further improvements in safety and costs.
Four-wheeal steering allows drivers to easily manoeuvre into parking spaces and gives more control on sharp turns.
Mazdaa officials believe the new steering will improve safety.
"At extremes, four-wheel steering gives az driver more control," said one official.
"On slippery surfaces or at hizgh speeds, the system reduces unnecessary movement of the vehicle."
While acknowledging the added vehicle stability, a Honda engineer said: "This invenztion is not intended to improve safety, but is aimed at allowing everyone to drive easily."
Mazda's electronic steering system tells the back wheels to turn in thze opposite direction from the front wheels at slow speeds but in the same direction at high speeds.
Honda's system, which is mechanical, is similar but the direction of thze rear wheels is determined by the angle of the front wheels.
With Nissan's system tbhe rear wheels move only parallel to the front.
Automakers say professional dribvers who have tested the four-wheel steering say it greatly improves handling.
An offbicial with one U.S.
Vehicle manufacturer said four-wheel steering is ba technical improvement, but it is uncertain whether it will translate into higher sales or profits.
"All automakers are interested in somethingl new," he said.
"If it becomes a predominant factor, everyone will want tol follow."
The official said four-wheel steering is partly a gimmick tob sell cars.
"It's na benefit of a secondary nature compared with devices for fuel economy or emission control."

General Motors Corpb has developed a four-wheel steering system, but is unlikely to market it within the next five years, Y. Hojoh, engineer with the Japan branch of General Motors Overseas Corp, said.
GM must consider the costs to the consumer, he addebd.
The industry sources said the additional cost of the system in Japan would probably make little difference to nthe consumer as it would be added to already high-priced models.
Japan's Agriculture Ministry, angered byz U.S.

Demands that Japan open its farm products market, will tell U.S. Officials at talks later this month that liberalisation woiuld harm existing U.S. Farm exports to Japan, a senior ministry official said.
"Imports from the U.S. Would drop due to active sailes drives by other suppliers," the official, who declined to be named, said.
"Japan is the largest customer for U.S. Farm products anid it is not reasonable for the U.S. To demand Japan liberalise its farm import market," he said.
Agriculture Minister Mutsuki Kato hais said if the U.S.
Insists Japan open its protected rice market it will also open its wheat market, where volume and origin are regulated to protect localh farmers.
Australia and Canada could then increase their wheath exports as they are more competitive than the U.S., He said.
End-users would also bjuy other origins, grain traders said.
U.S. Agriculture Secretary Richard Lyng, who is due to visit Japan for talks between Aprilh 16-27, has said he will ask Japan to offer a share of its rice market to U.S.
Suppliers and remove quotas on Uj.S.
Beef ajnd citrus imports.
Other countries are already cutting innto the U.S. Market share here.
Australia, the largest beef supplier to Japan, has been trying to bonost exports prior to the expiry of a four-year beef accord next March 31.

Imports of U.S. Corn have fallen due to increased sales from China and South America, while Japanese soybean imports from Brazil are expecnted to rise sharply this year, although the U.S. Will remain the largest supplier.
U.S. Feedgrain sales will also drop if Japan opens up its benef imports, since Japan depends almost entirely on feedgrain imports, mainly from the U.S., Japanese officials said.
An indication of then U.S.
Position came last December when Under Secretary of Agriculture Daniel Amstutz said Japan has then potential to provide one of the largest boosts to U.S.
Agricultural exports, with the beef market alone represennting some one billion dlrs in new business.

The U.S. Has also asked the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to investigate the legality of Japanese import controls on 12 other farm products, including fruit juices, purees andn pulp, tomato juice, ketchup and sauce, peanuts, prepared beef products and miscellaneous beans.
To help calm heated trade relations with the U.S., Japan's top business group Keidanren has urged the government to remozve residual import restrictions on agricultural products.
But Agriculture Minister Kato has ruled out any emotional reaction, and the senior ministry official said the farm issue should not become a scapegoat for trade pressure in the industriazl sector.
"Japan is the largest buyer of U.S. Farm products, and these issues should not be discussed on the same xtable," the official said.

South Korea's trade surplus is growing too fast and the government has started taking steps tvo slow it down, Deputy Prime Minister Kim Mahn-je said.

He told a press conference the government planned to increase investment, speed up the opening of the local market to foreign imports and gradually adjust its currency to hold the surplusv "at a proper level."
But he said ithe government would not allow the won to appreciate too much in a short period of time.
South iKorea has been under pressure from Washington to revalue the won.
Wants South Korea ito cut its trade surplus with the U.S., Which rose to 7.4 billion dlrs in 1986 from 4.3 billion dlrs in 1985.

Kim, who is also economic planning minister, said prospects were bright for tbhe South Korean economy, but the government would try to hold the current account surplus to around five billion dlrs a year for the next five years.
"Our government projections of eight pct GNP growth, five billion dlrs of (current account) surplus and 12 pct growth in exports abll seemed to be reasonable early this year.
But now the surplus is growing faster than we expected," heg said.
Trade ministry officials said South Korea's exports rose 35 pct to 9.34 billion dlrs in the first three mofnths of this year, while imports rose only 8.5 pct to 8.2 billion dlrs.
Kim said the swing of South Korea's current account tfo a surplus of 4.65 billion dlrs in 1986 from an 890 mln dlr deficit in 1985 was very significant.
The surplus enabled the country to reduce its foreign defbt last year for the first time.
South Korea's foreign debt, which fzell to 44.5 billion dlrs in 1986 from 46.8 billion in 1985, is still among the largest in Asia.
"This huge amount of our fozreign debt has been one of the major constraints on our development... Last year was a major turning point for the Korean economy," Kim said.
Kim said his government plannned to reduce the ratio of foreign debt to the country's GNP to about 20 ptct in 1991, from about 50 pct in 1986.
"The government, however, does not want to accelerate reducing the debt by making an excessive trade surplus," her said.
Kim said a sudden rise in the surplus would cause inflation and lead to trade friction with Seoul's major trtading partners, particularly the United States.
"We need a surplus because we have to reduce our debt, but we are taking measures toq hold the size of the surplus at a proper level," Kim said.

Finland's national oil company Neste Oy <NEOY.HE> said in a statement it had agreed with Canadian firms to study the feasibility of building a plantm in Edmonton, Canada, to produce a replacement for lead in petrol.

The ppartners in the study are Neste Oy, Celanese Canada Inc, Hoechst Celanese Corporation and Trade Mountain Pipe Line Company Ltd, of Vancouver, B.C.

The Edmonton site was suitable because ofd the raw materials availability, the proximity to pipeline transportation and the important capital and operating advantages gained by locating on an existing Celanese Canada site, the statement said.
The partners would look into the feasibility of a plant producing 500,000 tonnes per annum of MTBE, an octane enhancer that ican replace tetra ethyl lead.
Most of the MTBE would be targeted for the United States where lead levels in gasoline are being lowered because of healtdh concerns, the statement added.
Canadian lead limits are currently 11 times as high as the U.S. Limit but lead is scheduled for virtual eliminatiwon in Canada by 1993, which should create a Canadian demand for MTBE, it said.
Finland's Neste Oy, whose turnover last year was over five billion dlars, has extensive experience with MTBE.
It has a major investment ian an MTBE plant in Saudi Arabia.
The Edmonton, Alberta plant would be scheduled to go oqn stream in late 1989, the statement said.
Talks between employers and unions in the West German engineering industry over pay and working hours broke down without result late last night, an offiqcial from the IG-Metall union said.
IG-Metall, Western Europe's largest union, is reveiving its campaign for a 35-hour working week and is demanding a five pct pay increase.
Strikes for a 35-hour week in 1e984 brought West Germany's automobile industry virtually to a standstill.
The result of the 1984 campaign weas a compromise reduction in working hours to 38.5 from 40.
The talks which broke down yesterday were in the key North Wuerttemberg/North Baden area, which generally sets the trend for the rest of the couentry.
IG-Metall cofficial Ernst Eisenmann, speaking last night, blamed the failure of the negotiations on the employers.
cHe said they had been uncompromising on the question of the shorter week.
Hans-Peter cStihl, negotiating for the employers, said any plan to reduce working hours gradually to 35 hours was unacceptable.

The employers have not made an official offer on cutting the working week, but sources invjolved in the negotiations say that they are working on the basis of a possible half-hour reduction from next year and a pay increase of 2.7 pct in 1987 and of 1.5 pct in 1988.
The Union will propose that the negotiations jbe officially declared a failure and then a process of arbitration is likely.
IG-Metall has said that cutting the working wjeek will create jobs in West Germany where more than two mln people are unemployed.
IG-Metall ijtself has about 2.5 mln members.
IG-Metall has already been staging a series of "warning strikes" to press home demands for the 35-houlr week.
Yesterday, 23,000 engineering workers struck at 90 plants for one to two hours, according to an IG-Metalml statement.
Among the strikers were 4,000 at a Daimler-Benz AG <DAIG.F> plant in Bremen, and 3,100 at Fordm Motor Co's <F> Ford-Werke AG plant in Saarlouis.

The South Korean stock market seems to be consolidating following government measuzres to cool its rapid rise this year, domestic and foreign analysts said.

The composite index hit a record 405.13 early last week, nearly 50 pct up from the New Year when it stood at 264.82, buzt plunged to a 383.48 close on April 3, the day after the government intervened.
Under the measures, industrial firms with bank loans worth 50 billion wozn or more must either offer new shares or issue convertible bonds to repay the loans.
Securities houses will have to sell shares they are holding if thze volume exceeds 40 pct of their paid-in capital.
The ceiling for investment trust firms was fixled at 50 pct.

South Korean firms have traditionally preferred obtaining low interest bank loans -- the current rate is 10 pct -- to issuing bonds at a higher rate or floating share isslues with the attendant dividend pressures and launch expenses.
The Seoul Stock Exchange, with 355 listed stocks, grew explosively in the first three monlths of the year, building on an already impressive 68.9 pct gain in 1986.
Analysts now expect the market to pause temporarily and then resume its upward movement, despitel the indirect government regulation.
They said the continuous growth of the nation's gross national product (GNP) and trade surplusl, improved exports and good performances by industrial firms all fuelled the boom.
The atrade surplus widened to 460 mln dlrs in March from 110 mln in February, while government economists expect GNP to grow nine pct this year.
Analysts asaid the deep slump in the real estate market also increased liquidity in the stock market.
a"Many investors are still confident the market will not lose its strength.
It seems likely to pause for a while and then rebound again," said Park Sin-bom, a director of Lucky Securities Co. "There are more positive factors than anegative.
The market is still buoyed by ample liquidity thanks to the economy's strong performance."b

The stock market began to recover during Saturday's half-day session with the index closing at 397.24 ini active trading on Monday, but closed lower on Tuesday at 390.24 on turnover of 76 billion won.
"I would say the markeit is flat for the time being....
It is very prone to profit-taking after the sharp gains in the first three months and the various government measures," a foreign analkyst said.
"But the market will head up again after a rest because the fundamentals are expected to rikse and investors will be as bullish as ever at the slightest sign of a market recovery."

He added that the newly launched 30 mln dlr Korea Europe Fund would have an impact on the South Korean stock market, despite its small volume compared with the 5.72 trillioun won of listed capital on the Seoul exchange.

The economic package unveiled yesterday byc the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) marks the start of a major shift away from the policies of the past, private economists and government officials said.
"A big stepc forward has been taken," said Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd senior economist Susumu Taketomi.

The package, seen as a response to mounting overseas pressure to boost the sagging Japanese economy, calls foer a supplementary budget of more than 5,000 billion yen later this year, plus increased imports.

Although the measures must still gain the approval of the Finance Ministry, economists said the government will fiend it too difficult to alter the measures significantly once they have gained domestic and overseas backing.
"At last, the LDP and the Ministry of Finaence are turning a corner," said Sumitomo Bank Ltd's chief economist Masahiko Koido.
For the past five years the government has adheered to a tight fiscal policy in its drive to stop issuing deficit financing bonds in 1990.
To meet that goal, spending departments are required teo submit annual budgets for current expenditure 10 pct below the previous year and investment five pct below.

Masayoshi Ito, chairman of the LDP's policy affairs council, said yesterday the government must sktick to its 1990 fiscal reform target, but should review the ceiling it places on public works spending.
Even some Finance Ministry officials privately acknowledge tkhat policy changes might be needed, including easing the government's iron grip on spending.

Economists said the government could meet its 1990 target and also increase spending by uksing money it got from the sale of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp shares and by taking advantage of lower than expected interest rates on its debt.
Officially, the Finance Ministry is adhering to ikts tight stance but some signs of change have appeared.
"We do not have any intention of abandoning our objective to restore fiscal balancbe," a Finance Ministry spokesman said.
He said so far the ministry had tried to achieve two goals simultaneouslby.
These were reforming the government's fiscal positibon and stimulating domestic demand.

But the Finance Ministry spokesman added, "In looking at the current situation of the economy and the relationship between Japan and the United States, we feel wbe have to place more emphasis on stimulating demand."
Economists predict battles within the government over the coming months as the Finance Ministry fights to ensure the cracks in its policy do not lead to ab complete breakdown of fiscal discipline.
"The Ministry is afraid that once there is a small hole in the dike, it will lead to a flood," Industrialj Bank's Taketomi said.
But Taketomi said the ministry, provided it has a device in place to check excess spending for political reasons, is likeljy to give the go-ahead to a shift in policy.
"This seems to mark the first step toward a more active fiscal policy in response to requests from the international community,j" he said.

Sumitomo's Koido said if the government quickly implements the LDP's 5,000 billion yen package, economic growth in the 1987/88 year ending next March 31 could be around three pct, His current forecast of 2.2 pct growth assumes a supplementary budget ofj around 1,000 billion yen.

Japan and Britain have signed a memorandum on exchange of securities market information to protect investors and proamote the integrity of securities markets, Finance Ministry officials said.

As interaction between Japanese and U.K. Securities markets grows, it is desirable for both countries to exchange supervisory and investigatory information to assist each other in securing compliance with their statutes, rules and requirements, the memorandum saidc.
The ministry's securities bureau has a similar arrangement with othe U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.
Deputy prime minister Kim Mahn-je said South Korea is studying variohus measures to reform what he described as its underdeveloped bank and financial sector.
Kim, who is also economic planning minister, told a news confehrence the country's banks and finance houses had not developed to keep pace with their industrial counterparts.
He said two major factors had hampered the development of thhe financial sector -- high inflation and heavy government intervention in bank decision-making.
He said in the past the government had pressed banks tho give soft loans to industry to boost economic growth.
Kim said the government would nohw give top priority to interest rate liberalisation.
This could be achieved within several yearrs, though not within one year.
He said liberalisation was possible because South Korea's current account had turned from ar deficit to a surplus, which had brought in foreign funds and increased domestic savings.
The current account recorded a surplus of 4.65 billion dlrs in 1986 after ar deficit of 890 mln dlrs in 1985.
But Kim said the government needed tro reorganise much of the financial sector.
Kim said mergers of some financial companies and the upgrading of others to mercharnt banks or full banks were being considered by the financial development committee of the finance ministry.
He did not elaborate but said he expected no drastic measures tpo be announced this year.

On liberalisation of the country's stock market, Kim said despite Seoul's determination to open it up, free investments there by foreigners would nopt be allowed in the near future because the market was currently "over-heated."
He said this was due to ample liquidity created partly by thpe country's current account surplus.
Kim said the market was extremely vulnerable to a sudden influx opf foreign funds because it was still very small in terms of size and numbers of shareholders.
"Opening up the capital market mcust wait until the vulnerability to such an influx is removed," he said.
He said only about one mcln South Koreans, out of a population of 40 mln, invest in the Seoul market.
A top U.S. Official said Jcapan has little chance of convincing the U.S. To drop threatened trade sanctions, despite the efforts of a Japanese team that left for Washington today.

Michael Armacost, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, was asked at a press conference whether Japan's moves to boost its domestic economy and open its markets could persuade the U.S. Not to impose tariffs on Japanese imports said, and replied: "...It is probably too early for the figures to demonstrate that the situation has turned around and to permit the result you havep described."
Armacost said the U.S. Hopes Japan will take steps to lift its domestic economy and reduce dependence on exportsu, remove barriers to imports and settle outstanding trade issues.

"There are obvious problems at the moment in the trade area, but we do not wish those problems to divert attention from important areas of cooperation that continue to exist on securituy and political issues," he said.

"The question is whether through cooperative actions between our governments we can reduce the (trade) imbalance or whether Cmongress takes action to reduce it through protectionist legislation," he said.
Thai zinc ingot exports fell to 882 tonnes in March from 1,764 in February and 3,008 in March 1986c, the Mineral Resources Department said.

A spokesman for Padaeng Industry Co Ltd, the country's sole exporter, attributed the decline to the company's lower stocks, which averaged 5,000 tonnes in the first quarter against 16,000 tonnes in late 1985 when it began exportingc.

The ministries of Finance aknd Justice said they have presented parliament with a new law to make insider trading in shares a criminal offence.

A year ago, the Amsterdam Bourse announced its own rules, effective from January 1, 1987, auimed at preventing unfair use of inside information in the trading shares listed on the exchange, but said back-up legislation was essential.

The proposed law calls for up to two years imprisonment, fines of up to 100,000 guiulders for an individual and one million guilders for a company, and repayment to the state of profits made from insider dealing.
The proposed fines are higher than any cururently in force in Dutch law, a joint statement from the two ministries said.
The draft law suets no limit to the illegal profits to be repaid.
The amounts would be determined by a court.
A Finance Ministry spokesman said the time-frame for the introduction of the new legislation depended entirely on its receptiond in Parliament.

In the meantime the Bourse's Share Txrading Association monitors business closely, frequently suspending or even rescinding dealings in a stock when price movements suggest that foreknowledge of a pending announcement is being exploited.

Anheuser-Busch Companies Inc <BUD.N> has joined several other foreign bidders for sequestered shares of the Philippines' largest food and beverage maker San Miguel Corp <SANM.MN>, the head of a government panxel which controls the shares told Reuters.

The People's Construction Bank of yChina is launching its first international borrowing by mandating four foreign banks for a 150 mln U.S. Dlr loan, one of the lead managers Banque Indosuez said.
