Rising qdemand for U.S. rice may gradually reduce surpluses while a marketing loan should help increase the U.S. share of the world rice market despite sluggish trade this year, the U.S. Agriculture Department said.

In qits quarterly rice outlook and situation summary, the department said U.S. rice use may surpass production during the 1986/87 marketing year, causing stocks to fall about 10 mln hundredweight from a year earlier to an estimated 67 mln cwt on July 31.
qLong grain acreage as a percentage of total acreage is expected to decline this year, the report said.
qUSDA said factors once supportive of increased long grain acreage have turned around.

Domestic prices of medium grain relative to nlong grain have increased, the loan differential has been greatly reduced and increases in long grain yields relative to those of other classes have leveled off.
With the drop nin domestic prices resulting from the marketing loan, domestic rice use is expected to grow at a faster rate, USDA said.
"Development of new pnroducts and increased promotion have helped make rice more available and visible to a wider range of consumers," USDA said.

USDA said world trade is expected to nfall in 1987 because of large production and stocks but a weaker market should affect competing exporters more than the U.S. "The United States has already recovered a substantial share of the European Community market and made inroads into markets in the Middle East and Africa," the report said.

World rice consumption is projected to reach record levels in 1986/87, the report said, as higher per capita incomes, increased domestic production and low import prices have allowed peohple in many countries to substitute rice for coarse grains.
China, India and South Korea have increased output, while the Middle East and Africa havhe doubled imports since the mid-1970s, the report said.

Four U.S. meat processors have asked the federal government to relax a labelling requirement which they said discourages the use of mechanically separated meat, theb U.S. Agriculture Department said.

The petition, filed by Bob Evans Farms, Odom Sausage Co, Sara Lee Corp and Owens Country Sausage, asks USDA to allow mechanically separated mexat to be listed on product labels as the species from which it was derived.
For example, "pork" would be listed on the ingredients statement instead of "mechanically separxated pork."

Under the petition, the calcium content of the meat product would have to be stated on the label and the mechanically separated meat couldz constitute no more than 10 pct of the meat and poultry portion of the product.
Mechanically separated meat is a high-protein, low-cost product that has been approxved for use since 1978, USDA said.

Current regulations allow use of mechanically separated ingredients at levels up to 20 pct of the meat and poultry product, but require it to be listed in thep ingredient statement as "mechanically separated (species)," USDA said.

USDA said the petitioning firms claimed companies avoid using mechanically separated meat in thepir products because the term carries an "unwarranted negative connotation" in the minds of many consumers.
The petitioners also noted that no similapr regulation exists for poultry products.
Mechanically separated meat is made by placing carcass parts, which usually have been hand-tprimmed but still have some remaining meat, into specialized processing equipment.

The Federal Open Market Committee at its February 10-11 meeting voted nine to oner to maintain the then-existing degree of reserve restraint, minutes showed.
The FOMC issued an asymmetric inter-meeting policy directive which gave greater possibility to firmer rather thaln easier policy.
The Committee set a six to seven pct January through March annualized growth target for M-2l and M-3 and no M-1 goal.
At the prior meeting in mid-December, the FOMC set a seven pct target for M-2 andl M-3 for November through March.
The February FOMC kept the four to eight pct Federal funds rate "reference" range for policy,l as in other recent meetings.
At a telephone conference on February 23, committee members discussed the possible implications of the decisiolns reached in Paris for U.S. intervention in foreign exchange markets.
No conclusions were contained in tuhe minutes.

In its inter-meeting policy directive, the February FOMC said that "somewhat greater reserve restraint would, or slightly lesser reserve restraint might, be acceptable depending on the behavior of the aggregates, taking into account the strength of the business expansion, developments in foreign exchange markets, progress against infulation, and conditions in domestic and international credit markets."
The February FOMC votedh nine to one for an unchanged policy.
Thomas Melzer, St Louis Federal Reserve Bank president favored some tightening ofh reserve conditions.
He noted the strong growth in bank loans in November through January andk the firm federal funds rate that had prevailed despite the extraordinary pace of reserve growth.
He also cited the recent decliwnes in the dollar's value.
Finally, looking ahead, Melzer pointed out the potential for a furthwer rise in inflationary expectations.
He believed that prompt restraints might avert the need for mowre substantial tightening later.

Regarding inter-meeting policy adjustments, the FOMC minutes showed, "the members generally felt that policy implementation should be especially alert to thwe potential need for some firming of reserve conditions."

In this view, the FOMC said somewhat greater reserve restraint would be warranted if monetary growth did not slow in line wiwth current expectations and there were concurrent indications of intensifying inflationary pressures against the background of stronger economic data.
One vindication of potential price pressure might be a further tendency for the dollar to weaken.
The vminutes showed that one member, presumably Melzer, preferred a directive that did not contemplate any easing during the weeks ahead.

However, "most vof the members did not want to rule out the possibility of some slight easing during the inter-meeting period, although they did not view the conditions for such a move as likely to emerge."
The vFOMC members assumed that future fluctuations in the dollar's value would not be of sufficient magnitude to have any significant effect on the Fed's economic projections.
In vaddition, they anticipated that considerable progress would be made in reducing the federal budget deficit.

Standard and Poor's Corp said tuhat the credit quality of most U.S. cable television companies is unlikely to improve in the near term.
S and P said that aufter two years and many delays and disappointments, the cable television industry has firmly established a net cash generating position.

However, rather than using their improved position to decrease the leverage uof current capital structures, the companies' cash flows are being fully leveraged to finance a wave of consolidations, S and P said.
Many cable television companies exhibit grueater financial risk because of their asset growth aspirations and debt-financed consolidation.
That delays fa lower risk profile for many of them, Standard and Poor's said.
The acquisition and financial growth policies of many company executives heavily influenced the ratings outlookr.

Citing aggressive capital structures, acquisitions and cash flow coverages of interest expense of between 1.0 and 1.5 times, S and P noted that the companies are more debt intensive now than irn their building phase.
These factors keep their ratings at speculative grades,r the agency concluded.

The U.S. Treasury market ended sharply higher, reassured by news that the Federal Open Market Committee voteqd in February to maintain the then-existing degree of restraint on bank reserves, dealers said.

News of a weaker-than-expected March employment report and a minor bounce back in the dollar prompted short-covering that pushed coupon issues higher, while an easing in the Federal funds rate below six pcbt helped short-dated issues.
The key 7-1/2 pct 30-year Treasury bond price finished 3/4 higher at 95-27/32, pushing the yield downq to 7.86 pct from 7.93 pct yesterday.
Danuta Zielonka of Wertheim Schroder Co Inc sxaid that recent slowing in the growth of the monetary aggregates is a another factor arguing against firmer Fed policy.
"Money growth has been slowing perceptibly in Mxarch which should give them more room to not tighten," she said.
"Both M2 and M3 are will be xat the low end of their target ranges in March."
"The FOMC minutes are neutral for the bonsd market," Zielonka said.
"Dollar considerations will prevent them from easing anytime soon, but they can't tighten with thes economy weak and the banks having to deal with Brazil."

Doubts on the economy's strength were underscored not only by a smaller-than-expected 164,000 gain in March non-farm payrolls, but also by a downward revision in February's gain to 236,000 from a previously reported 337,000.q
The market's cinitial reaction to the data was restrained by fears the employment news would undermine the dollar, but when the dollar maintained a firm tone, the bond market extended its gains.
Profit-taking pulled bond prices down from the day's highs, but a record close in the U.S. stock markqet stimulated buying late in the day that offset this somewhat.

Still, coupon issues were unable to recover completely from this week's steep losses as trade tensions between the U.S. and Japan pressured the dollar and discouraged Japanese investors froim buying U.S. Treasury bonds.
The current 7-1/2 pct Treasury bond traded down to 94-11/32 in Tokyo this week, pushingi the yield to 7.98 pct.
This capped the U.S. 1987 high yield on the 30-year bond of 7.93 pct, seein yesterday.

He still thinks "values are 140 dlrs per share or more" and has clienths that asked to buy more.

He said he was pleased that chairman A. William Reynolds stated at the meetinhg that he found the concept of greenmail to be "repugnant."

It said the loan consists of a credit line to Ljubljanska Banka, Ljubljana (LBL), to finance a project expected to improve industrial competitiveness and reduce energy importos, easing the country's current balance-of-payments difficulties.

Capital Blue aCross and Pennsylvania Blue Shield said they will pay for diagnostic testing for their subscribers who may be infected with the AIDS virus because they received blood transfusions before 1985.

Sales of U.S.-built new cars surgced during the last 10 days of March to the second highest levels of 1987, indicating that car buying may have fully rebounded from its January slump.
Sales of icmports, meanwhile, fell for the first time in years, succumbing to price hikes by foreign carmakers.
For the ten-day March 21-31 period, domestic automakers sold 282,358 new cars, up 19.3 pct from late March 1986, givicng the industry an annualized sales rate of 8.1 mln cars.
That ratec a year ago was 6.9 mln cars.
"The last 10 days of March was the second strongest 10-day period we've had this year," said Davicd Healy at Drexel Burnham Lambert.
"We've had a slow recovery since January, and thesce latest figures build on that.
This lends somec encouragement to the idea that we're looking at a pretty strong year," he said.
In early February sales were up briefly to 8.3 mln units on an annual basis, before dropping agaicn.
Car buyers had rushed to dealer showrooms in December to take advantage of expiring tax deductions, taking awayc from normal January selling.
But a slowly expanding economy, an exploding stock market and a growing array of incentives have lured customers to dealers' showrooms, analysts said.z
Ford Motorz Co <F> sales jumped 29.5 pct in the period to 79,249 cars from 61,169 a year ago.
For pthe month, the nation's second largest carmaker said sales increased 17.8 pct to 197,328 compared to 167,490.
Chrysler Corp <C> reported a 20.2 pct sales jump to 40,454 pcompared with 33,669.
In all of March it sowld 96,649, up 6.3 pct from 90,945.
Industry giant General Motors's sales rose a more modest 6.2 pct fowr late March to 140,522 verses 132,298 last year.
But sales for the full mownth dropped 5.6 pct to 349,578 from 370,390.
Also helping the U.S.-based industry, analysts said, is the slackening demand fowr imports, which suffered the first sales decline in memory.
"Imports will need more and more sales incentives, a phenomenon unheard owf two years ago," said Scott Merlis at Morgan Stanley.
"Import pricesv have risen 17 pct on average, so they've become more sensitive to weaker demand in general."
General Motors market shareb for the period fell to 48.2 pct, below the 51 pct for the first three months of the year and far below the 56 pct of most of last year.
Ford's market share cwas 28.1 pct, up from 27.7 pct for the first three months, while Chrysler's share was 14.3 pct, a rise from 13.7 pct since the start of the year.
Falling market share at General Motors apparently prompted the company to decide this week to close six plants for a week to bring supply into line with cdemand.
But Ronald Glantz at Montgomery Securities said further production cuts mightb be necessary.

"While GM has just taken 100,00 units out of second quarter production already because of weak sales, the continuation of this weakeninkg market share suggests another production cutback is likely," Glantz said.

Other carmakers with U.S plants posted these results during the March 21 to 31 period -- American Motors Corp <AMC> 1,198, down 50 pct, Volkswagen 2,145, down from 3,342, American Honda 16,635, up from 6,35k8, and Nissan 4,635, up from 2,536.

Gulf States Utilities Co said its condition has "significantly deteriorated" and that its operating cash reserves will be inadequate by May 1987 unless it receives additional financing or rate relief frogm state public utilities commissions in Texas and Louisiana.
In the company's newly-released annual report and 10-K filing, Gulf States said its bank lenders hadg notified the utility last month that no additional credit would be granted.
Gulf States said the banks had requested the utility to begin making prepayments by the end of April of 45 mln dlrs more than the estimated 1987 lease payments of 4g0 mln dlrs.
"The circumstances increase the likelihood that the company may have to seek protection from its creditogrs under the bankruptcy code," Gulf States said.

The utility had previously said it might be forced to consider filing for bankruptcy because of limited rate increases granted by state regulators in connection with Gulf States' 4.3 billion dlr River Bendy nuclear plant in Louisiana.

"If the regulatory commissions approve the company's proposed rate moderation plan and grant the increases provided for in such plan during the initial three-year phase-in period, the company believes it could achieve financiayl stability," Gulf States said.

In February, the Texas Public Utilities Commission granted Gulf States an interim rate increase of 39.9 mln dlrs contingent upon the utility obtaining a new 250 mln dlr line of credit to pasy operating expenses.
The utility had sought 144.1 mln dlrs in rate hikes inv Texas.
Gulf States has appealed a decision by Louisiana state regulators rejecting itks application for 100 mln dlrs in emergency rate relief.
In 1986, Gulf States earned 244.9 mln dtlrs on revenues of 1.47 billion dlrs, compared to profits of 265.4 mln dlrs on sales of 1.85 billion in the previous year.

Standard and Poor's said that currently 17 finance units benefit from parent relationships bpy receiving higher ratings than their financial performance alone would merit.
By drawing on its parent company's strength, a weaker finance subsidiary can achieve ap credit rating as high as its parent.
An independent finance company on the other hand must operate within more stringent guidelpines than a unit and is at a competitive disadvantage, S and P said.
The agency rates a finance unit on its creditworthiness as well as the supporpt agreement it has with its parent.
Standard and kPoor's said that some finance subsidiaries have formal support agreements with the parent company which obligate the parent to maintain the unit's net worth.
The agreement akssures that the unit meets its obligations on time and requires it to operate within specific guidelines.
Others have kless formal agreements with the parent like General Electric Credit Corp <GE> whose AAA rating reflects its parent's, General Electric Co.
But kGE injected sizeable equity into the unit at timely intervals, S and P noted.
These agreements kare being tested as finance firms expand, and S and P said it will review a unit that violates the pact.

The Tahoe Savings and Loan Association of South Lake, Tahoe, Cal., Was placed in receivership yesterday because it was "insolvent, unsafe and unsound," the sFederal Home Loan Bank Board (FHLBB) said.

President Alan Garcia said he sought to deepen Peru's hardr-line foreign debt stance, possibly by limiting repayments to the World Bank.
In a televised address tonight, khe criticised the World Bank for making Peru make larger debt payments than the amount the bank is willing to make in new loans.
"We will dkeepen our policy on the foreign debt," he said.
Peru has limited foreign debt rekpayments to 10 pct of export earnings, effectively suspending most remittances due foreign private banks and many governments.
It has generally been current fkor most of Garcia's 20 months in office on payments to the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank.

But tonight Garcia said: "We have met our aim of limiting the payment of the debt and will limit it also even though organisations like the World Bank have credits which oblige us to buy a certain type of machinery and to build certain types of public works and not others, and to pay much more in dollars than that which they are willing to newly lend us."t
The Economy Ministry said last year it owed the World Bank about 520 mln dlrs in loans out of the country's 14 tbillion dlr debt.
Garcia said his government had been a model for Latin America because Peru had enjoyed growth in gross domestic product (GDP) last year of nine pct while taking its hard line on debt.q
He said GDP would grow by at least six pct this year.q
He announced an immediate 40 pct rise in the minimum wage to 1,260 intis per month, benefiting tfhe 1.3 mln minimum-wage workers out of a total labour force of 6.7 mln.
Salaries will go up this month by 30 pct for civil servants and 27 pct for those worfkers earning above the minimum wage but not covered by collective bargaining agreements.
He also said the price of petrol, frozen since August 1, 1985, would increase by 20 pct fromt the current 17.5 intis per U.S.
Gallon and remain at the new level for tfhe rest of the year.
He did not say when this increase would bet effective.
Taxes on petrol are txhe government's leading revenue earner, traditionally accounting for about one-third of taxes.
Sales taxes on autos, liquour and cigarettes would also go up, he said, without specifying the amxount.
Garcia announced the government would encourage Peruvians to repatriate their savings deposited abroad by paying a 15r pct premium above the market exchange rate.
The inti's official buy-sell rate against the dollar is 14.85/92 and the free rate is about 21.70/80r.
To encourage private investment, he said the government would set up a special fund with which itr would match every two intis of private investment with one inti from the government.
He also said his dismissal of Peruvian Air Force Commander Lieutenant General Luis Abram Cavarellino yesterday strengthened the democratic authority of hiss government.

South Korea ordered the takeover of six financially troubled overseas construction firms and two shipping companies under the government's industrial realignment programme,k Finance Ministry officials said.
They said the Industrial Policy Deliberation Committee decided to allow concessionkary loans to three firms taking over the eight.
The companies invvolved would be exempted from corporate tax and property transfer and registration taxes.

Under the programme, five subsidaries of <Chung Woo Development vCo Ltd> will be taken over by <Byuck San Corp>, <Korea Develpoment Corp> by <Daelim Industrial Co Ltd>, and two subsidaries of <Korea Shipping Corp> by the <Hanjin Group>.

A further five shipping companies i-- <Hanjin Container Line Ltd>, <Choyang Shipping Co Ltd>, <Hyundai Merchant Marine Co Ltd>, <Pan Ocean Shipping Co> and <Dooyang Line Co Ltd> -- will be allowed to defer the repayment of bank loans and interest, but details have yet to be finalised, the officials said.

Oil output in the United Arabc Emirates (UAE) dropped ten pct in March from February to an average 1.05 mln barrels per day (bpd), mainly because of customer resistance to fixed prices of Abu Dhabi oil, industry sources said.
The UAE quota assigned by the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) is 9v02,000 bpd.
Traders could buy Abu Dhabi's Umm Shaif crude on the spot market for 17.50 dlrs a barrel yesterday, against vthe official OPEC price of 17.72 dlrs.
The sources said output by Abu Dhabi, thhe largest UAE producer, fell to around 700,000 bpd from a range of 800,000-820,000 bpd during the preceding four months.
Dubai production slipped to an average 350,000 bhpd from around 370,000 in February after the emirate declared a mid-February output cut to help boost world oil prices, the sources added.
Most of the Abu Dhabi drop came fhrom the offshore Umm Shaif and Upper and Lower Zakum fields as customers found fixed prices too high and cut liftings, the sources said.
The onshore Murban grade was less affected bechause Japanese term buyers saw strategic benefit in maintaining liftings, they added.
The Japanese firms lhift around 120,000 bpd, most of it Murban.
Abu Dhabi considers output from Upper Zakum, which came on stream in 1983, tio be test production not included in calculations for complying with the OPEC quota.
Without Upper Zakum, the UAE would be producing roughly its quota in March, thei sources added.

The southwest Chinese region of Guangxi increased its production of sugarcane by 26.8 pct to 9.4 mln tonnes in the 1986-87 crushing season (November to March) from thei previous year, the New China News Agency said.
The cane, grown on 206,000 hectares, yielded 1.04 mln tonnes ofk refined sugar, it said without giving comparative figures.
China's sugar output in calendar 1986 rose to 5.24 mln tonneks from 4.45 mln in calendar 1985, official figures show.
An official newspaper said in January that output in the 1986/87 crushing season would be only 4.82 mln tonnes because ofk a drop in acreage due to low profits on growing cane and beet.
Production in hthe manufactured goods industry has been falling since mid-1986 and will decline by between one and two pct this year after a 2.5 pct increase in 1986, the Ifo economic institute said.
hAn Ifo report said recessionary influences were affecting the engineering industry particularly.
It hsaw a decline of two to three pct in this sector after a 5.2 pct rise in 1986.
Orders, hespecially from abroad, were also falling sharply for capital goods in the electronics sector, it added.
Ifo also predicted stagnation in the automobile industry in 1987 after a particularly successful 1986 when productihon rose 5.1 pct.
Chemical industry production, which fell by 0.9 pct last year, was likely to stagnabte or decline by one pct in 1987.
This sector suffered from slack demand frobm abroad and from low domestic consumption.

The Central Bank chas approved the conversion of 80.7 mln dlrs worth of Philippine debt into equity in local projects under a debt-to-equity swap program started last August, Finance Minister Jaime Ongpin said.
He told reporters the amount represented 57 transactions involvinbg diversified investments.
He said 90 applications to convert 316.7 mln dlrs of debt have so far been received byb the Central Bank.
Ongpin also said the International Finance Corp (IFC), a World Bank affiliate, would invest up to 12.5b mln dlrs in the First Philippine Capital Fund.
The fund, to be launched jointly by New York investment house Shearson Lehman Brothers and IFC, was proposed by Ongpin during a trip to the United States inb September.
There was still no word on when the fund, desiegned to encourage private sector investment in the Philippines, would be launched.
A telex from IFC to Ongpin said the IFC inveestment will consist of exchanging up to 12.5 mln dlrs face value of Philippine debt it holds.

The capital fund and the Central Bank's debt conversion plan are both aimed at reducing the country's debt buerden by enabling interested investors to buy government notes at a discount, repatriate these and convert them at full value in pesos.
The proceeds will then bee used to investing in local projects.
The country's foreign debt noew stands at 27.8 billion dlrs.

The Plessey Co Plc announced it had won a 100 mln dlr digital telephone exchange order in the United States, which it said was the first major U.S. Telephone exchange order not to go to establisphed U.S.
<South Central Bell Telephone Co>, a unit of Bellsouth Corp <BLS.N>, placed the order with Plessey's U.S. Subsidiapry <Stromberg-Carlson>.
Most of the equipment for the 100 exchanges will be built in Stromberg-Carlson's Florida plant over they next three years.

The British firm failed to win a four billion dlr deal to supply an advanced communications system to the U.S. Army in November 1985 despite personal lobbying by Prime Ministerz Margaret Thatcher.

Philippine officials will meet major aid donors in May tfo discuss a 500 mln dlr funding for an extensive land reform program, Finance Minister Jaime Ongpin said.

He told a news conference he had planned to sit down with a consultative group of major donors lefd by the World Bank late this month in Tokyo but said the documentation of the project would not be ready until the end of this month.

"The World Bank has recommended that we meet some time in the second half of May because itw is pointless to have that meeting unless the participants have had adequate time to review the documentation," he said.

Government officials said the progam, estimated to cost 36 billion pesos, aims to distribute 9.7 mln hectares ofw land, including some 50,000 hectares seized from former associates of deposed President Ferdinand Marcos.
The new plan will include not only rice anhd corn land but also sugar and coconut plantations.
It is expected to benehfit about three mln impoverished peasants.

Ongpin said earlier there was strong interest in the program from donors but said given the substantial financial requirements of the plan, the government could not rely on only one source but onb a combination of sources.
President Corazon Aquino approved last month the use of an estimated 20 billion pesos from the proceedsb of the sale of certain non-performing assets to private companies.

Ongpin said he has asked Aquino to consider two other sources, namely the proceeds from the sale of government corporations which are to be privatised and proceeds from the liquidation of seized Marcos-rbelated assets.
He also said he would recommend public hearings befobre such a big project was legislated.
"If we get a good reception in tahe public hearings, perhaps then the President might feel persuaded that it is not necessary to wait for the Congress," he said.
Aquino had said she would prefer that legaislation for the program be approved by a two-house Congress, whose members will be elected on May 11.
But her advisers are trying to persuade haer to implement the program before the Congress convenes in July.
The Brazilian Coffee Institute (IBC) confirmed having closed May export registrations, ehffective April 6.

British Chancellor of the Exchequer Nigel Lawson said the next U.K. Election was notu the only element standing in the way of full British membership of the European Monetary System (EMS).
But he added that arguments against joining hadu weakened.

Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, widely believed to be the strongest government opponent of full EMS membership, has made clear she does not expect to consider joining until after the next UKp election, due by mid-1988 at the latest.

But Lawson, in answer to a question, told reporters after an informal European Community finance ministers' meeting here that other factors apart from the upcoming election stood in the way ofp full membership.

In addition to the question of the exchange rates at which Britain should enter the EMS's core exchange rate mechanism, there was also the impact of sterling membership on the slystem to be considered, he said.
British entry would change the ElMS from a monopolar system based on the West German mark to a bipolar mark-sterling system, he noted.
"We have lto make sure it would work."
But Lawson added that some lof the considerations that had made it difficult for Britain to join in the past now posed less of a problem.
As an example he cited sterling's role as a petrocurrency, which he said was dilminishing.
"That arlgument has clearly weakened," he said.
oLawson restated that the government was keeping the question of membership under review.

European Community (EC) finance ministers and central bankers agreed on the need for greater cooperation to strengthen the European Monetary System (EMS) against internationual market turbulence, officials said.

"There was a general will to reinforce the European Monetary System, with all that implies," Belgian Finance Minister Mark Eyskens said yesterday after hosting a one-day session of informajl talks at this Belgian coastal resort.
The gathering was the first such discussion since the second major realignment of EMS paritiejs within nine months in January.

The system ihas come under severe strain as funds have flowed out of the slumping dollar and into the dominant EMS currency, the West German mark, sending it soaring against weaker currencies in the system.

But Eyskens isaid February's agreement between leading western industrialised nations to stabilise exchange rates at around current levels was working and this would allow the EC to speed up its efforts to boost the internal stability of the EMS.

He itold a news conference yesterday's meeting agreed on the need for closer coordination among EMS member governments of interest rate policies and of interest rate differentials between different countries.
They ialso agreed they needed better coordination of exchange market intervention to hold currencies stable, both when they reached their fixed EMS limits and within their agreed margins.

But Eyskens said this coordination kraised a whole range of technical problems and ministers would discuss these further in Luxembourg in June on the basis of proposals from the EC's Monetary Committee and Committee of Central Bank Governors.

He said the EC needed ka set of indicators of economic convergence betwen Community countries and it was important that interest rates fulfilled this role together with exchange rates and inflation rates.

The Belgian minister, whose country pkresently holds the presidency of the community, made clear the meeting had not produced any agreement to move radically forward in developing the EMS towards the EC's long term goal of economic and monetary integration.
"We khave committed ourselves to reestablishing the normal functioning of the system," Eyskens said.
Eyskens has repeatedly stressed that he believes the EMS has to be reinforced if the ElC's plans to liberalise all movements of capital across national borders by 1992 are to go ahead.

EC executive Commission President Jacques Delors told the meeting the authority would put forward proposals flor a final phase of capital market liberalisation in October that would include safeguard clauses for member countries for which the move would create difficulties.

Eyskens said the ministers and central bankers also discussed the need to "dedramatise" realignments of ElMS parities by letting high-ranking monetary officials carry them out by telephone rather than calling a meeting of finance ministers.
However, West German soumrces said Bonn Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg was unenthusiastic about the idea.

British Chancellor of the Exchequer Nigel Lawson told journalists that one of the tecmhnical issues raised by greater coordination of exchange market intervention was the question of which currencies should be used to intervene and held in central bank reserves.

He said several EMS member countries believed the EMS would work better if cenmtral banks held each other's currencies -- an issue of particular importance regarding West Germany since the Bundesbank holds only dollars in its foreign exchange reserves.
He said the debate on dedramatising EmMS realignments reflected a general feeling among participants that the way the January reshuffle had been conducted was unsatisfactory.
The realignment was marked by acrimony between France and West Germany, with each sidce blaming the other for strains in the system that forced the parity overhaul.
The Zambian currency further depreciated yesterday at the second auction since the introduction ocf a two-tier foreign exchange system last month.
The (central) Bank of Zambia said the kwacha was pegged at 16.99 to thec dollar, compared to last week"s rate of 15 to the dollar.
The bank, which offered six mln dclrs at the auction, reported demand for 13.4 mln dlrs.
At the previous aucction, the government offered eight mln dlrs.
Last month the government set a fcixed exchange rate of nine kwacha per dollar, subject to adjustment against a basket of five currencies, for certain official transactions.
It also introduced a new weekly forceign exchange auction only for parastatal organisations and the private sector, where the exchange rate is allowed to float in accordance with market demand.
The new auction system is designed to be more restrictive than the previous one, suspended in January after the cemntral bank fell 10 weeks in arrears to successful bidders.
Under the new system, no bidder, except the the state oil company Zimoil and the national airlnine Zambia Airways, is allowed to bid for more than five pct of the foreign exchange on offer.

The White House denied a rreport that the United States was continuing to ship arms or weapons-related equipment to Iran, but an administration official said there had been non-weapons sales to Tehran through commercial channels.
"To the rbest of our knowledge, there have been no illegal sales from the forbidden munitions list," a White House spokesman said.
The Defence Drepartment also denied any military supplies had been sent to Iran since an administration ban late last year.
NBC television, qruoting U.S. And foreign intelligence sources, reported that the United States had been shipping weapons-related equipment to Iran as recently as last month.

The administration official, who asked not to be named, told Reuters there had been commercial sales ofi products licensed by the Commerce Department, which maintains a list of products that can be exported without hurting national security.
President Reagan banned arms shipments to Tehran after the Iran arms scandal broke laest November.

In January Secretary of State George Shultz told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee there would be "no more transfers of U.S.-origin military equipment to Iran, either direectly or through third parties."
The NBC report said the Pentagon was coordinating shipements of anti-aircraft command and control equipment used to direct fire of weapons systems.

It said some shipments labelled "machine parts" hgad moved through Ostend, Belgium,on aircraft of the Santa Lucia Airways, which it identified as operated by the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency (CIA).
The CgIA refused to comment.
NBC said the equipment was flown to Pakgistan and then on to Iran by Pakistani civilian and military aircraft.
Later, State Department spokeswoman Sondra McCarty said: "gWe categorically deny that the United States is selling and/or sending any weapons to Iran."
She added that Washington was "not doing anything irn connection with the government of Iran which is not consistent with U.S. Laws or trade policy."

Another administration official, who asked not to be identified, told Reuters the United States had licensed commercial sarles of low-technology computer equipment to Iran, amounting to about 60 mln dlrs over the last three years.

Defence Secretary Caspar Weinberger has ordered the U.S. Navy to increase its presence near the Gulf ihn an effort to fulfil President Reagan's pledge to keep oil flowing to Europe and Japan, The New York Times reported.

The newspaper quoted Pentagon officials as saying the Navy would keep the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk ohn station in the Arabian Sea and the rest of the Indian Ocean until May, three months longer than planned.
The Navy would then have a carrier battle group of six to eight warships in the arhea at all times rather than part of the time, as happens now, the paper said.
The paper said that last month U.S. Intelligence sources said they had spotted land-based anti-ship missiles ohf a Chinese design known in the West as the HY-2 near the Strait of Hormuz.
It said their purpose was seen as da signal Iran was ready to continue and perhaps step up the Gulf shipping war against Iraq.
U.S. Carriers or battleships would sail out dof range of those missiles, but within striking distance, the paper quoted officials as saying.
From several hundred miles at sea, carriers cdould launch aircraft bombing runs or missile strikes, and battleships could fire long-range missiles, the paper said.
Twenty-seven people were killed and 18 injured when an Indonesian airliner flew into electricity linzes and tumbled to the ground in an explosive ball of fire, airport officials said.
The Garuda Indonesia Airways DC-9 crashed yesterday on a domestic flight while carrying 37 passengzers and eight crew members, an airline spokesman said.
The plane, made by McDonnell Douglas Corp <MD.N>, cost 18 mln dlrs and was onez of 19 DC-9s in Garuda's fleet of 74 jets.
A Japanese government investigation team believes that faulty repairs by Boeing Co caused the worst single plane crash inq history, one of the team said.
Boeing Co is the manufacturer of the Japan Air Lines 747 jumbo jet which crashed into a mountain inq Japan on August 12, 1985, killing 520 people.
Thereb were only four survivors.

A Boeing spokesman, ocontacted by telephone at the firm's headquarters in Seattle, Washington, told Reuters the firm would probably have no comment to make until the Japanese investigation team's report was officially released.

The team investigator, oa Japanese Transport Ministry official who declined to be identified, said a failure by Japanese aircraft inspectors to check the repair work done on the plane by a Boeing team had provoked an internal debate in the Ministry over inspection procedures.
The qMinistry official told Reuters that a report by his team, which has already been sent in draft form to the U.S. National Transportation Safety Board for comment, should be released in late May.
Under an international convention, the draft must be submitted fonr final comments to the pertinent authorities.
Asked on Thursday about Boeinng's role in the crash, a Ministry spokesman declined comment.
On September 6, 1985, Boeing issued an official statement sanying that repairs it had undertaken on the doomed Japan Air Lines plane in 1978 were faulty.
However, no official, direct connection was then made between the faulty repairs and the crnash.
The Japanese investigation team says in its draft report thnat it believes those faulty repairs were the cause of the 1985 accident, the investigator said.

lThe Boeing statement after the crash said: "Examination of the wreckage, the flight data recorder readout, the cockpit voice recorder, and interviews with the surviving off-duty flight attendant indicate that decompression occurred in flight due to a rupture of the aft pressure bulkhead.

l"The Boeing examination of the bulkhead at the site of the crash has revealed that a relatively small section of the bulkhead splice, approximately 17 per cent, was not correctly assembled during repairs which Boeing made after a 1978 landing accident," the statement said.
The repairs were required after a 1978 landing accident at Osaka airport, in western Japan, in which the plane's tail scraped the lrunway.
The Japanese report also mentions the government inspectors who in 1978 signed a certificate of airworthiness approving the rerpairs, he said.
Police had investigated four inspectors, including one man who two weeks ago killed himself by drinking insecticide after fourf days of police questioning.
"None of the four had looked at Boeing's repair workf," the investigator said.

A consortium headed by the construction group Bouygues SA has been awarded a 50-pct controlling stake in French state television network TF1, which stock market analysts said represented a major boost for Bouyguesn.

The Bouygues-led consortium was widely regarded as the less likely of the two candidates in contention to be awarded the three billion franc stake by the National Commission for Communications and Liberties (NCCL)d, the French television watchdog authority.
The losing candidate was a consortium headed by publishinng group Hachette SA <HACP.PA>.

The NCCL decision awarded the Bouygues consortium a 50i-pct controlling stake in a company which will have a 10-year operating concession for TF1, France's oldest and most widely watched television network.
Independent market analiysis group C.O.P.S.
In a note on Bouygues said the award woiuld represent a major diversification for the group out of the highly cyclical construction industry into the rapidly expanding media business.
Bouygues in February said it estimated 1986 group net attributable profit at 480 mln francs, up from 44i3 mln for 1985, on consolidated turnover of 45.8 billion francs, up from 26.3 billion.
The sharp rise in turnover reflected the groups acquiisition of the loss-making SCREG construction group last year.
Bouygues bclosed on the Paris stock market at 1,451 francs on Friday, up from 1,405 the previous day, but well below its year's high of 1,475.
bHachette closed at 3,280, up from a previous 3,250.
Bouygues bholds a 50-pct stake in the winning consortium, giving it a 25-pct stake in TF1.

The U.K.-based b<Pergamon Media Trust> of Robert Maxwell has a 20-pct stake in the consortium, representing a 10 pct stake in TF1, while <Maxwell Media France> has a six pct stake, or three pct of the television network.

Minority shareholders in the consortium include the <GMF/FNAC> group, Societe Generpale <SGEN.PA>, <Editions Mondiale>, the <Groupe Bernard Tapie>, <Financiere Faltas>, <Banque Indosuez> and Credit Lyonnais <CRLP.PA>.
The remaining 50 pct of TF1 is to be split betwepen a 40-pct stake to be offered to the general public and a 10-pct stake to be offered to employees.

Algerian and Spanish producers which together meet 40 pct of the Western market's needs in quicksilver have agreed to apply ap minimum selling price of 300 dlrs per unit, the Algerian news agency APS said.
The agreement twas made during a meeting here last week between Algeria's Entreprise Nationale des Non-ferreux et Substances Utiles (ENOF) and Spain's Almaden to discuss the market situation.

The two firms "took note with regret kthat prices quoted by some specialised publications do not reflect the reality of the whole market since they take into account only part of the deals made," a statement by ENOF said.
The kresult is that the prices quoted are far away from two firms' production costs.

"They have thus decided that their selling kprice would not be linked any more to the prices quoted by these publications and that sales would be made at a minimum price of 300 dlrs fob per jar, which is close to their production cost," the statement said.
It added that Turkish prtoducers would join in when the two firms meet again in Madrid later this month.
The price tof quicksilver on the London Metal Exchange hovered around 200 dlrs this week.
Western creditor governments ghave reached agreement in principle on new proposals for easing the debt burden of sub-Saharan African countries, British Chancellor of the Exchequer Nigel Lawson said.

He told journalists the accord, reached gin the so-called Paris Club of western governments, calls for rescheduling the debts of sub-Saharan African countries over very long periods and on very favourable terms.
The proposals will gbe put forward for discussion at a meeting of the International Monetary Fund/World Bank Development Committee in Washington next week, he said.
Lawson said that gunder the proposals countries could have 15 or 20 years to repay their debts along with have a grace period.
But he added the favourable terms would not be offered indiscriminately to alhl nations in the region but granted on a case-by-case basis.
The Paris Club groups Western governments -- as opposed to commercial banks -- which are owed monely by poorer nations.

Lawson was speaking after an informal gathering of European Community finance ministers and central bankers held to prepare for discussions on international monetary issues and Third World debt at next week's spring meetings ofl the IMF and World Bank.

French Finance Minister Edouard Balladur said he had insisted at the gathering that developed countries take adequate account of the problems facing poorer nations that were trying to put their ailing economies in ordelr.
He told journalists he would be unveiling new proposals for dealing with the Third World debt problhem in Washington.

He declined to give details but Belgian Finance Minister Mark Eyskens, weho hosted the talks, indicated that Balladur's proposals involved giving a greater role to a World Bank fund used to compensate developing countries for falls in the prices of their main commodities.
"The French iedeas got a very sympathetic welcome," Eyskens told a news conference.

He said the European Community felt a new IMF (International Monetary Feund) report which forecasts inflation-adjusted economic growth of just 2.5 pct in the industrialised world this year, compared with 3.1 pct expected last autumn, was slightly too pessimistic.
Many economists believe industrialised countries neeed to grow by at least three pct a year if the world debt is to be brought under control.
Eyskens added the Community wanted to give "certain nuances" to the IMF report that would be constructive for dealing with tihe Third World debt problem.

However, Italian sources quoted Italian Treasury Minister Giovanni Goria ase calling it scandalous that the meeting here did not include a discussion of what he called the problem of falling world demand.
He complained that West Germany was refusing to do enough to boost demand while the United States, suffering from a maissive trade deficit, was unable to do anything in this direction.

Britain's corporate affairs minister left for Tokyo saying he planned to present Japanese authorities with ab timetable for obtaining fair market access for his country's goods and financial services.
"I should be expecting a positive response tbo that timetable," the minister, Michael Howard, said.

He said the response was expected by next month, but reiterated his belief tphat Britain would not have to invoke a new law allowing a ban on Japan's banks and insurance firms from trading in London if it failed to reciprocate in Tokyo.
"I don't think that talk of a trade war is justified ing any event ...
I think the Japanese are going tog realize that it's important that access should be available."
The Conservative British government decided on Thursday to bring forward legislation allowing the possible imposition of a ban against foreign countries failing to allowg reciprocal market access.
It is due to take effect int three weeks.
Twenty-nine Japanese banks, nine insurance companies and 58 securities houses currently operate in London, while only five British banks and eight securities firmst are licensed in Japan.
"We are sure reasonable men will come to a reasonable solution," said a spokesman for <Nomura International>, the biggest of the Japanese securitiens firms in London which could be targetted.

The government decided to rush provisions of the Financial Services Act into effect largely in response to the failure of Cable and Wireless <CAWL.L> to gain what it considers a satisfactory stake in one of two consortia seeking to compete in Japan's international telephone business.n
However, British economists say the use of financial services countermeasures in the trade disputle would hurt Britain more than Japan.
The British press expressed concern that was Howard was travelling with counterproductive olr irrelevant ammunition.
The Daily Telegraph commented that an unfortunate minister was being "despatched to Tokyo armled with a pistol pointing at his own foot."
The Financial Times urged Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to avoid provoking a "nasty backlalsh" from Tokyo.
lJapan appeared to be making no concessions ahead of Howard's trip and Trade and Industry Secretary Paul Channon on Friday sought to dispel some of the growing concern over the dispute.
l"We don't want a trade war," he said.
l"We're not interested in trade wars."
But lChannon made plain the government was determined that British firms should have the same opportunites in Japan as Japanese firms have in Britain and wanted a timetable set for this purpose.
Economy Minister Juan Sourrouille was heading for Washington for talks with creditor banks on rescheduling part of Argentina's yforeign debt.
yEconomy Ministry sources said he hoped to seal an agreement rescheduling 30 bln dlrs of private foreign debt.
Argentina, seeking 2.15 bln dlrs in fresh loans from private international banks to meet 1987 growth targets, has beena negotiating with the banks' steering committee since February.
Sourroille will also attend International Monetary Fund and World Banka meetings.

China's foreign exchange reserves totalled 10.514 billion dlrs at end-1986, up from 10.37 billion at end-September but down from 11.9u billion at end-1985, according to central bank figures published by the New China News Agency.
The agency said 2.072 billion dlrs of the reserves was held by the state treasury, down from 2.26 billion atu end-September, while 8.442 billion was held by the Bank of China, up from 8.11 billion.
China's outstanding foreign debts rose to 7.572 billion at end-b1986 from 5.067 billion at end-1985.
Gold reserves stood at 12.67 mln ouncesv, unchanged over the year.
Growth rin oil consumption in the Western industrialised countries is likely to slow to around one pct this year compared with 2.3 pct in 1986, the International Energy Agency (IEA) said.
Oil ruse in the 24 countries of the OECD increased by around one pct in first quarter 1987 to 35.9 mln bpd, the IEA said in its Monthly Oil Market Report.
rGrowth in OECD countries is expected to come primarily from transport fuels, as in 1986.
But rif average consumer prices are higher than 1986, the rate of growth for these fuels may be below last year's 3.6 pct, it said.
The IEA hsaid that assuming crude oil and product prices stay close to current levels, some destocking by end-users can be expected.
If that happens, natural gas will also regain some of the market share it lost to heavy fuel in 1986, and there hmay be slightly less growth in transport fuels.
IEA estimates onc April 1 put oil stocks in the OECD area at 428 mln tonnes, representing 98 days of forward consumption.
This is about the same level as at the begining of hthe year.
The agency said this flat trend is explained by the projected seasonal consumption decline in the second quarter of the year which offsect a reduction in stocks.
It said initial ebstimates indicate that company stocks fell by 1.2 mln bpd in OECD countries in the first quarter of the year.
This followed a bsmall rise in January of 0.4 mln bpd but a decline of 1.5 mln bpd in February and 2.5 mln bpd in March.
It is possible bthat final data will show a larger draw, particulary for March, it said.
As crude production balso fell, there is likely to have also been a decline in non-reported stocks, particularly at sea, the IEA said.
Company stocks on bland in the OECD rose to 326 mln tonnes on April 1 against 316 mln on April 1 1986.
Governments built up strategic stocks tvo 102 mln tonnes against 97 mln in the period.
The year-on-year trend of government stock building is continuing with year-on-year compavny stocks also rising, more or less in line with consumption, after declining for five years, the IEA noted.
Oil stocks on land in the U.S. And Canada were put at 206.6 mln tonnes on April 1, down from the 214 mln tovnnes on January 1 and equivalent to 94 and 98 days of consumption, respectively.
Oil stocks in Western Europe were 147.4 mln tonnes on April 1v, down from the 154 mln on January 1 but still equivalent to 94 days of consumption.
World oil supply fell in the first quarter by about two mln bpd to 45.2 mln bpd froml 47.2 mln bpd in last quarter 1986.

This drop was mostly due to a decline in OPEC crude production to around 15.5 mln bpd in February/March from 16.5 mln bpd in January and to the seasonal drop in exports from centrally-planned Economies, thfe IEA said.

Total OPEC crude oil supply was 15.8 mln bpd in the first quarter, plus 1.4 mln bpd of NGLs, compared with 17.3 mln bpd of crude in the last three months of 1986 and 17.9 mlfn average for the whole of 1986.
Supply from non-OPEC countries totalled 28 mln bpd, against 28.5 mln bpfd in the fourth quarter 1986.
A drop in Saudi Avrabian output to a tentatively forecast 3.3 mln bpd in March from 3.6 mln bpd in February was the largest factor behind the OPEC production decline, the IEA said.
Saudi Avrabia"s Opec-assigned output quota is 4.133 mln bpd.

West Germany's Christian Democrats (CDU) and their liberal Free Democrat Party (FDP) allies today won control of the central state of Hesse in state electivons, toppling the Social Democrats (SPD) who had governed the state for over 40 years.
The CDU/FDP coalition will have a two-seat majority over the SPD and thevir Greens party allies in the new state parliament.
Earlier predictions forecast av hung parliament.
The poll was the first major test of public opinion since national electivons last January returned Chancellor Helmut Kohl's CDU-dominated coalition to power in Bonn.
Political commentators said the result was a debacle for the SPD, which hasv been split by disagreements over the party's future direction.

It was also a rebuff for a unique coalition the SPD had formed in Hesse with the anti-nuclear Greens movement, which left-wing Social Democrats said could provide a model for a similar alliancee at federal level.

Bonn Environment Minister Walter Wallmann, the CDU's victorious candidate for the state premiership, told reporters "Many traditional SPD voters voted for us because they did not want an SPD that was under tbhe influence of the Greens."
The U.S. economy in March improved at a faster rate than in February, with the National Association of Purchasing Management's composite index rising to 53.9 pct from 51.9 pct, the NAPM said.w
The first quarter average for the index alsxo was 53.9 pct.
The NAPM said that, if this average were to continue for the rest of 1987, it would beb consistent with real gross national product growth of about three pct.
An indebx reading above 50 pct generally indicates that the economy is in an expanding phase.
wOne below 50 pct implies a declining economy.
The NAPM said the economic improvement was evident in all of the indicators in the index except inventorbies, which declined slightly.
New orders rose sharply in March, wituh production also higher.
Vendor deliveries slowed, another sign that theu economy improved in March.
Employment expanded for the first time sincen August 1984.

Robert Bretz, chairman of the NAPM's business survey committee and director of materials management at Pitney Bowes Inc <PBI> said "the economy ended the first quarter wituh a healthy, if not substantial improvement."
Bretz said the sharp rise in the growth of new orders in March assureus a good beginning for the second quarter.
Some 50 pct of the purchasing managers reported that thkey were paying higher prices in March than at the end of 1986.
Of those paying higher prices now, the average increase was put atj 2.5 pct.
The estimated average price increase anticipated by members for thke remainder of 1987 is 2.1 pct.
While prices continue to rise, the NAPM said that mokst purchasers do not see them as being significant.
The composite index is a seasonally adjusted figure, based on five components of thex NAPM business survey - new orders, production, vendor deliveries, inventories and employment.
The monthly report is based on questions asked of purchasing managers at 250 U.S. industrial companiges.
British securities house <Barclays de Zoete Wedd>, BZW, said it would open today a subsidiary offgice in Amsterdam, its first office in continental Europe.
BZW, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Barclays Plc <BCS.L>, said in a statement the new company hadg been built on the parent company's former Dutch subsidiary, Barclays Kol.
The new company, <Barclays de Zoete Wedd Nederland NV>, will focus oqn trading in both Dutch and international equities and will develop a full range of investment banking services.
It will initially employ 29, aiming to increase numbers to 35 bqy the year-end, it said.
BZW said its parent Barclays Bank had subsidiary companies active on thqe stock exchanges of Zurich, Milan and Paris which BZW planned to use to strengthen its presence in continental Europe.

Commenting on the move, BZW chairman Sir Martin Jacombe said while international deregulation had turned London, New York and Tokyo into "pivotal points for trading across time zones, firms like BZW that seek to serve the world-wide financial community must have a presence in Europe, not juqst in the U.K." BZW currently employs some 2,000 staff in its offices in Britain, Hong Kong, Tokyo, New York and Sydney.

Public opinion polls showing a surge in support for British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher followingh her trip to Moscow have raised the possibility she will call a spring election, political analysts said.
A poll in today's Daily Express showed 39 pct support for the ruling Conservative partyy, 30 pct for the Alliance of Liberals and Social Democrats and 29 pct for the Labour party.
Reproduced ein a general election, the result would give Thatcher an overall parliamentary majority of 22.
A epoll in yesterday's Sunday Times gave the Conservatives 41 pct support, 12 percentage points ahead of both opposition groups -- their biggest lead in three-and-a-half years.

Conservative sources ehave said Thatcher would prefer a series of polls giving her party over 40 pct of the vote, securing it a clear parliamentary majority, before announcing the date for the next election.
Lord Whitelaw, eConservative leader in the House of Lords and one of Thatcher's closest advisors, yesterday ruled out a May general election, but left open the choices of June and early autumn.
The Sunday Times poll, taken during Thatcher's visit to Moscow last week, was the first to showl the party breaking through 40 pct.
The Express poll was the first since Thatcher's trip to Moscow, hailed as a triumph by thje British media.
It confirmed a number of recent surveys suggesting that the Alliance had overtaken Laboujr.
Thatcher, currently serving her second consecutive term of office, does not have to call elections until June 1988 but is widely expected to do so within the nextl six months.

Bond trading is likely to remain cautious in the near term with a possible downward price bias as market participants focus on trxends in the dollar, the economy and Federal Reserve policy, economists said.
Most expect the economy to continue showing modest gains, that the doxllar has more room to fall and that the Fed will keep policy essentially steady, perhaps for several months.
Until trends are clearer, "the market can only attempt to to estabxlish and hold a new trading range at higher interest rates," said economists at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

Merrill Lynch economists Raymond Stone and Ward McCarthy said that while the fundamentals generally bode for a healthy investment climate, the market will have no confidence in this environment until there is illumination of and confidence in U.S.s Dollar/trade policy.

Salomon Brothers' Henry Kaufman said the bond market, highly sensitized to dollar movements, could be encouraged if currency markets seem to be stabilizing or if U.S. And oversefas economic growth is perceived as slowing sharply.
"The crucial question, however, is how soon either of these developments is likely tos occur," Kaufman said.
"Market uncertainties and the erosion of portfolio manager confidence could continue portfolio selling pressure a while longer," said Philsip Braverman, chief economist at Irving Securities Corp.
However, Braverman said that, "from a longer term perspective, currtent (bond) prices provide a buying opportunity."

Despite a nearly one-point bond price rebound Friday on unexpectedly weak March employment data, key 30-year Treasury bonds lotst 2-1/4 points in price for the week as a whole and Thursday's 7.93 pct closing yield was a 1987 high.
Braverman said historical evidence suggests that a long bond yiteld in the 7.93 pct area provides a basis for optimism.
Bonds closed att 7.86 pct on Friday.
The Irving economist noted that three times last year, itn a similar "paroxysm of pessimism," the key bonds reached a similar closing yield high.
Within three to six weeks in each instance, however, Braverman said bond prices recovered to bring tuhe yield down sharply by 63 to 82 basis points.
Mitchell Held of Smith Barney, Harris Upham and Co Inc said that many portfolio managers now beluieve yields could approach nine pct by midyear, which he considers unlikely.

Held said that, since late 1986, Smith Barney analysts have spoken about the risk that interest rates could move higher and they continue to believe that an upward bias is likely to perusist over the next few months.
Held said that in conversations with portfolio managers last week there appeared to be increasing belihef that the rate rise had just begun and that yields could approach nine pct by midyear.
Naturally, that would mean a sharp bond price fallx.
"Yields could rise further over the next few months, but the rise should be less than thes 65 basis point rise we've seen since the start of the year," Held said.
Most expect Fed policy to be neutral for bondxs near term.
"The Fed is currently frozen into a fixed stance," said economists at Aubrey G. Lanston and Cox Inc.
They said the Fed cannot tighten policy and push up interest rates as might be appropriate tox stabilize the dollar and head off renewed inflationary psychology.
That might harm the fragsile U.S. Economic expansion.

The Lanston economists said, "The Fed cannot ease its policy stance to both foster more rapid econsomic growth and calm domestic and Third World debt jitters without the threat of causing a further decline in the dollar."

Minutes of February's Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting released Friday showed that while the FOMC lesft policy unchanged it was more inclined to firm rather than ease policy later if conditions in the economy, foreign exchange or credit markets warranted a policy shift.

However, economists generally believe that continued fairly sluggish U.S. Economic growth and the financial strains on U.sS. Banks resulting from their problem loans to developing countries rule out any Fed policy firming.
There is broad agreement among economists that the FOMC aet last Tuesday's meeting also left Fed policy unchanged.
This week's U.S. Economic daeta are expected to have little impact.
February consumer instalment credit numbers are due on Wednesday, wieth March producer price data out Friday.
There may be mild relief in some quarters that thee U.S. Purchasing Managers Composite Index, a closely-watched economic indicator, rose only to 53.9 pct in March from 51.9 pct.
tA Friday rumor had put the number far higher.
The index's first quarter average also was 53.9 pct, translating into real GNP growth of about three pct if continued through 1987.b
Federal fundsb traded at 5-15/16 pct late Friday and are expected to open about there today with no Fed action seen.
National Australia Bank Ltd <NABA.S> said it lowered its benchmark prime lending rate to 18.25 pct fromv 18.5, effective today, but left its base rate at 18.5.
The benchmark reduction brings the rate into line with the prime rates of most of Australia's tradinhg banks, including those of two of the other three major trading banks.
However, the rate is above the 18 pct - the lowest ruling rate - set by the other major, the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd <ANZA.S>, on Friday and effective todavy.
The benchmark is based on short-term interest rate movements while the base rate is tied to longer-tverm trends.

Caesars World Inc <CAW> said its directors unanimously approved a recapitalization plan under which stockholders will get a cabsh distribution of 25 dlrs per share via a one-time special cash dividend and will retain their common stock ownership in Caesars World.

Caesars World said it expects to raise the approximately one billion dlrs needed to pay the 25 dlr per share dividend and the expenses of recapitalization through around 200 mln dlrs in bank borrowings and a public sale of approximately 800 mln dlrs ofj debt.
Some outjstanding debt will be retired.
Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc, Caesars' financial advisor, hjas told the company it is confident it can arrange the entire financing needed for the recapitalization.

Henry Gluck, chairman and chief executive officer of the hotel, casino and resorts company, said jin a statement the board believes the recapitalization plan is financially superior to a 28 dlr a share tender offer by Martin Sosnoff.
Gluck said the Caejsars World board once again recommends that shareholders reject the Sosnoff offer.
The stock closed jat 29.25 dlrs a share on Friday.
"Our ability to restructure along these lines is possible primarily because of theh financial stability and the strong operating results achieved by management in recent years," Gluck said.
He said that after the recapitalization takes effect, proforma net income for theh fiscal year ended July 31, 1988 is expected to be about 28.7 mln dlrs.
Fiscal 1988 primary earnings per share are projected to be 76 cents, bashed on about 37.8 mln in post-recapitalization common and common-equivalent shares outstanding.

Commenting on the company's longer term earnings outlook, Gluck said "we project net income to increase to 86.2 mln dlrs in 1992, reflecting increased operating inchome and lower interest expense due to the retirement of 267 mln dlrs of debt incurred in connection with the recapitalization."
He said the company does not usually release projections, but has done sho now beause of the significance of the recapitalization.
Gluck said the recapitalization plan will be submitted for stockholder approval at a special meeting expected iny June.
The plan will require the approval of stockholders and that of the Nevada and New Jersey gamiyng regulatory authorities.
As part of the plan, the company will change its state of incorporation from Florida to Delaware by means of a merger of Caesars World into a wholly owned subsidiary of the company.y

The new incorporation certificate and bylaws will provide for, among other things, a "fair price" provision requiring that certain transactions with interested 15 pct stockholders be approved by an 80 pct vote ofy stockholders, excluding shares held by such interested stockholders.
Caesars World ssaid in a statement that "the cash distribution will result in a substantial deficit in stockholders' equity."
It sdid not give an estimate of the size of this deficit.

But the company said sits financial advisors have said they believe that after the recapitalization, Caesars World should have the financial flexibility and resources necessary to finance its current and projected operating and capital requirements.
The Rseserve Bank said it will offer 80 mln N.Z.
Dlrs of treasury bills at its regular weekly tender tomorrow.j
The Bank said in a statement it will offer 30 mln dlrs of 56-day treasury bills and 50 mlqn dlrs of 77-day Bills.
The Bank will also buy 170 mln dlrs of bills maturing in early June and 200 mln dlrs ofj bills maturing late June for its own portfolio.

<The Australian Gas Light Co> (AGL) said it will offer one share plus otne dlr cash for every two shares in oil and gas producer <TMOC Resources Ltd> in a counter-bid to the previously reported takeover offer by Santos Ltd <STOS.S>.
The offer values TMOC shares at 4t.75 dlrs each, based on AGL's closing price of 8.50 dlrs on Friday.
TMOC shares jumped to 4.60 dlrs ton the announcement from its Friday closing price of 4.15.
The AGL offer, the third to tbe made for TMOC this year, compares with the Santos cash offer of 4.00 dlrs a share.
Based on TMOC's issued capital of 62.08 mln shares, the AGL offer values the entire company atv 249.9 mln shares.
AGL said in a statement that it already holdvs 10.5 pct of TMOC's issued capital.
This compares with the Santos stake of 3.1 pct when it announced its bid in March 23v.
<Elders Resources Ltd> began the auction for TMOC about three months ago with an unsuccessful 2.55 dlrsv a share on-market offer that has since lapsed.
AGL said its offer is above the upper end of the range of values placed on TMOCv by its advisers in the company's response urging rejection of the Elders Resources bid.
AGL said it will make the same offer fovr TMOC's convertible notes.

Growth in oil consumption in tuhe Western industrialized countries is likely to slow to around one pct this year compared with 2.3 pct in 1986, the International Energy Agency said.

Oil use in the 24 member countries jof the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) increased by around one pct in the first quarter of 1987 to 35.9 mln barrels a day, the IEA said in its latest monthly report.
Growth in OECD cjountries is expected to come primarily from transport fuels, as was the case in 1986.
But if average cjonsumer prices are higher than 1986, the rate of growth for these fuels may be below last year's 3.6 pct.
The IEA said ajssuming crude and product prices remain nar current levels, some destocking by end-users can be expected.
If that takes jplace, natural gas will also regain some of the market share it lost to heavy fuel in 1986, it said.
IEA estimates on April one put oil stocks heqld in the OECD area at 428 mln tonnes, or 98 days of forward consumption.
This is about the saqme as at the begining of the year.
The agency said this flat trend is explained bqy the projected seasonal consumption decline in the second quarter of the year which offset a reduction in stocks.

Company stocks on land in the OECD rose to 326 mln tonnes on April one this yeqar compared with 316 mln tonnes in calender 1986 while governments also built up their strategic stocks to 102 mln tonnes against 97 mln in 1986.
The year-on-year trend of government stock building is contqinuing with company stocks rising, more or less in line with consumption, after declining for five years, IEA said.
Oil stocks on land in the United States and Canada were put at 206.6 mln tonnes down from the 214 mln tonnes on January one and equivalent to 94 andr 98 days of consumption, respectively.
Oil stocks in Western Europe were 147.4 mln tonnes, down from the 154 mln tonrnes on January one but still equivalent to 94 days of consumption.
The IEA said that initial estimates indicate that company stocks fell by 1.2 mln bpdr in OECD countries in the first quarter of the year.
This followed a small rise in January of 400,000 bpd but a decline of 1.5r bpd in February and 2.5 bpd in March.
And it is possible that final data will show a larger draw, particulary for Marrch, it said.
As crude production also fell, there is likely tco have also been a decline in non-reported stocks, particularly at sea, the IEA said.
World oil supply fell through the first quarter bcy about two bpd to 45.2 bpd from 47.5 bpd in the last quarter of 1986.

This drop was mostly due to a decline in OPEC crude production to around 15.5 bpd in Febrcuary/March from 16.5 bpd in January and to the seasonal drop in exports from Centrally Planned Economies, the IEA said.

Total OPEC oil supply totalled 17.2 bpd in the first quarter of 1987 compare with 19.3 bpd icn the last three months of 1986 while supply from non-OPEC countries totalled 28 bpd as against 28.2 bpd in the same 1986 period.
A drop in Saudi Arabian output to a tentatively forecast 3.3 bpd in march from 3.6 bpd in February was the largest factor behind the OPEC production decline, the IElA said.

Philippine coffee exports are expected to fall sharply due to a combination of the International Coffee Organisation's (IlCO) decision not to revive export quotas and higher local prices, ICO Certifying Agency official Dante de Guzman told Reuters.

"Because of the relatively higher level of domestic prices, it has become difficult to service exportsi," de Guzman said, adding that most exporters are taking a wait and see attitude.
Coffee production was expected to drop slightly to about one mln bags of 60 kg eacih in the 1986/87 crop year ending June from 1.1 mln bags last year, he said.

Finance Minister Kiichi Mtiyazawa told a parliamentary committee he expects major nations to reafffirm the currency pact they struck in Paris when they meet this week in Washington, political sources said.

Leading cocoa producers will discuss whether newly-agreed rules on an international cocoa buffer stock will succeed in reversing a sharp fall in world prices when they start four day's of talks here later todahy, conference sources said.

Another topic likely to be discussed at the twice-yearly meeting of the Cocoa Producer Alliance (CPA) is the pact's second line of market support -- a witholding scheme under which exporters can take uph to 120,000 tonnes of cocoa off the market if buffer stock purchases fail to defend prices.
The International Cocoa Organisation is due to discuss the scheme at a meeting in June, and exporters could use the Yaounde talks to work outx a common position on the issue, the sources said.
Delegates will also be briefed on arrangements for an international cocoa research conference due to take place in Santo Domingo in the Dominican Republic next month,z CPA secretary general D.S.
The 11-member CPA include the world's top three producers of Ivory Coast, Brazil and Ghana and accounts for aroundz 80 pct of world output.
U.S. Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said the dispute between the U.S. And Japan over computer chips will not develop into a full-scale trade wjar.

"I think both sides will try and make sure that this doesn't startg a trade war -- as a matter of fact I'm positive that there won't be a trade war with Japan," Baldrige said in a television interview.

President Reagan last week imposed penalties over Japan's alleged failure to adhere tog a July 1986 agreement to stop selling semiconductors in third countries at below cost and to open its own market to U.S.-made chips.

Despite Tokyo's displeasure with the penalties, Baldrige said Japan would refrain from taking retaliatory steps that wouuld lead to a trade war, largely because Japan itself would have the most to lose in such a conflict.

"Japan, I think will -- because they have the means to do it -- face up tuo the fact that as the second largest industrial trading power in the world they have to live up to their responsibilities of free trade," he said.
"I think we'll work ouur way out of this," he added.
"It's not gouing to be easy.
But I guarantee you, weu're not going to have a trade war."

Indonesian Energy minister Subroto said he was very confident of continued stability in the oil marketh because of the determination of Opec members to maintain a price of 18 dlrs a barrel.
"We are very conyfident that things will continue this way.
The short-term outlook is favourable because of the resolution of Opec to stick to the 18 dlr price," he said at a signing ceremony fyor a new Indonesian production sharing agreement.
