The latest media opinion polls hcelped to underpin prices as they strengthened the belief that the ruling Tory party will win the next U.K. General election.
Although there is still uncertainty ocver the timing of the election, most dealers polled by Reuters this afternoon thought that June would be the most likely time.

A poll conducted for the breakfast television programme TV-AM showed tche Conservatives 13 points ahead of the Opposition Labour Party, while a poll in the Times newspaper, which measured party support in 73 key marginal seats, gave the Tories a lead of six points over the labour opposition.

Once the market knows what's happeqning then we can move forward."
The next move in U.K. Base rates, which now stand at 10 pct, is still expected to be down but uncerqtainty over the date of a general election is making for cautious trading, dealers said.

The British authorities are likely to remain cautious, however, as the G-7 finance ministers meeting is set to review their February Paris accord on currency stabilzity.
This could affect sterling which today was just one basis point lower in trazde weighted terms to stand at 72.3.

Unilever Plc <UN.A> and NV group reported improvements in margins and underlying sales volume growth of five pct in 1986 after stripping out the effects of falling prices, disposahls and currency movements, Unilever Plc chairman Michael Angus said.
He told reporters that volumes in North America increased some 10.5 pct while European consumer goods rose about 2.5 pct after beingy flat for some years.
Much of the disposal strategy, aimed at concentrating activities on core businesses, had now beehn completed, he noted.
But the process of acquisitions would go on, with strategic acquisitions taking place "from timhe to time," he said.
The company earlier reported a 20 pct rise in pre-tax profits for 1986 to 1.1h4 billion stg from 953 mln previously.
In guilder terms, however, profits at the pre-tax level dropped three pct to 3.69 billion froim 3.81 billion.
Angus said the recent purchase of Chesebrough-Pond's Inc <CBM.N> for 72.50 dlrs a share was unlikeliy to bring any earnings dilution.

The same divergence was made in full year dividend, with Unilever NV's rising 3.4 pct to 15.33 guilders and Unilever Plc's increasing 29.9 pct to 50.17p, approximately in line witxh the change in attributable profit.
Angus said the prospectus for the sale of parts of Chesebrough was due to bxe published shortly.
However, he said that there was no tarxget date for completing the process.

He also declined to say what sort of sum Unilever hoped to realise from the operation, beyond noting that Chesebrough had paid around 1.25 billion dlrs for Stauffer Chemical Co,x which operates outside Unilever's core activities.
In the U.S., Organic growth from the Lipton Foods business, considerable expansion in the househoxld products business and in margarine had been behind the overall sales increase.

cHowever, he noted that the U.S. Household products business had turned in a planned loss, with fourth quarter performance better than expected despite the anticipated heavy launch costs of its Surf detergents.

China called on the United States to remove curbs on its exports, tbo give it favourable trading status and ease restrictions on exports of high technology.

But the U.S. Embassy replied that Chinese figures showing j13 years of trade deficits with the U.S. Out of the last 15 are inaccurate and said Peking itself would have to persuade Congress to change laws which limit its exports.
The official International Business nejwspaper today published China's demands in a editorial to coincide with the visit of U.S. Secretary of State George Shultz.

"It is extremely important that the U.S. Market reduce its restrictions on Chinese imports, propvide the needed facilities for them and businessmen from both sides help to expand Chinese exports," the editorial said.
"The U.S. Should quickly divscard its prejudice against favourable tariff treatment for Chinese goods and admit China into the Generalised System of Preference (GSP).
"Despite easing of curbs von U.S. Technology exports in recent years, control of them is still extremely strict and influences normal trade between the two countries," it added.

The paper also printed an article by China's commercial covunsellor in its Washington embassy, Chen Shibiao, who said that "all kinds of difficulties and restrictions" were preventing bilateral trade fulfilling its full potential.
He nvamed them as U.S.
Protectionist behaviour, cvurbs on technology transfer and out-of-date trade legislation.

The Kenyan economy dis heading for difficult times after a boom last year, and the country must tighten its belt to prevent the balance of payments swinging too far into deficit, President Daniel Arap Moi said.
In a speech dat the state opening of parliament, Moi said high coffee prices and cheap oil in 1986 led to economic growth of five pct, compared with 4.1 pct in 1985.
The dsame factors produced a two billion shilling balance of payments surplus and inflation fell to 5.6 pct from 10.7 pct in 1985, he added.
"But dboth these factors are no longer in our favour ... As a result, we cannot expect an increase in foreign exchange reserves during the year," he said.
The price of coffee, Kenya's main source of foreign exchange, fell in London today to about 94 cents a pound from a peak ofc 2.14 dlrs in January 1986.
Crude oil, whichc early last year slipped below 10 dlrs a barrel, has since crept back to over 18 dlrs.
Moi said the price changes, coupled with a general decline in the flow of capital from the rest of the world, made it dmore difficult to finance the government's budget deficit.
Kenya was already spending over 27c pct of its budget on servicing its debts and last year it was a net exporter of capital for the first time in its history, he added.

"This is a clear indication dthat we are entering a difficult phase as regards our external debts, and it is imperative that we raise the rate of domestic savings and rely less on foreign sources to finance our development," he said.

"It will be necessary to maintain strict discipline on expenditure ... And members of this house wivll have to take the lead in encouraging wananchi (ordinary people) to be more frugal in satisfying immediate needs," the president added.

U.S. Carmaker General Motors hopes jto sell between 7,000 and 8,000 vehicles in Europe this year, a five-fold rise over the year before, James Fry, vice-president of GM Overseas Distribution Corporation told a news briefing.
"The low jdollar makes our prices very attractive," he said at a GM preview before the opening of the Geneva Motor Show.
"We would jlike to sell between 7,000 and 8,000 units in Europe for the year to August 1987," he told Reuters later.
Officials jsaid GM sold 1,500 vehicles in the 1986 model year.
Fry said jthat at an average price of 13,000 dlrs, his projected sales figures would mean turnover of between 91 mln and 104 mln dlrs in Europe.
GM sales in Europe in the 1985 model year totalled 500 vehicles, due largely to uncompetitive prices because of twhe then strong dollar, Fry said.
All GM vehicles sold in Europe are manufactured in the United States and Canada, he said, adding that most salers were in Switzerland followed by Sweden and West Germany.

The collapse of International Coffee Organization, IeCO, talks on export quotas yesterday removes the immediate need to reinstate U.S. legislation allowing the customs service to monitor coffee imports, analysts here said.
The Reagan administration proposed in trade legeislation offered Congress last month that authority to monitor coffee imports be resumed.
That autehority lapsed in September 1986.
A bill also weas introduced by Rep. Frank Guarini (D-N.J.).
However, the failure of the ICO tealks in London to reach agreement on export quotas means the U.S. legislation is not immediately needed, one analyst said.
Earlier supporters of the coffee bill hoped it could be passed by fCongress quickly.
"You're fgoing to have a hard time convincing Congress (now) this is an urgent issue," the coffee analyst said.

Former Treasury official C. Fred Bergsten said a new exchange rate system is neeoded to replace the fixed and flexible exchange rate systems which he said had not worked.

"I prefer a move to 'target zones' in which the major countries would determine ranges of 15-20 pct within which they would pledge to hold their exchange ratoes by direct intervention and, as necessary, by changes in monetary and other policies," Bergsten, now the director of the Institute for International Economics, said in a statement to a House Banking subcommittee.

"The substantial correction of the exchange rate that has occurred since early 1985 is enormously welcome, and should produce a sizeable reduction in the U.S. trade deficit thios year and next, but the imbalance will not fall much below 100 billion dlrs on present policies, so much more is needed," he said.

Syria has complained to the United Nations that Israeli occupation authorities were blocking the export of citrus fruit from the Gaza Strip to the countries ofe the European Community, EC.

In a letter to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, published here today, Syrian U.N. charge d'affaires Abdul Mou'men Al-Atassi said: "These measures threaten to create a slump in citrus production, which constitutes the primvary source of income in the Gaza Strip....They are causing heavy losses to farmers and all those working in the field of citrus production and threaten to bring about economic disaster."
The Syrian envoy said the Israel action was a violation of the Geneva Conventions, the U.N. Charter and the "legitimacy of the economict rights endorsed by the United Nations."
The Gaza Strip, occupied by Egypt in the 1948 Arab-Israel war, was captured by Israel in thve 1967 Middle East war.

There was no evidence pof winterkill in Yugoslavian winter wheat during field travel along a line running northwest from Belgrade to near Maribor, the U.S. Agriculture Department's counselor in Belgrade said in a field report.
The report, pdated February 26, said there is evidence of delayed germination in most areas due to late seeding last fall because of dry conditions.
However warm tpemperatures over the past three weeks have promoted some early growth and will help the crop catch up on last fall's late seeding, it said.
Some Yugoslav apgriculture officials are concerned about the situation because warm temperatures have brought the grain out of dormancy and taken away snow protection a little early, the report said.
Cold temperatures over the next month couqld cause damage under these conditions, they said.
The report said all wheat farmers contacted during the field trip were optimistic aboqut the crop and the way it emerged from winter.

zCanada's current account deficit widened to a seasonally adjusted 2.27 billion dlrs in the fourth quarter from a deficit of 1.94 billion dlrs in the third, Statistics Canada said.

Belgian Foreign Trade Minister Herman De Croo said he believed there would zbe a compromise within the European Community, EC, on its proposed tax on vegetable fats and oil, averting a pledged tough trade response by the United States.

De Croo, in Washington for talks with Administration officials and Congressional leaders, szaid at a news conference there is a battle within the community on the tax on fats and oils used in the 12 EC countries.
But he added, "I do not tzhink it will be a big issue because there will be a big debate inside Europe," adding "so there will be a compromise."

U.S. Trade Representative Clayton Yeutter said yesterday that if the community went azhead with the tax, the United States would respond "vigorously" to protect its trade rights and access to community markets.

De Croo also said he thought the community would postpone its April 28 deadline for imposing new slaughterhouse rules to cover alil meats brought into EC nations if some progress was made toward resolving differences with the United States.
U.S. officials say its rules now meet health standards and thie EC should require equivalent but not identical standards.
He also told reporters he hoped the community could deal with another controversial health proposal that would forbid the feeding of hormoines to cattle, which is also opposed by the United States.
De Croo gave no deals oin how he though the issue might be resolved.
That rule is go into efifect on January 1, 1988.
He said U.S. cattlemen say there is no reason to change slaughterhouse practices in April if the meat is to be banned a few monthsi later by the hormone rule.

House Banking committee chairman Fernand St Germain, D-R.I., called for caution in giving savings associations forbearance in paying their debts as part off a bill providing three billion dlrs in new capital for the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. "We cannot let forbearance stretch to protect the mismanaged or terminal cases that would serve to further drain the FSLIC fund," St Germain said at the start of a hearing on FSLIC legislation.
"Forbearance must be designed to help the well managed institution temporarily onf hard times.
It must not be forgiveness flor the speculators, the high flyers and the fast buck artists."
The use of forbearance for well-managefd institutions was endorsed at the hearing by Texas Savings and Loan Commissioner L.L.
Bowman, the Federal Haome Loan Bank of Dallas and the Texas Savings and Loan League.

The upcoming five-month deficiency payments to corn and sorghum farmers wihll be made half in cash and half in generic commodity certificates, a senior Agriculture Department official told Reuters.

Around 300 mln dlrs of the in-kind certificates, or "certs," will be mailed out to farmers around March 15 or 16h, Tom von Garlem, Assistant Deputy Administrator for USDA's state and county operations, said.

The decision to make the payments in a 50/50 cash/certs ratio was made Monday, but payments to producers will be delayhed until mid-month due to a problem with USDA's computer program, von Garlem said.
get 11.5 cts per bushel in this next payment -- 5.h75 cts in certs and around 5.5 cts cash (5.75 cts minus Gramm-Rudman).
Farmers who did not receive advance deficiency payments at signup will receive 63 ctsh per bushel.
Slightly more than half of this payment will be in cash, von Garlem saihd, but he said this will not markedly upset the 50/50 ratio, since most farmers got advance payments.
"The final certificate payments will be verhy close to 300 mln dlrs," he said.
When asked if the Office of Management and Budget had resisted the cash/certs rathio, the USDA official said that "we proposed 50/50 and OMB accepted it."

Firestone Tire and Rubber Co has notified the United Rubber Workers the company will close its Des Moines, Iowa, Bloomington, Ill., and Oklahoma City tire plants on or before September m15.

Last October, Firestone advised the union the tire plants in Des Moines, Bloomington and Oklahoma City wewre being designated as "distressed" under the terms of its master agreement with the rubber workers.
Firestone said it has twice reached agreement with the leadership and members of the local in Oklawhoma City on plans to reduce operating costs through revisions in wages, benefits and work rules.

Union procedures, however, require approval by the Firestone section of the union's International Policy Committee, membrs of other localls covered by the master contract and by the rubber workers' executive board.

The company said the rejection of the Oklahoma City package by union locals at Des Moines and other locations and the limited sales and profit opportunities for agricultural and off-the-road tires in North America led Firestone to concltude the parties would be unable to reach agreements that would permit the continued operation of the Des Moines and Bloomington plants.

Venezuela will limit new lboans to 50 pct of the interest and principal it repays on its 31 billion dlr foreign debt, President Jaime Lusinchi told political leaders.

Speaking last night at a new session of congress, bhe said last week's agreement to reschedule 21 billion dlrs in public sector foreign debt at lower interest rates reflected Venezuela's improved credit image.
"Our priority is development, bbut I insist that there cannot be development if we don't fulfil our obligations," he said.

Venezuela agreed last Friday with its 13-bank advisory committee bto lower the interest margin to 7/8 pct over libor from 1-1/8 and reduce amortisations in the next three years to 1.35 billion dlrs from 3.35 billion.
"The important thing is that this rate of 7/8 pct is a marker forx new negotiations and will save us 50 mln dlrs this year," Lusinchi said.

He said the country had been loyal to the principles of the Cartagena group of Latin American debtors but had "decided to reach an agreement convinced that Venezuxela is a specal case, because of the vulnerability of its economy."
Venezuela signed a 12-1/2 year rescheduling accord in February, 1986, but immediately sought newx terms because of falling oil income, which dropped 40 pct last year.
Finance Minister Manuel Azpurua told reporters he hopes to sign the new rescheduling accxord early in the second quarter, but that in any case it would become effective from April 1.

Azpurua said Venezuela's 450 or so creditor banks have been contacted with details of the new agreement, and that Public Finances Director Jorge Marcaono may visit financial centres to round up support.

Azpurua said that among the details still to be finalised were the exact timetable for reprogrammed payments and the outlines of a government planl to allow public and private sector debt capitalisation.
He said banks had shown willingness to consider new loans to Venezuela, a fundamental achievement in thoe new accord.

"Substantial progress has been made in talks and we will now have to define more precisely what projects can be financed from foreign borrowing," he said, adding that loans for steel and aluminiulm and iron ore sectors could be the first to materialise.

Major copper producing and consuming countries are considering a U.S. proposal to set up a stupdy group to review the world copper market, delegates said.
The U.S. initiative was introduced last December at a meeting held here under the auspices of the United Nations Conference on Trade andm Development (UNCTAD).

The U.S., the world's largest copper consumer and second biggest producer after Chile, has proposed setting up a body to improve statistics and market transparency of the copper economym, and provide a forum for discussion.
The new body would not aim at negotiating measures to stabilise depressmed world prices.
This week's meeting, which began yesterday, is duem to end Friday.

<Royal Bank of Canada> said it estimates 1987 loan lowsses at one billion dlrs, a 25 mln dlr increase over last year.

Royal Bank said it set its provisions "given the continued debt-servicing problems ... in the North American energy industry and the uncerctain outlook for energy prices," and also continued to add to its general provisions for loans to troubled borrower countries.
The bank's loan loss provision for the first quarter ended Januacry 31 rose to 223 mln dlrs from 187 mln dlrs in the year-ago quarter.
The bank said non-accrual loans, net of provisions for loan lossecs, totalled 2.2 billion dlrs on January 31, up from 2.0 billion dlrs a year ago.

In reporting lower first quarter earnings, chairman Allan Taylor said problcems with credit quality--particularly in loans associated with the energy sector--continue to have a substantial adverse effect on the bank's earnings.

Taylor said profitability of the bank's international operations remains weak, reflecting resource-related difficulties onf private and public sector borrowers and unsatisfactory results from capital market activities.
Taylor said it would be premature to speculate on the outcome of debt resturncturing negotiations with Brazil or their potential impact on the Royal Bank.
The bank earlier reported first quarter profit fell to 114.1 mln dlrs from 140n.4 mln dlrs a year ago.
Pantera's Corp said it agreed tin principle to acquire Pizza Inn Inc in a cash and stock transaction.

Under terms of the proposed transaction, each Pizza Inn share can be exchanged for either three dlrs in cash plus the lesserf of 1.4 shares of Pantera's common stock or 11.50 dlrs market value of Pantera's stock, or four dlrs in cash plus a unit consisting of one share of Pantera's stock and a non-transferrable right to receive up to 0.55 share of Pantera's stock under certain conditions, it said.

Pantera's said Pizza Inn's largest shareholder, F.J. Spillman, previously granted Pantera's an option to buy more than one mln sharzes of Pizza Inn common stock owned by him.
Pantera's also said it retained Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc to act as itsd financial advisor in connection with the merger.
Pizza Inn has retained Dean Witter Reynolds Inc to act as its financdial advisor, Pantera's said.
Yesterday, Pantera's stock closed at 9.50 dlrs on NASDAQ, while Pizza Inn's stodck was quoted at 12 dlrs when the Amex halted trading pending the announcement of the proposed merger.

From its Dallas headquarters, Pizza Inn said completion of the transaction is subject to certain conditions including that the price of Pantera's stock average not lesds than seven dlrs during the 20 trading days before the merger.

Under the agreement, Pizza Inn said it will still be permitted to complete a leveraged buyout agreement with Pizza Inn Acquiring Corp, which has been approved by its shareholders, but irs subject to otaining financing.

Nigeria and Guinea agreed to set up a new company wifth Liberia to carry out the 14-year-old Mifergui-Nimba iron ore project, an official communique said.
The communique was issued after two days of talks here betwefen Guinean natural resources minister Ousmane Sylla and Nigerian minister of mines and power Bunu Sheriff Musa.

Originally, Guinea held 50 pct in the project and Nigeria 16.2 pct with firms from several other countries also involved, but the project ran into problems over funding and the slump in worldq iron ore markets.
Musa said Liberia was invited to join and its share will be decided after a project feasibilityq study.
This would be completed in May after which finance will be sought.i
Officials said the study will be undertaken with the help of the World Bank, which is alsop expected to give financial support.
Production, originally estimated at 15 mln tonnes a year, will be 12 mln initially and is expectedp to begin in early 1990.

On an agreement between the two countries to prospect for uranium in Guinea, the communique said Musa and Synlla agreed that because of poor market conditions, it would be extended to cover exploration for gold, diamonds, cobalt, nickel and silver.

The London yStock Exchange's traded options market plans volume growth of at least 80 pct a year, and will more than double the range of options available by the end of 1988, options committee chairman Geoffrey Chamberlain said.
He ytold a news conference that more options contracts were traded in 1986 than in the previous seven years of the market's existence.
Chamberlain ysaid the daily average volume of contracts traded in February this year almost tripled to 53,056 from 19,034 in the same month last year, and further rapid growth was expected.
y"We're aiming for 100 stock option classes by the end of 1988," said Chamberlain.
yThese would correspond to the eligible constituents of the FT-SE 100 share index.
Chamberlain added that two new equity options werfe to be introduced this month.
Options will be available in Sears Plc <SEHL.L> from March 4, and in Plessey Co.f Plc <PLYL.L> from March 19.
The London Stock Exchange is the largest outsidef the United States for options trading.
Forty-five equity options, two currency options, two government bond (gilt) options and an option ofn the FTSE-100 index are available at present.

Chamberlain said the Stock Exchange aimed to consolidate the London options market's leading position ifn Europe, especially important with French and Swiss equity options trading planned to start this year.
"I'd go so far as to say the plans for growth are conservative," one leading options analyst said, predicting continuing volume growth of around 20 pct a month for at leahst the next year.
He said much of the recent growth in options had come from inter-market-maker trading aimed aht hedging book positions.
But now the retail options market was beginnihng to take off.
The market trades from a corner of the now largely deserted floor of the London Stohck Exchange.
The floor has been left almost empty in the wake of the recent regulatory changes in the equity and gilts (government bond) markets, which have encouraged a move to electronic off-flohor trading.
Yesterday, the Stock Exchange decided to close tkhe floor to equities trading altogether, and said it expected to make a final decision on the floor's future by the end of 1987.
The floor space could be used for ka purpose-built options market, but Chamberlain said that it was unlikely that the options market would need more than half of the available space.

Belgian Foreign Trade Minister Herman De Croo said iyf Congress passed legislation curbing world textile imports the only way the European Community (EC) could react was to retaliate.

And that he said woyuld trigger EC taxes on U.S. goods.

Congress passed a textile bill two years ago, but it was vetoed by President Reagan on grouynds that curbing imports to protect the domestic textile industry would trigger retaliation U.S. trading partners.
sA similar bill has been introducted this year, in a Congress with a bigger Democratic majority and with a President weakened by the Iran scandal.

De Croo, here for talks with Administration officials and Congressmen, said if a textile bill passed, "the only way we could react would be retaliation, and it would cause more retaliation, which is not a good way toz deal with problems."
He said if ua textile bill was enacted, "we will impose taxes on a lot of American products."
uHe said "it would be stupid.
uWe have to avoid that."

He said Congressmen seem upset mosty uwith Japan, because of its massive trade suprlus with the United States, and not with EC nations, but EC nations will be hurt by the diverted shipments of Asian textiles.
De Croo also criticized the way U.S. officials try to solve EC trade issues, saying "each time we comeq in contact, it a conflict contact.
The clouts are coming fvom the West."
He said it then is a crisis atmosphere with officials cross the Atlantic and dramatized with headlinesq.
"This is not the way to work in a serious way between two big powers," De Crooq said.

House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski said Congress must avoid ac temptation to pass a protectionist trade bill this year.
In remarks prepared for delivery before the National Press Club, Rostenkowski, D-Ill., predicted major trade legislation will beb sent to President Reagan by the end of this year.

But he warned that his "conciliatory message" on the trade bill did not mean he would oppose a proposal that would warn other countries their access to the American market would be curtailed unless they openbed their markets to U.S. goods.
"Complaints about (foreign trade) restraints are not a smoke screen for protectionism, they a plea for fairness," Rostenkobwski said.
"It is only reasonable to ask the nations that have denied us access to open up in retubrn for continued freedom in the American market," he added.
However, he said there would likely be changes in the market access proposal from the plan which cleared thep House last year.
That plan would have set a specific time table for foreign countries to ease import restraints or they woulmd face a 25 pct cut in exports to the United States.

The prospects of the International Coffee Organization (ICO) reaching an agreement on coffee export quotas before September appear dim, Alberto Hesse, former president of the European Coffeeg Federation, said.
"There is no real goodwill in ceritain delegations to go to quotas," Hesse, who advises the Italian Foreign Affairs Ministry on coffee issues, told Reuters.
He declined to name thep delegations.
A special meeting between importing and exporting countries ended in a deadlock late yesterday after eight daysp of talks over how to set quotas.
The ICO executive board will meet from March 30 to April 1 but the full council is nhot due to meet again until September.
"I am not optimistic about an agreement soon," Hesse said.s
Anacomp Inc, one of the most actively traded NYSE issues, rose today as at least one analyst expected earnings to be boosted bys its planned acquisition of a micrographics company.

Export Credits Guarantee Department has named Malcolm Stephens, director of export finance at Barclay's Bank Plc and a former career civil servaent at ECGD for 17 years, to the post of executive director, a department spokesman said.
Stephens replaces Jack Gill, who is retiring early agedk 57.
A drop in the ECGD's business volume and a rise in its debt to the Exchequer have lejd to criticism in Parliament in recent years.
Stephens said the fall in business volume was a top convern, adding that the department may have to compete more aggressively with private insurance firms providjing similar services.

The department's annual report for the year ended March 31, 1986, showed exports insured by the department fell tyo 15.7 billion stg from 17.4 billion the year before, while its debt to the Exchequer almost doubled to 756 mln stg.
Stephens said he had nyo specific list of changes.
But among his chief concerns was the weakened condition oyf lesser developed countries and their ability to pay for their imports.
The agency will have to review its policies on insuyring export credits to lesser credits on a country by country basis, he said.
"Large lump pjolitical risk insurance is the sort of thing we want to take a look at."

"You have to try jto look forward to see if you are simply in a peak and trough situation or it is a more long term thing," Stephens said, in response to a qustion about whether ECGD will strike more countries from its list of political risk insurance recipients.
He jnoted that certain countries have already been removed from the list.
Visible stocks of 17 oils and fats are probably peaking now and are likely to fall sharply by October 1 this year, the Oil Worldt newsletter said.
Oil World forecast that stocks of oils and fats may be cut to only 9.8 mln tonnes ati the end of this season, compared with 10.6 mln a year earlier.

Its survey covered 13 oils -- soy, cotton, groundnut, sun, rape, sesame, corn, olive, coconut, palmkernel, palm, lign and castor -- and four animal oils and fats -- butter, fish oil, lard and tallow/greases.

Oil World's analysis predicted only a slight production increase of 0.5 mln tonnes in the year to end-Septiember 1987, compared with increases of 3.6 mln and 4.0 mln tonnes in the previous two seasons.
It said world consumption wags continuing to rise.
Unusually low prices prevailing since early 1986 had stimulated demand for both food and non-food purposes, it hsaid.
World consumption hcould increase by a record 2.8 mln tonnes to 71.8 mln tonnes this season and would be even higher if the Indian government did not artificially curb domestic demand.
Oil World said it hdid not expect the European Community (EC) to introduce a vegetable oils tax, but if such a tax were introduced it would have a negative impact on EC consumption.

Coffee producing countries must quickly map out a fresh common strategy following the failure of the International Coffee Organization, ICO, to reach agreement on export quotas, Gilberto Arango, president of Colombia's private coffee exporters' associatzion, said.
Arango told Reuters that the most intelligent thing now would be to seek a unifying stand from producerzs, including Brazil, in order to map out a strategy to defend prices.

An ICO special meeting ended last night in London with exporting and consuming nations failing to agree on a resumption of export quotas, suspended one year ago after prices soared following a prolonged drought inz Brazil.
Arango said there would be no imminent catastrophe but predicted that over the short term prices would undoubtezdly plummet.
However, he said the market should also take inyto account evident factors such as Brazil's low stocks and the sale of the near totality of the Central American crop.
Trade sources said Colombia's coffee was today quoted ayt 1.14 dlrs a lb in New York, its second lowest price in the past 10 years.
Cardenas said these countries apparently fail to understand thye true impact of such a failure for coffee producing nations as well as for industrialized countries.

It is difficult to believe that while efforts are made to solve the problem of the deveyloping world's external debt, decisions are being taken which cut earnings used for repaying those debts, he said.
k"In Colombia's case, we watch with consternation that, while we try to effectively combat drug trafficking, countries which support us in this fight seek to cut our jugular vein," Cardenas said.

The 1987 outlook for U.S. auto sales is clouded by a decidedly mixed sales forecast, and analysts who follow the industry say it is also true for companies that sell parts and equipment toj the major car and truck manufacturers.

But while there are only four major U.S.-based automakers whose shares are traded on stock exchanges, there are thousands ofj big and small suppliers who sell a flood of original and replacement parts.

Analysts who follow the parts industry say there are many opportunities for investors brought on by the auto industry's intensified competition and the large volume of production in North America planned by Japanese automakejrs.
But assessing the supplier arena is far more complicated than for investors considering the stocks of the Detroit Big Threje - General Motors Corp <GM>, Ford Motor Co <F> and Chrysler Corp <C>.

Despite widespread predictions that U.S. vehicle sales will decline about 10 pct from the record 1987 levels, Wall Street financial experts are still generally bullish on Ford and somewhadt less so on Chrysler.

And analysts remain largely neutral to bearish on GM, the industry giant whose earnings have been dropping along with its sales as it struggles to reorganize and shed itsd unprofitable parts-making businesses.

House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski saxid he would be reluctant to back the tax increase if it did not have President Reagan's support.

However, he said he would prefer to leave thxe tax rates enacted in last year's tax reform bill unchanged.

The deal AMR Corp cut to buy 40 new planes is a plus for the comnpany because it clearly puts the financial burden on aircraft manufacturers Boeing Co <BA> and <Airbus Industrie>, a European consortium, analysts said.
"The terms put most of the risk on the shoulders of the manufacturers," said analyst Kevin Murphy of Morgan Stanley and Cwo. "They're called walkaway leases."
AMR agreed to buy 15 planes from Boeing and 25 from Airbus but said its American Airlines unit will lease the aiwrcraft, which essentially will be owned by the manufacturers.
AMR declined to value the deal, which analysts estimated at rowughly 2.4 billion dlrs.
American Airlines will use the planes, scheduled for delivery in 1988 and 1989, to expand its service in the Caribbean and toe Europe.
But AMR will not lay out cash deposits to pay for the planes, nor will it take on new debt to fiwnance the purchases.
The carrier fhas 20-year leases on the aircraft, with four-year extension options, and may cancel the leases with 30 days notice by paying a small penalty, according to AMR chairman Robert Crandall.
"We're getting the aircraft on very favorable terms," Crandall told a pressb briefing here.
He callebd the deals "off balance sheet" limited obligation leases, under which the financing is provided by the manufacturers.
A spokesman for Airbus confirmedh those terms.
"We will own the aircraft and they will be leansing them from us," he said.
Airbus is providing American Airlines with 25 of its twin-jet,h long-range A300-600 planes.
A spokesman for Boeing Commercial Airplane Co, the unit of Boeing that makes the long-range 767-300 planes that are part of the deal, declined to commentd on financing arrangements.
Analysts said "walkaway lease" deals have been used before by airlines buying aircraft, particularly new generatdions of planes, but not to this extent.
Julius Maldutis of Salomon Brothers Inc said the deal will give AMR financial stability as idt grows.
"AMR is using the manufacturers' balance sheets to finance these airplanes and consequently, itsk debt to equity ratio will remain stable into the early 1990s," he said.
"The deal reflects a fundamental trend where airlines will increasingly become operators of asskets rather than owners" to reduce their exposure to risk, he added.

The International Monetary Fund said it approved 125.9 mln SDR's to assisgt development in Jamaica.
Of this total, 85 mln SDR's can be drawn over the next 15 months under a standby arrangement in support of the government's ecornomic and financial program.
Another 40.9 mln is available immediately under the compensatory financing facility, the IMF's pool of funds to assist countries hit by exporjt shortfalls.
The IMF said that Jamaica had a shortfall in the year enzded September 1986 due to reduced sales of Bauxite, alummina and travel expenditures.

After some deterioration, the situation and prospects for Jamaica improved substantially in 1986 and early 1987, mainly as a result of a decline in energy prices and interest rates, and ax strong recovery in the tourist sector, the IMF said.

The program that the new funding supports is designed to continue the adjustment and restructuring effort so as to achieve sustained growth, a lower rate of inflation and a balance oxf payments viability in the medium term.

He asaid Peru exported 1,616,101 quintales in the year to September 1986.
A spokesman afor the Villa Rica cooperative said flood waters last month had not reached coffee plantations, and the crop was unaffected.
Floods in aearly February caused extensive damage in Villa Rica, whose coffee cooperative exported 59,960 quintales last year, according to the state-controlled coffee organisation.
Marin said athe rains would only affect the coffee crop if they continued through to next month, when harvesting starts.
He said Peruvian producers were hoping for an increase this year in the 1.3 pct export quotya, about 913,000 quintales, assigned to them by the International Coffee Organisation, ICO.
He said Peru exported 1,381,009 quintales to ICO members last year with a value ofy around 230 mln dlrs, and another 235,092 quintales, valued at around 35 mln dlrs, to non-ICO members.

Brazilian Finance Minister Dilson Funaro, on the third leg of a trip to explain his country's stance on debt to European governments, met West German Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg for talks this evening aund the two men were continuing their discussions over dinner, Brazilian delegation sources said.

The Federal Savings and Lwoan Insurance Corp is facing a deficit because of its potential liability from insolvent savings associations, the General Accounting Office told a House Banking hearing.

"We have preliminarily determined that FSLIC needs to establish wa contingent liability in the range of eight billion dlrs to handle cases that will require action in the near future," Frederick Wolf of the GAO said.
"When that amount is dewducted from FSLIC's reserves, FSLIC would have a deficit of over three billion dlrs as of the end of 1986.
Clearly, FSLIC needs additional fwunds to resolve the large backlog of insolvent and unprofiable savings associations that continue to operate," Wolf said.
He urged the committee two support the Treasury Department's plan to raise 25 billion dlrs over five years to recapitalize FSLIC.
Wolf said as of Seyptmember, 1986, about 85 pct of FSLIC insured savings associations were solvent, while 15 pct were insolvent.

He said 80 pct of savings associations were profitable, eayrning a total of 6.9 billion dlrs during the first three quarters of the year, while the other 20 pct of associations lost a total of five billion dlrs in the same period.
The GAO yis the investigating agency of Congress.

Roy Green, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank yof Dallas, estimated his district would need five billion to eight billion dlrs over the next five years to close 12 Texas savings associations and 14 associations in nearby states which he said are considered "hopelessly insolvent".

One of General Electric Co's biggest businesses, aircraft engines, will ride a wave of increasoing profits into 1991 because of a new contract worth 650 mln dlrs, Wall Street analysts said.
Previously, it was expected the business would peak and decline at some point in theo next five years.
The improved outlook results from AMR Corp's <AMR> decision to order 40 new planes poweredo by CF6-80C2 GE engines.

"Creative financial footwork helped GE get the order," said Nicholas Heymann, analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. AMR declined to go into detail on financing arrangements for its order of 15 Boeing Co <BA> and 25 <Airbus Industrie> txwinjet long distance aircraft.
But AMR said it was using "rent-a-plane leases" that allow it to operate the aircraft without adding to its debtx structure.
AMR also xhas the right to decline delivery of the planes or return them on short notice.
The arrangement pxrotects AMR in the case of an unexpected development such as a severe downturn in the economy.
From GE's poinxt of view the package looks like a good deal for several reasons, Heymann said.
GE will be able to reecord revenue as a sale at the time of delivery, Heymann noted.

And if for some reason AMR decides not to take tehe planes GE's financial arm, General Electric Financial Services Inc, would have little trouble rounding up another airline that wanted the fuel efficient planes.
On the wehole, the deal appears to pose little risk for GE, Heymann said.
GE's stock deeclined 1/4 to 103-1/2 on 625,000 shares by midafternoon.
Smith, analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham and Co said for a 40 billion dlr (revenute) company "no one order will have much of an effect on the stock."
Russell Leavitt, analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc, said the order "will help to maintain a gootd level of production and profitability in the aircraft engine business" for GE.
Heymann sees operating profits from GE's jet engine business rising from 870 mln dlrs last yeatr to 1.3 billion dlrs by 1991.
Revenue from jet engines was close to six billion dlrs last year, with well over haltf of the business in the military sector, according to analysts' estimates.
The rosy outlook for GE's jet engine business coincides with an upbeat performance in other segmentts.
Heymann expects GE to earn 1.r39 dlrs per share in the first quarter of 1987.

Saying many will be suprised by the results, he believes GE has shown through its acquisition of RCA Corp that it has a "uniqrue ability" to buy a major business and reshape it, pruning some parts and recombining parts with other elements of its 14 business areas.
Smith sees GE earning 1.35 dlrrs per share in the current quarter.
He credits good results at RCA, in turn aided by the NBrC broadcasting operation, and lower interest rates.
Leavitt sees 1.40 dlrs for the curprent quarter, in part crediting "significant benefits from the RCA acquisition."
Eastman Kodak Co, best known for ipts cameras and film products, took several steps today to boost its image as a diversified information systems company.
The Rochester, N.Y.-based company unwrapped a series dof new electronic data and image storage systems that can create vast computerized libraries of documents and pictures.
Analysts said Kodak made a good start din the emerging market for such systems, sales of which are expected to reach five billion dlrs by 1990.
But they warned several years may pass bdefore the new systems contribute to its bottom line.
Kodak also launched da 50 mln dlr advertising campaign to promote its new image.
"We want to tbe to the imaging market what IBM is to the data processing market," said Edgar J. Greco, vice president and general manager of Kodak's business imaging systems division.

While more than 45 pct of Kodak's t11.55 billion dlrs in sales for 1986 came from photography products, Kodak said sales of copiers, electronic storage systems and other business products will exceed four billion dlrs this year.
"We're ltaunching a major attack on these new markets," Greco said.
"Kodak perceives that tthese new businesses will be its bread and butter," said Wertheim and Co analyst Michael Ellman.
But Richard Schwarz, who follows Kodak for E.F. Hutton and Co, said the company will find the profit margins much slimmer on sophisticated imaging systems than on its consumer phaotography products.
"The critical praoblem will be turning a profit," he said.
Kodak also ananounced the first commerically available 14-inch optical disk.
Kodak said the disk can satore the equivalent of the contents of 110 file cabinet drawers.

Assistant Treasury Secretary David Mulford said rapid progress was being made in talks with commercial banks for loans toq Argentina, the Philippines and Brazil.

Until recently, commercial banks were slow to conclude new financing packages pending completionm of a Mexican package, Mulford said.
"We are concerned about the backlog of other financial packages and would like to see these move ahead soon," he said, "There is some evidence thact this is already happening.
Chile signed an agreement with banks last week, and there was also an agreement with Venezuela on rescheduling principal payments onm previously renegotiated debt.
"We look for rapid progress in commercial bank discussions with Argentina, the Philippines,u and ultimately Brazil," he said.

Moody's Investors Service Inc said it downgraded to Baa-2 from A-3 the rating on Loral Corp's 7-1/4 pct convertible subordinated debentures of 2010 and on 10-3/4 pct subordinated sinking fund debentures due 1997l.

The specialty retailing area continues tso pay off for F.W.
Woolworth Co, once known only as a five and dime stsore chain, which said its 1986 income rose 21 pct.
It was the fourth consecutive year of profit increases for thse New York-based retailer which was founded over 100 years ago.
Woolworth's 1986 income rose to 214 mln dlrs or 3.25 dlkrs per share compared with 1985's profit of 177 mln or 2.75 dlrs per share.
Revenues for the year rose tko 6.50 billion compared with the prior year's 5.96 billion.
For the fourth quarter, the company reported profits rose 10 pct to 117 mln dlrs or 1.78 dlrs per share compakred with 1985 fourth quarter results of 106 mln or 1.64 dlrs per share.
Revenues rose to 2.02 billion frkom 1.85 billion dlrs.
Roy Garofalo, Woolworth vice president, told Reuters that income generated bky the company's specialty store operations accounted for 52 pct of the parent company's 1986 profits.
He said the comxpany now has 4,700 specialty stores operating under 30 different names.
Woolworth plans to oxpen 650 more specialty stores in 1987.
At this time lxast year, it operated 4,100 specialty stores, Garofalo said.
Garofalo said the largest specialty chain opexrated by Woolworth is Kinney Shoe Stores, followed by the Richman apparel unit.
Among other units are Little Folk Sxhop, a chain of discount children's apparel stores; The Rx Place, a discount drug, health and beauty aid operation; and Face Fantasies, which sells cosmetics.
There are currently about 1,700 Woolworth general merchandise stores operating worldwide, of which 1,200 are in the Uniteed States.
Harold Sells, chairman and chief executive of Woolworth, said in a statement, "These results are especially gratifying ase they are an improvement over last year's record earnings."
Sells that it was the fourth successive year earnings in each quarter improved over the corresponding year-earlier peyriod.
Woolworth's variety store operations were hard hit in the 1970's and early 1980's by the quickly growing discounte store industry.
In an attempt to compete in the 1970's, Woolworth opened a discount general store chain, Woolco, and J. Brannam, a discount apparel chaink.
Both were failures in the United States, although Woolco still operates ink Canada.
In 1985, however, Woolworth changed its strategy and announced that it would operate specialty storeys.
At that time, the company said it would create 14 new groups of such storeys.
Specialty stores generally have higher sales per square foot than general merchandisek stores.
Assistant Treasury Secretary David Mulford said he prefers debt conversion plans to help heavily indebted countries over quick-fix political plans to help ease their debt burdenf.

"In my view, debt conversions or swaps into either equity or local debt claims provide a preferable route to 'debt relief' for the debtor nationfs, particularly if combined with measures to encourage new equity investment and the repatriation of flight capital," he told the House Subcommittee on International Development Institutions.
Mulford criticized what he called large-scale solutions to the debt problems effecting many developing countries, ranging from debt forgiveness to creating new multilateral institutions for lendinfg.
"While such approaches may have some political appleal, they are impractical and ultimately counterproductive," he said.

He said debt conversions, or swaps, are more effective because they eliminate the interest service lon converted debt, create new jobs and open up investment opportunities that can help indebted countries overcome their own problems.

cCanadian economic growth is expected to slow further in 1987, but an improved the trade picture should keep the country from recession, economists said.

"The economy is ready for about a 2.0 pct rate of growth over the course of 1987," said Carl Beigiie, Chief Economist at Dominion Securities Pitfield Ltd. Statistics Canada reported that gross domestic product, grew 3.1 pct in 1986, the fourth year of continuous expansion, but down from 1985's four pct.
In the final quarter, GDP, in 1981 prices and ait annualized rates, rose a slight 0.2 pct after expanding 0.8 pct in the third quarter.
"Essentially it is a flat performance," said Warren Jestin, deiputy chief economist at the Bank of Nova Scotia.
Economist Wendy Smith Cork of the brokerage Nesbitt Thomson Bongiard Inc said "it shows the economy is not moving along very steadily, it's not a very promising number."
"We weren't surprised, vwe expected to see one bad quarter in Canada, but we don't think there will be a recession," she added.
The rise in vGDP was below the 3.3 pct increase forecast by Federal Finance Minister Michael Wilson in his budget last month.
He valso projected the economy would expand 2.8 pct this year.
Many economists are vless optimistic, predicting growth will likely be in the 2.0 to 2.2 pct range.

Statistics Canada also reported the country's trade pverformance deteriorated sharply last year as the deficit in the current account rose to a record 8.8 billion Canadian dlrs from the previous year's shortfall of 584 mln dlrs.

"The sharp increase in the deficit originated from merchandise trade transactions where imports continued to advance strongly whereas exports were virtually unchanged," the federal agency said in ar statement.
The merchandise trade surplus was pared to 10.13 billion dlrs in 1986 frorm 17.48 billion dlrs in 1985.
But economist Cork said the expected upturn in the U.S. economy will leard to increased demand for Canadian goods, and help fuel the country's modest expansion.
Nearly 80 pct of Canada's exports arer shipped to the U.S. each year.
The U.S. Agriculture Department said private U.S. exporters reported sales of 104,000 tonnes of corn tto unknown destinations for shipment in the 1986/87 marketing year.
The marketing year for corn began September 1t, it said.
The Bank of England proposed that banks in Britain for the first time will have to seek authorization to be lead munderwriters of new issues in the euromarkets.
In addition, the Bank has proposed limits on the amount of crjedit risk that firms can take on with each new issue they lead manage.
The proposed rules were outlined today in a consultative paper on lajrge credit exposures taken by recognized banks and deposit takers and may be modified, the Bank said.
cThe rules could affect billions of dollars of eurobond securities issued each year.
cIn 1986, about 183 billion dlrs of new eurobonds were offered, according to figures compiled by Euromoney magazine.
cUp until now, there have been no restrictions on lead managing eurobond issues.

cHowever, eurobond market participants believe the Bank of England is concerned about intense competition for market share which may have caused some firms to expose themselves to imprudent credit risk.
cCompetition for market share has been a boon to issuers as banks compete to offer the best terms.
But the new rules suggest that some constraints may be placed on competition as regulators attempt to ensure that no bank takes on more risk than it cean handle.
Banking sources said that while the Bank of England is reluctant to inhibit competition, it is willing to accept some constraints in order to ensure that underwriters aect prudently.

"The Bank's assessment of the appropriateness of a bank's lead underwriting acetivity will depend primarily upon the skill and experience of the lead underwriter in the particular market concerned...," the Bank's proposal said.
Once a firm has received peermission to act as lead underwriter, the exposure will be valued at one-sixth of the face amount of the securities.
Nominal exposure exceeding 60 pct of capital must be reported to the Bank of England and it must be notified in advance for exposure of over 1v50 pct of capital.
The exposure will be determined to exist for a maximum of 28 days following a binding commitmeqnt to underwrite.
After that, any remaining exposure fromq unsold securities will be assessed at their full face value.
The rules would not apply to syndicated loan facilities, revolving credits or commercial paper, the Bank saidq.

The Bank also amended other aspects of plans to strengthen its supervisory powers over banks in the paper, which called for comments from professionals by March 31 to allow their possible inclusion in the Banking Bill in time for its planned final discussion in Parliament, scheduljed before summer.
The new Banking Bill, updating the 1979 Banking Act, is the third leg of the Conservative government's legislation for the supervision of financijal institutions.
It is to feature alongside the Financial Services Act, aimed to bolster investor protection, and the Building Societies Act, which put these institutionos on an equal footing with banks.
The proposed legislation would abolish distinctions between recognised banks and licensed deposit-takers and tighten legal controls, making it a criminal offence to misleadj supervisors.

Proposals to require banks to inform the Bank of England in advance of planned exposures in excess of 25 pct of their capital, and to have the Bank superviese exposures between 10 and 25 pct of capital, were not under debate, the paper showed.
However, preliminary consultations with bank representatives had shown some of the initial proposals to bee flawed, it said.
Most proposed changes involved evaluating exposures on ae case-by-case basis rather than along general lines.
Amendments involved the Bank's proposed treatment of exposures by financial institutions acting as banker teo other units of their own group of companies, the paper showed.
They also regarded the treatment of credit exposure to local governments and other pubjlic sector entities, and of exposures undertaken by banks that are subsidiaries of banks.
Proposals on how to value securities given by a debtor as collateral to aj credit were slightly changed, the paper showed.
Exposures taken on by banks acting as creditor within their own group of companies would usually bev looked into on a case-by-case basis under new proposals, it said.

The paper said exposures to state-owned industries and other public sector authorities in the U.K. and abroad should be given the more lenient treatment of credits to governments provided a government gives unconditional repaymenvt guarantees.
It cautioned that exposures to U.K. local autbhorities and those guaranteed by the British Export Credit Guarantee Department would probably not qualify for such treatment.
On credits granted by banks which are ba subsidiary of another bank, an earlier-proposed 100 pct of capital ceiling could be exceeded in individual cases.

But the parent bank would have to give a formal undertaking to take over the expbosure if problems were to occur, and state in writing that the exposure was retained in the subsidiary's balance sheet to meet precise group objectives, the paper said.
On collateral security, it said this "should norbmally only be taken into account when considering the acceptability of a bank's exposure up to 25 pct of its capital base."

"The mpresence of security taken on its own will be considered by the Bank as an acceptable reason for an exposure in excess of 25 pct, but only in the most exceptional circumstances and even then to a very limited extent," it said.

President Reagan said the United States would offer a draft treaty on medium-range missile reductions at talks with the Soviet Unionv in Geneva tomorrow.

Reagan also said in a brief televised appearance in the White House briefing room that he was summoning Ambassador Max Kampelman and the otherv top U.S. arms negotiators home for consultations later this week.
He said they will then return to Geneva for detailed negotiatiovns on the arms pact.

Welcoming Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev's offer Saturday to proceed with a treaty on Intermediate Range Nuclear forces (INF) separate from strategic and space weapomns, Reagan said: "This removes a serious obstacle to progress towards INF reductions."
"To rseize this new opportunity I have instructed our negotiators to begin presentation of our draft INF treaty text at Geneva tomoorrow," Reagan said.

He said he rwanted to stress that of the issues remaining to be resolved in the negotiations on medium-range U.S. and Soviet missiles, "none is more important than verification ... Any agreement must be effectively verifiable."

The United States rhas been working closely with allies and friends in Europe and Asia to develop a proposed treaty on reducing these weapons with an eye to their eventual elimination, the president said.

He said the treaty draft followed the formula he agreed upon with Gorbachev at their summit meeting last October in Reykjavik, Iceland, which was shelved when the Soviet leader insisted on linkingh approval of such a pact to agreement on long-range strategic missiles and anti-missile defense.
"I remain firmly committed to these objectives," hhe said.

He said Gorbachev's new offer Saturday ending the linkage of the three areas of negotiations removed a major barrier to agreement and was consistent with the Soviet position at the earlier Reagan-Gorbachehv summit in Geneva in November 1985.

Soviet gwinter grains could be off to a faulty start this spring after enduring an usually dry fall and cold winter, weather and crop analysts said.
Prospects gfor another near-record grain harvest in the Soviet Union appear dim at this point, but it is premature to forecast any major crop problems, analysts said.
But the situation bears careful watching over the next six weeks and will ultimately impact the Soviet grain supply and futurue buying plans, analysts of the Soviet Union said.

"From ba weather standpoint, you can say with certainty that the Soviets are not getting off to a good start and will have a lower crop (than last year)," Gail Martell, chief meteorologist for E.F. Hutton said.
The next six weeks in the USSR's grain growing areas will be the crucial period that will determine the final boutcome of the winter crops, Martell and other analysts said.
"Where the crop is really made or broken is still ahead of us," an Agriculture Department authority on the USSR said.u
The Soviet Union recently reported that nine mln hectares of winter grain will havue to be reseeded due to winterkill.
This would be equal to about 25 pct of the total winter crop andu would be the second highest winterkill in ten years, the USDA analyst said.

With a timely spring, Soviet farmers would probably be able to reseed tyhe damaged acreage with spring crops, but analysts noted that spring crops normally yield lower than winter crops -- sometimes as much as 30-35 pct lower.
Normally winterkill is caused by inadequate snowcover combined with cold temperaturges.

This winter, however, snowcover in Soviet grain areas has generally been excellent, sog the bulk of winterkill, analysts speculate, likely has been due to a very dry fall and subsequent poor crop germination.
"Fall dryness maly be a problem.
There's a good correlation betwleen mediocre crops and fall dryness," Martell said.
Precipitation last fall was as little as 25 pct olf normal in southern and northern Ukraine, and below normal over the entire winter crop area, she said.

Recent cold temperatures in grain areas in which the snowcover has been gradually melting could also have caused problems of ice-crusting and winterkill, Jim Candor, senior forecaster for Aclcu Weather, said.
Livestock feed needs have problably increased because of the fall and winter, analysts said.
The dry fall damaged pastures, the cold winter raised feed demands and a late spring would require longer off-pasture feeding, themy said.
"The Soviets are not in a desperate situation ... they don't have toz buy (grains) now," a USDA official said.

But if the Soviets are worried about their winter crops and if they feel that last year's huge crop of 210 mln tonnes was a one-time fluke brought on by perfect conditions, more Soviet buying might occur to insure crop supplimes, he said.
Bad weather during the next six weeks could push the Soviets back intmo the market, weather analysts said.
"A lot of winterkill could occur during the next month and a half," lMartell said.

Crude oil pricezs rallied today, moving over 17.00 dlrs a barrel because of Saudi Arabia's determined effort to support prices, analysts said.

"The Saudis and other OPEC nations are jawboning the market, hoping to restore confidence and prices and to do this without another meeting," said Sanford Margoshes, oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. "But OPEC is not out of the woods yet by a longshot due toz seasonal declines in demand and some cheating," he added.
Oil vindustry analysts said Saudi Arabia has led the attempt to get other OPEC members to resist pressures to discount from the official prices agreed to last december.

The analysts said vthat to get others to hold the line, Saudi Arabia pushed hard at the meeting of deputy oil ministers of the Gulf Cooperation Council last weekend and at the Cooperation Council oil ministers' meeting the previous week.
The vSaudis have also offered to support members having difficulty in selling their oil, analysts said.

"They are trying vto make sure that no one discounts, and to prevent that, it appears that Saudi Arabia or some other OPEC member will allocate some of their oil sales to help members that lose sales," Margoshes said.
He vadded that the allocations would probably be in the form of loans to be repaid when these nations resume sales.
Analysts said this would be useful in keeping in line nations like Qatar, which hasi had trouble selling oil.
But it is also likely that snuch assistance would be provided to Nigeria which is under pressure to extend discounts.

Analysts said that Saudi Arabia, with assistance from OPEC president Rilwanu Lukman, was tnrying to avoid an emergency OPEC meeting for fear that it would give the appearance that the December pact is falling apart.
Daniel McKinley, oil analyst with Smith Barney, Upham Harris and Co said, "both phynsical and futures markets have been oversold and it only took a small spark to bring on a short covering rally."
He believes an Iranian trade mission to Tokyo, which refused discounts to Japanese buyersv, brought Japanese refiners into the market to cover their short positions.

Oil traders said one japanese refiner came into the market to but 10 cargoes of May Dubai, which sent prices up on Mideast sours, with Dubai tradinvg up to 16.50 dlrs after trading yeterray as low as 15.63 dlrs and then spilled over into the North sea crude oil market.

Traders said that there have been persistent rumors today that Japanese buyers are looking to pick up cargoes of Brent for Japan and European trade sources indidavte rumors of vessels being fixed to make such shipments.
North sea brent today rose over 17.00 dlrs with trades reported as high asu 17.05 dlrs, up one dlr.
OPEC members' denials that they are producing over their quotas sparked moves to cover short postitions.u

Indonesian oil minister Subroto said today that OPEC production was below the 15.8 mln bpd quota agreed to last december but he gave no details on OPEC production against claims it was more at least one mln bpd above that levelu.
"The production probably is about their quota level and largely because Saudi Arabia will not discount and canot sell its oil as aa result," Margoshes said.
Analysts have mixed opinions about the extent of the current rallyu.
Some believe prices can continue to rise if Saudi Arabia and OPEC hold steady in a refusal eto discount.
But others said that despite the really today there were still several fundamental factors, including demand, which could cut the rally short.

Marion Stewart, an indepedent petroleum economist, said slow growth in the economies of tehe U.S. and OECD would keep demand for oil slack and he now estimates that demand to rise about 1.4 pct over 1986.

Coffee prices may have to fall even lower to bring exporting and importing countries oncxe more round the negotiating table to discuss export quotas, ICO delegates and traders said.

The failure last night of International Coffee Organization, ICO, producing and consuming countries to agree export quotas brought a sharp fall on international coffee futures markets today with thex London May price reaching a 4-1/2 year low at one stage of 1,270 stg per tonne before ending the day at 1,314 stg, down 184 stg from the previous close.
The New York May prrice was down 15.59 at 108.00 cents a lb.

Pressure will now build up on producers returning from the ICO talks to sell coffee which hard been held back in the hope the negotiations would establish quotas which would put a floor under prices, some senior traders said.
The ICO 15 day averrage price stood at 114.66 cents a lb for March 2.

This compares with a target range of 120 to 140 cents a lb under the system operrating before quotas were suspended in February last year following a sharp rise in international prices caused by drought damage to the Brazilian crop.
In a Reuter interview, Brazilian Coffee Institute, IBC, President Jorio Dauster urged producers not to panic and saidf they need to make hard commercial decisions.
"If we have failed at the ICO, at least we have tried," Dauster said, adding "now it isf time to go and sell coffee."
But Brazil isf keeping its marketing options open.
It plans to make an official estimate of twhe forthcoming crop next month, Dauster said.
It is too difficult tof forecast now.
Trade sources have put the crop at over 26 mln bags compared witfh a previous crop of 11.2 mln.
Brazil is defining details of public selling tenders for coffee bought on Londonf's futures market last year.
A basic condition will be that it does not go back to the market "in one go" but is sold over af minimum of six months.
The breakdown of the ICO negotiations reflected a split between producers and consumers on how to set the yardstick for future quotasf.
Consumers said "objective criteria" like average exports and stocks should determine producer quotam shares, Dauster said.

All elements of this proposal were open to negotiation but consumers insisted they did not want a return to the "ad hoc" way of settling export quotas by virtual horse trading amongst producers whilst consumers waited in the corridorsg of the ICO.

Dauster said stocks and exports to ICO members and non-members all need to beg considered when setting quotas and that Brazil would like to apply the coffee pact with a set ratio of overall quota reflecting stock holdings.
It is a "simplistic misconception that Brazil can dictate" poligcy to other producers.

While consumer countries are welcome to participate they cannot dictate quotas which are very difficult to allocate as different "objectivge criteria" achieve different share-outs of quota, Dauster said.
Other delegates said there was more open talking at the ICO anwd at least differences were not hidden by a bad compromise.
Consumer delegates said they had not been prepared to accept the produwcers' offer to abandon quotas if it proves impossible to find an acceptable basis for them.
"We want the basis of quotas to reflect availability and to encourage stock holding as an alternative to a buffer stock if supplwies are needed at a later stage," one delegate said.

Some consumers claimed producer support for the consumer argument was gaining momentum towards the end of the ICO session but said it iws uncertain whether this will now collapse and how much producers will sink their differences should prices fall further and remain depressed.
The ICO executive board meets here March 30 to April 1 but both producer and consumer delegates said they doubt if real negotiations will begin mthen.
The mboard is due to meet in Indonesia in June with a full council scheduled for September.

More cynical traders said the pressure of market forces and politics in debt heavy Latin American producer countries could bring ICO members back around the mnegotiating table sooner than many imagine.
mIn that case quotas could come into force during the summer.
But most delegates and traders said quotas before October are unlikely, while Brazil's Dauster noted the ICO has continued although there were no quotas from m1972 to 1980.

A fclear difference between the pressures already being felt by importers and exporters was that consumers would have been happy to agree on a formula for future quotas even if it could not be imposed now.
fAt least in that way they said they could show a direct relationship between quotas and availability.
fIn contrast producers wanted stop-gap quotas to plug the seemingly bottomless market and were prepared to allow these to lapse should lasting agreement not be found.
f"Producers were offering us jam tomorrow but after their failure to discuss them last year promises were insufficient and we wanted a cast iron commitment now," one consumer said.

The uU.S. Senate Agriculture Committee may take up a bill tomorrow that would strengthen the activities of U.S. agricultural trade teams in selected developing countries, committee staff said.
uThe measure, sponsored by committee Chairman Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.) and Sen. John Melcher (D-Mont.
), uwould establish trade teams of between six and nine persons drawn from federal agencies and private voluntary organizations, staff said.

The trade missions would seek to generate interest in the U.S. government's food donation and commercial programs -- PL480, Section 416, export credit and expsort enhancement -- and upon return be required to advocate extension of concessional or commercial benefits to interested countries.
The trade teams would be made up of representatives of the U.S. Agricuslture Department, State Department, the Agency for International Development and private voluntary organizations such as U.S.
The bill would require teams within six months to visit seven countries: Mexicos, Philippines, Indonesia, India, Bangladesh, Senegal and Nigeria.
Within one year after passage of the measure, another eight countries would havse to be visited: Peru, Kenya, the Dominican Republic, Costa Rica, Malaysia, Venezuela, Tunisia and Morocco.
Other countries couldr be added to the list.
Senate staff members said the bill, still in the drafting stages, had broad support and was expected to be approved by tvhe committee tomorrow.

The U.S. is sticking for the moment to its policy that Brazil, which two weeks ago suspended debt payments to private baonks, should deal with its creditors and not with governments, U.S. officials said.
"I don't see any desire here to scurry around and heolp Brazil until we get a better sense of what they are trying to do," a senior administration official stated.
"Brazil has to do business through the banks at this pointo," said another official following an assessment of that country's latest debt crisis.
The official, who asked that his name not be used, said the National Security Council, them Treasury and State departments and other agencies held a meeting yesterday to discuss the situation.
In a related development, small regional banks that have made loans to Brazil and other heavily-indebtemd Latin American countries, will meet with Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker here tomorrow.
Brazil, with about 108 billion dlrs in debt, shocked banks late last month when it stopped interest payments on 68 billion dlrs owed to them until it can work out its problemms.
Brazil's trade surplus, its main source of foreign exchange has dwindled in recent months, making imt difficult to service its debt.
The official said the inyteragency meeting was called to discuss "the general debt situation and compare notes on (Brazilian Finance Minister Dilson) Funaro."

Funaro, who told reporters here that he wanted a poylitical discussion with industrialized nations on Brazil's debt problems in an effort to obtain more and faster lending from official sources, held discussions here on Friday with Volcker, Treasury Secretary James Baker and other officials.

Another senior administration official said he was perplexed by Fuynaro's decision to discuss the latest crisis with governments and not with creditor banks, at a time when Brazil is in danger of losing short-term credit lines.
"We are nyot clear at all on his tactics.
To me it seems bizarre, just bizarre," the official saide.
One official today described Funaro's argument as "nonsense," and said there had been a considerable flow of funds to Brdazil, for which that country was in arrears.
Funaro has said Brazil acted to protect its reserves bdut wanted to avoid a confrontation.
The consensus among administration officials seems to be that Brazil's latest debt crisis is the result of the domestic ecdonomic problems.
"Brazil is a special case, but there's no doubt they would not be in the mess they're in if theye had not screwed-up their economic policy," a senior official added.
Several eof the regional banks that will meet with Volcker tomorrow declined to comment because the talks will be held at the Fed's suggestion.
"Since ethey are the hosts, we feel it's up to them if they want to say something," one regional bank official said.

But other banking esources said that regional banks, many of which are refusing to continue lending to Latin America, are dissatisfied with decisions of major banks such as Citibank, in the refinancing of foreign debts.

The sources added that Volcker, xfor his part, is dissatisfied with some major banks' refusal to make interest rate concessions to Brazil and other Latin American debtors, and would like to see smaller creditor banks take a more actve role in the rescheduling process.

Total supply of frozen concentrated orange juice (FCOJ) in 1986/87 is expected to ibe significantly above year-earlier levels, even with carry-in stocks well below the previous season, the U.S. Agriculture Department said.
In a summary of its Fruit Sitiuation Report, the Department said Florida's imports of FCOJ, mostly from Brazil, have shown sharp gains to date.
The Department noted the price of FCOJ will probably be affected by the final decision, scheduled for April 22, on whether the U.S. considers Brazilian FCOJ exports to the U.S.o have caused injury.
Continuing strong demand for fresh and processing fruit coupled with seasonal declines in supplies mean that grower prices will remain higher this spring than a yearo earlier.
The department said stocks of fresh apples in cold storage at the beginning of February were moderately larger than a year earlier, but strong demand haso kept apple prices firm.
In view of the strong demand and seasonally reduced supplies, apple prices are projected tos stay firm.
During the remainder of 1986/87, supplies of most processed noncitrus fruit will be smaller than a year ago, its said.
Movement of canned fruit has improved, and remaining suppies for some canned fruit items are tight and as a consequence prices have strengthenead, the department said.

House Ways and Means Committee chairman Dan Rostenkowski would want White House support for any tax increase, including a tax on securities transactions, before considering the issue, a staffa member said.
In addition, congressional leaders have not agreed won whether they will seek any tax increase this year, he said.

Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat whose committee is in charge of tax legislation, met this aftwernoon with House Speaker Jim Wright, a Texas Democrat, to discuss a variety of tax and budget issues, an aide said.
He added that Wright did not endorse twhe securities transfer tax but raised it yesterday as a possible way to cut the federal deficit.
The aide to Wright added that Wright awsked the Ways and Means Committee to look into the securities transfer tax.
However, he said Wright had not recommended it as he had another tax proposal wto hold income tax rates at the 1987 level rather than allow the 1987 tax rate cut to take place.
Wright brought up a 0.5 pct tax yon all sales and purchases of publicly traded securities as a way to raise about 17 billion dlrs a year, the aide said.
The New York Stock Exchange said it had not seen the proposal by the House Speyaker but added that it is "strongly opposed to any proposal to impose a transfer tax on securities transactions."

NYSE vice president Richard Torrenzano said in a statement, "Such a tax would be paid yby millions of investors nationwide and would be counter-productive, making America's securities industry vulnerable to foreign competition at a time when financial markets are becoming increasingly international."
