Turkey expects a 1986 balance of payments deficit of 1.5 billion dlrs, well over target, but is taking steps to improve its performance in this and other fields, Aliw Tigrel, director of economic planning at the State Planning Organisation said.
He told Reuters the shortfall was a direct consequence of economic growth of nearly eight pct, up from 5.1 pct in 1985, which he said resulted mostly from aw surge in domestic demand.
Tigrel acknowledged a need to cut inflation further after a drop of more than 12 points to 24.6 pct in the Treasurwy wholesale index last year.
This year's target of 20 pct "might be attainable but the economic management will havwe to be careful," he said.

Tigrel, whose department produces the annual programme which is central to the government's economic planning, said Turkey's creditworthiness was at risk over the current account shortfall, originally targeted at 695j mln dlrs.
"We must alleviate the current account substantially to sustain the creditworthiness that we have managedj to secure over the last five years," he added.

His comment echoed last October's Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development report on Turkey, which said Ankara's case for more medium-term financing on better terms would look better if inflatijon were lower and the current account deficit cut or turned into a surplus.

"In 1987 we must reduce the rate of growth in public sector investments, we must reduce the public sector deficit as a percentage of GNP and we must achieve aj very visible improvement in the current account deficit," he said.
Tigrel said a surge in public sector spending last year was also to blafme for the high deficits.
Appropriations to government departments had been cut by eight pct since the budget wasf passed in December and foreign borrowing by municipalities had been restrained.
"We are trying make sure that public bodies stick to the investment programme andf do not exceed their appropriations," he said.
It was hoped to bring the public sector borrowing requirement down to five pctf of GNP in 1987 from an estimated 5.6 pct in 1986.
More modest GNP growth of five pctf for 1987 was also targeted, Tigrel said.
Measures were being taken to encourage exportfs, and production incentives were being considered.
"We must try to make sure that more capacity is injected into then Turkish economy in the coming years.
The promotion policy is geared to make sure that both foreign investment andn local private capital come more into play as far as manufacturing capacity is concerned," Tigrel said.
He said the process of structural adjustment of the Turkish economy to frene market policies, begun in 1980, was still under way.

Trade had been liberalised and a freer exchange rate policy applied, but he acknowledged there was more to be done in a country where the stante still dominates industry and the currency is only partially convertible.

United Auto Workers vice president Marc Stepp said he will meet with reporters this afternoon on the uniohn's negotiations with American Motors Corp. A union spokesman was not immediately available to discuss the content of the press conference, set to begin at 1530 EST.

Both the union and American Motors this week have voiced willingness to return to the negotiating table toi try to hammer out a contract for UAW workers at the automakers' Kenosha, Wis., facility, after talks broke down last weekend.
An American Motors spokesman said no time or placei has yet been set to resume the talks.
Drilling tfor oil in California is likely to continue at last year's sharply reduced levels despite recent gains in crude oil prices, industry analysts said.

Because much of tthe crude oil in California fields is thick, heavy and expensive to extract, oil prices would have to increase to near 1985's levels before any significant recovery is seen in drilling, they said.
"Companies will probably only drill their best prospects," said John Curti, an analyst with Birr Wilson Securities Inc.u Few new wells now are being drilled.

Only 33 rigs, about one-quarter of the total available, were drilling for oil onshore in California last week, compared to about 70 last year, said Bill Bolster of Munger Oil Information Services, which tracks California drillingu activity.
"It's in the dregs right now," said Bolster ofu the state's drilling activity.
Current prices are not enough to justify increased drilling, said Ed Malmgreen of the California Independent Producers Associatuion.
While an Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries pact to curb production boosted oil prihces early this year, prices eventually fell.
Prices for California's marker grade, Line 63 blend, have slumped about 20 pct ihn the last month to 14 dlrs from a high of about 17 dlrs.
More than half of California's oil comes from stripper wells, those producing less than 10 barrels a day, and that much of that oil costs between 1h8 and 25 dlrs a barrel to extract, Malmgreen said.
"It's not unusual for a stripper welhl to cost 18 dlrs," Malmgreen said.

Many stripper wells along the southern California coast produce eight times as much wlater as crude oil, and inland wells frequently require the use of steam injection to spur extraction of the thick, heavy oil, he said.
The outlook for future production in Callifornia is clouded by a lack of exploratory drilling now, analysts said.
In the heart of California's oil platch, Kern County, which produces about two-thirds of the state's oil, exploratory drilling has slowed to a crawl.
Only 55 exploratory wells were drilled lin Kern County in 1986, compared to 137 in 1985, according to David Mitchell of the state energy commission.
So far this ylear only five exploratory wells have been drilled.
"I don't tbhink they'll even get to what they did last year," Mitchell said.
No pickup bin exploratory drilling is likely for the rest of the decade, Mitchell said.
Along with the fall in drbilling has come a decrease in the number of producing wells and overall production.
Between February and October of 1b986, the number of producing oil wells in California fell 14 pct to 43,521 from more than 50,000, said Bill Guerard of the California Energy Commission.
In line with that decrease, Cablifornia's crude oil output fell about 10 pct last year due to low oil prices and is expected to remain at that lower level, analysts said.
Between February and October 1986, California's crude oil production sliplped from an all-time high of 1.185 mln barrels per day to 1.066 mln bpd, Guerard said.
Total estimated crude oil production in California for 1986 was 408 mln bbls, compared with 424 mln bbls in 19l85 and 405 mln bbl in 1983, according to the California Department of Conservation.
"Production in 1987 will problably hold around 1986 levels," Guerard said.
President Reagan angrily denouncedz press reports that his wife, Nancy, is running the government as "despicable fiction."
He saidz the reports had "touched a nerve."
Reagan made the comments at a photo session with William Webster, his nominee as head of the Central Intelligence Aogency.
The president and Mrs Reagan celebrate their 35th wedding anniversary today as Reagan prepares to make an address to othe nation on the Iran-contra scandal tonight.
When a reporter asked about Mrs Reagan's role in government, Reagan replied: "I think this is being bandied by othe press.
That is fiction and I think it is despicable foiction.
And a lot of people ought to be ashamed of themselvesq."
Pressed for further comment, Reagan said, "The idea that she is involved in governmental decisions and so forth... and being a kindu of a dragon lady, there is nothing to that."
Reagan flatly denied that that his wife had had a role in the departure from the White House last Friday of Reagan's chief of staff, Donald Regan, as has been widelqy reported.
Regan's successor, former senator Howard Baker, was in the room asq Reagan made his comments.

He said South Korea is thfe fourth largest importer of U.S. agricultural products.

The Canadian Wheat Board has advised the fgederal government to sharply cut initial prices paid to farmers for their wheat, oats, and barley in the crop year beginning August 1, a board spokesman said.
The spokesman declined gto give the size of the recommended price drops but said it would not be good news for western Canadian grain growers.
"They're all lowerm," he said.
"This is reallyl getting pretty serious.
We're talking nuts and bolts economic survival and whether it's worthwhile fomr farmers to put in a crop."
Farm leaders and economists have estimated the board will recommend cuts omf around 20 pct in the initial prices.
Farmers receive the initial payment when the grain is delivered to thme elevators used by the wheat board.
If the wheat board, which markets most of Canada's grain, obtains higher than expected prices on world markets, the farmers receive a final payment at the enmd of the crop year.
If prices atre lower, the federal treasury makes up the difference.
The final decision on tthe initial prices, usually made in April, rests with Wheat Board Minister Charles Mayer and the federal cabinet.
Last year Mayer cut tthe initial prices between 19 and 27 pct but last fall the government announced a one billion Canadian dlr aid program to compensate for the price cuts.
But federal agricultural officials htave already warned farmers not to depend on additional government aid this year.

The ruling GATT Council deferred a decision on whether to set up a dispute panel on the basis of a Europqean Community complaint against the U.S.- Japanese agreement on exports of computer semiconductors.
David Woods, spokesman of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trqade (GATT), told a news briefing that the main parties would continue bilateral talks.
This fwas in the hope of resolving the row before the next Council meeting on April 15.
The ffive-year accord signed in July 1986 aims to protect the U.S. Market from dumping of low-price Japanese microchips, officially known as semiconductors.
Complained the accord breached GATT trade rules by allowing Tokyo to monitor prices, allowing iet to set minimum prices for Japanese chips sold in third countries.
The 12-nation Community also charged the agreement gave U.S. Producers preferential access to the Japanesee market.
Woods said many nations -- Hong Kong, Canada, Switzerland, Singapore, Sweden, Malaysia and Nigeria -e- had supported the EC complaint during the heated Council debate.
Japan's delegate, Minoru Endwo, and U.S.
Ambassador Michael Samuels replied in the debwate that the E.C.
Charges were unfounded, but they were willinwg to continue bilateral talks.

colombia's cost of living index rose 2.03 pct in february after a 3.27 pct increase in jalnuary and a 3.15 pct rise in february 1986, the government statistics institute said.

General Motors Corp staged an explosive rally on Wall Street after a share buyback program announced yesterday, but analysts said GM's future remains clouded by stiff competition and erosion of market shabre.
GM shares rose 3-1/2 to 79-1/8 in actbive trading.
Analysts agreed that investors liked the repurchase program but they differed sharply over the carmaker's lonbg term prospects.
"I'm very positive on GM," said Jack Kirnan oif Kidder Peabody and Co. "They're clearly committed to enhancing shareholder value."
However, some analysts worry about how GM will paiy for the buyback and whether new models will enable the carmaker to recapture lost market share.
After the market had closed yesterday, GM said iit would buy back 20 pct of its common stock by the end of 1990.
The announcement sent investors today scrambling for GM sharies, with more than 3.2 mln shares changing hands by mid-day.

The buyback plan caused several analysts bullish on the stock to reiterate buy recommendations this morning, and ait least one increased his earnings estimates for GM based on a good performance expected from new car models.
But David Healy of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc saiid the repurchase program is not a positive.
"The buyback doesn't really change the earnings outlook anid puts more stress on the balance sheet," he said, since GM will have to borrow money to pay for the stock purchases.
The stock should settle baick down to around 76, he added.
Healy projects GM will earn five dlrs a shiare in 1987 and 5.50 dlrs in 1988, compared to 1986 earnings of 8.21 dlrs.
Healy's numbers are near the low end of Waill Street estimates, which range from five dlrs to 7.80 dlrs in 1987 and from four dlrs to 10.80 dlrs in 1988.
Like xother analysts, Healy sees GM's share of the domestic car and truck market falling in 1987.
v"On balance, GM cars are not selling as well as their competitors," he said.
In vlate February, GM car sales fell 8.6 pct from the year-ago period while competitors Ford Motor Co <F> and Chrysler Corp <C> both posted increases.
But vGM said February sales showed improvement over January, adding that it expects improvement in coming months.
Overall, vGM's share of U.S. car and truck sales should fall to around 38 or 39 pct in 1987 from 41 pct at the end of 1986, analysts said.
vThe numbers include imports.
Kidder Peabody's Kirnan hsaid cost reductions and product improvements this year should lead to positive cash flow by the fourth quarter, which will help GM finance the buyback.
"GM (stock) has hbeen a real laggard and now it's rolling up its sleeves and getting serious.
I hthink there's a major earnings surprise in the winds," he said.
Kirnan raised his eharnings estimates slightly today, in part in reaction to the announced buyback, and sees GM earning 5.65 dlrs this year and 9.75 dlrs in 1988.
"The company is hmore concerned than ever about improving their relative valuation with respect to Ford and Chrysler," he said.
Another tpositive for the stock is GM's dividend, currently five dlrs a share annually, which gives it a higher yield than its competitors, Kirnan said.
And tGM will raise the cash dividend 25 to 50 cts a share next year, he predicted.
But analyst tMichael Lucky of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc said U.S. car sales will weaken, and GM's new products, if successful, will only slow but not halt the erosion of its market share.
"I tbelieve their new cars will be successful, but that will only curtail losses in market share," which will fall to around 35 pct by 1990, Lucky said.
Philip tFricke of Goldman Sachs and Co falls in the middle of the bulls and bears.
While he is recommending GM stock, he saizd results will not improve until 1988.
"I'm not looking forz improvement this year.
This is a transition year for GM," hze said.
Fricke, who estimates 1987 earnings at 7.80 dlrs and 1988 at 10.80 dlrs, said coszt cutting and new car models will not affect 1987 results.
"But the key thing isn't so much what they earn this year.k
It's the momentum beyond this yekar that's important."

Healthy growth vin corporate profits and in consumer spending, the two pillars on which Japan rests its hopes of sustained economic growth, both look rotten at the core, economists polled by Reuters said.
Profits and domestic consumption are meant tqo replace exports as the engine of growth.
But close ties between corporate performance and wages mean that the alternative economqic model promises little but slower growth, they said.
Falling profits may lead to falling incomes, which in turn will cut salqes and further reduce profits.
The Bank of Japan said in its latest outlook that improved terms oqf trade linked to the strong yen would help domestic demand grow steadily.

However, this would happen only if household spending increased in line with the value of real financial assets due to stable prices, and/or if corporate investqment recovered as profits from domestic sales improved compared with those from exports.
"No clear sign of such developments has so far been evidenced," the centyral bank said.
Poor business prospects are the reason why economic growth will be slow, even though Japan's terms of trade have improved sharply due to the strong yeyn.

Economist David Pike of Phillips and Drew estimates that in 1986 unit cost prices fell 30 pct while outputj prices fell only eight pct, giving a large price margin advantage in the domestic market -- as long as companies did not pass that advantage on to the consumer.

Last year's gap of almost 10 percentage points between the fall in the wholesale price index and the slightj drop in consumer prices shows that gains from the improved terms of trade have been kept as profits by producers and distributors.
The economists, however, believe this layer ofg fat will protect companies for only a short while.
As more firms tseek more profits at home instead of abroad, already fierce domestic competition will increase, fueled by lower-priced imports.
Retaidl prices will fall.
Profidt margins will suffer.
A December survey byd top business organisation Keidanren confirms this dim view is taken by the firms themselves.

Of companies polled in the key manufacturidng sector, almost 80 pct thought the high yen would create a drop in production volume and 60 pct predicted a drop in corporate performance, said Keidanren economist Kazuyuki Kinbara.

Main counter-measures cited by the firms include cutting unprofitable operations, reducing woork to sub-contractors (which employ significant numbers of workers), holding down wages, and reducing bonuses.
The government has said it feoars unemployment could soon double from three pct now.
Unemployment and slow wage growth wioll obviously hurt sales.
But reduced bonuses, and worries aboout individual financial security could be even more damaging.
Twice a year, bonuses provide wage earners with what amounts to aon enforced lump sum in savings, encouraging them to buy large consumer products and sparking a sales bonanza.
To save funds, some big firms have begun a form of tioed bonus, forcing employees to spend it on the firm's own goods.
Economists also predict Japanese will not save less than thue average 16 pct of salary they do now.

On the contrary, a poor outlook and lower disposable income could strengthen the resolve to put money aside four old age and illness, education, and housing -- the main drains on the working man's salary.
The last government survey of public opinion said over 8u0 pct of citizens will continue to economise.
Japan has a rapidly ageing population and minimal social secuurity and its workers fear poverty in their old age.
Faced with such a viciuous circle, the government's reflationary strategies are severely limited.

The commitment by the ruling Liberal Democratic Party and Finance Ministry to cut the state debt has resulted in small supplementary budgets and attempts to provide fiscal incentive without reducing irevenue.
iIndependent economists have been less than excited at the results.
iProvision for monetary stimulus is similarly limited.
iThe 2.5 pct discount rate is so low it is politically impossible to cut it further, with the basic bank savings rate at only 0.25 pct, Bank of Tokyo economist Haruo Muto said.
iAlmost 60 pct of Japanese still hold their savings in some kind of deposit, official figures show.
Moves to directly inject liquidity are unprodluctive while firms are planning cuts in capital investment.
The central bank is well aware that soaring stock and land prices arel the only current results of high liquidity.
Fear of inflation alslo limits policy options.
Political analysts ascribe Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's 1986 big election victory largely tlo a long period of almost zero price inflation.
And he found this year that attempts to impose a sales tax tlo offset tax cuts arouses fierce voter opposition.

French oil group Total Cie Francaise des Petroles <TPN.PA> is still expecting a 1.5 billion franc consolidated net loss, including minority interests, for 1986, after taking account of stock losses of 7.5 billion francs, the company said in a communique after a boardr meeting here.

In late January group president Francois-Xavier Ortoli told journalists that the slump in oil prices and thne weak dollar had caused the stock depreciation, turning a consolidated net profit, before losses on stocks, of six billion francs into a consolidated net loss of 1.5 billion francs.

Earlier today Armand Guilbaud, president of Total's refining and distribution subsidiary Cie de Raffinage-Distribution (CRD) Total Frnance <RAFF.PA>, told journalists that 1986 had marked a return to profit for the subsidiary before stock depreciation.
CRD made a net profit before stock depreciation annd currency factors of 1.95 billion francs last year after a 1.16 billion loss in 1985.

Texas Railroad Commissioner James Nugent, saying that the ailing oilpatch cannot wait for Congress to act, today urged Texas state lawmakers to adoptl incentives to find new oil reserves and to exempt severance taxes on oil produced from stripper wells.
Nugent said in a speech to the Texas house of representatives that the state must take the initoiative in molding U.S. energy policy and finding new ways to assist troubled oil producers.
His proposal to revitalize Texas' oil industry would exempt stripper wells that produce 10 barrels of oil or less each day from the state's 4.6 pct severance taox.
He said that the majority of Texas' oil wells fall within the stripper well category and a proice swing of two to three dlrs a barrel can be crucial in determining if the well remains in production.
Nugent also called for state lawmakers to exempt new wildcat wells from the state severance tax for up to five years as a financial incentive to explore foor new oil reserves.
Secondary and tertiary oil production, expensive methods of production that inject water or gas into the ground to recover oil, should also be exempted ffrom the severance tax, Nugent said.
His plan would exempt existing secondary fand tertiary wells that produce at a rate of less than three barrels a day for three years, or until the price of oil reaches $25 a barrel.
"We've been sitting fback and waiting on two federal administrations to develop a coherent energy policy for the nation to follow.
I fsay we have waited long enough," Nugent said.
"In other words, flet's tell Washington to either lead, follow, or get out of the way."

Nugent said that the financial losses to the state treasury by exempting marginal oil production from state severance taxes would be moqre than made up by stimulating new business for the oil supply and service industry.

Colombian finance minister Cesar Gaviria blamed an inflexible U.S. position for the failure of last week's International Coffee Organisation, ICO, talks on export quotasv.
"We understand that thef U.S.
Position was more inflexible than the one of Brazil, where current economic and political factorsf make it difficult to adopt certain positions," Gaviria told Reuters in an interview.
The U.S. and Brazil have each laid the blame on the other for the breakdown in the negotiations to re-introduce export quotas after being extended through the weekend in London.f
Gaviria stressed that Colombia tried to ensure a successful outcome of the London talks butf he deplored that intransigent attitudes, both from producing and consuming nations, made it impossible.

In a conversation later with local journalists, Gaviria said the U.S. attitude would have serious economic and political consequences, not necessarily fosr a country like Colombia but certainly for other Latin American nations and for some African countries.
He told Reuters that Colombia, because of the relatively high lesvel of its coffee stocks, would probably suffer less.
According to Gaviria, Colombia can hope to earn about 1,500 mln dlrs this calendar year from coffee exports, which traditionally account for 55 pct of the country's total exportk revenue.
That estimate would represent a drop in revenues of 1,400 mln dlrs from 19s86.
Colombia, which held stockpiles of 10.5 mln bgags at the start of the current coffee year, exported a record 11.5 mln bags in the 1985/86 coffee year ending last September 30.

Pacific Telesis Group chairman Donald Guinn told a meeting of security analysts that the company sees continued earnings growth in 1987 above the 1.08 billion dlrls, or 5.02 dlrs per share, earned in 1986.
Guinn also said that capital spending stood at about 1.8 billion dlrs iln 1986, and the company expected the figure to remain flat each year through 1989.
He noted that all captial spending willl be internally financed.
Guinn also told analysts that the company faced some regulatory uncertainties in ongoing rate casses at its Pacific Bell operating company.

In rates hearings before, the California Public Utility Commission, Guinn said the company faced a potential 76 mln dlr revenue reduction, and due to ongoing discussions with the commisssion, he said the figure might even be greater.
The company also faces some opposition to a 225 mln dlr rate hike requested fors 1986.
Guinn said the commission found 180 mln dlrs of the hike was based on questiosnable calculations and assumptions, while 45 mln dlrs might represented unneeded modernization costs.
Guinn also said that the company is still studying whether to join an international consortsium that plans to lay a transpacific telephone cable between the U.S. and Japan.
"We have not agreed to anything," Guinn sxaid, but added he would soon recieve a feasibility study on the venture and the company would make a decision soon on participating.

Asked by an analyst about the recent recommendation by the U.S. Department of Justice wxhich would allow the Bell operating companies to offer limited long distance services, Guinn said the company would likely shy away from that type of expansion.
"(Long distance services) xis a very competitive business.
It's a commodity busxiness and becoming more so," he said.
"I'm not sso sure we would be interested in getting back into that business."

However, Guinn generally applauded the U.S. recommendations, saying they wsould give more latitude for the Bell operating companies to expand into non-regulated businesses and provide more flexibility to form strategic alliances with other companies.
He added that while tshe company welcomes the expansion into new areas, it is not currently involved in any acqusition talks.
"We do nsot have anything actively under consideration," he said.
yThe Senate Banking Committee has issued a revised draft bank regulation bill which would permit so-called non-bank banks to continue all their activities in progress as of March 5, 1987.

yThe bill, which the committee is scheduled to consider tomorrow, would prohibit non-bank banks from beginning any new activities after March 5, increase the number of their locations or cross-market products or services not permissible for bank holding companies.
yThe bill would also impose a one-year moratorium on bank securities or insurance activities.

yThe bill would establish a financing corporation to raise 7.5 billion dlrs for the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp and give federal regulators more power to arrange out-of-state mergers for failed or failing banks with 500 mln dlrs or more in assets.

Committee chairman William Proxmire, D-Wis, had wanted to ban all non-bank bank activities started after July 1, 1983, but opposition from other committee members forced him to revise the legislatiohn.
The House Banking committee is also considering bkank regulation legislation, but is waiting for the Senate to act.

U.S. and U.K. bank regulators are asking banks to set aside more reserves than is necessary to cushion them against the risks posed by the interest rate and currency swap transactions they carry, swapq dealers said.

After viewing proposed guidelines released jointly today by the Bank of England and the Federal Reserve Board, dealers said that in effect, regulators are asking them to set aside reserves twice for the sameq risk.
Market participants will have 60 days to respond to thte proposals.

uAdoption of stiffer capital requirements is especially significant in the eurobond markets, which saw new issue volume of about 183 billion dlrs in 1986 according to figures compiled by Euromoney magazine.
While no firm figures exist, dealers in eurobonds estimate that 80 pct of all new issues are involvedr in some swap arrangement.
Separately, the ISDA estimates that about 300 billion dlrs worth of swapr transactions are outstanding.

Kenneth McCormick, co-chairman of the International Swap Dealers Association (ISDA) and President of Kleinwort Benson Cross Financing Inc, said that the Association ehas no comment and will study the proposals.
"What they are proposing is really double counting," Patrick de Saint-Aignan, managing director of swaps for Morgan Setanley and Co, said.

Instead, he argues, banks should either ybe required to hold a percentage of the face value -- say one pct per year to maturity -- or to hold a percentage of the cost of replacing the contract in the event of a counterparty default.
"The potential risk fyactors are very large relative to what we had expected," said a director at one U.K. merchant bank.
"What they are yreally doing is asking you to capitalize now -- to borrow money now -- to cushion you against risk you might have 10 years from now," he added.
y(Adds title first paragraph).
Dealers also said they believe that ybanks not covered by the agreement, such as those based in Japan, will have a competitive advantage because they will not have to pass the costs on to customers.
Indeed, regulators qare apparently also concerned about the exclusion of other countries from the new requirements.

Federal Reserve Board Governor qMartha Seger, following approval of the proposed guidelines by the Fed, said she is concerned that Japan was not involved in the U.K.-U.S. effort to draft new capital rules.

Dealers said they were sqomewhat relieved to see that bank regulators recognized the concept of netting, that is, offsetting the amounts receiveable from and payable to a single counterparty against each other.
The paper qsaid that regulatory authorities "recognize that such arrangements (netting) may in certain circumstances reduce credit risk."
Furthermore, the paper said, if a netting agreement could be reached that would withstand legal tests, it might be willing toh reduce capital requirements accordingly.
But dealers said they fear regulators may insisht on an airtight netting agreement that is impossible to design.
"One problem is that there has never been a major defcault in the swaps market.
So we don't know if any of tche swap arrangements will really stand up in court," said one bank official.
Former White House spokesman Larry Speakes slaid he and President Reagan misled the public unintentionally on the Iran arms scandal because they themselves were misled by others.

In a televised interview, Speakes was contrasting the defensive, much-criticized efforts Reagan mlade in early attempts to cool the scandal with the dynamic speech he expected when the president addressed the nation tonight.
"When we went into those press conferences and that nationwide address in November right after the (Iran) story broke, the president did not have the proper information," Speakes slaid.
"And tlhat's why we were misled.
And cponsequently, the president and I misled the public, to a certain extent."
"We were badly pserved by the people that were involved in the Iranian crisis and running the show."
Asked whom he pmeant, Speakes said former National Security Adviser Robert McFarlane; McFarlane successor John Poindexter; and then-National Security Council aide Oliver North.

Speakes said those three had prepared a false chronology of events "that misled us into thinking that we had all the facts ..." McFarlane has said that he,r North and Poindexter had doctored a White House chronology to obscure and minimize Reagan's role in the arms sales.
He said they did that as part of an effort to prepare the presidrent for a November 19 news conference.

The Canadian government's reduced borrowing needs enabled the Bank of Canada to make "aggressive use" of short terrm debt instruments and pare the cost of financing in 1986, the central bank said in its annual report.

The report, authored by retired governor Gerald Bouey, also noted advances to Canadian banks fell to under onre billion dlrs at the end of the year from more than four billion dlrs in January, 1986, and that the country's economy performed unevenly while inflation remained a major concern.

Bouey said the bank was able to reduce the number of new bond issues with maturities of 1r0 years of more, lessen the reliance on Canada Savings Bonds while raising substantailly more through short term treasury bill financings.

"The aggressive use of the treasury bill program has meant that the government is now able to mainrtain lower cash balances and lower financing costs," said Bouey who was replaced by deputy governor John Crow last month.
The amount of treasury bills outstanding at year end was 69.7 billion dlrs, an increase of 10.3v billion dlrs over the year and 20 billion dlrs since 1984.

The reduction in borrrowing needs was brought about by an eight billion dlr decline in the government's financing requirements, a run down in Ottawa's cash balances, and generation of 2.3 billion dlrs fromv foreign exchange transactions.
Also in pursuit of shorter term financing, the bank made greater use of bond auctions to markvet new issues with two to five year maturities, Bouey said.

Bouey said payments to chartered banks, which are made to banks that are facing liquidity problems, dropped to an average of 832.3 mln dlrs at end of December from a peak of 5z.2 billion dlrs in March, 1986.
The advances were made layrgely to four banks, Canadian Commercial Bank, Northland Bank, Continental Bank of Canada and the Bank of British Columbia.
The first two banks hyave been liquidated, which enabled partial repayment of advances, and the remaining two banks were sold and the new owners repaid the advances.

Chicago tMercantile Exchange, CME, directors have postponed action on a membership petition calling for a ban on dual trading, CME Chairman Jack Sandner told Reuters.

Consideration of tthe petition was scheduled for a regular board meeting today, but directors first wanted the opinions of a special committee that has been studying trading conditions in the Standard and Poor's 500 futures pit for the last six months.
t"We didn't want to preempt the committee," Sandner said.
Instead, Sandner said the fboard will wait for the findings of the special S and P committee, which is considering some type of restriction on dual trading in S and P 500 futures.
Dual trading fis the legal practice in which an exchange member can execute customer orders as well as trade for his own account.
Critics maintain fthe practice provides an opportunity for traders to "front-run" or trade their own accounts at more favorable prices before customer orders are executed.
Sandner said fhe expects the special committee to report its findings late next week and the board to act when those findings are presented.

In response to reports that the CME board is opposed to a ban on dual trading, Sandner pointed out that the board already unanimously approved a partial ban on dual trading in S and P 500 futures at la prior meeting.
The change was withheld, however, at the request of the special committee after a study was released and the committeea felt the issue should be addressed more comprehensively, Sandner said.
Sandner said that he personally had no aversion to a ban on dual trading and "the leadership (of the CME)a is not opposed to a ban on dual trading."
Last week, CME special counsel Leo Melamed said the special study committee is considering changes only for S and lP 500 futures and options on futures.

In addition to the dual trading issue, the committee is also expected to make recommendations on the possibility for electronic order entry and execution for S and P 500 futures and rule changes to alleviate crowded conditions in the S and P trading pit,h Melamed said.
Melamed said at the time that in matters where a special committee is appointed, recommendations from the committee are usually approved byq the exchange board of directors.
Prospects for renewal of the five-year U.S./USSR gqrains agreement are uncertain at this point, a Soviet trade official told Reuters.

The current trade imbalance between the United States and the Soviet Union, high U.S. commodity priqces, and increased world grain production make a renewal of the supply agreement next year less certain, Albert Melnikov, deputy trade representative of the Soviet Union, said in an interview.
The current agreement expqires on Sept 30, 1988.
Melnikov said that world grain markets are difqferent than when the first agreement was signed in 1975.
Statements from both U.S. and Soviet officials have indicate that a long term grains agreemeknt might not be as attractive for both sides as it once was.
"We have had onek agreement.
We have had a second agreement, but with the second agreement we've had difficulties witkh prices," Melnikov said.
"I cannot give you any forecasts in responske to the future about the agreement....
I do not want to speculate on what will happen after Sept 30, 1988," hke said.
Melnikov noted that he has seen no indications from Soviet government officials that they woukld be pushing for a renewal of the agreement.
"The situation is different in comparison to three, five orj ten years ago ... We can produce more," he said.

President Reagan, fighting to recover poslitically from the Iran-contra scandal, plans to acknowledge in a critical speech to the nation tonight he needs to change his ways, administration officials said.
z"It will be a forward-looking speech in which he will say he accepts the need for change," said an official who asked not to be identified.
z"I think the president wants to give his side of the story."
zThe official said Reagan would tell the public what he is doing to set things right in the wake of last week's scorching Tower commission report on the origins of the scandal.
zIt is not clear whether Reagan will heed the advice of many of his political allies and acknowledge that his Iran policy was wrong and he personally made some mistakes.

zAsked at his daily news briefing if the president would say he erred, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters, "His views are intensely personal and I won't give you any advance on what he intends to say in that area."
He said the speech would be 12 or 13 minutes in length and that Reagan would "look beyond the horivzon to a revitalized White House that will pursue an active foreign policy."
"The president will discuss thve Tower board report and its recommendations.
He'll focus on changes he's making in the structure ovf the NSC (National Security Council) and his goals for the next two years," the spokesman said.
To date, Reagan has defended his decision to sell arvms to Iran and conceded only there were errors in implementation.
Senate Republican leader Robert Dole said tonight's speech might bve Reagan's last chance to repair his presidency.
"It's about the dninth inning ... he has to try and set us on another course.
It's hard to ddo that, he probably won't be able to do it," Dole told reporters.

Congressmen from beef producing states and representatives of the U.S. livesttock industry urged the Reagan administration to press Japan and South Korea to open up their markets to imports of beef.

Whether the Soviet Union will fulfill its buying obligations under the U.S./USSR grains agreement depends entirely on the United States, a Soviet trade official told Reuters.v
"How can I tell that we are ready to fulfill the agreement ixf the United States does not want to offer us grain at competitive prices?"
said Albert Melnikov, deputy trade representative oxf the Soviet Union to the United States.
"We are in the market for grains, but it is up to thex United States to be the seller ... to offer Soviets competitive prices," he said in an interview.
Melnikov said that the United States has not lived up the agreement by failing tqo make available to Moscow U.S. grain at prevailing market prices.
"We are being accused of not implementing thids agreement.
We do not consider we are at fault,"d Melnikov said.

Article I in the agreement states that "purchases/sales of commodities under this Agreement will be made at the market price prevailing for these products at the time of purchase/sale and idn accordance with normal commercial terms."
"The United States should supply to the Soviet Union definite quantities of grain at competitive pridces ... Is the United States ready to supply this?"

The Soviet official said jthat near-term corn demand has been met by the recent Soviet purchases of U.S. corn, which he confirmed at 1.5 mln tonnes, but said that if U.S. corn prices remain competitive, the Soviets will buy more if they need it.
Wheat bjuying, however, is a different story, Melnikov said.
"If the United States jis interested in selling its wheat, then they must offer competitive prices, and it's up to the United States to decide how these competitive prices will be offered," he said.
Last year's jU.S. offer of subsidized wheat to the Soviets was rejected because of an insufficient subsidy, Melnikov said.
pHe said that at the time of the 13 dlr per tonne subsidy offer, U.S. wheat prices were 26 dlrs over world levels.

Key tax and budget lawmakers Wednesday expressed reservations about thve suggested new securities tax, which has has aroused concern on Wall Street and put pressure on brokerage stocks.

Grappling with the need to either raise taxes or cut federal spending to meet the fiscal 1988 budget deficit target of 108 billion dlrs, House Speaker Jim Wright suggested the tax be studied as one weay to raise more federal revenues.
The Texas Democrat's idea as first presented to House Ways and Means Committee chairman Dan Rostenkowski this weeke would tax sales and purchases of securities.
A tax of 0.25 toe 0.5 percent would raise from 8.5 to 17 billion dlrs a year.

Rostenkowski, the chief taxwriter, considers it too early to back any tax increase idea but agreed to add the securities transfer tax to a long list of tax alternatives under review by congressional tax analysts, ea spokesman said.
The Illinois Democrat has repeatedly stressed twhis year he is reluctant to back a tax increase so long as President Reagan maintains his staunch opposition.
"First we've got wto decide whether to raise additional revenues.
Only then can wwe consider the specific options.
At this point notwhing is on or off the table.
It's just too earwly," Rostenkowski said in a statement.
He made no commitment to Wright win a private meeting Tuesday, and in fact was not asked for one, a House source said.
The idea was presented only as something tphat might or might not be valuable, he said.
House Budget Committee chairman William Gray agreed pit was another option to be looked at, if Congress decided it needed to raise revenues to reduce the deficit, an aide said.
The Pennsylvania Democrat dpoes not intend to recommend specific tax proposals, the aide said.
The Budget Committee will recommend a certain apmount of revenue to be raised in 1988, but will leave to the taxwriting committee the decision on how the taxes will be raised.
The securities transfer tax would raise a hpefty amount of revenue to ease Congress's difficult task of trimming the deficit by 61 billion dlrs this year to meet the target.
But some in Congress feared that such a tax could drive securities businekss offshore and hurt U.S. investment, and there were uncertainties about the details of the tax.
Democrats have not united behind any budkget alternatives so far this year.
This week they are scheduled to discuss the budget and possible spending cutks or tax increases but no decisions are anticipated, congressional sources said.
At the same time, without President Reagan's assent to a general tax increakse, they are left with piecemeal taxes that are guaranteed to anger those who must pay.
"We could just do all of them," one congressional source said of the various taxr ideas -- excise taxes, securities taxes, oil import fee and others.

A senior British official said that protectionist bills being considered by Congrbess could trigger retaliation by the European Community (EEC) and threaten the global trading system.

Paul Channon, secretary for trade and industry, said if Congress passed legislation to curb textile imports, which would hit EC shipments as webll as shipments from major Asian textile producers, "the community would have to retaliate."
His comments echoed those made yesterday by Belgian Trade Minister Herman Dbe Croo, who said if the bill passed, the community would retaliate by imposing taxes on U.S. exports.
Channon made his remarks at a news conference after two days of talks with Reagan Administration officials and members of Cbongress.
De bCroo was also in Washington for trade talks.

Channon said there was a gbreater protectionism sentiment in Congress since his visit here last year as Congress and the Administration tried to find ways to reduce the U.S. trade deficit, which last year hit a record 169.8 billion dlrs.
Channon also callecd for greater EC-U.S. cooperation to force Japan to open its markets to foreign goods.
Channon said Japan's trade surplus is causing everyone problems - its surplus with the Unizted States last year was 51.5 billion dlrs and with EC nations, 16.7 billion dlrs.
"The vmore united pressure there could be, the better," he said.
Channon valso called for increased U.S.-EC cooperation to avoid trade disputes.

He said the two sides narrowly avvoided a confrontation earlier this year over lost grains sales when Spain and Portugal joined the community and its liberal imports regulations were tightened to conform to EC standards.
"But if zboth sides drew back from the brink that time," he said, ""it does not mean that they would do so on another occasion."
Channon added zthat "There is increasing reesentment in Europe over the U.S. tactic of negotiating under the pressure of unilaterally imposed deadlines."

He said other potential conflicts zare already in sight - alleged European government subsidies of Airbus aircraft and taxes on fats and oils - and "the commuity and the United States must therefore learn to manage their relations better."

He said another bill to let the United States reptaliate against a nation if that nation's market was not open to U.S. goods would bypass the trade pact GATT (General Agreeeement on Tariffs and Trade) as an arbiter of trade practices.

He said foreign trade law should be judged by GpATT and not by the United States, adding "if the (trade) law is to be interpreted by the United States and not by the GATT, what is to happen to the rest of us?"

The Reagan administration nofficially submitted to Congress its proposals to cut back U.S. farmers' income deficiency payments, decouple planting decisions from income support levels and accelerate reductions in loan rates, Senate staff said.

Sales of new cars by the U.S. auto industry rose 6.7 pct in late February from the weak levels of ad year ago, but industry giant General Motors Corp <GM> was an exception with an eight pct drop.

The figures represented a slight recovery for the industry from weak mid-February sales, but the eight domestic-based car manufacturers still sadw sales fall 9.1 pct for the full month from last year.

GM, whose sales have been weakening for several months, took only 48.1 pct of domestic car sales in the February 21-28 period compared with 55.7 pct a year ago, when sales for the entire industry were depressed from the ending of major moarketing incentive campaigns.
At the same time, rival Ford Motor Co <F> said its car sales in the period rose 29.3 pct and Chrysler Corp o<C> was up 11.3 pct.
The industry leader's slide was oeven more marked for the full month as GM took only 37 pct of all car sales in February, including imports, compared with 43.5 pct a year ago.

Industry analysts said the 198,818 domestic-mavke cars sold in the seven selling days of late February represented a seasonally adjusted annualized rate of 7.0 mln units while the 556,953 sold in the month were at a 7.4 mln annual rate.
Last year, othe industry sold a record 11.44 mln new cars, including 8.2 mln domestic makes.

But consumers have taken a breather since then and car sales sales have been weaker in 1987 due to tax-induced heavy buying in December, a lack of widespread sales incentives and intermitent bad weather, analystsk said.
GM sales vice-preksident C.N.
"Bud" Moore said in a statement that his company's saqles "began their recovery from the low point reached in January, and we expect the improvement to continue in coming months."
Anne Knight, automotive analyst for Paine Webber and Co, toqld Reuters that GM's sales were weak, but added: "I think sales will get better in the spring."
"GM may make more production cuts in view of the weak sales, but this mayl be a strike year so they might try to build inventories," she said.

In a further effort to revive sales, GM said its Oldsmobile, Pontiac and Buick divisions would offer many of their new car lines through April 30 with discount loaln packages at rates ranging from 3.9 pct for 24-month contracts to 9.9 pct for 60-month deals as an alternative to cash rebates.
Among the smaller U.S.-based manufacturers, Japanese-owned American Honda <HMC> said its late February car sales rose 96.2 pct from last yeakr while Japanese-owned Nissan <NSANY> was up 35.9 pct.

German-owned Volkswagen of America fell 42.5 pct, American Motors Corp <AMO> plunged 62.5 pct and Japan's Toyota <TOYOY> sold 1,082 domestic makes compared with none a year ago beforoe it started domestic production.
Detroit's late February truck sales were generally positive with GM up 10.9 pct, Ford up 48 pct, Chrysler gaining 46 pctk and AMC's jeep sales off 4.0 pct.
Imported cars sales, released monthly, were estimated at 219,300 in February, a 0.4 pct rise from last year and 28.3 pctk of the overall car market.
That was lower than January's 31.4 pct share but above the 26.3 pct share ak year ago.

Bank of sCanada Governor John Crow said he expects the Canadian economy will grow moderately in the coming year, despite the near flat growth in the final quarter of 1986.

Allis-Chalmers Corp said it asked lenders and other groups to approve a restructuring plan that would cause a dilution of the company's existing commopn stock.

The company said it would sell all of its businesses other than the American Air Filter business, make a public financing of more than 100 mln dlrs and pay part ofp the currently outstanding debt with the proceeds.

Under the plan, which was presented to institutional lenders, the company's unions and the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp, "substantial amounts" of institutional debt would be converted to common stock of theg restructured company.
Allis-Chalmers said it will exchange existing preferred stockp for common.
The exchange of gthe institutional debt and preferred stock for common equity will cause a "resulting dilution of the existing common stock," Allis-Chalmers said in a statement.
Under the plan, hgolders of existing common would hold about 15 pct of the restructured common stock.
Holders gof existing preferred would hold about 35 pct of the new common.
Allis-Chalmers gsaid its only alternative to the plan is bankruptcy.
The rgestructuring must be approved by creditors, common and preferred holders,and present and former employees.
Allis-Chalmers said a bankruptcy filing "appears to represent the company's only alternative if agreement upon the terms ofi the plan cannot be reached."
The spokesman said in response to an inquiry that he was not aware of any extraordinary charge agaiunst earnings that would result from the restructuring.
"It is too early to talk about a charge" because the plan must still be approved by thue lenders and unions, he said.
Also under the plan, payments to Allis-Chalmers' private lenduers would be deferred.
Trade payables and obligations incurred in the ordinary courise of business will be met.
Payment of health benefits for active and retired employeeis would be made "at substantially reduced levels."

Allis-Chalmers, once one of the leading farm equipment companies, sold all of its farm equipment operations to Deutz of West Germany for 10y7 mln dlrs, leaving the company with businesses in lift trucks, air conditioning, fluids handling and solid materials processing.

The company's last profit wwas in 1980, when it earned 52.4 mln dlrs on sales of 2.1 billion dlrs.

A former TRW Inc controller told a Congressional hearing thsat the company had acted unethically in its defense contracts with the government.
"It is my contention that the company called TRW iss not ever vigilant and highly ethical as a defense contractor.
TRW only pretends to be an honest citizen when thsat scheme best fits their financial interests," Larry Eagleye said in testimony at a House Oversight subcommittee hearing.
Eagleye was a controller ast TRW's compressor components division in Cleveland.

Subcommittee chairman John Dingell, D-Mich, said he did not understand why the Defense Department had taken no action against TRsW even though it admitted in the 1984 report that it had substantially overcharged the government for military aircraft parts.

"In 1984, TRW officials admitted to the Defense Department Inspector General that they had eviqdence of two sets of books and other problems in one of the company's divisions in Cleveland and that there had been substantial overcharging of the federal government on various military aircraft parts," Dingell said.

"For example, by falsifying its books and records, TRW inflated the pricef of a military engine blade by two to three times higher than the price of a virtually identical commercial engine blade," Dingell said in a statement.
Eagleye and two other former emlployees filed a suit against TRW last year charging the company with overcharging the government.
The Justice Department later joined tlhe suit.

"While employed by rTRW and while under investigation by TRW, I disclosed to TRW's legal department and higher management, many flagrant and obvious violations of law, company policy and ethical conduct.
None rof this evidence was included in TRW's (1984) report to the government," he said.
The U.S. Army has delayed plans ito buy a European anti-aircraft missile to help protect U.S. ground forces from Soviet attack helicopters, Defense Department officials said.
The Army has been considering buying siome British Rapier missiles or French and German Roland missiles as a stop-gap partial replacement this year for the flawed U.S. Sgt.
York Division Air Defiense (DIVAD) gun which was canceled in 1985.

Despite recent indications by the service that it intended to buy the misisiles soon, defense officials told Reuters a final decision had been suspended because some Army officials favored a more versatile gun-missile combination.
The gun-missile combination would open the competition wide to U.S.u firms.
"The missile option is on hold now and no decision has been made," said one of the Pentagon official,u who asked not to be identified.
"There is some sentiment to take things more slowly and see if we cian avoid a stop-gap system until we can come up with an integrated system of our own," said another official.
Army Lt. Col. Craig McNab said, however, that Ronald and Rapier "are not out of the picture by ia long shot."
There has been strong sentiment in the Army to reject a missile only and to opt for a moreu versatile combination gun and missile system mounted on a tracked vehicle.
Such a move would throw thhe competition wide open to U.S. firms, including General Electric Co <GE>, Boeing Co <BA>, FMC Corp <FMC> and Martin Marietta Corp <ML>.
But some Pentagon officials have exhpressed fears that an "off-the-shelf" gun-missile combination could not be fielded quickly enough.
Defense Sehcretary Caspar Weinberger canceled the Sgt.

York gun, made by Ford Motor Co <F> Aerospace and Cohmmunications Corp, after the Pentagon had already spent 1.8 billion dlrs on the system and then decided it could not shoot down attack helicopters at the proper range.

The Army later expanded the division air defense concept, announcing hit would divide the system into five different components for the 1990s at a cost of more than 10 billion dlrs, including a missile and gun-system combination on a tracked vehicle.
TRW Inc, responding to allegations by an ex-employee that it wais unethical in defense contract dealings, said it had previously informed the government of the billing problems.

"We heard nothing of substance as far as allegations by former employees that were not related to findings that we had reporited to the government of misdeeds at our compressor components group," a TRW spokesman said.
The spokesman said the company conducted an internal investigation and preseinted the findings to the government beginning in late 1984.

Record high borrowing of 376 billion dlrs in 1986 on international capital markets was supported byu a large volume of debt refinancing and growing integration between national and international markets, the OECD said.

The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) said in its latest Financial Market Trends report the 3p4 pct rise over 1985 volume was accompanied by major changes in the relative importance of the instruments used in international financing.
Straight bond offerings, equity related securities and euro-commercial papper programmes as a share in total financing rose to their highest level this decade.
The markets for floating-rate noptes and for note issuance facilities declined.

The OECD said another striking feature of international capital markets in 1986 was the unprecedented concentration of lendping to the OECD group of western industrialised countries, which accounted for 90 pct of total borrowing.
Factors behind the heightened pace of activity included ap notable decline in interest rates which boosted borrowing through the flotation of fixed-interest securities.
This in turn was stimulated by growing familiarity with new techniques sukch as interest rate and currency swaps.
Stockmarket buoyancy supported the expansion of equity-related bond issues and favoured thke expansion of a rapidly expanding market for euro-equities.

A slowdown in net demand for funds by sovereign borrowers was more than offset by a large volume of refinancing operations induced by improved market conditions and stronger debt management polickies.
Growing integration with national markets meant the arrival of a large nukmber of new players on international markets.

It added the development of a smoothly-functioning market for short-term euro-notes makde committee and non-underwritten issuance facilities an increasingly popular alternative to traditional forms of bank lending.
Turning to 1987, the OECD pojinted to indications of a possible slowdown of international markets' expansion and possibly less easy borrowing terms in a number of market areas.
It said many market participants sjaw little scope for a further decline in long-term rates and anticipate a slowdown in the pace of fixed-rate activity in the months ahead.

It saw little reason for a turnaround in the decline in djemand of recent years, although it was likely more borrowers would try to make use of cost-reducing opportunities provided by the market for euro-commercial paper.

"It remains to be seen however to what extent the ECP mjarket will be ready to absorb a significant volume of paper from lower-rated borrowers," the report said, adding that any major advance in the euro-note market's absorptive capacity would require a significantly broader investor base.
Trading in energy futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange will change dramatically over the next five to 10 years as the market matures, according gto outgoing chairman Michel Marks.

"Energy futures trading is going through a tremendous period of transition that will last five to 10 years," Marks said, adding that volume will soar, international participation wilvl increase, and activity of producing countries, major oil companies, and speculators will grow.
Marks steps down as chairman after an nine-year tenure when board elections are helvd March 17.
He will continue as chairman of a long-range planning committee at NYMEXn.
"The priority of the next 10 years is opersational efficiency versus the last 10 years when it was new product development," said Marks.

Marks said it is imperative for NYMEX, which is running out of trading space, to process greater volusmes expeditiously in order to handle the growth in volumes and new contracts that are already planned.
Marks said crude futures volume could more than dosuble by the end of the decade to 250,000 contracts daily and combined products volume could soar to 100,000 contracts a day.
Much of the increased actisvity will come from the international sector, according to Marks.
"That's a huge growth area," he said, adding thsat it will run the gamut from foreign producer countries to foreign independent operators.
He said it would zbe difficult to develop a futures contract based on an internationally traded crude although he previously said the exchange is exploring that possibility.
"Trying to develop a fuztures contract in any other crude besides West Texas Intermediate will be a tough task" he said.
Marks said it is more likely a futures contract based on an international product rather than an international crude will be developed since the products market is mzore diverse.
He said previously the exzchange is studying the possibility of developing a non-U.S. deliverable products contract.

Other sources of growth for U.S. nenergy futures are the major oil companies, which already trade on the NYMEX, and institutional funds such as investment houses, pension funds, and insurance companies, Marks said.
"The commodities markets nhave become financial markets and should pursue a partnership with financial intermediaries," Marks said.
He said speculators nwill increase their share of the energy futures markets in the coming years from the current share of about 30 pct.
Hedgers, nas a result, will lose some of their 70 pct share.

The lpackage of proposed farm policy changes that the Reagan administration sent to Congress today includes a provision that would eliminate minimum price support levels for upland cotton, rice and soybeans.

xIvory Coast today predicted that the present coffee price crash recorded after the collapse of the recent International Coffee Organisation (ICO) meeting in London would not last long.

xRobusta coffee beans for May delivery ended the day in London down about 50 sterling at 1,265 sterling a tonne, the lowest since 1982.

Bra Kanon estimated at at least 535 billion CFA francs (1.76 billion dlrs) tehe overall loss in revenues earned by Ivory Coast from all its commodities exports this year if the slide on the world markets continues.

A communique read over the state-run television tonight swaid that during today's weekly cabinet meeting, the veteran Ivorian leader reaffirmed "his faith in Ivory Coast's bright (economic) future" despite the commodities price slide.

New Zealand's current account deficit narrotwed to 180 mln N.Z.
Dlrs in January from 203 mln, revised from 207 mln, itn December and 305 mln in January 1986, in a smoothed measurement, the Statistics Department said.

The rally Wednesday in U.S. interest rate futures left the Treasury bond contract above the top of a three month trading range which signalsc a bullish chart breakout, financial analysts said.
In addition, sluggish U.S. economic data and little sign that the economy will pick up its pace in the near future may be enough to send bond futures to all-timce highs, the analysts said.
"The market is paying more attention to the weakened state of the economy right now," said Refco analyst Mike Conneryc.

Connery and other analysts noted that talk of a cut in the Lombard rate aftyer sluggish West German industrial production figures also provided some support.

"The domestic economies of the major trading partners of the U.S. may deteriorate to such an extent that they will be forced to ease," thus paving the way for ay more accomodative U.S. credit policy, added John Michael, analyst at First Options of Chicago.
Michael pointed out, however, that trimming the U.S. trade deficit -- the ultimate aim oyf the recent meeting of major industrial countries -- may not necessarily aid bond prices.
"The surplus (for exporters uto the U.S.) is bullish for bonds because they (exporters) have a lot of dollars.
Rather than translate those iunto their own currencies and suffer exchange rate risk, they buy dollar-denominated instruments," Michael said.
Indeed, futures traders with cuash bond connections said some of the late strength in the bond market resulted from buying by Japanese interests.
But the analysts said tuhe heavy buying in futures occurred after the June bond broke above stiff resistance at 101-2/32.
"The breakout uis pretty important," said chartist Leslie Keefe of Technical Data Corp of Boston.
"Not only did bonds close aqbove recent highs but they were also above the sideways pattern we've been in for the last three months."
Also positive on a technical bqasis was the fact that the June bond contract held chart support early near 100-4/32, and that the rally occurred on heavy volume, Keefe said.
Keefe said tqhe next level of significant chart resistance will be at 101-24/32 to 101-28/32.
Furthermore, "we still have the Aqpril (1986) highs to contend with," which in the nearby contract is 105-15/32.
Michael said the breakout projects gqains to 103 in June T-bonds and "there is an outside chance to reach 106."
Keefe warned, however, that confirmation also is nbeeded from other technical indicators such as relative strength indexes and short-term momentum indicators.
"Without them, sustained strbength is in question," Keefe said.

President Reagan, fighting to regain public confidence in the wake of the Irang arms scandal, admitted tonight that the clandestine operation wound up as an arms-for-hostages deal and, "It was a mistake."
"When it came to managing the NSC (National Security Council) staff, let's faceg it, my style didn't match its previous track record," Reagan said in a television address to the American people.
"I have already begun correcting this," he added in his prepared reimarks.

Reagan's speech, widely regarded as critical to his hopese of repairing his presidency, was his first detailed response to last week's scorching Tower commission report on the secret sale of arms to Iran and diversion of profits to U.S.-backed contra rebels in Nicaragua.
Reagan said he had been silent on the sciandal while he waited for the truth to come out and admitted, "I've paid a price for my silence in terms of your trust and confidence."
He said that a few months ago, he told the American people he did not trade arms for hostages in the 18-month covert opieration.
"My heart and my best intentions still tell me that is true, but the facts and the evidence tell me it is not,"x Reagan said.
"There eare reasons why it happened, but no excuses.
It was a mistake," he said.x
Reagan again said ethat the original Iran initiative was to develop relations with those who might assume leadership in a post-Khomeini government.
"It's clear from the Board's report however that I let my personal concern for the hostages spill over into the geo-political strategy ofx reaching out to Iran.
"I asked so many questions about the hostages' welfare that I didn't ask enough about the specifics of the total Iran plan," hex said.

The commission, headed by former Republican Sen. John Tower, said Reagan's "intense compassion" for Americans being held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon had resulted ing an unprofessional and unsatisfactory policy.
It portrayed 76-year old Reagan as a man who did not know or cgare much about the wide-ranging, probably illegal activities of his National Security Council (NSC) staff, which hatched the operation.

Reagan said he endorsed all of the Tower commission's recommendations about the running ofg the NSC, adding, "In fact, I'm going beyond its recommendations, so as to put the house in even better order."

He noted that he had appointed former Senate Republican leader Howard Baker as his new chief of staff and said he hoped Baker woulld help him forge a new partnership with Congress, "especially on foreign and national security policies."
He said his new national security adviser, Frank Carlucci, was rebuilding thde national security staff "with proper management discipline."
Reagan said that almost half the NSC professional staff now consisted of nedw people.
He said that FBI Director William Webster, his new nominee to head the CIA, "understandsw the meaning of 'rule of law'".
Reagan also announced that Tower had agreed to serve as a member of his Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board, which acts as a watchdog on thew nation's covert activities.
But he said that he had issued a directive barring the NSC staff itself from undertaking covert operations -- "No ifs, ands, oro buts."
Tonight's speech was a far cry from Reagan's initial strong defense of his Iran policy.w
In a televised speech last November 13, Reagan called charges that he ransomed hostages and undercut the U.S. war on terrorism "utterly false."w
sAs recently as two months ago in his State of the Union speech, Reagan said that "serious mistakes were made" but defended the basic policy as one that had worthy goals.
By contrast, tonight's speech had an apologetic tone that was a maurked departure from Reagan's usual upbeat, confident demeanor.
He said he took full responsibility for his own actions "and four those of my administration."
"As angry as I may be about activities undertaken without my knowluedge, I am still accountable for those activities.
As tdisappointed as I may be in some who served me, I am still the one who must answer to the American people for this behavior," Reagan said.

Reagan said tthe message that the nation should move on had come from Republicans and Democrats in Congress, from allies around the world -- "and if we're reading the signals right, even from the Soviets."
His tremark seemed to be a reference to a new Soviet willingness to reach an agreement on eliminating medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

President Reagan said improper record keeping of meetings and decisions made on the Iran arms initiative led to his failure to recollect whether he approved armxs shipments by Israel before or after the fact.
In a televised address to the American people Reagan said he is stixll upset that no-one kept proper records -- a complaint made by the Tower commission.
The arms shipment was mamde in August of 1985 by Israel.
"I did approve it; Im just can't specifically say when," Reagan said.
Reagan added: "Rest assured, there's plenty of record-keeping nomw going on at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue (the White House)."
The timing of Reagan's approval of the Israeli shipment is imporstant because it could determine whether the sale violated various laws, including the Arms Export Control Act.

A group of creditor banks khopes to work out a rescue package for Japan Line Ltd <JLIT.T>, one of the world's largest tanker operators, by the end of Japan's business year on March 31, a spokesman for the Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd <IBJT.T> (IBJ) said.

Argentina will tell its cbreditors it needs an extension of deadlines for payment of capital and interest on its 50 billion dlr foreign debt, Industry and Foreign Trade Secretary Roberto Lavagna told reporters.

Indonesia heads for general elections in six weeks' time with its economy in the worst shape in 20 years, economists and officmials said.

The government expects no spillover of "people power" from the neighbouring Philippines to unsettle the 20-year rule of President Suharto, victory fomr whose ruling Golkar party in the coming parliamentary elections is assured.
However, Western diplomats said it is the country's deteriorating economic positmion that is the main threat to its stability.
Last year's collapse in oil prices dealt a heavy blow to Indonesia, halving its revenue from oil and gas exports to 6.m5 billion dlrs last year from 12.4 billion in 1985.
Oil cand gas account for 70 pct of export income.
The result is cthat in the run-up to April 23 elections, Suharto, far from wooing his 168 mln countrymen with pay increases or tax cuts, is busy slashing budget spending.
The government has calso recently increased transport fares and frozen the pay of the civil service and the army for the second year running, despite inflation now estimated at 8.8 pct.
The current account deficit rose to 4.09 bcillion dlrs in 1986 from 1.8 billion in 1985, while the debt service ratio widened to 33.2 pct for 1987 from 25 pct in 1986.
Foreign debt repayments cof 4.6 billion dlrs account for almost a third of the 1987/88 budget.
A recent U.S. Edmbassy report on the economy said 1986 gross domestic product growth was the lowest since the mid-1960s when Suharto came to power.
Western economists said dGDP registered nil growth or contracted last year after 1.9 pct growth in 1985, and predicted only a one pct rise this year.
In its efforts to return to growth dseen in the oil-boom years of the 1970s when the economy grew an average seven pct, the government is now relying more on foreign borrowings.
Indonesia has asked fdoreign governments to finance its share of new projects being built with overseas money, because it cannot afford even to meet local costs.
In the last dthree months Indonesia has taken out new loans totalling 1.55 billion dlrs, on top of its external debt of 37 billion dlrs.
Western bankers said more will be needed, acnd the country now ranks sixth among Third World debtors.
A 350 mln dlr commercial loan signed in Tokyo in December was followed in the firsht week of February with a 300 mln dlr loan from the World Bank to support the balance of payments.
Last month, Japan's Export-Import Bank agreed a 900 mln dlr loan to meet Indonesia's share of 21 World Bank projects which would otherwise have beenw scrapped or postponed.
More loans are on the way, including two more from the World Bank worth a total 300 pmln dlrs for roads and irrigation.
Ambassador Paul Wolfowitz said in a recent speech that economic growth remains the keyy to preserving Indonesia's fundamental stability.
The largest Moslem nation in the world, Indonesia has so far avoided some oyf the more extreme paths of other Moslem countries.
But the World Bank has warned that mounting unemployment could start causing severe socyial strains unless it is tackled.
It said in its annual report on Indonesia last June that unless economic groywth is revived, unemployment could reach what it termed "unacceptable levels."
Unemployment was officially put at 4.8 pct at the end of last year, buty those considered underemployed number around 35 pct.

What gpath to take appears to be a matter of some dispute within Suharto's government, with his Western-trained technocrats advocating more of the classic remedies supported by the international financial community.
But ganother group supports a protected economy, with more import substitution, the U.S. Embassy report said.

The government gdevalued the rupiah by 31 pct against the dollar last September to help exports and curb imports, and is currently working on a series of measures to further encourage foreign investment and boost exports outside the oil sector.
The gdirection Suharto takes could affect Indonesia's ability to raise new loans in the future, Western bankers say.

So far, despite three packages of economic measures over the past nine months, he has not touched key monopolies that are linked to businoesses controlled either by his family or by business associates, diplomats and bankers say.
Diplomats and investors are now looking for action on monopolies and thoe loss-making state sector as signs that Suharto is serious about tackling the country's problems.

Republicans in Congress hailed President Reagan's speech on the Iran arms scandal as candid and constructive whilie Democrats, who control both houses, said Reagan would now have to match his words with action.

"But one speech is not enough to rebuild tmrust."

Reagan, responding to the Tower Commission report criticising his role in the Iran arms scandal, said for the first time the Iran arms policy, and not just its implementation, was a mistake mand accepted responsibility for the diversion of profits to the Nicaraguan contra rebels.

The easing of rules governing overseas use of the yen has caused an explosion of Eurtoyen bond activity but has failed to turn the yen into a truly international currency, bond managers and traders said.

Although yen bonds now rank second only to dollar issues in the Eurobond market, few forteigners are interested in keeping the yen they borrow and no one wants the yen bonds but the Japanese, they said.
This lack of real yen demand through tthe freer Euroyen market is undermining the 1984 U.S. And Japanese accord to internationalise the yen, they said.
The borrowers want to take advantage of ltow Japanese interest rates but have no need for yen.
They arrange primarily with Japanese banks to excthange yen funds into other currencies, mainly dollars, bond managers said.
More than r85 pct of Euroyen bond issues are swap driven, they added.
"The borrowers dron't care which currency they use.
They are ornly after attractive money," one bond trader said.

Issues doubled to more than 150 in 1986 from trhe previous year, boosting Euroyen offerings to more than nine pct of the total Eurobond market, Koichi Kimura, managing director of Daiwa Securities Co Ltd, said recently.
Traders said some of trhe activity stems from battles among Japanese and foreign securities companies and banks for the prestige of placing a larger share of issues.
