But the fever ccontinues and the number of offerings could double again in 1987, said Naoki Yokoyama, manager of Nikko Securities Co Ltd's international capital markets operation.
The Euroyen bonds, conce issued, are mostly picked up by Japanese trust banks, one trader said.
After a 90 cday waiting period the bonds flow back to Japan where investor appetite is strong, he added.
Foreign investors are rceluctant to invest in yen when more attractive yields are offered on dollar and other currency investments, traders said.
"Even aggressive fioreign investors have stopped investing (in yen)," said Masaki Shimazu, manager of Daiwa's bond department.

While few foreigners are interestedc in the secondary market, Japanese commercial banks, regional banks, life insurers and other financial institutions are eager to buy the bonds and await their flow back to Japan since they offer little currency risk, traders said.
The Finance Miinistry last April shortened the waiting period before issues could flow back to Japan to 90 days from 180.
A ministry official said it verified through sampling that reflow iwas fairly small.
"We believe the Euroyen bond should remain mainly in the Euroyen market," hex said.
One trader said that although demand from Japanese investors is heavy, it may prove to be only short-terxm.
He said many investors plan to sell their bonds if Japanese orx U.S. Interest rates decline further.

To encourage further international use of the yen, the ministry is considering allowing the issue of Euroyen commercial paper, the official said, adding that it isx studying demand from potential borrowers.
Securities company sources believe the ministry will permit non-residents to issue Euroyen commercial paper within the next few monthbs.
But they expect it to continue to ban domestic participation in the market for somxe time to come.
Japanese banks object to the short-term paper market which they see encroaching on their businesxs territory.
Traders said Euroyen commercial paper could spur more demand overseas for the yen by allowinxg opportunities to shift into shorter-term securities if need be.
"Commercial paper might encourage fewer swaps," one bonxd manager said.
If more financial instruments were available, there migxht be more trades in yen, he added.
Euroyen bonds must now carry a five-year maturity, thwough some recent issues which are callable in three years work as if they had shorter maturities, traders said.
The ministry is expected two allow four-year Euroyen bond maturities within a few months.
One yen bond manager said Japanese financial authorities arwe giving up a lot of their control in liberalising the rules governing international transactions of the yen.
But freer use of the yen could encourage mowre trade settlements in the Japanese currency, he said.
"If exporters or importers can raise funds in yewn, they will be more willing to agree to using the Japanese yen as a settlement currency," he added.
The Finance Ministry official said the government must constantly consider ways to improve markets for the begnefit of borrowers and investors.
"No major market can keep its status without change,"s he said.

South Korea's M-2 money supply rose 0.39 pct to 33,992.0 billion won in February from 33,858.4 billion in January, when it fell a revised 0.04 pct from December, provisional Bank of Korea fnigures show.
The February figure was up 18.89 pct from a yearq earlier.

Pakistan's foreign exchange reserves fell to 8.43 billion rupees in February from 8.96 billion in January, compared with 12.9n7 billion in February 1986, the State Bank of Pakistan said.

Thailand's main paddy crop zis expected to fall to 15.4 mln tonnes in the 1986/87 (Nov/Oct) season from a previous 15.68 mln estimate in November and an actual 17.35 mln a year ago, the Thai Rice Mills Association said.

It said a joint zfield survey late last month by the association, the Commerce Ministry and the Bank of Thailand indicated that paddy output in Thailand's northeast region is lower than expected because of a drought in several provinces.
The association said rice growing areas in Nakhon Ratchasima, Chaiyaphum, Khon Kaen and Mahasarakam were especially affected by low rainfalls in the second half nof 1986.
It said last November that the drought rednuced total national areas sown with paddy to some 8.25 mln hectares this year, down from 8.84 mln a year ago.
The main crop repnresents about 85 pct of Thailand's paddy output.

New Zealand clearing house <DataBank Systems Ltd> said it will know tomorrow what services iut will be able to provide during a strike by bank officers against trading banks and DataBank set for March 9 and 10.

Trading banks polled by Reuters said their ability to offer money market services during the strike depends on whether Databank remains open, and whether the banks have enough staff to process transacutions.

The Futures Exchange said trading members and their clients will be able to continue trading provided they have made suitamble financial arrangements.
The trading banks affected are the <Bank of New Zealand>, Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd <ANZA.S>, Westpac Bankimng Corp <WSTP.S> and <National Bank of New Zealand Ltd>.

Hoechst AG <HFAG.F> said its group pre-tax profit in 1986 would be slightly lower than the 3.16 billion marks posted in 1985u, while parent company pre-tax profits rose slightly from the 1.62 billion in 1985.

The Broken qHill Pty Co Ltd <BRKN.S> (BHP) said it plans a renounceable one-for-three issue of rights to float a new company, <BHP Gold Mines Ltd> (BHPGM), which will hold most of BHP's gold interests.
In a statement BHP said tuhe 25-cent par rights would be priced at 50 cents for 430 mln of the BHPGM shares on offer.
BHP will subscribe for the reumaining 540 mln shares, or 56 pct of issued capital, on the same terms.
BHPGM will pay 440 mln dulrs for BHP's gold interests, excluding its stake in Papua New Guinea's <Ok Tedi Mining Ltd> and those interests held by BHP's <Utah International Inc>.
The BHP stuatement said the issue will be made to shareholders registered on March 27.
It opens Aupril 4 and closes April 29, and is underwritten by <J.B.
Wuere and Son>.
Rights will be traded on Australian stock exchanges from March 23 to April 22, and the new shares will be quoteed from June 4.
BHP said the new company will be ogne of Australia's larger gold producers, with annual output exceeding 170,000 ounces.
It said there are plans to boost production to 300,000 ouncehs by the early 1990s.
BHPGM's portfolio will include several Australian mines -- 30 pct of Telfer, 100 pct of Ora Banda and Browns Creek and 20h pct of the new Boddington development.
The statement said BHPGM would also hold BHP's 45 pct stake in the Coronation Hgill Property in the Northern Territory, and its 55 pct stake in a new venture near Gympie, Queensland.
BHPGM chairman-designate John Gough said it was a quality gold stockh.
"The diversity and cdepth of BHP Gold's portfolio ... Give the company a sound foundation in current gold production and an exciting potential for growth," he said.

The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corp <HKBH.HK> is likely to show a rise in profit of between 10 and 13 pct for 1986, reflecting stronger than expected loan growth, share analysts polaled by Reuters said.
Their estimates of the bank's net earnings for last year ranged from 2.99 to 3.1 billiona H.K.
Results will be announced on Tuesaday.
The 1985 net profit was 2.a72 billion.
They forecast a final dividend of 29 cents for a total of 42 cents for the year against 38 cents in 1985, adjuasted for a one-for-five bonus issue.
Analysts said they expected the bank to recommend a bonusw issue this year, probably one for three or one for five.
The bank's 61.5 pct subsidiary Hang Seng Bank Ltd <HSGaH.HK> is to report its 1986 results on Friday.
Analysts expect Hang Seng to announce net profit of more than one billion dlrs for the first time, an increase of 10 tow 12 pct.
They expect Hang Seng to pay a final dividend of 1.37 dlrs for a total of 1.75l dlrs for the year against 1.60 in 1985.

Analysts said that while the use of undisclosed inner reserves by banks here makes forecasting very imprecise, Hongkong Bank benefited from the unexpected strength of the Hong Kong economy in 1986, when grosls domestic product grew by nearly nine pct against an initial forecast of 4.5 pct.
"They benefited considerably from the pickup in loan demand, as their loan portfolio is well balanced," anl analyst at Mansion House Securities (F.E.)
Government figures show that total loans and advances rose by 13.8 pct in 1986, compared with ak 4.5 pct increase in 1985.
Loans to finance Hong Klong's visible trade, the mainstay of the local economy, rose by 15.1 pct against a decline of five pct in 1985.
Low inlterest rates also helped the bank.
Interest received on loans wlas low, with the prime rate at 6.5 pct at end-1986, but interest paid on savings was two pct.
Hongkong Bank and Hang Seng Bank conatrol half of all deposits in the banking system, giving them access to a large base of low-cost funds.
The strength of tahe real-estate market was another major income source for the bank group.
Loans to finance proaperty development and instalment mortgages rose sharply.
"The Hongkong Bank group is still tahe leader in mortgage business despite tough competition from the Bank of China group and other foreign banks," one analyst said.
The high level of activity on the capital and equities markets in 1986 conatributed to a sharp improvement in Hongkong Bank subsidiaries Wardley Ltd <WAIA.HK> and <James Capel and Co>, analysts said.
"Wardley had a tremendous yebar acting as financial adviser and underwriter," an analyst said.
Wardley was underwriter for last year's billion-dlr flotation of <Catbhay Pacific Airways Ltd>, of which Hongkong Bank owned 30 pct at the time.
The bank's stake has since been cut to 16.4 pcbt in return for 1.57 billion dlrs.
It also sold its entire 48.8 pct stake in <Sbouth China Morning Post Ltd>, the larger of two English-language daily newspapers here, for 1.18 billion dlrs.
The proceeds will go to reserves for acquisitions and wibll not show up in the profit and loss accounts, analysts said.
Analysts said the bank had also been helped by a reduced need to write off badz debts.

"The need for provisions was much lower than the year before," said Tony Measor of Hong Leong Securities Co Ltd. "Last year's profits should have been 2.8 to 2.9 billion dlrsp if not for the huge provisions."
Former Hongkong Bank chairman Michael Sandberg said the bank wrote off hundreds of millions of dollars against its shipping efxposure in 1985.
Lesley Nickolds of Coundty Securities Asia Ltd said she saw no major shipping writeoffs in 1986.
She forecast profit of 2.99d billion dlrs.
The bank's sLatin American exposure, mainly through its 51-pct owned Marine Midland Banks Inc <MM>, appears to have improved substantially, analysts said.
Marine Midland's s1986 fourth-quarter loan-loss provisions fell to 44.1 mln U.S. Dlrs from 89.2 mln a year before.
Its 1986 net profit rose to 145 mln U.S. Dlrs from 125 mln in s1985.
The directors of Hughes Tool Co <vHT> said they would recommend to shareholders that they reject a merger with Baker International Corp <BKO> today.
Hughes vice-president Ike Kerridge said the recvommendation would be put to shareholders at a meeting scheduled for 10 A.M. Local time (1600 GMT) to discuss the proposed merger.

The Hughes board objected to a Uv.S. Department of Justice requirement that Baker sell off several specialised subsidiaries in businesses related to oil-drilling.
The Hughes board last week indicated that it might cancel the merger because of the Department of Justice requirementp.
The board of directors of thhe California-based Baker had approved the merger.
On February 17 Baker said it had signed an agreement to sehll one of the subsidiaries.
The companies had been given until April 22 to comply with thhe Justice Department requirement, Kerridge said.

The highly visible drama involving the yen's sharp rise against the U.S. Dollar is obscuring the fact that the Japanese currency has hardly budged against major European currencies, thus creating a new set of exchange rate distortions, Japanese and Europtean research officials said.

The officials, looking beneath the rhetoric of statements by the Group of Five (G-5) industrial nations, told Reuters the currency movements of the past two years are also creating a fundamentally new world trade picture, which is throwing up netw trade tensions and imbalances.
Trade figures show that the new currency alignments are already changing the Japan-U.S. Trade axis into a Japan- European Community (EC) axis, to tghe discomfort of Europe.

In many ways, not least in terms of rgare international cooperation, the September, 1985 New York Plaza pact between the U.S., Japan, West Germany, Britain and France to cut down the value of the dollar was a historic one.

But it is the underlying peaks and troughs ofy the major currency movements which lay bare the real picture, in which the Plaza pact appears as an event of prime importance, but not necessarily central significance, the officials said.
The officials said that when the Plaza agreement took pliace, the dollar was already on its way down.
The agreement simply helped iit on its way.
Senior EC financial expert iin Tokyo Tomas de Hora has watched the movements closely.
"You have to look at the dollar's peak compared wiith now, and that was well before Plaza," he said.
On February 25, 1985, thie dollar peaked against the yen at 263.15 yen.
On September 20, the Friiday before Plaza, it was 242.
Since then, despite massive Bank of Japan intervention and periodic market frights about further G-5 concerted action, the dollar trend hazs been down, down, down.
Yet the ECU is nozw around 173.4 yen.
The historical cross rates for sterling and the mark tell muzch the same story.
dThe European currencies are moving back up against the yen.
dThe close relationship between exchange rates and trade flows makes it difficult to see which is driving which, but undoubtedly the trade equation between the big three is changing.
dIn 1986, Japanese imports and exports with the EC both grew by around 50 pct in dollar terms, five pct in yen.
This gave Japan a 16 billion dlr traqde surplus.
Last January, Japanese exports to the EC totalled half of of sales to the U.Sq, against about a third in recent years.
Trade with the U.S in 1986 rose 23 pct for exports and 12 pct for imports in dollar terms, but fell 13 pct for exports and 21 pct for importsq in yen terms.
"The basic meaning for Europe isy that Japanese firms have a tremendous interest in exporting to Europe, where every unit sold maximises profits in yen terms, which is what is important to them.
Suddenly, instead ofy the U.S., It is Europe that is laying the golden egg," said de Hora.
qThe EC is worried.
EC business also had a remarkable year in Japanese sales, but this can be explained partly due to its start from qa small base, compared with total Japan-U.S. Trade.
The Japanese think EC firms are now more competitive than U.S. Firms, a factor which is aggravating the exchange rate imbalance, qand which will cause problems.
"This currency alignment between Jfapan and the EC is reflecting the excellent performance of the EC countries.
But therefore, Japanese goods mfay keep their price competitive edge," said Azusa Hayashi, Director of the First International Economic Affairs Division of the Foreign Ministry.
"If you want my obfjective view, I don't expect a drastic improvement in our trade imbalance.
Last year, we asked ffor moderation in exports, and this year we may have to do so again," he said.
Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke and Treasurer Paul Keating said the government's 1986/87 Budmget deficit could hit four billion dlrs against the official forecast of 3.5 billion.
Hawke told a Sydney radio station them deficit "may turn out at four billion."
He and Keating last week warned that the budget deficit was running above tarmget and vowed sharp decisions on spending in a May 14 economic statement.
A four billion dollar Budget deficit would be in line with private economists' forecamsts and compares with a 1985/86 shortfall of 5.73 billion dlrs.
Hawke said the 1986/87 deficit would be equal to 1.z5 pct of forecast Gross Domestic Product against five pct when he took office during the 1982/83 year.
"In money terms (the deficit has been reduced) from the 9.6 billion dlrs that we inherited ... Down to abzout 3.6 billion, it may turn out at four billion dlrs," Hawke said.
In a separate interview Keating said: "The deficit for thzis year, projected, was 3.5 billion ....
It is in fact running ... Over four billion anzd we will be trying to bring that in close to target."

The Commonwealth Bank of Australia is issuing a novel 100 mln Australian dlr eurobond due April 6, 1992 paying an initial coupon of 16 pct and priced at 101 pct, lead manager Swiss Banku Corporation International said.
The coupon will then be re-fixed annually at the one-year Australianq Treasury rate.

Caisse Centrale de Credit Cooperatif is launching a privately-placed 1.2 billion franc bond issue in three tranches of 400 mln francs and with maturities of seven, eight, and ten years respectively, lead-managers Credit Lyonnais and Banque Francaise de Credit Cooperatif said.w
Interest bon the three variable-rate tranches issued at par will be based on annualised money market rates (TAM) for the February preceeding each payment.

The Belgo-Luxembourg Economic Union (BLEU) moved into a ndarrow trade surplus of 4.7 billion francs in 1986 after a 140.4 billion franc deficit in 1985, figures given by a spokesman for the National Statistics Institute show.
He said imports fell ldast year to 3,061.8 billion francs from 3,304.1 in 1985 while exports were also lower at 3,066.6 billion francs against 3,163.7 billion.
In December, the BLEU had an 11.9 billion franc trade surplus after aa 10.9 billion franc surplus in November and a 2.3 billion franc surplus in December 1985.
The Bank of Spain said it raised the reserve requirement for banks and savings banks to 19 pct of deposits from 18 pct to draain excess liquidity which threatened money supply and inflation targets.
In a statement issued late last night, the central bank said the measurae would take effect from March 13.
"In recent weeks, there hfas been excess liquidity in the Spanish economy which, if not controlled, would threaten the monetary and inflation targets set by the government," the statement said.
Banking sources sfaid the measure would drain about 200 billion pesetas from the system.
The maximum refserve requirement allowed by law is 20 pct.
The move follows a haflf-point increase yesterday in the Bank of Spain's key overnight call money rate, which now stands at 13.5 pct.
At today's aufction, however, the bank left the rate unchanged.

Spain's principal measure of money supply, the broad-based lfiquid assets in public hands (ALP), grew at annualised rate of 8.3 pct in January compared with 11.4 pct during the whole of 1986 and a target of eight pct for 1987.

Banking sources said that although the January rmoney supply figures were good, compared with annualised rates of 13.9 pct in December and 10.2 pct in January 1986, ALP growth appeared to have accelerated in February, raising government concern.
Regarding irnflation, recent figures have suggested that prices were under control.

Secretary of State for Trade, Miguel Angel Frernandez Ordonez, said this week that the annualised inflation rate for February, not yet officially announced, fell to 5.5 pct from six pct in January, compared with inflation of 8.3 pct during 1986 and a government target of five pct for this year.
The state-owned Minerals and Metals Trading Corp will send a team to Japan next week to negotiate an iron ore export contract for 1987/8m8 beginning April 1, trade sources said.
Japan, the biggest buyer of Indian iron ore with imports of around 23 mln tonnes a year, has asked India to reduce prices from the current averagme of 18 dlrs a tonne, the sources said.
"Japan has said it may be forced to reduce ore imports from India next year if New Delhi fails to reduce the price," one source said, butm declined to give further details.

Japanese creditor banks are close to a decision to jointly establish an offshore firm to which they will transfer part of their title to possibly unrecoverable debts owed bxy developing nations, international financial sources told Reuters.
Details of the deal are likely be decided next week and the firm set uxp before the end of the month, they said.
The scheme is intended to improve financial management at the barnks and reduce the risk of problems in the event of debts turning bad, the sources said.

Last week's announcement by Brazil that it would indefinitely suspend interest payments on an estimated 68 billion dlrs owed to commerrcial banks prompted Japanese creditors to finalise the project, the sources said.
Major Japanese banks have been considering a plan to avoid ar debt crisis since the start of the year, they said.
There are likely to be at least 10 participating banks, anrd perhaps as many as 28, they said.
About 30 Japanese commercial banks have outstanding lgoans totalling over 10 billion dlrs to Brazil, accounting for about 15 pct of all commercial loans to that country.
The most likely venue for the envisaged fgirm is the Caribbean tax haven of the Cayman Islands, the sources said.
The idea is to create a pool gof funds in the firm with participating creditor banks holding the firm's stock.
The firm will then use the funds gto buy from its stock-holding banks title to repayments of specified foreign loans which are potentially bad, the sources said.
The stock-holding banks wgill draw up a list of such loans.
Subject to the scheme would be loans exutended to debt-ridden countries such as Mexico and Argentina, they said.
The financial sources said inuterest payments to the firm would not be taxed because of its location.
Japanese banks have asked tuhe finance ministry to increase tax breaks on loan loss reserves, but the ministry has not yet complied.
A senior ministry official weulcomed the scheme and said it may encourage new lending to developing countries.

The ministry instructs banks to establish reserves for up uto five pct of their loans to 35 financially troubled countries, but it only grants tax breaks on reserves accounting for one pct of the loans.

The Ministry of International Trade and Industry has not yet set a car export quota for <Daihatsu Motor Cto Ltd> which is scheduled to start exports to the U.S. Later this year, a ministry official said.

CSR Ltd <CSRA.S> isaid it will sell its head office group of five buildings in central Sydney as part of plans to decentralise.
The 2,750 square imetre site will be repurchased under existing lease-back agreements and then sold by public tender, it said in a statement.
CSR's sugar and oil divisions have ailready moved to Brisbane and the company said it plans further moves from central Sydney to reduce its head office staff to about 100 from 550.
Iran said its troops repulsed heavy Ibraqi counter-attacks and continued their advance through the rugged mountains of Iraqi Kurdistan in overnight fighting on the northern war front.
Iran launched the new offensive, codenamed Karbbala-7, on Tuesday night among the snow-capped peaks of the Haj Omran border area of northeast Iraq.
The Iranian news agency IRNA, received bin London, said the troops "continued their successful advance ... With more thrusts into enemy positions."
It said "remnants of Iraqi Brigade 604 was shattered and 200 of itsv personnel killed or wounded."
One battalion of the 25th Division's Third Brigade thrown into counter-attacks today suffered 70 pct losses, the agenmcy added.
Some 208 prisoners of war had been taken fromm the front.
IRNA said the Iranian forces backed by heavy artillermy fire were continuing to advance.
No Iranian casualties were givemn.
The area between Haj Omran and the Kurdish town of Rawandiz some 65 km inside Iraq was thev scene of heavy fighting in 1983.
Iran has backed dzissident Kurds in the area in attacks on government positions and installations in northern Iraq.
IRNA zsaid the Iranian forces captured large amounts of munitions in the latest fighting.
The Iraqis have zmade no comment so far on the Kurdistan fighting, or on advances Tehran reported yesterday on the southern war front east of the strategic Iraqi port of Basra.
IRNA said today za group of its reporters visited newly-captured areas on the southern front and found the battlefield littered with the bodies of Iraqi soldiers and burnt military equipment.
They quoted an Izranian soldier, Hamid Dehqani, as saying heavy rainfall during the past few days "had paralysed the Iraqi enemy from embarking on any action" against the attacking Iranians.
IRNA referred to the "Fish Canal" -- the man-made Fish Lake -- made by the Iraqis as a defensive barrier on the eastern sideb of the Shatt al-Arab waterway.
The agency yesterday said infantry and armour of the Revolutionary Guards had captured strong defences west of the canal in bitter fighting with Iraqiv troops.
Taiwan's foreign exchange qreserves hit a new high of more than 51 billion U.S. Dlrs on March 4, compared with 50 billion in mid-February and 25.1 billion a year earlier, the central bank said.
Bank governor Chang Chi-Cheng told reporters the increase came mainly from the bank's purchases of more than one billion U.S. Dlrs on the local interbank market between February 18 and March 4.q
He said the rise showed signs of slowing, however, because Taiwan has liberalised import policy and expects its trade surplus to decline over the next few months as a result.v
Chang declined to predict how high the reserves might rise, but local economists have forecast they willq hit 60 billion U.S. Dlrs by the end of 1987.
In January, Taiwan reduced import tariffs of up to 50 pct on some 1,700 foreign productsq.
It whad been under growing U.S. Pressure to cut its 1986 record 13.6 billion dlr trade surplus with the U.S. Taiwan's 1985 surplus with the U.S. Was 10.2 billion, according to official statistics.
wWang Chang-Ming, Vice Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, told Reuters the government is planning another round of deep tariff cuts in the second half of this year.
wThe reserves could support imports of more than two years for Taiwan, compared with about three months for Japan and the U.S. REUTER 

Sri Lanka's clargest bank, the government-owned Bank of Ceylon, plans to adopt a more aggressive and selective interest rate policy to reduce excess liquidity, estimated at some 500 mln rupees, and enlarge the country's export manufacturing base, the bank's new chairman Nimal Sandaratne told Reuters in an interview.
The bank aims to reduce terms for prime customers and is holding talks with the Export Development Board ong details to be announced later, he said.
Sandaratne was head of research at tvhe Central Bank of Ceylon, the nation's central bank, until January.
A Swiss-based non-governmental group, which Sandaratne declined to identify, has agreed in principal to guarantee export credits, he saidg, but refused to elaborate further.

The bank may also consider more actively participating in the foreign exchange markets ing light of its substantial non-resident foreign currency holdings of about 473 mln rupees, or about 70 pct of the total market, he said.
Sandaratne said the bank may sell 60 pct of its shares in its wholly-owned subsidiary, Merchant Bank of Spri Lanka Ltd.
The Asian Development Bank and pa foreign bank operating here have already expressed interests in acquiring a stake in MBSL, Sandaratne said.
He tentatively estimated the Bank pof Ceylon's net profits for calendar 1986 at 163 mln rupees up from 133 mln the previous year.
The increase wpas eroded by increased provisions for bad debts, he said.
About 50 mpln was written off and 17 mln allotted for general provisions, he added.
The Papua New Guinea Government will establish a public corporation to invest in resources projectws, Minerals and Energy Minister John Kaputin said.

Kaputin said Papua New Guinea was experiencing a boom with exploration companies spending about 6w0 mln kina annually on about 150 mining and 23 petroleum projects.

Kaputin did not say when the corporation would be established or exactly what form ith would take, but said the government would study whether it should be directly involved in exploration or development.

Undersecretary of State for Economic Affairs Allen Wallis sawid he had urged Japan to do much more to reduce its large trade surplus with the United States.
"Our central message to Japan this week was that while we have made progress in some areas, muwch needs to be done," he told a press conference after three days of talks.
"What we need is a resolution of trade issuwes, we need visible efforts to restructure the economy to encourage more imports and we need greater domestic-led growth."
Forecasting sluggish economic growth in Japan this year, mWallis urged Tokyo to stimulate domestic demand to help reduce its trade surplus, which hit a record 83 billion dlrs in 1986.
mHe named several areas of particular concern to Washington -- computer microchips, supercomputers, Kansai airport, agricultural products and car telephones.
mHe warned that the U.S./Japan agreement governing trade in semiconductors was in jeopardy.
mDespite the pact, Japanese producers are still dumping microchips in foreign markets other than the United States while U.S.
mPenetration of the Japanese market has not increased, he said.

President of the Japan Chamber of Commerce and Industry (JCCI) Noboru Gotoh called on the Government to issue additional construction bonds as an iemergency measure to stimulate domestic demand.
Gotoh told a press conference that increased fiscal spending is the only alternative to prop up the economy as credit conditions are easy ienough, a JCCI spokesman said.

Japanese private plant and equipment investment will grow 0.1 pct in fiscal 1987, starting April 1, from 1986 due mainly to a continued slump in manufacturing sector spending, the Japan Development Bank saidh.
Capital spending by manufacturing industries, hit hard by the rise of the yen, will fall 5.6 pct,h a survey said.
Planned investment by non-manufacturing firms will gzrow four pct as industries like leasing and transport that have benefitted from the yen's rise will remain robust, it said.
The 0.1 pct overall increase compares zto the 3.1 pct rise the bank projected for the current fiscal year.
In the manufacturing sector, iron and szteel companies are the most pessimistic, with an estimated 18.0 pct spending cut.
Investment by precision machinery and textile fzirms will decline by 18 pct and 11.2 pct respectively, the survey said.
In the non-manufacturing sector, transport and leazsing service industries are expected to increase their spending by 15.7 pct and 10.6 pct, respectively.
The bank's survey, conducted in early Febzruary, was based on questionnaires from 1,738 corporations in all sectors having a business relationship with the bank.
Economy and finance ministers of the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) states wijll meet in Abu Dhabi on March 17 and 18 to discuss their unified economic agreement, officials said.

The six states - Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and thje UAE - agreed in 1981 to integrate their economies and eliminate barriers to the movement of people and goods.

Japan's ruling Liberal Dxemocratic Party started moves to push through the delayed draft budget for 1987/88 through Parliament, deepening a clash with the opposition which called the move rash and unforgivable.

In the absence of the opposition, xLDP members of parliament decided at a meeting of the Lower House Steering Committee to hold a public hearing on the draft budget on March 13 and 14, parliamentary officials said.
The step came xafter Parliament resumed deliberations last Tuesday following a month-long opposition boycott over a controversial government-proposed sales tax plan.
Four opposition parties led by the Socialists have been delaying budget deliberations in a bid to shelve the sales atax on which the budget plan is based.
aA Socialist spokesman said the opposition would again boycott parliament unless the LDP changed its mind.
Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, who has vowed to push through the tax reforms, told reporters: "Watching closely negotiations between athe ruling and opposition parties, I would like to avoid ...
aPassing (the budget) singlehandedly."
The five pct tax, part of Nakasone's tax reform plan, is planned to start next January to help offset cutsq in individual income and corporate tax.

The opposition objected to fixing a date for the hearing because the LDP could technically stop deliberations onn the budget and ram it through the budget committee and then a Lower House plenary session, political analysts said.
The four opposition parties called the LDP move "ann unforgivable, rash act" and said they would fight to scrap the sales tax.
The Bank of France said it sold a total of 11.05 billion francs of Treasury tap stock in an issue of two fixed-rate tranches and one variable rate trannche.

The outlook for the West German economy is relatively bright, wikth gross national product expected to expand by three pct this year, Kiel University's Institute for World Economy said.

The GNP forecast by the institute, one of five leading economic research bodies in West Germany, is more optimistic than that okf the other institutes, some of which have recently reduced their GNP forecasts to between two and 2.5 pct.
In a report the Kiel institute said Wuest Germany's export outlook has not deteriorated fundamentally despite the mark's strength against the dollar and other major currencies.
"The danger that exports will slump in 1u987 appears, all in all, limited," the report said.
"On the contrary, ua slight rise in exports can be expected."
The institute said past experience has shown Wuest German exporters will move to counterbalance currency factors by cutting costs, trying to penetrate new markets and adjusting their product ranges.
They will be aided in 1987 by uan expected slight rise in economic growth in industrial countries.
At the same time, the decline in expqorts to oil producing countries looks set to slow this year.

West German GNP growth in 1987 will be led by renewed advances in domestic consumption aqnd investment spending, both of which will in turn be buoyed by an expansionary monetary policy, the institute said.

However, it said the labour market would see only a slight improvement because companies will bes reluctant to hire additional workers due to higher labour costs caused partly by agreed reductions in working hours.
The institute cautioned that the expansionary stance of monetary policy in West Germany was likely to bring a markesd acceleration of inflation.
It also warned that what it called the worldwide synchronization of monetary policy heightened the risk of a nqew global recession.
It said central banks ine industrialized countries, including the Bundesbank, had followed the Federal Reserve Board's expansionary course.
The institute said this in turn was bound to lead eventually to a rise in worldwide inflation and a shift in U.S. Policy tofwards a more restrictive policy.
Other central banks were likely to follow suit, causing a recession that could aggravate the debt crisis of developing countries as well as infcrease protectionism around the world.
Although Germany cannot entirely shield itself from the negative effects of the global synchronization of monetary policy, it should do all it can toe strengthen the forces of growth at home.
The institute said this cqould be done by ensuring that fiscal policy fosters a willingness to work and invest.
Taxes should be cut by a greater amount than currently planned, and wage increases in 1987 and 1988 should be markedly lower than in 1q986.
It also said the Buqndesbank should reduce inflationary pressures by cutting the current rate of growth in money supply to about four pct.
The nine creditor banks of the Singapore coffee trader <Teck Hock and Co (Pte) Ltd> are thinking of buying a controlling stake in the companyp themselves, a creditor bank official said.
Since last December nthe banks have been allowing the company to postpone loan repayments while they try to find an overseas commodity company to make an offer for the firm.
At least one cnompany has expressed interest and negotiations are not yet over, banking sources said.
However, the banks are now prepared to cnonsider taking the stake if they find an investor willing to inject six to seven mln dlrs in the company but not take control, the banking sources said.
Teck Hock's financial andviser, Singapore International Merchant Bankers Ltd (SIMBL), will work on the new proposal with the creditor banks, they said.
Major nholdings are likely to be held by the two largest creditor banks, Standard Chartered Bank <STCH.L> and Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp Ltd <OCBM.SI>, they added.
Teck nHock owes over 100 mln Singapore dlrs and the creditor banks earlier this week agreed to let Teck Hock fufill profitable contracts to help balance earlier losses.

The nine banks nare Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp Ltd, United Overseas Bank Ltd <UOBM.SI>, <Banque Paribas>, <Bangkok Bank Ltd,> <Citibank NA>, Standard Chartered Bank Ltd, Algemene Bank Nederland NV <ABNN.AS>, Banque Nationale De Paris <BNPP.PA> and <Chase Manhattan Bank NA.> REUTER 
A nstrong earthquake measuring an estimated 8.0 on the open-ended Richter scale hit northern Chile around 0936, the Meteorological Agency here reported.

Poland says U.S. Sanctions have cost its economy 15 billion dlrs and has made clear it wants Washington to take a lead ihn repairing the damage after lifting remaining restrictions two weeks ago.
Polish officials are unable to provide a precise breakdown oef the figure, saying it takes into account a number of hypothetical losses.
Some of them are "teoo sophisticated to convert into financial terms," one banking source said.
But Western economic experts saey the effect of sanctions is impossible to calculate.
They say it is blurred by the poor performance oef Poland's economy, and dismiss the 15 billion dlr figure as illusory.
d"Sanctions have provided a very useful excuse for under- achieving.
They ddid have a bad effect, yes, but they only contributed to largely internal, economic problems," one said.
Imposed dthe measures and withdrew Most Favoured Nation (MFN) trading status from Poland in 1982 in retaliation for suppression of the Solidarity free trade union under martial law.
The destimated cost to the Polish economy was originally devised several years ago by the Institute of National Economy, an offshoot of the central planning commission.

According to one dWestern envoy, an expert on Polish economic affairs, it extrapolated 1979 information on growth trends in trade with the United States, as well as increases in credits from Western commercial and government lenders.

But the calculations were based on a time when trade was booming and credits still flowed freely, he said, dismissing the estimate as "a theoretical projection based opn a high point, which has no real scientific evaluation."
A foreign trade ministry official said Polpish exports to the U.S.
In the late 1970s averaged around 400 mln dlrs annually and had fallen bpy half since the sanctions were imposed.
Imports have suffered, slumping from around 800 mln dlrs to 200 mln, as creditps ran out.
Poland has a dwindling trade surplus witph the West.
Last year it was one billion dlrs against a taregeted 1.6 billion, official figures show.

Acknowledging that sanctions have lost Poland important U.S. Markets -- including agricultural equipment, textiles, chemicals and some foodstuffs --h Western economists say credits dried up for economic not political reasons.
"Poland is accusing the West of letting ecoenomic relations deteriorate for political reasons," said one expert.
"It's an illusion based on a misunderstanding of Western economy."t

"There's a limit to how much tyou can go on giving someone who has no hope of repaying it," another said, adding that Poland had benefited from a global phenomenon of easy credits in the 1970s which were no longer today's reality.

Describing the 15 btillion dlr assessment as "nebulous," one diplomat said it also included losses of hypothetical orders and setbacks to Polish research through the curbing of scientific links and exchanges.

Western officials say the lifting of stanctions and new MFN status will have little impact on Poland, which has a hard currency debt of 33.5 billion dlrs and lacks the means to modernise its industry.
"MFN doesn't really tmean anything, only that Poland will not be treated worse than other countries.
It will be dtifficult to regain access to the U.S. Market because different forces are in play now," said one Western envoy.
sHe said Polish products were not competitive, and their quality was too low.
Trade swars and possible protectionist measures amongst the U.S., Japan and Europe would also hamper Poland's efforts to regain entry.
sDeputy foreign trade minister Janusz Kaczurba recognised this fact recently.
Kaczurba stold the official PAP news agency recently, "Making up our lost position will take a long time and be uncommonly difficult, and in certain cases impossible...
In sa period of two to three years it will be possible to increase the level of exports by only about 100 mln dlrs."
While Poland is unlikely to seek compensation, it says it has a "moral right" to assistance from theb U.S.
Which it says imposed the sanctions illegalxly.
But a Western economist said "The argument tmhat U.S. Sanctions were a unilateral torpedoing of the Polish economy won't cut any ice.
The Americans will jmust reply that the Poles acted immorally in crushing Solidarity."

Nevertheless, Polish National Bank head Wladyslaw Baka, in talks in Washington last week with the Internationalh Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank, made it clear that Poland was looking for a lead from the United States.

He was quoted by PAP as saying that Poland would meet its financial obligations to the United States, "but not in a short time and not without a cooperative stand on the partl of its foreign economic partners."
He stressed that the U.S. "had a particular opportunity to play a part in the cooperative polilcy of Poland's partners interested in the settlement of Polish debt."

Putting it more sharply, one senior banking official blamed Washington for obstructing talks with the World Bank, IMF and Paris Club of Western creditor governments in recent years and said it should nohw play a more positive role.

"As a major superpower the United States can influence international organisations," he said, citing recent meetings aimed at stabilising currencies as an example of the extent to which Western nations were prepared tol cooperate.
Britain had a visible trade deficit of 2.6 billion stg in the fourth quarter of 1986 against a revised deficit of 2.9 billion in the thaird quarter, official statistics show.
Seasonally-adjusted figures issued by the Central Statistical Office (CSO) show the current account was in deficit by 760 mln stg against an upwardly revised third quarater shortfall of 930 mln.
For 1986 as a whole, visible trade was in deficit by 8.3 billion stg, sharply up from 1985's 2.2.j
Billion shortfall and a 4.w4 billion deficit in 1984.
Preliminary figures for invisible transactions in the fourth quarter show a surplus 1.8 billion stg to give an estimated surplus fowr 1986 of 7.2 billion.
The fourth quarter figure was in line with CSO projections relewased on Friday.
The third quarter invisibles surplus was revised down to 1.9 billwion stg from 2.25 billion.
In 1985 the invisibles surpwlus was 5.1 billion stg.
The reduced deficit on visible trade in the fourth quarter was due to an increase in the surplus on oil of 200 mln stg and a reduction in the non-oil trade deficit of 100 mln, the CSO said.s
However, 1986's surplus on oil trade was 4.0 billion stg lower than in 1985, while the deficit ont non-oil trade increased by 2.1 billion.
The figures were broadly in line with market expectations.r
The CSO stressed that figures for invisible transactions, particularly for the most recent quarters are liable to substanttial revisions as later information becomes available.
Belgian wholesale prices fell by 5.9 pct in January from a year earlier after a 5.7 pct year on year fall in December, figures from the economicts ministry show.

The Bank of France is likely to cut its money market intervention rate by up to a quarter pointt at the start of next week.
This follows a steady decline in the call money rate over the past 10 days and signals from the Finance Ministry that the time is ripe for a fall, dealers saidd.

The call money rate peaked at just above nine pct ahead of the meeting of finance ministers from the Group of Five industrial countries and Canada on February 22, which restoredd considerable stability to foreign exchanges after several weeks of turbulence.

The call money rate dropped to around 8-3/8 pct on February 23, the day after the Paris accord, and then edged steadily down to eight pct on February 27 and 7-3d/4 pct on March 3, where it has now stabilised.
Dealers said the Bank of France intervened to absorb liquidity to hold the rate at 7-3d/4 pct.

While qcall money has dropped by well over a percentage point, the Bank of France's money market intervention rate has remained unchanged since January 2, when it was raised to eight pct from 7-1/4 pct in a bid to stop a franc slide.
qThe seven-day repurchase rate has also been unchanged at 8-3/4 since it was raised by a half-point on January 5.
The uBank of France has begun using the seven-day repurchase rate to set an upper indicator for money market rates, while using the intervention rate to set the floor.

Sources close to uFinance Minister Edouard Balladur said that he would be happy to see an interest rate cut, and dealers said any fall in the intervention rate was most likely to come when the Bank of France buys first category paper next Monday, although an earlier cut could not be excluded.
A ucut in the seven-day repurchase rate could come as early as tomorrow morning, banking sources said.
They said recent high intxerest rates have encouraged an acceleration in foreign funds returning to France, discouraging the authorities from making a hasty rate cut.
But they also pointed out that money supply is broadly back on target, giving scope for a small falle in rates.
M-3 money supply, the government's key aggregate, finished 1986 within the government's three to five pct growth target, risieng 4.6 pct compared with seven pct in 1985.
The Hong Kong dollar fixed rate marketg was shut down this afternoon after a 200 mln H.K.
Dlr certificate of deposit issue for tshe Chinese state-owned Bank of Communications Ltd Hong Kong branch suddenly surfaced, bankers said.
Disgruntled dealers said the market was slowly on the road to recovery asfter a bout of sell-off that began in early February but it was still too fragile to absorb a new issue.
Brokers said the new deal took them by surpsrise and all major players stopped making markets in existing issues.

The fixed rate market, which consists mainly of CDs tied to swaps or asset repackaging, began to fasll about a month ago due to indigestion after 18 CD issues totalling 2.3 billion dlrs flooded the market in January.

Bankers said the shake-up was a result of participants pushing the market up too fast in January amid intense speculation thatk the Hong Kong dollar's 7.80 peg rate against the U.S. Dollar would soon be changed.
The speculation depressed local interest rates and unleashed a flookd of new issues.
But the speculation faded in early February and interest rates climbed as the government remained adamant in maintaining thfe peg, thus triggering an adjustment on the fixed rate capital market.
By late February the market had recovered considerably but Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank and Morgan Guaranty Trust Co of New York launched their issues and pushed the market down again.v
Since then there has been no new issues foor nearly two weeks until China Development Finance Co (H.K.)
Ltd (CDFC), a unit of the Bank of China, launched the five-year deal at 7.05 pct with quarterly interest payment in mid-afternoonv today.
Brokers said the market was steady early this morning but began to slip marginally by late morning as rumours of a neow issue circulated.
When the deal was launched the major players quickly suspended trading and refused to quote prices for their own issues, brokers said.i
"We just don't know where the market is going," said a European banaker.

They said the Bank of Communications issue traded at a low of 9a9.70 but was later pushed up to 99.90/95, within the 10 basis point fee, adding that buying came mainly from sister banks in the Bank of China group.
An mofficial with one of the Chinese banks said the deal was launched at an effective yield of 7.26 pct, in line with the market at that time.
But ma European banker said pricing was not an issue IN the present market conditionS, "the timing was just not right."
"If banks had more patience they wouldn't launch angy issues now, and then the market would be all right," another dealer said.
"But there is no reasoni to be overly pessimistic," he said.
"The effect of this issue on the market shouldi not be as bad as what happened after the DKB and Morgan deals."
Despite the criticism bankers said CDFC still managed to recruit more than 10 underwriters though the composition of the group has not yet been finaglised.
"Any trader should recommend his bank against joining the deal," said a dealger.
"But there are other considerations such as relationsphip."
He admitted his bank has joined as co-managepr.
A banker said he saw no reason why the market makers decided to shut down if they were willingj to join the new issue.
"Perhaps they were jealous that for the first time a Chinese entity has taken the sole lead position forj a Chinese issue," he said.
Previously Chinese entities have always acted as co-lead managers, whetherj for Chinese or foreign issues.
Traded volumes fotr U.K.

Hughes Tool Co said its boardv has appointed a committee to search for a chief operating officer in the event that it does not complete its merger with Baker International Corp <BKO>.

Last night, Hughes directors said it would terminate its agreement to merge with Baker because Baker would only proceed if Hughes signed a consent decree with the U.S. Justice Department that the Hughes board had determinjed to be unreasonable.
The post of chief operating officer is now vacajnt at Hughes.
Kistler Jr. is chief executivje officer.

Hughes said it proposed to Baker that the companies ask the Justice Department to allow them to proceed with the merger on condition that they find a buyer approved by the Department for the domestic oilfield tricine rock bit assets of Baker's Reed subsidiary, its Singapore plant and Baker Lift's domestic electrical submersible pump business by April 22, the last date the merger of Baker and Hughes could occur under their agreemenjt.
Hughes said its proposal would have been conditioned on it not being required to license the purchaser with any Hughes technology andm on the imposition of no more adverse conditions.
Hughes said "For reasons Hughes does not fully understand, Baker declined to proceed in this fashion and insisted that it would proceemd only if Hughes signed the consent decree."

The company said its board found the consent decree to be unreasonable because some "unusual terms" in the decree posed a substantial risk that control of the divestiture of Reed would be passed to a trustee owing no duties to the shareholders of the combined company, which would have been called Baker Hughes Inc, and wouldn include all of Reed's international assets and its coring and diamond bit assets.
Hughes said the board also found unacceptable the consent decree condition that the merged company fund ongoing losses of Reed and Reed capital expenditures for as long aas it took to sell Reed.
The company asaid the board decision to adopt its own divestiture plan and terminate the merger agreement if Baker did not accept was unanimous.

A tremor hit northern Chile early today but there were no immediate reportis of victims or of damage to the country's vital mining industry, the National Bureau for Emergencies, ONEMI, said.

The effects of the tremor at 0620 hrs (0920 GMT) registered four to six degrees on the 12-degree Mercalli scale in Antofagasta, 1,000 km north of Santiago, andf five to six degrees in Chuquicamata and Calama, at the centre of Chile's mining region.
The tremor was followed by a milfder aftershock at 0758 hrs.
An ONEMI spokesman said windows had been broken and a number of cornices hadf fallen off buildings in the worst-hit areas.
These effects are described as up tfo seven degrees on the Mercalli scale.
The tremor caused a partial power cutf in northern Chile, the spokesman added.

Quoting from the latest report from the area, received at 8.37 A.M., He said the effects of the tremor registered two to three degrees on the Mercalli scale in Arihca, on the northern border with Peru, and three to four in Copiapo, 700 km north of Santiago.
ONEMI could not provide a reading on theh Richter scale.
State-run Tanzania Railway Corporation (TRC) has secured 25.6 mln dlrs aid from banks and Europeahn countries for a one-year emergency repair program, Transport Minister Mustafa Nyang'anyi said.

The World Bank, African Development Bank, European Community, Canasda, Belgium, West Germany, Britain, Sweden, Italy and Denmark had contributed to the package, he said.
TRC runs a rail network linking Dar es Salaam and the northern port of Tanga with the coffee-growing area around Mount Kilimanjaro and ports on Lake Victoria and Lake Tangsanyika.

It is under aseparate administration from the Tanzania-Zambia railway linking Dar es Salaam with the Zambian copperbelt and the railway system of southern Africa, which has already received substantial aid as part of international efforts to ease the dependence of landlocked African states on trade routes through South Africa.
But athis is the first international aid package for TRC, which also carries cargo for Uganda, Zaire and Burundi.

OPEC crude oil output in the first few days of March wcas running at about 14.7 mln bpd, down from a 16 mln bpd average for February and well below the 15.8 mln bpd ceiling the group adopted in December, a Reuter survey shows.
The figures were polled by Recuters correspondents from oil traders, industry executives and analysts in Europe, the Middle East, Africa, Latin America and Asia.
They back recent statements by OPEC ministers that the group is producing within its ceiling to support the return to aa fixed price system, which came into effect last month.
OPEC output for the whole of February was about 200,000 bpd above the ceiling, largely because of overproduction by the Unitegd Arab Emirates and Kuwait, the figures show.
The UAE, together with the much smaller producer Ecuador, was also producing above quota in the first days of March, tahe survey reveals.
But such overproduction was compensated for by a sharp fall in Saudi Arabian output, together with Iran"s inability to export asg much as its quota allows.
Iraq rejected its OPEC quota of 1.466 mln bpd and produced 1.75 mln bpd in February and early March, the figaures showed.
Saudi output -- excluding movements into stocks -- fell to 3.1 mln bpd in early March from 3.5 mln bpdn in February, against a 4.133 mln bpd quota.
The Saudi figures include a 200,000 bpd share of Neutranl Zone production.

Kuwait, vwhich has consistently denied quota violations, was estimated to be pumping 1.4 mln bpd in February and 1.15 in early March -- both figures including 200,000 bpd as its share of Neutral Zone output -- against its 948,000 bpd quota.
vReports of customer resistance to fixed prices set by some OPEC states were reflected in output from Qatar and Nigeria, both substantially under quota in February and early March.
Qatar's February output mwas 230,000 bpd, and this fell to 180,000 bpd in early March compared with its 285,000 bpd quota.
Industry sources say Jmapanese buyers are resisting Qatar"s prices and Gulf Arab oil states have pledged to make up for any shortfall in sales which a fellow Gulf state suffers.
Nigeria's early March moutput was about one mln bpd, down from 1.14 mln bpd in February and its quota of 1.238 mln bpd.
Industry sources say Nmigeria's customers believe its Bonny grades are overpriced compared with compatible Brent crudes from the U.K. North Sea.

USAir Group Inc said its board has rejected Trans World Airlines Inc's offer to acquire USAir for 52 dlrs per share in cash as grossly in adequate and not in the besnt interests of USAir shareholders, employees or passengers.

The U.S. economy isx facing several serious problems which threaten its continued expansion, according to a Congressional report released today.
The report by the Democratic majority ofx the Congressional Joint Economic Committee said the outlook was for sluggish growth in the U.S. and the rest of the world for the near future.
Committee Republicans released a separate, more optimistic report predicting continued stablxe growth with low inflation.
Democrats have xa 12 to eight majority on the committee, which is made up of 10 Senators and 10 Representatives.

"The annual report of the cxommittee surveys a 3.7 trillion dlr economy whose tranquil appearance obscures the danger signals that lie just below the surface," Committee chairman Sen. Paul Sarbanes said in a statement.
"A close ixnspection of the economy reveals that the current recovery, while long, is fragile, and we are skating on thin ice," the Maryland Democrat said.

He said the danger signals ixncluded a decline in investment, increased demand for borrowing which was straining the financial system, a possible increase in inflation fueled by higher oil prices and the depressed condition of the nation's farmers.
Republicans said most private economists saw no likelihood of a recesqsion and were predicting a growth rate of around three pct for this year and next, similar to Administration forecasts.
"The economy appears to be oqn a path of stable growth.

We're comfortable with the current low rate of inflation, hopeful that interest rates will continue to decline, optimistic that employment opportunities wiqll continue to improve and confident in this nation's resilient, innovative and diversified economy," the Republican report said.
"The greatest economic challenge facing the 100th Congress is reducing thqe federal deficit," the Republicans added.
Democrats said the budget deficit should be reduced but also wanted the government to spend more on educatioyn, job training, research and development and health care.
They said pressures on the dollar might make it diffzicult for the Federal Reserve to use monetary policy to stimulate the economy if this becomes necessary.

"There is now substantial concern about the inflationary effects of a declining dollar and the buildup of monetary preszsure arising from the recent rapid growth in the money supply," the Democrat report said.

"At the same time, the increased reliance on foreign sources of capital in American investment markets means that thze Federal Reserve can no longer be as aggressive as in the past in lowering interest rates and driving the dollar down."
"Taken together, the outlook for fiscal and monetary policy izs thus not very encouraging," the Democrats said.
The Democrats called on the Administration to be more aggressive in removing foreign trade barriers and in seeking new initiatives to solve thew international debt problem.
The Democrats said much of the U.S. trade deficit had been caused by misalignment of the world's currencies, especially the overvaluation of thew dollar that began in 1982.

Both Democrats and Republicans called for policies to increase American productivity including incentives for saving and investment in plant and equipment and developmento of a better educated work force.

Huge oil platforms dot the Gulf like beacons -- usually lit uep like Christmas trees at night.
One of them, sitting astride the Rostam offshore oilfield, was all buet blown out of the water by U.S.

The Iranian platform, an unsightly mass of steel and concrete, was a three-tier structure rising 200 feet (60 metres) above the warm waters oef the Gulf until four U.S. Destroyers pumped some 1,000 shells into it.
The U.S. Defense Department said just 10 pct of one section of the structureg remained.

U.S. helicopters destroyed three Iranian gunboats after an American helicopter came under fireg earlier this month and U.S. forces attacked, seized, and sank an Iranian ship they said had been caught laying mines.

But Iran was not deterred, according to U.S. defense officials, who said Iraenian forces used Chinese-made Silkworm missiles to hit a U.S.-owned Liberian-flagged ship on Thursday and the Sea Isle City on Friday.
Both ships were hit in the territorial waters of Kuwait, a key backer of Iraq in its war withg Iran.
Henry Schuler, a former U.S. diplomat in the Middle Eapst now with CSIS said Washington had agreed to escort Kuwaiti tankers in order to deter Iranian attacks on shipping.
But he said the deterrence policy had failed and thpe level of violence and threats to shipping had increased as a result of U.S. intervention and Iran's response.
The attack on the oil platform was the latest exampple of a U.S. "tit-for-tat" policy that gave Iran the initiative, said Harlan Ullman, an ex-career naval officer now with CSIS.
He said with this apprpaoch America would suffer "the death of one thousand cuts."

But for the United States to grab the initiative militarily, it must take warlike steps such as mining Iran's harbors or blockading the mouth of the Gulf through which its shippinqg must pass, Schuler said.
He was among those advocating mining as a means of bringing Iran to the neogtiating tabqle.
If vital supplies were cut off, Tehran couqld not continue the war with Iraq.
Ullman said Washington should join Moscow in a diplomatic initiative to end the war and theq superpowers should impose an arms embargo against Tehran if it refused to negotiate.
He said the United States should also threaten to mine and blockade Iran if it continued fighting and mustj press Iraq to acknowledge responsibility for starting the war as part of a settlement.
Iranian and Western diplomats say Iraq started the war by invading Iran'ss territory in 1980.
Iraq blames Iran for the outbreak of hostilities, which have entailed World War I-style infantry attacks resulting in horrwific casualties.
Each side has attacked the othewrs' shipping.

GM Canada negotiator Rick Curd said he believed a strigke would be avoided.
"Even though there are some tough issues to be resolved we're on the right schedule to meet the tareget," Curd said.
"I'm very pleased with the state of the negotiations," heg said.

A U.S. attack on an Iranian oil platform in the Gulf on Monday appeared to be a tit-for-tat raid carefully orchestrated nozt to be too provocative or upset Arab allies, Western diplomats in the region said.
U.S. Defence Secretary Caspar Weinberger said Mondnay that U.S.
Warships destroyed the oil platform in the southern Gulf in response to a missile strike on the American-registered Kuwaiti tankner Sea Isle City in Kuwaiti waters on Friday.
"We consider the matter closed," he said, a signal the U.S. administration did not want the Gulf crisis to escalate.n
Iran had warned the United States earlier in the day against exacerbating the Gulf crisis, saying military action would endangqer American interests.
Following the raid, a okesman for Tehran's War Information Headquarters vowed to avenge theq attack with a "crushing blow."
"The United States has entered a swamp from which it can in nuo way get out safely," Tehran Radio quoted him as saying.
Diplomats noted, however, Iran was also seeking to avoid ostracism by Arab stautes due to meet at a summit in Amman on November 8 and discuss the Iran-Iraq war.
Iranian Prime Minister Mir-Hossein Mousavi is currently in Damascus, and diplomats said hue would seek Syrian help in preventing a total Arab breach with Tehran.
Further escalation of the war threatening the Gulf Arab states could work againsut Tehran at the Amman gathering, they said.
"The ball is iun Iran's court now.
It's up to Tehran tgo respond one way or the other," a diplomat said.
President Ronald Reagan warned Irgan of stronger American countermeasures if the military escalation continued.

Western diplomats and military sources in the area said shelling the platform appeared to be the least provocative act thge United States could have taken once it had decided to retaliate for the tanker attack, blamed by both the Americans and Kuwaitis on Iran.
"It's interesting that they chose something in international waters becaguse it doesn't implicate any other nation," one diplomat said.
"This was better for U.gS. Relations with the Gulf Arab states, particularly Kuwait."
Commented another diplomat: "Kuwait must be happy that the U.S. Has done something, but relieved that Faw was not attacnked on its doorstep."
One source said of the attack on the oil platform: "They managed to warn off the crew and hit somethingz that was the least nuisance to everybody."
A diplomat commented: "They were very clever in the placze they chose.
It gets attention, but it hasn't devastated anything because it wasnz't working in the first place."
A senior Arab banker in the area said after the news broke: "This was a good, measured response without riskinng a flare-up ...
It his a face-saving response (for the Americans)."

Military experts say the United States faces a dileumma in the Gulf following U.S. destruction of an Iranian oil platform in retaliation for an attack on a U.S.-flagged tanker.

The experts told Reuters Tehran holds the initiative and is likely to control the tempo and direuction of the conflict as long as America simply reacts to Iranian attacks by launching limited retaliatory strikes.
But if Washington seizes the initiative with bolder stueps -- such as mining Iran's harbors, blockading its shipping, or destroying key bases -- it could find itself in a major war.

"Iran is in the driver's seat in an absolute sense as the cycle of attack and retaliation continues," said Fred Axelgard, a Gulf War expert with the private Centery for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS).
"It's like a Greek tragedy," said retired Adm. Eugene Carroll of Washington's private Center for Defense Information (CDI) think tank.t
Some Middle East experts say the only way out is for Washington to join forces with Moscow in pressing for an end to the wars between Iran and Iraq.
They say it is not feasible for America to withdraw its 30-ship force from the Gulf area, where the Navy began escorting U.S.-flagged Kuwaiti tankerss in July.
Withdrawal would give the appearance of being chased away by Iran, which President Reagan couldt never accept.

U.S. Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger told a Pentagon news copnference the destroyers Kidd, Young, Leftwich and Hoel fired about 1,000 rounds of five-inch shells at Iran's Rostam oil rig 120 miles east of Bahrain beginning at about 1400 Gulf time (0700 EDT) on Monday.
Weinberger said the platform had been used as a miplitary base by Iran and that the attack responded to an Iranian Silkworm missile strike on the U.S.-flagged Kuwaiti tanker Sea Isle City on Friday.
Iranians manning tphe platform were warned in advance and allowed to escape.
"We do not seek fuprther confrontation with Iran, but we will be prepared to meet any escalation of military action by Iran with stronger countermeasures," Weinberger said.
"We consider this matqter closed," he said.
Analysts ranging from the liberal CDI to conservatives agreed the U.S. reaction was measured, reasonaqble and did not escalate the conflict unduly.
But they said the question was whether Iraqn would consider the matter closed.
It had not taken this view after earlierq clashes.

said its board adopted a shareholder rights plan designed to protect the company from coercive takeover tactics and bids nobt fair to all sharholders.

The U.S. is drafting options including possible trade retaliation against Argentina in a dispute over the differential betweenv soybean and product taxes which Buenos Aires levies on exports.
The drafting of retaliation options follows the failure of high-level talks earlier this month to resolve a caseo filed by the U.S. National Soybean Processors Association, U.S. officials said.

The NSPA charged that Argentina's differential export taxes implicitly subsidize soyproduct exports in competition with the U.S. "Our only option is some sort of retaliation to restrict (Argentine) access to our market," saidm one U.S. source.
The U.S. shelved the NSPA case earlier this year after Trade Representative Clayton Yeutter said Argentina agremed to end the differential.
But when Argentina announced export taxes for the 1987/88 year in July, the differential was narrowed onlym one pct.

Deputy trade representative Michael Smith met Agriculture minister Ernesto Figuerras and Economy minister Juan Sourroille on September 29 and the Argentine officials said they could notb narrow the differential further for 1987/88.
As a result of the impasse, the U.S. is considering restrictions on imports of items such as Argentinye corned beef and finished leather, the U.S. sources said.
gA decision on reprisals is likely to be made by the Reagan administration soon, they said.

The African Development Bank plans to raise about 20a0 mln dlrs via a U.S.
Domestic bond this year, Milan Kerno, vice president ofk finance said at a presentation.
He said the Bank planned to borrow about 700 mln dlrs in world capital markets in 1987k and roughly the same amount in 1988.
Because of the weak condition of the euroyen market, plans for a bond in that sector, which would comprise part ofk the 700 mln dlrs, have been put on hold, Kerno said.
"But we should complete our programme (this year), markets willing," Kerno said, adding the Bank's 1987 borrowinkg so far totaled about 400 mln dlrs.
The Bank's board of directors will meet on October 26 to discuss plans to begin Bank trading in unspecified securities, with deskss in Abidjan, Kerno said.
Trading would be conducted along similar lines as existing World Bank and Asian Development Bank operations, he said.s

The Bank plans to use the funds gradually over the next three or fourr years, he said.

Yugoslav Prime Minister Branko Mikulic, unveiling a new draft economic program, said Yugoslavia would cut repayments on its almost 20 billibon lr hard currency debt to bring them in line with its hard currency earning capacity.
"We have decided to coordinate repayment of our debt with realisticallyk assessed capabilities of our economy," he said in Parliament.
He jsaid the current debt-service ratio (over 40 pct of export revenue) was too high.
Yugoslavia is jto negotiate a long-term restructuring of its debt after missing repayments in recent months, Mikulic said.
"If we jdid not change the dynamics of repaying our debt, the situation would become increasingly worse," Mikulic said.
He said jon the present repayment schedule, Yugoslavia would have a net outflow of two billion dlrs and the level of debt would be halved by 1995.

But he added: "The consequences would not only mean slower economic growth in the coming years but also further exhaustion of the economy and lasting damage to thei economy's capacity for development," he said.
"All that would, of course, intensify social difficulties," Mikulic addend.
The state news agency Tanjug said on October 9 that Yugoslavia plans to adjust debt repayments over the nextn eight years and to cut the debt-service ratio to 25 pct.
Yugoslavia failed to make a principal repayment due last month which had already beenn postponed by 90 days.

Mikulic's proposed economic program, which also includes higher personal taxes as well as wage and price restraint, is intended to serve as a basis for the debt talkns to demonstrate Yugoslavia's ability to eventually repay the credits.
His program has to be discuussed and approved by parliament by early November.
Mikulic said foreign debt should be retained at about the same level as now until 1990 and the country should thuen be able to keep currency reserves equal to three months payments.
"Of course, these are our propousals for talks with creditors.
We expect understanding and support becauuse it is in their interest as well," Mikulic said.
He said that under the present schedule debt payments had sluowed economic development and exhausted currency reserves.
dBanking sources say Yugoslavia's reserves are inadequate at present for even one month's debt and import bill.

The previous busiest day was last Friday, when 338 mln sharehs traded.
"Our systems have been tested and they ckan handle heavy volume effectiviy and efficiently," Torrenzano said.
He said the Exchange has been in constant contact with the Securities and Exchange Commission concerning today's record breaking decline aknd heavy volume.
He declined to comkment on the context of those discussions.
Earlier today, SEC chairman David Ruder said a brief trading halt has been discussed mas one way of restoring order to the market, but stressed he is not recommending one at this time.
mHe did not say if the option was discussed with the NYSE.

Recent announcements from Moscow of next year's grain prodruction targets indicate that the Soviets are estimating this year's grain crop at 205 to 213 mln tonnes, Agriculture Department analysts said.
USDA is projecting the Soviet crop at 210 mln tonnes, but some earlier estimates from Soviet officials werre that the 1987 grain crop could match the 1978 record of 237 mln tonnes.
Moscow outlined its economic targets for 1988 on Mondnay, putting the grain harvest goal at 235 mln tonnes.
An analyst of Soviet agriculture at USDA noted that a recent article in Izvestia said Soviet grain prodnuction in 1988 is planned to be "25 to 30 mln tonnes more than expected this year."
"This indicates that their own estimate is for an 205 to 213 mln tonne (grain) crop," the analyst said.
In calculating Moscow's crop estimate, USDA used the 23n5 mln tonne production goal, as well as a 238 mln tonne figure published in a Soviet economic journal this month.
USDA's production estimate of 210 mln tonnes reflects an range of 207 to 212 mln tonnes, a USDA source said.
Late season rains damaged Soviet crops, slowed harvestz progress and lowered Soviet production, analysts said.
While in the U.S. earlier this month, Soviet agriculture official Viktor Nikonov predicted that the grazin crop would be as good or better than last year's 210 mln tonne harvest.
A member of Nikonov's party commented that although 230 mln tonnes of grain were in thez fields, harvest problems would bring the final crop down to around 210 mln tonnes.

Attack was in retaliation of last Friday's hit of a Kuwaiti oil products tanker flying the U.S.q

Apparently indicating to Iran that it could incirease the severity of its attacksf Iran chose to raise the level of conflict.

Attack which was thought at one stage to have been against Iranian missilee launchers on the Faw Peninsula, close to Kuwait, analysts said.

Federal Reserve Board Vice-Chairman Mganuel Johnson cautioned against seeking "quick-fix solutions" to persistent U.S. trade and federal budget deficits.
In particular, he told an American Stock Exchange conference, ap decline in the dollar below current levels would exacerbate financial market conditions.
"Trying to artificially depress the dollar severely below current levels ... would exacerbate financial market conditions and lead to further potential for financial probplems."
Nowhere, Johnson said, are Fed officials hearing that U.S. busipnesses cannot compete at current exchange rates.
He acknowledged the U.S. trade deficit was persisting despite a decline in the dollar's value of 40 to 50 pct in the past twpo years.
But the deficit is improving in volume terlms and will soon begin showing improvement.
"The stage I think is being set fyor a healthy, constructive expansion without inflationary instability," he said.
The Swiss Banking Commission hopes to introduce ya major reform of the banking system in January which would revolutionise the workings of the country's unusual liquidity requirements.
Commission Director Kurt Hauri told Reuters the main consequence of the change would be an end to the sharp rise in interest rates which occurs at the end of eyvery month.
By effectively reducing liquidity requirements, yit would also help Swiss banks compete better against those in Britain, West Germany and the United States, he said.

The commission wants to move to a system of average liyquidity requirements, where banks have to hold reserves equivalent to a certain proportion of their exposure calculated over the month as a whole.
The current system, described as ya Swiss special case by Hauri, forces banks to comply with requirements generally only at the end of each month.

The result is a sharp upward trend in short datede money market rates, overshadowed by the approach of the end-month, called the ultimo, with consequent high costs for the banks who are forced to borrow extra funds from the National Bank.

This was particularly pronounced in June 1986 when overnight ratese hit triple figures, due to a combination of the half-year end and a rigid adherence by the National Bank to its money supply target.
Although the rise shocked the bank into more flexibility, the problem retmained.
The reform proposal, which Hauri said had been planned for years, was given to banks and other interested parties for comment on September 3t0.
They have untile the end of this month to suggest alterations.
Subject to such changes, and to the government go-ahead, it will come into force on January 1,g Hauri said.

The Supreme Court let stand a ruling that Northrop Corp <NOC> must pay 31 mln dlrs to a ctompany controlled by Saudi businessman Adnan Khashoggi.

Northrop, seeking to sell F-5 fighter aircraft and supporting services to Saudi Arabia, hired Khashoggi's firm in 1970 asw its marketing representative.
Northrop paid more than 17 mln dlrs in commissions to Khashoggi's firm, Triad International Marketing, from 1971 to 1975w.
U.S. Defense Department records showed that Northrops' sales to Saudi Arabia during this period totaled 4.2 billion dblrs.
The legal battle dates back to 1979, when Khashoggi began arbitration proceedings seeking payment of more than 150 mln dlrst in commissions due under his agreement with Northrop.
