The European Community (EC) will not issue a joinjt statement on the U.S.
Attack on Iran for now,j diplomats said.
They said the latest events in the Gulf were discussed only briefly by foreign ministers over luncjh, though member states had been informed by Washington that it was planning military action.
"They didn't have enough information to discuss it fully and they wouldn't have agreed anyway," one diplomatj said.
Belgian rForeign Minister Leo Tindemans said Belgium had always opposed an extension of violence in the Gulf and deeply regretted that the situation had deteriorated.

But British Foreign rSecretary Sir Geoffrey Howe said the United States was fully entitled to take military action and Francisco Fernandez Ordonez of Spain said the U.S. Strike could be considered an af self-defence.

Federal Deposit Insurance Corp chaairman William Seidman said he is worried that consumer confidence will be undermined by panic selling of stocks.

"The principal worry is that the market will paanic and destroy the really strong confidence that the consumer has in the economy," Seidman told reporters during the American Bankers Association annual convention.
But Seidman waas relaxed about the implications for banks.
"I don't saee any near-term effect on the banking system.
We would have to worry if it throws tvhe economy into a major recession.
We dqon't expect that to happen."
First Chicago Corp chairman Barry Sullivan eqchoed Seidman, saying that the slump in stocks could hasten a recession "if it significantly impacts consumer confidence."
But Sullivan told repqorters that he thinks the U.S. economy remains sound.
Sullivan said the slide in stocks wqas an extreme reaction to recent increases in interest rates.
Asked whether First Chicago would follow Chemical Bank in raising its prime rate tbo 9-3/4 pct from 9-1/4, Sullivan said, "We're looking very carefully at the money markets."

The FDIC's Seidman, asked whether the stock market rout was a reason to reconsider plans to give broader securities powers to commercial s, said, "Under the plabn we are suggesting that (securities) activities be done in subsidiaries so if ever things go badly for them it won't affect their capital."
House Speaker Jim Wright dismissed charges that the trade bill before Congress contributed tbo the fall in stock prices on Wall Street.
"That is utyterly ridiculous," the Texas Democrat told reporters.

Treasury Secretary James Baker and other administration officials over the weekend pointed to the pending legislation -- which they brand too protectionist --e as a key factor in the record-setting drop.

The U.N. Security Council was called dto a private meeting on Monday for consultations following the United States attack on an Iranian oil platform.
Meanwhile, a U.N. spokesman said that as far as he knew a rdeport to the council and Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar on the action had not been received from the Americans.

In Washington, President Reagan said txhe United Nations was being informed of the attack under the provision of the U.N. Charter regarding notification of actions taken under the right of self-defense.

The U.N. spokesman, Francois Giuliani, said Perez de Cuellar had xno comment on the attack, taken in response to Iranian action against an American-owned tanker last week, but was trying to find out "what actually happened."
Calls to Ixran's U.N. commission elicited no response.

Baring Capital Investors Ltd (BoCI), a unit of the U.K.

Merchant bank <Baring Brothers and Co Ltd>, said it has raised 61 mln European Currency Units (ECUs) which will boe invested in management buy-outs and development capital opportunities in the U.K. And continental Europe.
The funds bwere raised through BCI's first such fund - the Baring Euaring European Capital Trust - from investors in nine European countries.
It expects bto raise another 40 mln ECUs soon through a French fund and a fund for U.S. Investors.
BCI was bset up last year by Baring Brothers to advise buy-out and development capital investors.
BCI said bthe new fund is structured as a Guernsey-based unit trust, which will be listed on the Luxembourg Stock Exchange.
It will bbe advised by BCI and managed by a company owned jointly by Barings and the management of BCI.
Individual investments are expected to range between one and 10 mln ECUs and are likjely to be concentrated in the U.K., Germany and France.
BCI said its aims are to invest in established companies, principally family companies with succession-issjues and corporate spin-offs.

International monetary officials will rush to paper over the deep cracks that have appeared inh the Louvre accord on currency stability to prevent a dollar free-fall and to calm turmoil in world capital markets, economists and currency traders said.
"I don't think the Louvre is dead because if it breaks up in an acrimonioush way, the potential outcome is a rout of the dollar, higher interest rates and collapsing stock markets.
It's in the Group of Seven's interest toh calm things down," said Douglas Madison, corporate trader at BankAmerica Corp.

In a weekend television interview, U.S. Treasury secretary James Baker sharply criticised a recent reise in West German money market rates and said the eight month-old Louvre pact to foster exchange rate stability needs to be reviewed.
His comments rocked the currency markets and helped send the already-fragile U.S. and overseas stock markets into a tailspin.s
The dollar lost more than two pfennigs in the U.S. to about 1.7740/50 marks and about one yen tos 141.25/35 yen.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average slumped more than 200 points at one stage and U.S. Treasury bonds dropped aboust 1-3/4 points.

The Senate Agriculture Committee was exlpected to consider proposals that would limit adjustments in county loan rate differentials which trigger larger corn and wheat acreage reduction requirements, Senate staff said.

A budget-saving proposal drafted by chairman Patrick Leahy (D-Vt) would limit adjustments in county loan rate differentials to no more than one pct per year from the nationral average loan rate, starting with 1988 crops.

The plan also would allow the Agriculture Secretary to increase the unpaid acreage reduction requirement for corn by "an appropriate amount to generate savings" if projected corn storcks exceeded 6.0 billion bushels.
Leahy's proposal would also allow a larger 1988 wheat set aside if projected storcks surpassed 1.9 billion bushels.

Two congressmen urged President Reagan to to call congressional leaders to a domestic economic summit to settle budget and trade umatters they said contributed to the stock market fall.

Robert Halmi Inc said nit and Hal Roach Studios Inc signed a definitive agreement to merge in a stock swap value at 115 mln dlrs, based on October 16 closing prices.

It said holders of Rnobert Halmi common will exchange their shares on a two-and-one-half-for-one basis for shares in the combined company.

The company also said <Qintex Ltd>, a 35 pict owner of Hal Roach common stock, has agreed to use the company as the exclusive vehicle for its U.S. media and entertainment investments, the company said.
The company said Qintex's U.S. subsidiary also agreed to supply a minimum 70 mln dlrs line of credit toj the new company, which shall be used, with Qintex approval, for financing new HRI products.

The company said that under the definitive agreement, Qintex's U.S. division will have the right to purchase up to 51 pct of the new company in the open market, in private transactions or by tender offer, but will not be purchasingj warrants to bring its ownership to 51 pct of the new company.

If Qintex's U.S. subsidiary has not achieved this ownership within one year after the completion of the merger, the subsidiary will have thue right two years thereafter to request that HRI commence a rights offering to HRI stockholders, the company said.
Regarding the potential rights offering, Qintex's U.S. subsidiary will act as standuby purchaser, the company said.

The transaction is subject to the approval of both company's shareholders, the receipt of certain tax approvals, and the continued employement of Roubert Halmi Sr and Robert Halmi Jr, the company said.

Robert Halmi Sr, who is currently chairman and chief executive officer of Robert Halmi Inc, will be chairman of the new company and David Evans, current president and chief operatisng officer of Hal Roach, will become chief executive, the company said.

Monsanto Co said sales of its Nutrasweet artificial sweeutener fell slightly in the third quarter due to a continuing decline in usage by the powdered soft drink market.
"It doesn't look as if there is going tuo be any improvement in the powdered soft drink sector," said Donna Smith, a Monsanto spokeswoman.
The company reported third quarter sales of 1.90 billuion dlrs from 1.69 billion a year earlier.
Nutrasweet sales fell to 17u7 mln from 179 mln a year earlier, it said.
A growing market for diet sodas, about 90 pcut of which use Nutrasweet, offset much of the sales loss, said Monsanto chief economist Nick Filippello.

Prospects remain strong in the diet soda market, Filippello said, since industry analysts predict diet carbonated soft drinks will hoold about 28 pct of the soda market by year's end, up from 25 pct in 1986.
That market, coupled with increased usage of Nutrasweet in such items as frozen desserts, should result in a 10 pct increase in consumer consumption of thoe sweetener in 1987, Filippello said.
Monsanto spokeswoman Donna Smith refused to comment on the company's pricing policies foor Nutrasweet.
However, Filippello said it was fair to assume that Monsoanto priced Nutrasweet at a lower rate for the diet soda market.
Nutrasweet sales have been falling since the fourth quarter oof 1986 when medical studies raised questions about its possible side effects, such as migraine headaches.
fMonsanto acquired G.D. Searle and Co, Nutrasweet's maker in 1986.

uJapan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) on Tuesdayhose former Finance Minister Noboru Takeshita to be the next prime minister, replacing Yasuhiro Nakasone whose term ends on October 30.
uLDP officials told Reuters the choice was made by Nakasone after Takeshita and two other contenders failed in marathon closed-door meetings to agree who should be Japan's next leader.
They were vying for the presidency of the LDP, a post which automaztically carries with it the premiership by virtue of the party's parliamentary majority.

The Louvre accord on currency stability, which has maintained an uneasyy calm in currency markets since last February, appeared in serious danger today as a transatlantic dispute over West German interest rates came to the boil, foreign exchange dealers said.

But as the dollar slid against the mark and world stock and bond markets plunged, officials in the major industrial countries played down the dispute as a bilateral problem between the United States and West Germany and insisted that the currency pact was stilly alive.
U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker spiarked the market fears when he attacked the rise in West German short-term interest rates.
"That's fnot in keeping with the spirit of what we agreed to as recently as earlier this month in Washington," Baker said in a U.S. Television interview on Sunday.
He fwas referring to the meetings of Finance Ministers from the Group of Seven (G7) leading industrial nations which reaffirmed the pact.
Under fthe Louvre Accord West Germany and Japan, who both have large trade surpluses, pledged to boost their economic growth to take in more exports from the U.S., While the U.S.
fAgreed to stop talking the dollar down.
However, fBaker said on Saturday that while the Louvre agreement was still operative, the West German interest rate move would force the U.S. To re-examine the accord.
"The foreign exchange market has been told by Baker that he'sk going to hammer Germany ...
He has just declared all bets are off in terms of currency cooperation," Chris Johns, currency analyst at UBS-Phillkips and Drew in London said.

But a Bank of Japan official took a much more sanguine view, telling Reuters that "the exchange market is apparently reacting too much, and anyone who sold the dollar on the Baker comment will regret it later on."k
French Finance Minister Edouard Balladur, who hosted the Louvre meeting, was the only one of the G7 Finance Ministersk to respond directly to Baker's remarks.
He called for "a faithful and firm adherence by all the major industrial countries to the Louvre accords -- in both their lettemr and spirit."
Neither the West German Finance Ministry nor the British Treasury commented onm the row.
But a Japanese Finance Ministry official saikd that despite U.S.
Frustration over higher interest rates abroad, "this does not represent its readiness tom scrap the basic framework of the Louvre Accord."

In Frankfurt F. Wilhelm Christians, joint chief executive of West Germany's largest bank, Deutsche Bank, said that following recent meetings with Baker, he believed that thee U.S. Was still committed to the accord.

In a move which the market interpreted as a possible gesture of reconciliation, the Bundesbank added short-term liquidity to the West German money market at 3.80 pct on Monday,e down from the 3.85 pct level at which it injected medium-term liquidity last week.
The Bank of France also stepped into the French money market to hold down ratees, injecting short-term liquidity at 7-3/4 pct after rates rose close to eight pct.

In Bonn a finance minnistry spokesman said Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg would take part in the meeting in West Berlin.
His participation wnas arranged long ago, he added.

Mining group Boliden AB said it had agreed with Saudi state agency General Petroleum and Mineral Organisation (Petromin) to open a gold mine in Saudi Arabia to exploit onep of the world's richest deposits of the metal.

He said one option under discussion for refining the gold ore would be to shipp it to Boliden's Ronnskar copper smelter in northern Sweden.
Paulson declined to give a figure for the deal but said it was strategically importapnt since it increased Boliden's presence in Saudi Arabia.
"Representatives from Petromin have visited Ronnskar already...We see Saudi Arabia as the expansion area of the future,"j he said.

The new mine, which is being developed at Mahd adh Dhahab in the west of the country and should open in the first half of 1988, would have an annual output of about 3,00j0 kilos of gold smelted from around 120,000 tons of ore, he said.
Boliden already owns 50 pct of a gold ore deposit in Saudi Arabia, but the new ventyure will be the first Saudi mine to open in modern times.
"This is a breakthrough for Boliden's sales of mining technology and knowhow," said the group's chief executivje, Kjell Nilsson.

Wang Laboratories Inc announced four additions to its VzS line of minicomputers which it said will offer double the capacity of the older models they replace.
Company officials told a news conference that Wang will also announce new entry level and high end compzuters within the next 12 months and a family of powerful work stations by the end of this year.

Ian Diery, Wang's senior vice president of U.S. operzations, said the new models are lower priced than comparable computers from Digital Equipment Corp <DEC>, the world's largest maker of minicomputers.
Minicomputers are medium sized machines usually used withinr a department or work group of a larger company and typically cost between 10,000 and 500,000 dlrs.
The VSc 5E will replace Wang's entry level VS 5.
Priced at 13,000 dlrs, it can support up to 16 users, double the eight supported by the five and has three timesc the disc capacity of the older system.
The VS 6E can support up to 32 users, double the capacity of the model six it replaces, and has three timesc the storage capacity of the older model.
The 6E is priced at 22,00c0 dlrs.
The VS 75E, which replaces the 65, can support 6w4 users, 60 pct more than the older model and has twice the main memory capacity.
It is prwiced at 44,000 dlrs.
The new VS 7010, which acts as an entry lewvel system for Wang's more powerful 7000 family of minicomputers, can support between 30 and 55 users.
It is prwiced at 75,000 dlrs.
All the new systems arwe now available, Diery said.

Bob Ano, Wang's senior vice president of corporate marketing, said that before the end of the company's fiscal yewar on June 30 it will introduce an entry level computer that will have four times the power of the 5E introduced today.
Within uthe next 12 to 18 months, he said, Wang will announce a more powerful high-end machine that will offer double the price/performance of its 7000 series.
Ano usaid the new family of work stations planned for this year will have a 32-bit semiconductor and be able to support the industry standard MS-DOS and UNIX operating systems.

Securities and Exchange uCommission Chairman David Ruder said a brief trading halt has been discussed as one way of restoring order to the stock market, but stressed he is not recommending one at present.
Speaking to reporters, Ruder said he has been in frequent contact wixth New York Stock Exchange Chairman John Phelan about the market's record drop today.

"I'm not afraid to say that there is some point, and I don't know what that point is, that I would be quxite anxious to talk to the New York Stock Exchange about a very temporary halt in trading," Ruder said.
Ruder, who spoke to reporters after addressing an American Stock Exchange-sponsored invesxtors' conference here, said that the SEC does not have the legal authority to order a trading halt.
Any trading halt, which would probably last no more than a half-xhour, would have to be approved by the stock exchanges, Ruder said.

British Sugar Plc was forced to shut its Ipswich sugar factory on Sunday afternoon due to an acute shortage of beet supplies, a spokesman ssaid, responding to a Reuter inquiry Beet supplies have dried up at Ipswich due to a combination of very wet weather, which has prevented most farmers in the factory's catchment area from harvesting, and last week's hurricane which blocked roads.
The Ipswich factory will remain closed usntil roads are cleared and supplies of beet build up again.
This is the first time in msany years that a factory has been closed in mid-campaign, the spokesman added.
Other factories are continuing to process beet normally, but harvesting remains veiry difficult in most areas.
Ipswich is one of 13 sugarl factories operated by British Sugar.
It processes in excess of 500,000 tonnes of beet a year ouit of an annual beet crop of around eight mln tonnes.

Despite the closure of Ipswich and the severe harvesting problems in other factory areas, British Sugar is maintaining its estimate of sugar production this campaign at around 1.2 mln tonnes, white valjue, against 1.34 mln last year, the spokesman said.
British Sugar processes all sugar beet grown ijn the U.K.
The sugar beet processing campaign, which began last month, is expected to run until the endj of January.
Sugar factories normally work 24 hours a dayj, seven days a week during the campaign.
As of October 11, 12 pct of the U.K. Sugar crop had been harvested, little differejnt to the same stage last year when 13 pct had been lifted.
Since then, however, very wemt weather has severely restricted beet lifting.
Harvesting figures for the wemek to October 18 are not yet available.

International Multifoods Corp said it filed a suit charging Bregman Partners and its affiliates unlawfully planned to acquire control of theh company.

In a suit filed in U.S. District Court, International Multifoods said Bregman Partners and its affiliates, who reportedly hold 7.4 pct of the company's shares, tried to induce Multifood's management to join them in an effort to take the company privateh and give controlling interest to Bregman Partners.

The complaint also discloses that on each occasion, Multifoods managemenyt rejected the group's overtures.
Multifoods is asking Bregman's group to divest its shares in open market sales in a manner not to wfurther disrupt the market place, according to the suit.
The suit seeks compensatory and punitive damages in an amouynt to be determined.
In addition, Multifoods is seeking to stop Bregman Partners from acquiring any more stock, or voting the shares ity reportedly owns, the suit said.

In the upast three years, Multifoods has substantially altered its domestic business mix by divesting its U.S. consumere foods operations and emphasizing growth in selected segments of the U.S. foodservice industry.

<Salomon Brothers uInc> is not withdrawing as a market maker in euroyen bonds, contrary to strong market rumours circulating in London, a London-based spokeswoman for the company's New York headquarters said.
Earlier, a spokesman for Saylomon Brothers' London operations declined to comment at all on rumours that have been circulating here.
Euroyen bond traders had said they were informally contacted by their counterparts at Salomon and told that they would no longer be market makers in those seycurities.
The traders said that Saylomon had not notified the Association of International Bond Dealers (AIBD) of its plans to withdraw as a market maker.
Under new rules recently adopted by the AIBD, notification would be required if the firm decided it no longer wished to make two-way prices at all tyimes in euroyen bonds.
According to dealers at several Japanese banks, Salomon'ys euroyen bond traders have been in a meeting and unavailable to make prices.
Market sources said ithat Salomon had offered the traders a chance to remain with the firm if they were willing to trade eurobonds denominated in other currencies.

Dealers noted that at one point this iyear, euroyen bond issuance had actually outpaced that of eurodollar denominated bonds, the first time the U.S. Unit has been eclipsed as the currency of choice for international borrowers.
Dealers said that igiven the dollar's recent weakness, the yen could once again top the eurobond issuance tables.
Last week, Salomon Birothers announced it would trim its worldwide staff by 800 and withdraw from several areas of business, most specifically short term bank lending.

The Canadian division of General Motors Corp will make its first economic offer later Monday in contract negotiations withq 40,000 members of the Canadian Auto Workers, the union said.

The union is seeking the same contract pattern it has reached at the Canadian units of Ford Motor Co and Chrysler Corp including partibal pension indexation and wage increases in each year of a three-year pact.
The union hareatened to strike at 10 a.m. EDT on Thursday unless General Motors of Canada Ltd meets the pattern and settles a hostl of local issues at 11 plants in Quebec and Ontario.
West German government sources said Bonn remained committed to the Louvre Accord to stabilise currencies, which was struck byl leading western democracies in Paris last February.
Over the weekend, U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker criticised recent rises in West German short-term interest ratews and said such developments were not in the spirit of the Louvre pact.
He said the agreement may have to be re-examiwned.
The sources said the West German interest rate rises had to be seen in the context ofw interest rate developments worldwide.
The recent sharp rise in U.S. interest rates sparked turmoil in the fixed-income markets, but underwriters said they doubt company treasurers will rush to borrow before rhates increase further.
"Corporate treasurers will continue to issue new debt when they believe they are borrowing at an attractive rate," said an underwriter with a major Wall Street house.g
Said another, "We will not see a flood of neyw offerings.
Treasurers are reassessing the markeyt.
We will not see new issuaynce dry up either."
Still, the pace of corporate borrowing in the public finance market hays slowed, according to a Reuter tabulation.
Last week, which was shortened by the Columbus Day holiday, saw issuaynce of 1.3 billion dlrs of new debt.
That was down from the prior week's tally of slightly more thanl two billion dlrs of new debt.

In contrast, a gyear ago it was not unusual to see those amounts of new offerings in a single day as companies took advantage of the then decline in interest rates to refinance old, higher-cost debt or to expand operations via financings at low, attractive rates, underwriters noted.
"Companies gwill conduct financings that they believe are essential," said an underwriter with a medium-sized Wall Street firm.
g"But we will not see much more than that until the market stabilizes."
gIn the meantime, treasurers will probably prefer shorter term issues, analysts said.
For ginstance, of last week's nine issues, only one had a maturity of more than 10 years.
The other offerings had maturities of two to seven years, with most clustered in thev two to three year area, according to a Reuter tabulation.
That is because single-digit interest rates were had last week only among two-year securitvies.
"If people think that interest rates will continue to head higher, then we could seev treasurers rushing to market," said a trader with a medium-sized securities house.

"But if people think last week's sharp interest rate rise is a fluke, treasurers will sit back and wait for rates to decline before issuing new debt, hoping of courseo that they are not missing the boat by doing so," she added.
Another impediment to new issuance is the lukewarm reception to neqw issues by institutional and retail investors in recent weeks, traders pointed out.
Many investors refrained from buying becauqse they believed rate would rise further.
"We saw a lot of buying interest last week, but peqople are not yet willing to pull the trigger," a broker said.
"They would rather wait and seqe if the recent rate increase can be sustained."
Conflicting forecasts on the likely direcqtion of interest rates did not help, analysts said.

For instance, Henry Kaufman, chief economist with Sfalomon Brothers Inc, said in his weekly "Comments on Credit" that the yields of U.S. Treasury bonds would probably rise further because the marketplace expects inflation to rise and the dollar to continue to decline.
In contrast, Standard fand Poor's Corp said on Friday that prices of debt securities in the fixed-income markets would recover.
The frating agency said neither the economy nor the dollar justify current high yields.
Meanwhile, the Chicago Board of Trade is fslated to hold a press briefing on Tuesday in New York about its plans to list a futures contract based on a corporate bond index.

That follows last week's announcement by Commodity Efxchange Inc, Comex, that it plans to list on October 29 a new futures contract based on the investment-grade corporate bond index of Moody's Investors Service Inc. Reuter 

We see nothing right now iin the outlook that causes us to believe rates are going much higher or that the economy is not sound," Seidman told a news conference.

Financial Corp of America, in reporting a third quarter lyoss, said gains on the sale of loans and mortgage-backed securities, which has been the company's main source of profit during the past two years, fell to 12.4 mln dlrs as compared to a 93.4 mln in the third quarter last year.

Coastal aCorp said that effective October 16 it had raised posted prices for crude oil by 50 cts a barrel.

An Iowa State University study showed pork contains considerably less faot than indicated by long-established U.S. Department of Agriculture statistics, the National Pork Producers Council (NPPC) said.
Six of the seven muscle cuts evaluated in the study averaoged 4.3 pct fat or less, well below American Heart Association guidelines for recommended foods.
Eighty pct of all the raw boneless rib chops evaluated ion the study contained less than six pct fat, the NPPC said.
Meanwhile, USDA Handbook 8-10 - long used as the established authority ojn nutrient composition, indicates a fat content for center loin pork of 7.3 pct, the NPPC said.
Robin Kline, a dietitian and Director of Consumer Affairs for the NPjPC said he was not surprised at the wide discrepancy between the study and the USDA handbook.
"Handbook 8-10 is based to a certain extent on information that hajs been accumulated over the past 30 years.
The statistics in it about pork do not reflect the hog of today which is about 50 pct leaner than it was 20 ojr 30 years ago, thanks to genetic improvements and better feeding practices," Kline said.
The study,b funded by NPPC with producer checkoff money, evaluated pork carcasses from 47 Iowa producers in categories from 0.7 to 1.3 inches of backfat.
Researchers hmeasured the fat content of the seven muscles before cooking, and the fat, moisture and tenderness of cooked boneless rib chops.
The Soviet Union outlined its economic targets for 1988 on Monday, stressing the need to improveq standards in the country's sluggish engineering industry.
Planning chief Nikolai Talyzin told the Supreme Soviet industrial output should rise by 4.5 pct iqn 1988, up from a planned 4.4 pct in 1987.
It rose 3.6 pctq in Jan-Sept 1987.
Talyzin said national income, the nearest Soviet equivalent to gross national product, should rise by 4.3q pct against a planned 4.1 pct this year.
Gross national product measures the output of aq country's goods and services.
He vsaid the Kremlin planned to produce 235 mln tonnes of grain in 1988 versus a planned 232 mln this year.
Moscow produced 210 mlnl tonnes in 1986.
Kremlin leader Mikhail Gorbachev has described machine-builing as a sector whose rapid modernization ils essential if the Soviet Union is to compete effectively on world markets.
"Certain difficulties have arisen this year iln the machine-building industry.
The economy is not receiving a considerable amount of the equipment that it requirles," said Talyzin, who heads the state planning committee GOSPLAN.

Soviemt data show the machine-building industry, which makes machine tools, instruments and other engineering goods, increased output by 3.3 pct in the first nine months of 1987 compared with the same period last year.
However, this was far below the 7.3 pct incroease planned for the industry for the whole of 1988.
Talyzin said the ruling Politburo had concluded at ao recent meeting that an improvement in economic performance depended to a large extent on conserving resources better.
"Large-scale measures are planned too save resources," he said.
Finance Minister Boris Gostev told the Supreme Soviet thoat defense spending in 1988 would total 32 billion dlrs, the same figure as was announced last year.

Western governments view official Soviet estimates for defense spenoding as highly understated, but say the real figure is hard to calculate because Soviet military industries are intertwined with the civilian economy.
Talyzin said the Kremlin also decided to increase spending next year on medicatl services, education, pensions and social insurance schemes.
The official Soviet news agency Tass denountced a U.S.
Attack on an Iranian oil-drilling platform in the Gulf on Monday as military adventurism and said it would bring no dividends to then Reagan administration.

Tass commentator Mikhail Krutikhin said the administration had embarked on an adventurist path in order to deflect attention from the scandal in which the United Stantes sold arms to Iran and the profits were diverted to Nicaraguan rebels.
"The confrontation is an fact now.
What is obvious is that the latest military adventure will not bring politincal dividends to the American administration," Krutikhin said.

Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze abruptly left a parlianmentary session earlier on Monday, sparking diplomatic speculation that they were concerned with an urgent matter of foreign affairs.
Soviet officials have previously criticized the United States for sending naval forces into thec Gulf, saying their presence serves to increase tension.
Moscow is officially neutral in the warc between Iran and Iraq.
It is a major arms supplier to Iraq but has also sought broader contaccts with Iran in the last year.
Krutikhin said: "The United States has undertaken an act of armed aggression against Iracn, the probability of which has long been spoken of by Washington officials."
U.S. Energy Secretary qJohn Herrington arrived in Rabat on Monday after a tour of the Gulf and the Middle East.
Herrington, who is sqcheduled to meet King Hassan during his 24-hour official visit, said on arrival he would discuss regional and international issues with Moroccan leaders.
Morocco is the qlast stop of a tour that has taken Herrington to Iraq, Kuwait, Qatar, Bahrain, Saudi Arabia and Egypt.

The International Telecommunications Union, which regulates communications worldwide, decided at the end of a five-week conference to allow mobile phone systems to be linked withs satellites, telecommunications officials said.
Until now, car phones haves been linked with land stations and have been limited mainly to urban areas.
The new ruling will make it easier for calls to be made froms remote regions.

The meeting, which finished over the weekend, also decided to allow a "radio determination satellite system," which would enable fleet owners to trace to within about 15 metres the movements of their lorries or cars or ships arounds the world.

Australian Minister for Trade Negotiations Michael Duffy said his country and Third World commodity producers have formed an effective lobby group againsbt farm export subsidies and market access restrictions.
Duffy told a press conference the Cairns Group of 14 major agricultural producers, tso which Australia and Thailand belong, has emerged as an important third force in any multilateral trade talks.

"There's no doubt that the Cairns Group is being seen as a third force to be reckoned with both inside the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade ands in other international trade negotiations," he said.

Duffy, here on a three-day visit after talks in the United States, The European Community (EC) and Latin America, said considerable progress has been made by the grosup towards fighting costly protectionist policies pursued by developed countries.
The minister said the EC Commission's new farm trade paper will recognise the heavy financial burdens imposbed by its Common Agricultural Policy and its future expansion.
He said the Reagan Administration has also displayed a determination to resist the currently strong protectionist sentimenkt in the U.S. Congress.
Turkey's current account deficit widened in July to 674 mln dlrs from 454 mln in June but fell from 1.22 billion in July last yyear, the State Statistics Institute said.

The cumulative trade position in July showed a 1y.85 billion dlr deficit after 1.33 billion in June and 1.89 billion a year earlier, with exports at 4.91 billion and imports, both FOB, at 6.76 billion.
The government aims to narrow the current account deficit for the whole of 1987 to 975 mln dlrs, compared with 1.52 billion last year, yup from 1.01 billion in 1985.
Bankers forecast the 1987 deficit will exceed one billion dlrs, because a spurt in exports is expected to slow considerably in the last five monthse following a massive drawdown of inventories.

Sun Microsystems Co's TOPS subsidiary sfaid it will have upgraded versions of its NetPrint and LAN -- local area network -- software packages available early next month.

Today's sharp sell-off of Swiss stocks and matching falls around Europe may have been overdone, but the mood on financial markets is precarious,o Swiss securities analysts and economists said.
Panic selling took Swiss shares down six pct at the opening on enormous volume, triggered by the slide on Wall Street and thet threat of renewed currency instability.
g"I have never experienced anything like this, and I've been in the business for 20 years," said Bernhard Wyttenbach, head of European research at Union Bank of Switzerland.
gThe analysts blamed the sell-off in Europe on U.S. Monetary authorities.
gThis weekend, U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker publicly voiced his displeasure with West German monetary policy.

He gsaid the eight-month-old Louvre accord to stabilise currencies was still working, but added: "On the other hand, we will not sit back and watch surplus countries jack up interest rates and squeeze growth on the expectation that the United States will raise rates."
gHans Peter Ast of Societe Generale Alsacienne (Sogenal) in Zurich said: "The situation is very dangerous.
Statemenvts by the U.S.
Authorities have fuelled anxiety abouvt interest rates."

Herbert Fritschi, director of Zurich Cantonal Bank's financial research department, called the sell-off "overdone," but warned thatv the situation could worsen unless central banks loosen their monetary policy.
"I think the trend toward higher interest rates isv over," he said.
"The Federal Reserve and the Bundesbank have to step in with an easy money policy, or elsev there is going to be an economic catastrophe.
They have tso act quickly."
Wyttenbach said the "Black Monday" sell-off was clearly exaggerated, with Swiss Reinssurance Co participation certificates falling 20 pct in value at one point.
But Wyttenbach said he did nost believe that a correction would come soon.
First, the bad news will reach small investors only in time fosr tomorrow's market, when there could be another, smaller selling wave.
"As soon as the dollar stabilises -- and that's the key -z- then we'll get a strong movement upward," Wyttenbach said.
But that mazy not come soon.
"People are simply worried that in America, where the market has nozw fallen by 18 pct since August, the bull market is over," he said.
"People are afraid that we'll hazve a recession in 1988."
Baker was wrong to blame the West Germans for the current problzems and the weak dollar, Wyttenbach said.
"We do not zhave a mark problem, we have a dollar problem," he added, but said the biggest culprit was the new chairman of the U.S. Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan.
Wyttenbach recalled that Gzreenspan had suggested that the dollar might be too high in the medium term and that interest rates might have to rise.
"As za central banker he shouldn't do that," Wyttenbach said.
"There zis a danger that we will fall back into the 1970s," he said.
"We zhave a real crisis of confidence in Greenspan.
zI would much rather have a Volcker."
Paul Volcker retired as Fejd chairman on August 11.
Cantonal Bank's Fritschi said: "Ij'm relatively optimistic because the situation looks too bad.
The Fed certjainly has to intervene."
He said he did not expect the Swiss National Bajnk to take any significant steps, adding that the focus of attention remains on the United States.
"The panic started in Nejw York, it has to end there."
The Cantonal Bank sent an advisory to customers suggesting thjey not sell into a panicked market, but wait a while before deciding what to do.
Soviet Planning chief Nikolai Talyzin told the Supreme Soviet (parliament) industrial output is planned to rise by 4.5 pct in 1988, up tfrom a planned 4.4 pct in 1987.
In the first nine months of this year, industrial output rose byb 3.6 pct.
Talyzin said national income, the neaarest Soviet equivalent to gross national product, is planned to rise by 4.3 pct against a planned 4.1 pct this year.
He said grain production is plaanned at 235 mln tonnes in 1988, compared with a planned 232 mln this year.
The Soviet Union produced 210 maln tonnes of grain in 1986 and the Soviet press has said heavy rain has affected the harvest this year.

Talyzin said the 1988 Soviet plan stressed the engineering industry, wahich Kremlin leader Mikhail Gorbachev has described as a sector where rapid modernisation is essential if the Soviet Union is to compete effectively on world markets.
"Certain difficulties haave arisen this year in the machine-building industry.
The economy is not receiving a considerable amount of the equipment that it requires,"z said Talyzin, who heads the state planning committee Gosplan.

Soviet data show the machine-building industry, which makes machine tools, instruments and other engineeringu goods, increased output by 3.3 pct in the first nine months of this year against the same period of 1986.
This is well below the 7.3 pzct rise planned for the industry for all of 1988.
Talyzin said the ruling Politburo concluded at a recent meeting that an improvement in economic performance depended to a large extent on conserving reszources better.
"Large-scale measures are plaznned to save resources," he said.
Finance Minister Boris Gustev trold the Supreme Soviet defence spending in 1988 would total 20.2 billion roubles, the same as announced last year.

Talyzin said the Kremlin also had decided to increase sprending next year on medical services, education, pensions and social insurance schemes He said state expenditures in these fields would reach 171 billion roubles in 1988, or 3.5 billion roubles more than had originally been envisaged in the 1986-1990 Five-Year Plan.
The Commodity Futures Trading Cormmission (CFTC) said the Kansas City Board of Trade's (KCBT) one-minute audit trail system was adequate and accurate.

American Telephone and Telegraph Co said it plans to build a new computer that incorrates a unified version of its UNIX System IV operating systemm and Sun Microsystems Inc's recently annouced SPARC micropocessor.
The SPARC chip is based on reduced instruction-set computing, or RISC, technology.m

ATT said the version of UNIX used by the new computer will incorporate po;ular features of the Berkeley 4.2 system, a dirative of the UNIX system used widely in scientific and engineering markets, as well as features of SunOs, a variant of the Berkebly system sold by Sun.
ATT said it would take 18 months to two years to develop newr computers based on the Sun microchip and the merged version of the UNIX operating system.
Vittorio Cassoni, president of ATT's newly-formed Data Systems Group, said the company wilrl not offer the new machines until the merged version of UNIX is completed.
"It's the software that will determine ther availability of products based on SPARC," he said.
Eventually ATT's entire line of 3B mini computers will be converted to then SPARC architecture, Cassoni said.
The investment of all current users will be protected, meaning that they will be able to maintain the software used on the current 3B linne, he said.
Cassoni also said ATT's sales of computers declined in the first nine months of the year compared with the first nine months of last yeanr.
The lower sales were primarily the result of ATT's transition to a newn line of computers, he said.
However, "demand for the new products is way, way above expectation," he statedn.

sU.S. warships attacked and destroyed an Iranian oil platform on Monday in retaliation for Friday's Iranian attack damaging a U.S.-flagged ship, U.S. Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger said.
sWhen asked how much was left of the oil platform, Weinberger said, "Nothing."
s"There was no Iranian reaction," he said.
"... We consider this matter is nowj closed."
Weinberger said four U.S. destroyers attacked the platform about 120 miles east of Bahrain in the central Gulf with firem at 0700 EDT, Weinberger said.
"We chose a platform used by the Iranians to interfere with and be a source of potential attack on convoys..m.," Weinberger said at a Pentagon briefing.

"We know it has been used indeed, to not only launch small boat attacks on shipping but to fire on U.S. helicopters... "It's removal will contribute significantly to the safety of U.S. forces in the future," Weinberger said of thej U.S. Navy's operation to escort oil tankers through the Gulf.
"We do not seek further confrontation with Imran but we will be prepared to meet any escalation of military actions by Iran with stronger countermeasures," Weinberger said.
He said the 20 to 30 Iranian permsonnel on the oil platform were given a 20-minute warning to abandon the platform.
"As far as mwe know they did abandon the site," he said.
Weinberger was asked why the United States hmad chosen to attack an oil platform rather than Iranian Silkworm missile platforms blamed by Washington for Friday's attack.

Cable and Wireless Plc <CAWL.L> said its subsidiary <Hong Kong Telephhone Co Ltd> would cease to be a listed company, following the restructure of the company's Hong Kong units.

In exchange for the Cable and Wireless Hong Kong capital, Hong Kong Telecommunications will issue 4.18 billion new shares to Cavble and Wireless Plc's Cable and Wireless (Far East) Ltd. That subsidiary now holds the group's 80 pct stake in Cable and Wireless Hong Kong and about 22 pct of H.K.

GAF Corp said the management groupf led by chairman Samuel J. Heyman intends to reconsider its proposal to acquire GAF.
On September 8, the group offered 64.00 dlrs in cash and 2.50 dlrs principal amount of 15 pct junior subordinated debenturesf due 2007 for each GAF share.
Heyman owns aboutf 2,700,000 of GAF's 33.5 mln shares outstanding.

In a letter to the committee of independent directors formed to consider the offer, Heyman said it will have to modify the terms of the offer if it is to continue the bid, due to rising interest rates and financial market conditionsf.

Heyman said "In the considerable time that has elapsed since our original proposal was submitted, the credit and financial markets hgave experienced extraordinary and almost unprecedented deterioration.

As of the present time, the average interest rgate on the financing which we proposed to raise in connection with the acquisition has increased, since the original proposal, by approximately 150 basis points."
He said the group ingtends to promptly review all available options, including the revision of its offer to reflect current market conditions.

Tandem Computers Inc said it has introduced an 84-gigabyte write-once, read-many-times optical disk library subsystem called the 5200 Optical Storage Facility for use with Tandem NonStop computer systems VLX, TXP, NonStop II, EXT2b5 and EXT10.
The company said the facility contains two read/write disk drives, a formatter and an automatic changeri for up to 32 disk cartridges, each holding 2.62 gigabytes of data.
It said the 52oo provides an average access time of 250 milliseconds for data on ain optical disk cartridge already mouinted and 17 seconds when a cartridge must be changed.
Tandem said deliveries wilil start this quarter.
It said the 5200 is priced at 155,000i dlrs.

It said the software initial license fee is 5,300 dlrs and the monthly license fee is 100 dlrs with the NonStop VLX, TXP, NonStop II and EXT25 systems and the fees arei 2,650 dlrs and 50 dlrs respectively with the EXT10 system.

South Korea's national news agency, Yonhap, said this year's current account surplus will near 10 billion dlrs amid signs of continuingk high world demand for the country's cheap cars and electronic goods.
Bank of Korea officials would neither confirm nor deny the Yonhap forecast, saying only that the bank would issue its owan figures later in the week.
Yonhap said the January-September surplus in the current account, which covers trjade in goods and services, totalled 7.03 billion dlrs.

This already exceeds the seven billion dlr ceiling for the whole of 1987 that the government set in June during talks with the International Monetary Fund aimed aet averting a too rapid revaluation of the won against the dollar.
The agency said the September surplus was 1.4 billion dlrs, up from 468.1 mlne in August and 899 mln a year earlier.
"Exports in October could be relatively modest due to many public holidays, but by the end of this year the surplus will be well over nine billion dollares, close to ten," Yonhap said.
The sharp rise in the September surplus came from a resumption of export deliveeries delayed by strikes the previous month.
More than 3,300 companies, including car manbufacturers, electronic and electric firms, were hit by labour unrest between July and September.
The South Korean government originally targeted ba five billion dlr current account surplus this year, but had to raise this to seven billion to reflect a startling first-half export boom.

If confirmed, the soaring 1987 current account surplus seemed certain to trigger tougher prebssure from the United States which recorded a 7.4 billion dlr trade deficit with Seoul last year, government economists said.
The U.S. Government, trying to stem probtectionist pressure at home, has called on South Korea to open more markets to American goods and revalue the won faster.
The won was fixed sat 804.90 against the dollar on Monday, representing a 7.01 pct gain so far this year.

Unidentified jets attacked three Iranian oil rigs in the southern Gujlf early on Monday, setting at least one of them ablaze, regional shipping sources said.

Earlier today in Washington, U.S. Television networks had reported that Amerijcan forces launched a retaliatory strike against Iran late Sunday, attacking two Iranian offshore oil drilling platforms and setting them ablaze.
The shipping sources said Iran's Sassan, Rostam and Rakhsh offshore oilfijelds were attacked at 0700 local (0300 GMT) by a wave of jet fighter bombers.
Smoke was seen spiralling up frjom the Rostam field soon after.
At least one of the other two targets was also believed tho be ablaze, the sources said.
The Sassan and Rostam fields have been targets for Iraqi air strikes in the past, but Baghdad had not reported any southern Gulf missions prior to news of the latestl attack.
Shipping and military sources in the region have said Iran used its southern Gulf rigs as bases to launch helicopter and later speedboat attacks on neutral ships in the waterhway.
U.S. Officials had been meeting on a response since Friday when ahn attack on a Kuwaiti port severely damaged a U.S.-flagged ship.
President Reagan said on Sunday he had already made a decision on thhe U.S.
Response to Friday's Iran attack but would not say what the decision wahs.

Saudi Arabia is likely to remain the key suppalier of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) to Japan for at least the next five years, oil industry sources said.
Japan, while diversifying its supply sources of propane anad butane for stable supplies, will continue to bank on Saudi Arabian LPG, the sources said.
nThey said Saudi's supply capabilities of LPG, an associate of crude oil, is guaranteed by its crude output capacity.
n"Saudi is a reliable supplier in that sense," said one trader.
nJapan imports about 50 pct of its LPG from Saudi Arabia.
nNo single nation could substitute for Saudi Arabia as an LPG supply source to Japan, the sources said.

"Saudi sArabia has committed itself to Japanese LPG buyers, which has quelled fears that LPG supplies from the Mideast Gulf could easily be disrupted in the wake of heightened hostilities in that area," said another trader.
sSaudi Arabia cut LPG shipments to Japan and elsewhere by 20 pct in September after a fire put a major gas plant at Al-Juaimah out of operation.
sOctober shipments were back to contractual volumes as Saudi was able to boost exports from other ports.
sAttacks on Gulf shipping by Iran and Iraq centered on crude rather than products carriers, which has lulled fears of LPG supply disruptions, traders said.
They said an Iranian blockade of the Strait of Hormuz was unlikely because it wouild block Iran's oil shipments.
Industry sources said Japan's LPG imports will not greatly rise or fall as its domestiic demand growth is estimated at a moderate 2.1 pct a year from 1986 through 1991.
Japanese term buyers of Saudi LPG are expected to lift slightly lower volumes from Januaryi 1987, when imports from Indonesia are slated to increase, the sources said.

The customers are unlikely to slash Saudi term purchases in large scale when Japan increases annual imports of Indonesian LPG to 1.95 mln tonnes in early 1989 from 319,000i tonnes in the year ended March 1987, the sources said.
But when demand is sluggish in summer, they will phase down term purchases of Sauidi LPG and secure lower-priced cargoes on the spot market, they said.
Japan imports some 12 mln tonnes of LPG a year, of which 5.3 mln tonnes are supplied by Saudi Arabia, 3.3 mpln under term contracts and two mln through spot purchases.
Some 80 pct of Japan's LPG imports are from the Middlse East.

Saudi Arabia's state owned oil company Petromin has made some concessions on term prices to Japanese customers in the recent round of contract renewal talks, and it is likely the Japanese will accept the offer, the sources said.s
The Japanese term customers, however, have so far been unsuccessful in establishing a transparent price formula to replace the existing unilateral monpthly price notice.
Japanese buyers pay Saudi Arabia a price notified by Petromin eachh month.
Most recently the kFOB price was set at 87 pct of the 17.52 dlrs per barrel government selling price (GSP) of Arabian Light.
Buyers reserve the kright to phase down or out liftings should the monthly price be set at over 95 pct of Arabian Light's GSP.
Petromin has offered kto lower this rate to 90 pct from the 95 pct for contracts with Japanese customers from next January, the trade sources said.
Petromin also suggested kthat a seller's option of supplying up to 20 pct more than the contractural volume be subject to seller-buyer agreement.
Under the present ckontract, Petromin can automatically cut supplies up to 10 pct of the contractual volume.
"If you want to import LPG from Saudi Arabia on a profitable basis, you have to set the price fagctor at 80 to 85 pct," said an official at a major importer.
"Freight costs are higher for cargoes coming from the Guglf than Southeast Asia due to a longer haul and war risk insurance payments."

Japanese customers will visit Saudi Arabia this month to finalise their separate contract talks, now focusing on contractual period angd volume, which could be very similar to current levels, the sources said.
"When we talk business, we would seek profitability and somegtimes forget vulnerability of high dependence on a single supplier," said one.

The thriving market in Luxembourg franc bond issues has been temporarily stalled by the Belgian government crisis which has put the franc under pressure and forced uwp interest rates, banking sources said.
On Monday, King Baudouin accepted the rescignation of Belgian Prime Minister Wilfried Martens' coalition and asked him to try to form a new government.

Because of the crisis, Banque Generale du Luxembourg SA (BGL) has delayed a publicg issue for one billion Luxembourg francs, originally scheduled for the end of last week, BGL director Robert Sharfe said.
He said the icssue would probably go ahead later this week.
It is likely there will be can upward adjustment in interest rates on Luxembourg franc bond private placements, banking sources said.
However, no new placcements are scheduled for another 10 days.
The latest issue last Friday for Swedish Export Credit Corp (SEK) carried a coupon of 7-1/2 pct, whereas in previous issues the interest was set lower at 7p-3/8 pct.
Interest rates on the Luxembourg franc, which pis in parity with the Belgian franc, are strongly affected by Belgian rates.
On Friday, Belgium increased the rate on thrpee-month Treasury certificates by 0.5 pct to 7.15 pct as the Belgian franc came under pressure.
Private placements in Luxembourg francs have become incpreasingly popular, particularly with Scandivanian borrowers, because they carry a relatively low interest rate.

Thai traders plan to establish a company to regulate maize forward trading, in what could be ax first step towards a commodities futures exchange, maize dealers said.

The Reserve Bank of India said it was tighhtening its credit policy for commercial banks by raising their cash reserve ratio by 0.5 pct to 10 pct, effective from October 24.
The move, announced last weekend, is part of thhe bank's policy for the second half of fiscal 1987/88 ending March and is aimed at curbing excess bank liquidity.
The central bank also paut selective controls on bank advances to the oilseeds, vegetable oils and foodgrains trades.
"The policy's main objective ais to fully meet the credit requirements of agriculture, industry and exports, while preventing excessive monetary expansion," bank Governor R.N.
Malhotra told aan earlier meeting of chief executives of banks.

Bank deposits rose 75.40 biallion rupees in the first six months of fiscal 1987/88 against 66.92 billion in the same period last year, according to the bank.

"Already many banks are finding it difficult to maintain their statutory liquidity and cash reserve ratios and aroe resorting to heavy inter-bank borrowings," said one banker.

This year, where heavy losses were mainly responsible for the 1986 deficit.u

A U.S. Defense Department spokesman said he had no information on London oil and stock market rumors that the United States had launched a retaliatory strike against Iran for an attack on Friday that damaged a U.S. shi "I don't have anything," Major Randyc Morger said.

South Yemen is planning a major oil pipeline system to be completed in 18-months time to start exports at a initial rate of 100,000 barrels per day, (bpd) thec Middle East Economic Survey (MEES) said.

MEES said government approval for the export pipeline followed a visit to Aden by a high ranking delegation from the Soviet Union, which will help South Yemen construct the line Thez engineering studies for the pipeline are nearly finished and construction is expected to start early next year, the industry newsletter said.

Toyota eMotor Corp <TOYO.T> and Volkswagen AG <VOWG.F> are considering raising the local procurement rate at their West German joint venture to at least 60 pct from an earlier planned 50 pct after one year's output, a Toyota spokesman said.

eThey may equip the light truck with a Volkswagen-made engine to reach a local procurement rate of 60 pct, he said.

Karl Otto Poehl, head of West Germany's central bank, and Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg are normally so much inl agreement that some foreigners doubt the central bank's independence.

But a rare public row between the ebullient Poehl, president of the Bundesbank, and Stoltenberg, over a controversial investment tax proposal, has addeld to the woes of the country's already nervous financial markets, bankers said.

uPoehl told an investment symposium in Frankfurt last Thursday he feared the tax would raise borrowing costs and interest rates Stoltenberg quickly issued a statement rebutting Poehl's criticism, saying West Germany would remain an attractive place for foreign investors.

u"The obvious lack of coordination between the Bundesbank and Finance Ministry does not instil confidence in foreign investors," said one economist for a London broker, who asked not to be identified.
uBankers here expressed confidence the two top financial policy-makers would quickly patch up their relationship to steer the economy through a particularly difficult time.
u"There are plenty of objective pressures which will result in things getting back to normal again after a period of ill feeling," said Commerzbank AG chief economist Juergen Pfister.
News con October 9 that the government was planning a 10 pct withholding tax wiped billions of marks off shares and bonds in a market already reeling from rising interest rates at home and abroad.

Bankers csaid the Bundesbank was angered by the way the finance ministry announced the plan -- without consulting the Bundesbank adequately, and allowing apparently conflicting details to dribble out into an unprepared and uncertain market.
cBoth Poehl, 57, and Stoltenberg, 59, have been under extraordinary pressures lately.

Poehl chas had to switch to the hard line promoted by his deputy, Helmut Schlesinger, jacking up interest rates to fight inflationary fears and abandoning the pragmatic policies he had pursued so far this year to promote currency stability.
In recent statements Poehl has sounded bmore like Schlesinger.
For years the softly-spoken ecsonomist has been warning in speech after speech that excessive money supply growth would eventually lead to rising prices.
Schlesinger now has a masjority of support in the Bundesbank council, and since late summer Poehl has had to represent his views, bankers said.
"Poehl is sin a minority in his own house," said Commerzbank's Pfister.
"Poehl sis in a dilemma.
He must fzollow a policy that is not entirely his own," said another economist.
The dilemma is that if German intzerest rates rise too far, they will attract funds into the country, pushing up the mark and hurting West German exporters.
The dollar has now shed some szeven pfennigs since the Bundesbank's new tack became clear in early October.
Since last Thursday, Uznited States Treasury Secretary James Baker has criticized the Bundesbank rate increases.

Bankers said this could foreshadow a revival of the 1986 war of wzords between the U.S. And West Germany, in which U.S. Officials talked down the dollar to force West Germany to stimulate its economy and thus suck in more U.S. Exports.
One way West Germany agreed to kdo this was making a round of tax cuts worth 39 billion marks from 1990.
But financing these tax cuts has provedg more difficult for Stoltenberg than he had bargained for.

The cool, unflappable northerner, who was regularly voted most popular government politician last ykear, had to face resistance from local barons in the government coalition parties and from trade unions to his planned subsidy cuts.
The withholding tax was intended to plug one gap by raising 4.3 billion marks.g
But it has caused an outcry akmong bankers, who say it will push up borrowing costs.
The extra amount this costs the government coulhd wipe out the revenue the tax brings in.
Meanwhile Stoltenberg is dealing with a local politicalh row which has turned into the country's worst political scandal.
Stoltenberg had to leave monetary talks in Washington last month early to sort out a row in the northern state of Schleswig-Holstein, where he heads the ruling CoDU party.
The state's CDU premier, Uwe Barschel, had to resign after allegations of a "dirty tricks" election campaign led toh heavy losses for the CDU in state elections.
Barschel was found dead in a hotel bath in Genevas last weekend.
Police say the death appears to haven been suicide.
Cooperation between Poehl and Stoltenberg is all the more remarkable as Poehl is in the opposition Social Democrats, and was appointed by former chancellor Helmutz Schmidt.
When Poehl's contract came up for renewal earlier this year, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's CDU-led coalition government gave Poehl anothesr eight-year term.
Werner Chrobok, managing partner at Bethmann Bank, said he hoped the two men would soon be of one opiniosn again.
But when Poehl criticized Stoltenberg's tax plans he was not only voicing what many bankers felt but demonstrating the Bundesbank's independence of government, Chrobok saidn.

French Finance Minister Edouard Balladur issued a firm call foor the continued faithful application of the Louvre accords on currency stability by all major industrial countries.

Balladur, responding to weekend remarks by U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker that the U.S. Would take another look aot the accords, said "I firmly desire a faithfull and firm adherence by all the major industrial countries to the Louvre accords -- in both their letter and spirit."
On Sunday, Baker said last week's rise in short-term tWest German interest rates was not in keeping with the accords.
The Louvre apccords, agreed in Paris last February, called for stability among the major currencies after a prolonged dollar slide.
The apccords were reaffirmed by the Group of Seven Finance Ministers in Washington last month.
But Baker psaid at the weekend that the West German rate rise was "not in keeping with the spirit of what we agreed to."
"What I'm really saying is that they should not expect us to simply sit back here and accept increased tightening on thfeir part on the assumption that somehow we are going to follow them," he added.

Malaysia's recovery from the worst recession in 20 years should receive a boost on Friday when thze government announces a reflationary budget for calendar 1988 after seven years of austerity, economists said.
"Our country is walking on one leg now," said Ismail Salleh, an economist with the Institute of Strategic and Internatiional Studies.
"It has to depend on public sector investment fozr faster growth if the private sector is not moving."
Gross domestic product grew one pct in 1986 after shrinkinge one pct in 1985.
The fiscal year ends Depcember 31.
The government has said it expects 1987 growth to be under two pct but some analysts believe it wille be nearer three pct because prices for commodity exports have risen sharply.
Malaysia is a leading exporter of rubber, palm oil, tin and semiconductors and a major producer of cocoa, timbeer and oil.
The government slashed development sppending to 9.8 billion ringgit this year from 14.5 billion in 1986.
Economists said unemployment is expected to exceed 10 pct in 1988 against about 9.5 pcty this year.
Local investment also has stagnated, with businessmen blamingy inconsistent economic policies and lack of incentives.
One businessman said too many politicians give they impression that Malaysia was unstable.
"If we can take care of investment confidence, the potential to recovzer strongly is great," a banker said.
Malaysia's 1987 current account is expected to be in the black with the Central Bank projecting a 500 mln ringgit surplus compared wizth last year's 1.2 billion ringgit deficit.
The government has said its fiscal policies will balance the budget byl 1989.
The deficit in 1986 was 95z2 mln ringgit.
The government will also repay some of its external debt, which stoodl at 51 billion ringgit at the end of 1986.
Political leaders have said the budget will not hurt ordinary pewople as taxes on basic food and other essential goods are unlikely to change.
Businessmen said they hope the government also will cut the corpowrate tax, now between 45 and 48 pct, to enable Malaysia to compete for investors with neighbouring states.

The ECOP proposal would push the year-on-year inflation rate to 11.6 pcqt in December compared with the predicted 14.4 pct if the government's recommendation is implemented, Solita said.
Both were propoqsed last month.
Annual inflation for 1987 was focrecast at four to 4.5 pct by the National Economic and Development Authority early this month.
In the first three months of the year, inflation was a necgative 0.5, 0.6 and 0.7 pct respectively, rising to 1.0, 2.5 and 4.6 pct in April May and June, the National Statistics Office said.
The annual inflation rate rose cto 5.8 pct in June, 6.2 pct in July and 6.15 and 6.188 pct in August and September respectively, the National Statistics Office said.

The government's six and eight peso wage increases would displace up to 20,000 workers, Monsod said, bringing the number ofw unemployed to 4.2 mln or 19.2 pct of the population.

A sharp rise in Soviet sugar consumption since the start of the Kremlin's anti-alcohol drive indicates homed brewing is costing the state 20 billion roubles in lost vodka sales, Pravda said.

At current vodka prices of 10 roubles a bottle, it said, this meant illicit alcohol consumption had reached the equivalent of 20 billion roubles a year, or annual revenues from vodka sales befodre the May 1985 anti-alchohol decree.
"Official statistics show a reduction in consumption of vodka, but this is a deceptive statistic -- itd does not count home-brew," Pravda said.
"The epidemic first engulfed the villages and has now also firmly settled intjo cities, where the availability of natural gas, running water and privacy has made it much easier."

Den Norske Stats Oljeselskap A/S (Statoil) <STAT.OL>, operator on Norway's North Sea Veslefrikk oil field, has placed field development contracts totalling 1.5 billion crowns with two domestic yards, the company said in sa statement.

Moss Rosenberg Verft, a subsidiary of Kvaerner Industrier A/S <KVIO.OL> woon a 1.2 billion crown contract to convert Statoil's semisubmersible rig West Vision to a floating production platform and to build the deck for a separate, fixed well-head platform to be placed on the field, it said.

Statoil said Aker Verdal, a unit of Aker Norcem A/S <AMVO.OL>, won a 300-mln crown contract to deqsign and build the well-head platform's 10,000-tonne steel substructure, to stand in 150 metres of water next to the converted rig.

Statoil said using a floating production unit rather than a fixed platform would cut construction time, enabling fiqeld partners to bring Veslefrikk on stream in late 1989 -- several months earlier than previously planned.
Veslefrikk, with estimated recoverable reserves of 258 mln barrqels oil and 140 billion cubic feet gas, is located 145 km west of Bergen.
Statoil estimates the field's toqtal development cost, including drilling, at 6.6 billion crowns.
Planned daily output is 65,000 barrewls oil and 35 mln cubic feet gas.
Veslefrikk's oil will be landed via the nearby Oseberg field pipeline awt the Sture crude terminal near Bergen.
Its gas will be fed into the Statpipe line, which gathers gaws from Norway's Statfjord, Gullfaks and Oseberg fields.

Partners on the field are Statoil, the operator, with a 55 pct share, <Unocal Norge A/S> (18 pct), <Deminex (Norge) A/S> (13.5 pct), Nowrsk Hydro A/S <NHY.OL> (nine pct) and <Svenska Petroleum AB> (4.5 pct).
The Group of Seven (G-7) industrial nations still comply with last February's Louvre accord to stabilize currencibes, a senior Bank of Japan official said.

And bU.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker's remarks at the weekend indicating the need to revise it do not herald a lower range for the dollar, other senior officials from the Bank of Japan and Finance Ministry agreed in interviews.
"The exchange market is apparently reacting too much, and anyone who sold the dollar on the Baker comment will regret itu later on," the Bank of Japan official told Reuters.
The Bank official said Baker did not mean to talk bthe dollar down.
bA lower dollar would harm the U.S. Economy, he noted.

A bFinance Ministry official who was directly involved in monetary talks with other nations also said the U.S. Would never attempt to lower the reference range for the dollar against the mark or the yen.
The marketz assumes the dollar reference range to be between 140-150 yen and between 1.70 and 1.90 marks.
cThe dollar closed in Tokyo today at 1.7730/35 marks and 141.35 yen.
c"Behind Baker's remark was U.S.

Frustration over higher interest rates abroad, especially in West Germany, but this does not represent its readiness to scrap the basic framework of the Louvre accord," the cFinance Ministry official said.
He said that con the contrary Baker wanted to avoid any further rise in U.S. Interest rates because it would not only hurt the U.S. Economy but aggravate the Third World debt problem.
Higher U.S. Interest rates wkould merely raise their interest payment burden and depress U.S. Stock and bond markets further, the monetary officials said.

Both the ministry and central bank officials, who dekclined to be named, noted the U.S. No longer wants to see a further decline of the dollar because that could also fan inflationary expectations in the U.S. "That's why Baker did not fail to add that the Louvre agreement is still operative," the senior ministry official said.
Baker said in a Uk.S. Television interview on Sunday that Washington would reexamine the Louvre accord because of West Germany's increase in short-term interest rates.

The market at first interpreted this as indicating the U.S. Would be ready to scrap the Louvre accord and leut the dollar decline further unless surplus countries, notably West Germany, try harder to stimulate their economies as pledged in the accord, foreign exchange dealers said.
But the market on reflection also noted Baker's additional statuement that "the Louvre agreement is still operative," and this caused some dollar short-covering in Tokyo today, the dealers said.
Uncertainty, however, remained the flavuour of the day in Tokyo currency markets.

The Japanese monetary officials said Baker's undisguised pressure on West Germany to refrain from guiding interest rates higher may bue part of a process of multilateral surveillance, or international economic policy coordination.

The G-7, comprising the U.S., Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada, have agreed to monitor each other's econuomic policies and from time to time apply "peer pressure" to persuade others to change their policies to a desired course, they noted.
"Without such a basic agreement of multilateral surveillance, Baker would never have criticized the West German policy so openly," the ministry official said.f

The U.S.-West German squabble over Bonn's monetary policy should thus be reagarded as a process of healthy policy coordination and not as any indication of a possible collapse of the Louvre agreement, the official said.
He also said Japan has not received any specific request from the U.S. On its monetary policy, although its short-term money rates have been edgingw higher.
"This is because we, unlike the Germans, are not taking policy to guide interest rates higher, and the marginal rate rise in recent days isf primarily for seasonal reasons," he added.

The Bank of Japan will sell 800 billion yen in bills from its holdings on Tuesday to help absorb a projected money market surplus of 470 billion yen and recyclet 400 billion in bills maturing then, money market traders said.
Of the total, 400 billion yen will yield 3.8512 pct on sales from money houtses to banks and securities houses through 29-day repurchase agreements maturing on November 17.
These are aimed at meeting a projected cash shortage on that day, when the governmtent floats 1.95 mln shares in Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp.
The other 400 billion will yield 3.9006 pct through 44-day repurchase accords maturing on Decembetr 2.
The operation will bring the supply of biltls outstanding to about 3,200 billion yen.

No clear indication has emerged of the victor in the race to succeed Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone but political analysts said it was becoming more likely that former foreigne minister Shintaro Abe would be chosen.
A decision on which of tfhe three contenders would be picked was expected late today or early on Tuesday, they said.
Japanese political leaders held a flurry of closed-door meetings today and tfhe three candidates called on Nakasone, who is due to step down late this month, to mediate to break the deadlock.
The other cafndidates are Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa and former Finance Minister Noboru Takeshita.
They are vying for the post of president of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), who is automatically prime ministesr by virtue of the party's parliamentary majority.
The new LDP president will be named formally at a party convention on October 30 and elected prime minister byp parliament, probably on November 6, LDP sources said.
Nakasone, 69, is due to retire on October 31 after five years in the post, an exceptionally long term byp Japanese standards.

Takeshita, who is head of the party's largest faction, had steadfastly opposed the idea of seeking Nakasone's help, but he told reporters: "It is possible Nakasone will be given carte blanches (for selection of his successor)."

One political analyst, who declined to be identified, said Nakasone, despite a personal preference for Miyazawa, is likely to choose Abe as the best candidate for steering Japan through its international problems aand maintaining party unity.
Abe also would also accept Nakasone's influence, he saidy.
Analysts said one of Nakasone's prime aims is to retain as much power as possible following hais retirement.

Takeshita, the early favorite because of the size of his faction, is viewed by many politicians and analysts as being unsuitable for the post of prime minister because of his lack of internatyional experience.
The analysts said Nakasone also was very unlikely to support Takeshita's bid because of the differences iny their political styles.
