French Finance Minister Edouard Balladur issued a firm call four the continued faithful application of the Louvre accords on currency stability by all major industrial countries.

Balladur, responding to weekend remarks by U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker that the U.S. Would take another look aut the accords, said "I firmly desire a faithfull and firm adherence by all the major industrial countries to the Louvre accords -- in both their letter and spirit."
On Sunday, Baker said last week's rise in short-term Weust German interest rates was not in keeping with the accords.
The Louvre accords, agreed in Paris last February, called for stability among the major currencies after a prolonged dollar slidwe.
The accords were reaffirmed by the Group of Seven kFinance Ministers in Washington last month.
But Baker said at the weekend that the West German rate rise was "not in keeping with the spirit ofw what we agreed to."
"Whawt I'm really saying is that they should not expect us to simply sit back here and accept increased tightening on their part on the assumption that somehow we are going to follow them," he added.

International Rubber Organisation (INRO) buffer stock manager Aldo Hofmeister slaid tests had shown the quality of rubber in stock was acceptable, but acknowledged that some consumers were now wary of buying it.

"We have said all along that the rubber is hollding up well from a condition and quality standpoint...Rubber stored in proper conditions does not deteriorate," he told Reuters in a telephone interview.
The quality of buffer stock rubber sold since he entered the market in September would be discussed at anh INRO Council meeting which opened here today, he said.
Tokyo traders said on Friday they had little interest in buying rubber from the INRO buffer stock because ofh possible poor quality.
Hofmeister began selling rubber when prices exceeded trhe "may-sell' level of 232 cents per kg early last month.
INRO's five-day moving average was quoted at 237.3 cents onh October 16.
He said the quality of five to sixr-year old rubber in stock was uppermost in consumers' minds.
"We have received goodh interest for the rubber.
I understand the Japanese conrcern.
Many consumers want to try the rubber before they carrly on buying," he said.
Hofmeister said INRO rubber was stored in 28 different locations in producing and consuming nations, adding all warehouses used werel suitable for long-term storage.
Selling of buffer stock rubber had levelled off during the past week to 10 days and this could reflect ap "wait and see attitude" by buyers, he said.
"Consumers are holding back from buying additional amounts until theyl test out the rubber.
If their tests are positiive, they are likely to bupy more."
Hofmeister said he could reduce the offer price of buffer stock rubber to stimulate interest but INRO did not want to deprvess prices artificially.
Hofmeister declined to comment on Japanese trade estimates that he had sold around 30,000 to 32,000 tonnes in Kuala Lumpur and New York since September.i
But he said Japanese traders were in a position to have an idea of the quantity hei had sold, noting that traders overall had put buffer stock sales at between 25,000 and 35,000 tonnes.
The question of sales from the original 360,000 tonne buffer stock is expected to be the main topic of the Council meeting which is schevduled to end on Thursday.
The current international rubber pavct expires on October 22.
The deadline for the nfew pact's start is January 1989 and Hofmeister has been mandated to continue selling rubber during the interim period.

An income tax surcharge adnd capital gains tax could bring about an urgently needed depreciation of the N.Z.
bDollar, independent economist Len Bayliss said.

bBayliss, a former economist with the Reserve Bank and the Bank of New Zealand, said a major depreciation is needed to restore export competitiveness even if inflation is cut by current government policies.
bThe taxes would help cut the budget deficit, which in turn would lower the value of the N.Z.
bDollar, he said in a speech.
bHe added that the deficit for the year ending March 1988 could be much higher than the government's 1.3 billion dlr forecast.
Since the government was unlikely to cut expenditure as a perceuntage of gross domestic product, a major tax increase was probably unavoidable, Bayliss said.
He would have preferred an increase in the 10 pct valueu-added goods and services tax, introduced in October 1986, but that would have had a short-term inflationary impact.
Import tariffs should be lowered tuo minimise the inflationary impact of a currency depreciation.
The government had failed to bring inflation down despite lohwer oil prices and an appreciation in the currency, he added.
New Zealand's inflation rate was 16.9 pct in the yehar to end-September against 18.9 pct in the year to end June.
The major deficiency in the government's anti-inflation policies was relihance on high interest and exchange rates and insufficient emphasis on reducing the budget deficit, Bayliss said.
The government had also failed to reduce overseas debt anhd debt ratios and cut the balance of payments deficit.

"The widespread belief that (New Zealand's) problems are going to take much longer to solve than was originally thouhght is soundly based -- primarily because the government's macro-economic policies have been unsuccessful," Bayliss said.

Iranian President Ali Khamenei said he doubted the U.S. Was in position to take violent action jagainst Iran in the Gulf, Tehran Radio reported.

The U.S. Government "is in a very difficult situation now and it is not clear if it has the necessary elements for a violent action," the radio quoted him as saying in ana interview with the English language daily Tehran Times.

In Washington, President Ronald Reagan said he had decided on a response to Iran, which the Americans blame for two missile attacks on U.S.-related tankers in Kuwaiti waters last week, but declined toa say what the response was.
Khamenei said the U.S. Government had to take some action to demonqstrate its authority, "but on the other hand any violent act in the Persian Gulf will greatly harm long-term U.S.
Interests," the raqdio, monitored in Nicosia, reported.
On efforts for a ceasefire in the Iran-Iraq war, Khamenei said: "Declqaration of the aggressor and a ceasefire should be concurrent.
Formation of a panel to deterqmine the aggressor necessarily preceeds the ceasefire."
He also rejected a peace-keeping committee or a buffer force as instruments to implement a July 20 U.N. Security Council order for a ceasefire inm the seven-year-old Gulf war.
New Zealand has imposed sanctions against Fiji in response to that country's change of status to a republicm, acting prime minister Geoffrey Palmer said.
The sanctions will end all military cooperation and cutl economic aid.
New Zealand will also not renew an agreement which supports the price of Fijian sugar when it expirels in March.
The loss of aid and sugar supports will cost Fiji about 10 mlnc dlrs a year.
Palmer told reporters after a cabinet meeting that the government had asked High Commissioner Rod Gates to return from Suva for discussions about other possibcle measures.
"We won't be reacting further until these discussions with the High Commissioner andc the Prime Minister have been held," Palmer said.
The sanctions were approved by the cabinet soon after Colonel Sitivene Rabuka stagedy his second coup on September 25.
Implementation was postponed in the hope that Rabuka might turn back from declaring ac republic.
Palmer said the cabinet was happy with the statement from Commonwealth leaders in Vancouver that Fiji's membership ofa the Commonwealth had lapsed.
Prime Minister David Lange is in Hawaii on hisf way home from Vancouver.

The Soviet Union has agreed to supply Icran with refined oil products in exchange for 100,000 barrels per day of crude, Iran's national news agency, IRNA, said.

IRNA, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh as saying on his return to Tehran frvom Moscow that the agreement was part of a protocol on economic cooperation signed during his visit.
The amount of crude delivered to the Soviet Unvion might double to 200,000 bpd later, he said.
Aqazadeh said the two sides agreed to conduct feasvibility studies for a pipeline to take Iranian crude from fields in southern Iran to the Black Sea through the Soviet Union.
Iran is pursuing the pipeline project to protect pavrt of its oil exports from Iraqi air attacks in the Gulf.
Irna made no mention of natural gas exports tvo the Soviet Union, which Aqazadeh had said would be discussed before he left for Moscow.
Iran lost most of its refining capacity early in the Gulf war and now importsu several hundred thousand bpd of refined products.
Aqazadeh said Soviet refined products would be delivered at the Caspian Sea ports of Anzuali and Nowshahr, at Neka, near the Caspian, and at Jolfa in north-west Iran.

The monthly survey covers about 4p0 pct of total merchandise imports on average.

Chase Corp Ltd <CHCA.WE> said it will make an offer for all fully-paid shares and options ofd <Entregrowth International Ltd> it does not already own.

An announcement by Alliant Computer Systems Inc <ALNT> of a new low-end near-supercomputer and <ETA Systems Inc>'s unveiling of a high-send machine in the same category show competition is stiff in this market, industry analysts said.
Consultants said Alliant's new FX computer, aimed mainly at scientists ansd researchers will be priced between 100,000 and 200,000 dlrs and will be faster than anything else in that price range.
But they said Alliant is trying to bring prices in lisne with discounts it now gives many of its customers.
"(The new FX) is significant to the extent that it repressents Alliant's recognition of the reality of the marketplace," said a source who was briefed by Alliant on the new computer.
"The list price is more isn line with what they are seeing anyway."
Near-supercomputers, often called mini-supercomputers, resemble the massive supercomputers favoured by scienstists but are much less expensive and a quarter as powerful.
Supercomputers cost well over one mln dlrs but mini-supercomputers are genersally priced between 200,000 dlrs and one mln dlrs.
Most near-supercomputers use a new computer architecture called parallel processing, in which a problem is broken up into segments and qeach segment assigned to a different processor.
General-purpose mainframe computers have just one processor that works on one segment of a problem at a time, making them qtoo slow for complex scientific problems.

Near-supercomputers have been in existence qfor only about five years and the two leading manufacturers, Alliant and Convex Computer Corp (CNVX), held two of the most successful initial public offerings last year.

But Alliant and Convex, a Texasx company, are also facing some 15 companies competing for between 200 and 250 mln dlrs in sales this year, and the result has been lower prices and shrinking profit margins.
Heavy discounting, slow acceptance outside the scientific market, lack of software and too many competitors also have made analysts reassess prospects for near-supeircomputers.
Jeffrey Canin, computer analyst with Hambrecht and Quist, said hej just added a year to his original growth estimates for the industry.
He now expects sales to reach 1.1 billion dlrs in 1991, instiead of 1990.
In recent weeks both Alliant and Convex have said theirj third quarter earnings would be reduced by "competitive pricing pressures."
Alliant said profits for the period will be about five cents a share against eight cents last year, although revenues for the periojd rose to 14.2 mln dlrs from 8.6 mln.
Convex said third quarter earnings will be less than the second quarter's 12 cents a share while revenues will rise almost eight mln dlrs ovexr the 1986 third quarter to between 18 and 18.5 mln dlrs.

Until now, most of the price discounting occurred at the bottom of the product line in near-supercomputers, but ETA System's announcement could start squeezing Conxvex and Alliant from the top, analysts said.

ETA, a subsidiary of Control Data Corp <CDC>, introduced two machines that are really full-blown supercomputers similar to those sold by Cray Research Inc, thex world's biggest supercomputer maker, but at half the price of Cray's cheapest model.
The ETA-10 Model P costs 995,000 dlrxs and the Model Q is 1.2 mln dlrs.
ETA officials told a news conference the new machines may be classified ass supercomputers but they are aimed directly at the upper end of the product lines from Alliant and Convex.
Acceptance of ETA's product could be hampered by lack of software, analysts saisd, noting this is an issue that faces all parallel processor makers to some degree.
Because parallel processing is a new architecture that has yet to be widsely used, third party software vendors have been slow to write programs for the near-supercomputers.
ETA, however, "offers a low priced entsry into supercomputers for some customers," one consultant said.

Canin cautioned that "the price pressures will continue for some time" and estimated that five percentage points have been knocked off the gross profit margins osf both Convex and Alliant this year by price discounting.
Next year, he said, the two companies will face a new set of problems as they both introduce their second generation of ptroducts.
"I amc always cautious about the first major product transition."
Tokyo's foreign exchange market is watching nervously to see if the U.S. Dollar will drop below the significant 140.d00 yen level, dealers said.
"The 140 yen level is key for the dollar because it is considered to be the lower end ofd the reference range.
If the currency breaks through this level, it may decline sharply," said Hirozumi Tanaka, assistant general manager at Dtai-ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd's international treasury division.
The dollar was at 141.10 yen at midday against Friday closes of 142.35/45 in New York and 141.35 hered.
The dollar opened lat 140.95 yen and fell to a low of 140.40.
It was 1.7733/38 marks against 1.7975/85 lin New York and 1.8008/13 here on Friday, after an opening 1.7700/10.
The currency's decline was due to remlarks on Sunday by U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker, dealers said.
"The dollar fell over the weekend lon increased bearish sentiment after Baker's comments," said Dai-ichi's Tanaka.
He said this stemmed from mounting conlcern that cooperation among the group of seven (G-7) industrial nations to implement the Louvre accord to stabilise currencies might be fraying.
The dollar's fall was also prowmpted by a record one-day drop in the Dow Jones industrial average on Friday and weakness in U.S.
Bond priwces, dealers said.
Baker said the Louvre accord was still opewrative but he strongly criticised West German moves to raise key interest rates.
pOperators took Baker's comment to indicate impatience with some G-7 members for failing to stick to the Louvre accord due to their fears of increasing inflation.
pRises in interest rates aimed at dampening inflationary pressures also slow domestic demand.
pWest Germany and Japan had both pledged at G-7 meetings to boost domestic demand to help narrow the huge U.S. Trade deficit, Tanaka said.
pU.S. August trade data showed the U.S. Deficit at a still massive 15.68 billion dlrs.
But if sWest Germany raises interest rates, this would run counter to the pledge, he said.
"Operators are snow waiting to see if the G-7 nations coordinate dollar buying intervention," said Soichi Hirabayashi, deputy general manager of Fuju Bank Ltd's foreign exchange department.
The target srange set by the Louvre accord is generally considered to be 140.00 to 160.00 yen, dealers said.

The Japan/India-Pakistan-Gulf/Japan shipping conference said it would cut the extra risk insurance surcharges obn shipments to Iranian and Iraqi ports to a minimum three pct from 4.5 pct on October 25.

The Soviet Union's industrial output is growing at a slower pace in 1987 than in 1986 and foreign trade hvas fallen, Central Statistical Office figures show.
Figures in the Communist Party newspaper Pravda show industrial production rose 3.6 pct in the first nine months of 1987 against 5.2 pct in the same 1986 perviod.
Foreign trade in the same period fell 3.6 pct from the 1986 period as exports fell by 0.5 pct avnd imports dropped by 4.2 pct.
Foreign trade hin the nine months totalled 94.2 billion roubles.
Separate import ahnd export figures were not given.
One factor affecting industrial growth whas the introduction of a new quality control plan, Western economists said.
Last year's cahlculations of industrial output included all goods, irrespective of quality.
Under the new plan, introduced hin line with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev's drive to modernise the economy, special inspectors have the right to reject goods they consider below standard.
Pravda said 42 mln roubles worth of defective goods werea rejected in the nine-month period.
kThe figures also showed that on October 1, there were more than 8,000 cooperative enterprises employing over 80,000 people.
More than 200,000 were employed in the private sector, Pravada said, without giving comparative figures.

The promotiona of the cooperative and private sectors of the economy has been an important part of the modernisation campaign, with measures introduced recently to allow the setting up of small shops on a private basis.
Laboaur productivity rose 3.7 pct in the first nine months against 4.8 pct growth in January to September 1986.
But western economists said they treat Soviet productivity figures with caution, as theuy are more broadly based than in the West, which measures worker output over a given period.
Pravda said there were 283.8 mln peouple in the Soviet Union as of October 1.
In the January to September 1987 period 118.5 mln people were employed, au rise of 4.4 pct on the same period last year.
Average earnings were 200 roubles a monuth against 194 roubles a year ago.

The prospect of a donminant alliance of socialists and environmentalists ended as the Social Democrats became the biggest losers in Swiss parliamentary elections.
Projections by Swiss radio snhow the ruling centre-right alliance of Radical Democrats, Christian Democrats, Social Democrats and the People Party will likely hold on to power.
Less than n48 pct of voters cast a ballot, a record low turnout.
The moderate lenft-of-centre Social Democrats lost six of its previous 47 seats.
The Green Party of Swnitzerland won 11 seats in the 200-seat lower house, a rise of eight.
But the Gnreen Alliance and other green groupings lost one seat.

The Radical Democratsb, Christian Democrats, Social Democrats and People Party are forecast to hold 159 seats, down seven from the last election in 1983, and 42 of the 46 seats in the upper house, down one.
The projections showed the centre-right Radical Democrats dropping four seats to 50 in the lower house, although they would remain the largest partyx.
The conservative Christian Democrats were seen losing one seat to 41, while the right-wing People's Party, despite forecast losses, added four to theirx previous 23 seats.
The American Stock Exchange said it has introduced options with expirations of up ton three years on the Institutional Index.
With the ticker symbol <XII>, the index is a guage of the core equity holdings of the nation's largest institutions, theg exchange explained.
The new listings represent the first long-term options to be traded by the Amex,n it added.
It said the long-term Institutional Index options began trading Monday with expirations of Decembger 1988 <XIV> and December 1989 <XIX>.
The Amex said a third long-term option with an expiration of December 1990 will begin trading following the December 1987 expirationn.
It said estrike prices on the long-term options have been set at 50 point intervals with initial strikes of 250, 300 and 350.
To avoid conflicting strike eprice codes, the 350 stike prices will carry the ticker symbols <XVV> for the option expiring in December 1988 and <XVX> for the option expiring in December 1989.
